Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin



Chapter 1



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Money matters<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Not only litigation involving loans, inheritances, gifts, or real estate, but also distribution of public funds (cf. Mishnah <i>Peah</i> 8:7).</i> are judged by three [judges]; robberies<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">Including fraud.</i> and injuries<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Inflicted on humans.</i> by three [judges], damages<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Caused on living or inanimate property.</i>, half damages<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Caused by somebody’s animals (cf. Mishnaiot <i>Bava qamma</i> 1:4–5).</i>, double restitution<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">To be paid by the thief of inanimate objects, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 7:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.7.1.1">Mishnah <i>Bava qamma</i> 7:1</a>. The thief of livestock pays quadruple or quintuple restitution.</i> quadruple and quintuple restitution. The rapist<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Who has to pay under four different categories (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.1.1">Mishnah <i>Ketubot</i> 4:1</a>).</i>, the seducer<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Who has to pay under three different categories.</i>, and the calumniator<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Who accuses his wife not to have been a virgin (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:13-19" href="/Deuteronomy.22.13-19"><i>Deut.</i> 22:13–19</a>).</i> are judged by three [judges], the words of Rebbi Meïr; but the Sages say that the calumniator is judged by 23 because it might be a capital case<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Since the woman is stoned if the husband’s accusation is proved correct (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:20-21" href="/Deuteronomy.22.20-21"><i>Deut.</i> 22:20–21</a>) and the biblical text implies that the court which might sentence the husband to a fine is the one which might pass a death sentence, the case has to be tried in a tribunal empowered to try capital cases.<br>According to rabbinic principles, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:13-21" href="/Deuteronomy.22.13-21"><i>Deut.</i>22:13–21</a> cannot refer to a husband accusing his wife of not being a virgin since 1° by marriage, the husband became his wife’s relative and relatives are barred from appearing as witnesses; his case could not be heard. 2° there is no verse threatening a woman with death if she married when not a virgin. Therefore, the rabbinic interpretation of the paragraph is that the husband presents witnesses to the fact that his wife committed adultery while preliminarily married to him. A preliminarily married woman is married in respect to criminal but not civil law (cf. Introduction to Tractate <i>Qiddušin</i>).<br>Another aspect of criminal law in this case is the law of perjury, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:18-19" href="/Deuteronomy.19.18-19"><i>Deut.</i> 19:18–19</a>. Since the husband’s witnesses intended to have the woman stoned, if they are shown to be perjured they themselves are stoned. Therefore, the case may be heard only in a court competent to impose death sentences.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Money matters are judged by three [judges],” etc. From where comes this? <i>These shall be the laws of procedure to you</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:29" href="/Numbers.35.29"><i>Num.</i> 35:29</a>. The chapter covers the rules of levitic cities, laws of property, and of the homicide, criminal law.</i> I would say that both civil cases and criminal cases are subject to the rules of verification and examination<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.1.1">Mishnah 4:1</a>. <i>Examination</i> refers to cross-examination relating to questions which answer to “who”, “when”, and “where”. <i>Interrogation</i> refers to answers to “how”. The distinction between the two is in regard to rules about discrepancies in testimony between different witnesses, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.1.1">Mishnah 5:1</a>. The verse makes it clear that the rules also apply to lawsuits about subjects not covered by the detailed list in the Mishnah.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 3b" href="/Sanhedrin.3b">Babli 3b</a>.</i> From where that civil cases are heard by three [judges]? <i>The owner shall go to the judge</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:7" href="/Exodus.22.7"><i>Ex</i>. 22:7</a>.</i> he added here one judge. <i>Before the judge</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:8" href="/Exodus.22.8"><i>Ex</i>. 22:8</a>.</i> these are two. <i>Whom the judges will find guilty,</i> these are three<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Since the paragraph mentions <i>judge</i> three times.</i>, the words of Rebbi Joshia. Rebbi Jonathan said, the first mention introduces the subject; one does not infer anything from introductions<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">This is a generally accepted principle (Babli <i>loc. cit</i>.). The expression which introduces a subject always is necessary and cannot be considered additional or extraneous to the subject at hand.</i>. But <i>before the judge,</i> there is one. <i>Whom the judges will find guilty,</i> there are two. No court may be even-numbered,<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">The duty of the court is to decide matters based on incomplete information. The possibility of a deadlock would defeat the purpose for which the court was convened. Therefore, no court may be even-numbered. If any of the judges did abstain from voting, the case would have to be tried anew with another judge substituting for the abstaining judge.</i> so one adds another one; this makes three.
Rebbi said, the verse speaks about two. You say about two, or maybe it is only about one? What He said, it is not written “whom the judge will find guilty” but <i>whom the judges will find guilty</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The plural in this sentence alone implies that at least two judges are involved.</i> No court may be even-numbered, so one adds another one; this makes three.
Rebbi Abbahu asked. According to Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Who in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 1:1" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.1.1">Tosephta 1:1</a> requires five judges to hear civil cases.</i>, should not civil suits be heard by five; should sentence not be passed by 23<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi probably also will agree that common practice was to hear cases by a panel of three judges. If one already deviates from traditional practice, should not <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:29" href="/Numbers.35.29"><i>Num.</i> 35:29</a> be interpreted as requiring identical procedural law for both civil and criminal cases?</i>? It was found stated by (Rebbi)<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Probably one should read דבי instead of  (רבי) ר׳ and translate “the House of Hizqiah,” referring to one of the twin sons of the Elder Rebbi Hiyya, known as the last person who formulated <i>baraitot.</i> The fourth generation <i>Rebbi</i> Hizqiah would be much too late. The <i>baraita</i> is found in both <i>Mekhiltot</i> (dR. Ismael, ed. Horovitz-Rabin p. 323, dR. Simeon ben Iohai ed. Epstein-Melamed p. 214.)</i> Ḥizqiah: Since the Torah said, kill by a vote of the majority<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Majority rule for judicial sentences is introduced in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:2" href="/Exodus.23.2"><i>Ex.</i> 23:2</a>: “to bend after the many.” The same verse forbids a guilty verdict by a simple majority: “Do not follow the majority in bad things.” Since the plural used for “many” implies at least two, it follows that a guilty verdict by a majority of one is an acquittal, while by a majority of two it is a guilty verdict.</i>, kill by the testimony of witnesses. Since witnesses must be two<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Since unanimity is not required, the court would have to be composed of at least 4, hence 5, members. The majority accepts this interpretation of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:2" href="/Exodus.23.2"><i>Ex.</i> 23:2</a> for criminal cases only.</i>, a majority also must be two<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Since unanimity is not required, the court would have to be composed of at least 4, hence 5, members. The majority accepts this interpretation of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:2" href="/Exodus.23.2"><i>Ex.</i> 23:2</a> for criminal cases only.</i>. No court can be even-numbered; one adds another one. This makes five.
Do not robberies and injuries fall under the same rules<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">The same question is asked in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 2b" href="/Sanhedrin.2b">Babli, 2b</a>. In contrast to the Babli, here it is understood that torts do not necessarily follow the same rules as disputes over money, and it is not obvious that a panel of three judges would be sufficient for these.</i>? It was found that Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai stated: <i>These are the procedures which you shall put before them.</i> It serves to explain to you the plain sense of the verse<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:1" href="/Exodus.21.1"><i>Ex</i>. 21:1</a>. As in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21-23" href="/Exodus.21-23"><i>Ex</i>. 21–23</a>, pure money matters are treated first, then torts. The order of the Mishnah follows the order of topics in these chapters.</i>. This follows Rebbi Yose bar Ḥalaphta.
Rebbi Yose bar Ḥalaphta, when two people came before him for judgment and told him, “on condition that you judge us by the law of the Torah,” told them, “the law of the Torah I do not know<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">He knew the theoretical law of the Torah but not necessarily the application to the case before him, since that would have presumed perfect and complete information. But the judge, by biblical decree, is dependent on what is told him in court. The information given to him by necessity is incomplete.</i>, but He Who knows thoughts should collect from those people<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Who either lie in court or withhold information.</i>. You have to accept what I shall tell you.”
When a person came to Rebbi Aqiba to have a suit decided before him, he told him: “You should know before Whom you are standing, before Him Who commanded and the world came into existence, as it is said: <i>The two people who are quarrelling shall stand before the Eternal,</i><sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:17" href="/Deuteronomy.19.17"><i>Deut.</i> 19:17</a>. The verse continues: “before the priests and the judges.”</i> not before Aqiba ben Joseph.”
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">The correct version of this <i>baraita</i> is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:2:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.2.2-5">7:2</a>; the first part is also quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 15a" href="/Shabbat.15a">Babli, <i>Šabbat</i> 15a</a>. The second part never applied in Babylonia.</i>: Forty years before the Temple was destroyed, criminal jurisdiction was removed from Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">When Judea came under direct Roman rule.</i>, and in the days of Simeon ben (Šetaḥ)<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">One has to read with 7:2: Simeon ben Iohai, as confirmed by the next sentence. The removal of civil cases to Roman courts cannot be dated to the reign of Alexander Yannai, Simeon ben Shetah’s brother-in-law, but to Hadrian, in the aftermath of the war of bar Kokhba.</i> civil jurisdiction was removed. Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai said, praised be the Merciful<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">For preventing me to have to act as a judge.</i>, for I am not intelligent enough to judge<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">From his time on, rabbinic jurisdiction in Palestine was limited to courts of arbitration which are not representatives of God and therefore under less pressure to render absolutely correct judgment.</i>.
Samuel said, if two men acted as judges, their judgment stands, but they are called an insolent court<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 3a" href="/Sanhedrin.3a">Babli 3a</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 5b" href="/Sanhedrin.5b">5b</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 30a" href="/Sanhedrin.30a">30a</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 87b" href="/Sanhedrin.87b">87b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 22a" href="/Ketubot.22a"><i>Ketubot</i> 22a</a>. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 7:1:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.7.1.3"><i>Berakhot</i> 7:1, Note 18</a>.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish both are instructing: Even<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Even if the parties accepted them as judges.</i> if two men acted as judges, their judgment is no judgment<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, this opinion is represented by Rava (5b) and R. Abbahu (87b), the student of R. Johanan and R. Simeon ben Laqish.</i>. There, we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Bekhorot 4:4" href="/Mishnah_Bekhorot.4.4">Mishnah <i>Bekhorot</i> 4:4</a>. The Mishnah refers to a person who did not pass the required examinations and was not formally qualified as a judge.</i>: “If he rendered judgment, acquitted the guilty and condemned the innocent, declared the pure impure or the impure pure, what he did is done but he has to pay from his own pocket.” Rebbi Abba in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: if they told him, we accept you as if you were two<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Since R. Abbahu follows his teachers and holds that any judgment passed by a court of two judges is void, as well as from the following quote, it is clear that one has to read “three” in place of “two”.</i>. What are we dealing with? If his error was that he judged them on his discretion<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">If there exists no clear precedent for the case; different schools promulgate different rules and he followed a minority opinion because it seemed to him to be the correct one, his judgment is valid but there is no reason why he should have to pay. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 33a" href="/Sanhedrin.33a">Babli, 33a</a>, declares a judgment against a clear majority of opinions as an error in law.</i>, then what he did is done. If his error was that he judged them by Torah law<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">If his judgment contradicted a Mishnah or a clear precedent, in Israel a judgment of the Patriarch’s court or in Babylonia a concurrent judgment of both Yeshivot, his judgment is void (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.2.2"><i>Ketubot</i> 9:2, Note 100</a>). If any money changed hands as a consequence of the erroneous judgment, it has to be returned.</i>, why should he pay from his own pocket? Rebbi Abba in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: if they told him, we accept you as if you were three on condition that you judge us by Torah law. He erred and judged them on his discretion. What he did is done, but since he erred and judged them on his discretion, he has to pay from his own pocket<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">As a fine.</i> because he was presumptuous to judge alone by Torah law, as we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Pirkei Avot 4:8" href="/Pirkei_Avot.4.8">Mishnah <i>Avot</i> 4:8</a>.</i>: “Do not judge sitting alone, for only One judges sitting alone.”
Rebbi Jehudah ben Pazi said, even the Holy One, praise to Him, does not judge alone, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 22:19" href="/I_Kings.22.19"><i>1K.</i> 22:19</a>. In MT, “was standing.”</i>: <i>all the hosts of Heaven were standing by Him, to His right side and to His left.</i> These vote to acquit, those to convict. Even though He does not judge alone, He signs alone, as it is said: <i>really I shall tell you what is noted in true writing.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Daniel 10:21" href="/Daniel.10.21"><i>Dan.</i> 10:21</a>.</i> Rebbi Joḥanan said, the Holy One, praise to Him, never does anything in His world unless He took counsel with the Heavenly Court<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 38b" href="/Sanhedrin.38b">Babli 38b</a>.</i>. What is the reason? <i>True is the statement and a large host.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Daniel 10:1" href="/Daniel.10.1"><i>Dan.</i> 10:1</a>.</i> When is the seal of the Holy One, praise to Him, true? When He took counsel with the Heavenly Court. Rebbi Eleazar said, any place where it is said “the Eternal, Almighty,<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Vayikra Rabbah 24:2" href="/Vayikra_Rabbah.24.2"><i>Lev. rabba</i> 24(2</a>) in the name of R. Eliezer, in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bamidbar Rabbah 3:3" href="/Bamidbar_Rabbah.3.3"><i>Num. rabba</i> 3(3</a>) in the name of “the rabbis”: Any place where it is said “<i>and</i> the Eternal.” Since the verse quoted in support refers to this version, the editor of the Žitomir-Wilna edition changed the text here. It is more likely that the text originally read “the Eternal of hosts” and the proof text was <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 11:17" href="/Jeremiah.11.17"><i>Jer.</i> 11:17</a>.</i>” it is He and His Heavenly Court. The paradigm of all is: <i>and the Eternal spoke evil about him.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 22:23" href="/I_Kings.22.23"><i>1K.</i> 22:23</a>.</i>
What is the seal of the Holy One, praise to Him? Rebbi Bevai in the name of Rebbi Reuben, “true.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 55a" href="/Shabbat.55a">Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 55a</a>, in the name of R. Hanina, a midrash on <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 22:23" href="/I_Kings.22.23"><i>1K.</i> 22:23</a>.</i>” What means “true”? Rebbi Abun said, that He is a Living Power and the King of this World. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, א is the start of the alphabet, מ the middle,<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Hebrew alphabet has 22 letters, the middle is between the 11th (k) and the twelfth (l) letter.</i> and ת the end. To say, <i>I, the Eternal, am First,</i><sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 41:4" href="/Isaiah.41.4"><i>Is.</i> 41:4</a>.</i> I did not receive anything from another. <i>Besides Me there is no supreme power</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 44:6" href="/Isaiah.44.6"><i>Is.</i> 44:6</a>. The verse probably should have been quoted three times.</i> for I have no co-owner. <i>And with the last, I shall be</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 41:4" href="/Isaiah.41.4"><i>Is.</i> 41:4</a>.</i> I shall not in the future turn it over to anybody else.
Rebbi Abba and Rebbi Benjamin bar Jephet had a lawsuit before Rebbi Isaac; the judgment was for Rebbi Benjamin. Rebbi Abba wanted to complain<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">After the fact, he wanted to invalidate the judgment because R. Isaac sat as sole judge.</i>; Rebbi Immi came and taught: If an expert<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">A person who passed the required examinations and was ordained as a judge, in Palestine by the Patriarch, in Babylonia by the Head of the Diaspora.</i> forced his opinion as a judgment, his judgment stands.
Rebbi Abbahu was sitting as sole judge in the inclining<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">A synagogue built on an incline in his hometown of Caesarea Philippi on the slopes of the Golan Heights.</i> synagogue of Caesarea. His students said to him, did the rabbi not teach<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Pirkei Avot 4:8" href="/Pirkei_Avot.4.8">Mishnah <i>Avot</i> 4:8</a>.</i>: “Do not judge sitting alone”? He told them, since you see me sitting alone as a judge and they come to me, it is because they accepted this. It was stated thus<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 5a" href="/Sanhedrin.5a">Babli 5a</a>, <i>Rosh Haššanah</i> 25b.</i>: “When was this said? If they did not accept it. But if they accepted it, he even judges as sole judge.<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Since he is acting as an arbitrator.</i>”
Rebbi Joḥanan went with a lawsuit before the Elder Rebbi Ḥiyya. He took a student to sit with him. But did we not state: “A father and his son, a teacher and his student, the two are counted as one.<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 7:2-3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.7.2-3">Tosephta 7:2</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 36a" href="/Sanhedrin.36a">Babli 36a</a>. The son or the student cannot be counted on for an independent opinion.</i>” Let us say that he was both student and colleague, like Rebbi Eleazar to Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Where both Talmudim report many disagreements between them. At this stage, the former student will have independent opinions and, more importantly, will not be afraid publicly to state them.</i>.
Judgments were rendered by Rav alone, by Rav Aḥa alone, by Rebbi Jonah and Rebbi Yose by themselves<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">The head of a Talmudic Academy everywhere is empowered to sit as sole judge.</i>.
There, we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Bekhorot 4:6" href="/Mishnah_Bekhorot.4.6">Mishnah <i>Bekhorot</i> 4:6</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bekhorot 29a" href="/Bekhorot.29a">Babli <i>Bekhorot</i>29a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 105a" href="/Ketubot.105a"><i>Ketubot</i> 105a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 58b" href="/Kiddushin.58b"><i>Qiddušin</i> 58b</a>.</i>: “If somebody takes a fee to judge, his judgments<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">The plural implies that all his judgments are invalid, even those for which he did not take money.</i> are invalid.” So is the Mishnah: “He who is suspected of taking a fee<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">It takes an action of a supervising authority to invalidate his judgments.</i> but he judges.”
A person brought a suit before Rav Huna<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Who started out poor as an agricultural worker and only became rich when middle aged. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 105a" href="/Ketubot.105a">Babli <i>Ketubot</i> 105a</a>.</i>, He told him, bring me a person who climbs the date palm instead of me.
Rav Huna was a cowherd when he knew testimony for a person, who told him, come and testify for me. He answered him, give me my wages. It was stated thus: “One pays the judge for his time and the witness for his testimony.
A person made a Cohen impure<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">He made it impossible for him to eat heave, which must be eaten in purity. One has to assume that the impurity was that of corpses, which can be dissolved only by sprinkling with water containing the ashes of the red cow, which at that moment had become unavailable; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.1.1"><i>Berakhot</i> 1:1, Note 3</a>.</i>. The case came before Rebbi Isaac who made him eat profane food<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">He forbade the Cohen to eat heave; this is a biblical rule agreed to by everybody. It is implied that he required the offending party to pay for the Cohen’s food since heave, permitted only to Cohanim, is sold at a discount.<br>Impurity of persons and food is <i>invisible damage</i> which according to the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 53a" href="/Gittin.53a">Babli, <i>Gittin</i> 53a</a>, can be punished only by a rabbinic fine. According to the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 8a" href="/Sanhedrin.8a">Babli, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 8a</a>, fines can be imposed only by a panel of three ordained judges. Since it is implied here that R. Isaac was sitting as sole judge, the Yerushalmi strongly disagrees with the Babli. (Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 9:1:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.9.1.5"><i>Bava qamma</i> 9:2, Note 24</a>.)</i>. They wanted to say that one deducts the price of heave from the amount<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">The guilty party only had to pay the difference between profane and sanctified food, i. e., the additional cost incurred by the victim.</i>.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 1:1-3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.1.1-3">Tosephta 1:2</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 6b" href="/Sanhedrin.6b">Babli 6b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 92a" href="/Yevamot.92a"><i>Yebamot</i> 92a</a>.</i>: Rebbi Eliezer ben Rebbi Yose the Galilean says, the person who arranges a compromise is sinning<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">It is clear from the following paragraphs and the parallels, that the statement is interpreted to apply to cases where either the trial already has started or where existing law allows a clear decision.</i>, and the one who praises a compromiser is like a blasphemer before the Omnipresent, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 10:3" href="/Psalms.10.3"><i>Ps.</i> 10:3</a>.</i>: <i>he who blesses a compromiser slanders the Eternal!</i> The law should pierce the mountain, as Moses did<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Who ordered ail people with suits to appear before him for judgment (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 18:16" href="/Exodus.18.16"><i>Ex</i>. 18:16</a>) and did not invite them to an arbitration panel.</i>. But Aaron promoted peace<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">The midrash (<i>Avot dR. Nathan</i> I 12, II 24) explains that he dissuaded people from going to court. This is preferable according to everybody.</i>, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Malachi 2:6" href="/Malachi.2.6"><i>Mal.</i> 2:6</a>.</i>, <i>in peace and straightness he went with Me</i>.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 1:1-3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.1.1-3">Tosephta 1:2</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 6b" href="/Sanhedrin.6b">Babli 6b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 92a" href="/Yevamot.92a"><i>Yebamot</i> 92a</a>.</i>: <sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 94a" href="/Bava_Kamma.94a">Babli <i>Bava qamma</i> 94a</a>. In other Yerushalmi sources (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Challah 1:5:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Challah.1.5.8"><i>Hallah</i> 1:9 Notes 218–221</a>; <i>Šabbat</i> 13:3 14a l. 50) it is an Amoraic statement.</i>“Rebbi Eliezer ben Jacob says, why does the verse say<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 10:3" href="/Psalms.10.3"><i>Ps.</i> 10:3</a>.</i>, <i>he who blesses unlawful gain slanders the Eternal</i>? They gave a parable, to what can this be compared? To one who stole a <i>se’ah</i> of wheat, brought it to the baker, separated its <i>ḥallah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">To avoid committing a deadly sin. If he recites the required blessing, he commits an intentional sin; if he induces the baker to recite the blessings, the baker commits an unintended sin and the thief violates the commandment not to put a stone in the way of a blind man.</i>, and fed it to his children. He pronounces blessings but it is blasphemy.
<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 1:3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.1.3">Tosephta (1:3</a>) an anonymous statement.</i> Rebbi Meir says, why does the verse say<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 10:3" href="/Psalms.10.3"><i>Ps.</i> 10:3</a>.</i>, <i>he who blesses unlawful gain slanders the Eternal</i>? These are Joseph’s brothers, as it is is said<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 37:26" href="/Genesis.37.26"><i>Gen.</i> 37:26</a>.</i>: <i>What is the gain if we slay our brother,</i> etc.”
<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 1:3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.1.3">Tosephta 1:3</a>.</i>“Rebbi Joshua ben Qorḥa says, it is a good deed to mediate a compromise, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Zechariah 8:16" href="/Zechariah.8.16"><i>Zach.</i> 8:16</a>, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Taanit 4:2:2-15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Taanit.4.2.2-15"><i>Taˋaniot</i> 4:2</a> (68a l. 75), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 3:6:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.3.6.2-3"><i>Megillah</i> 3:7</a> (74b l. 48).</i>: <i>Truth and judgment of peace</i>. If there is truth, there is no judgment of peace. If there is peace, there is no judgment of truth. What is truth containing a judgment of peace? I am saying, this is compromise.”
<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 1:3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.1.3">Tosephta 1:4</a>, a statement of Rebbi; the same in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 6b" href="/Sanhedrin.6b">Babli 6b</a>.</i>“If somebody judged correctly, absolved the innocent and condemned the guilty, the verse counts it as if he practiced kindness both towards the innocent and towards the guilty. Kindness towards the innocent, because he returned his money to him. And towards the guilty, for he removed the proceeds of robbery from his hands.<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">And therefore protects him from the judgment of Heaven.</i>” Rebbi Abbahu said, <i>judgment</i> and <i>judgment</i> is written in the verse<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Zechariah 8:16" href="/Zechariah.8.16"><i>Zach.</i> 8:16</a>, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Taanit 4:2:2-15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Taanit.4.2.2-15"><i>Taˋaniot</i> 4:2</a> (68a l. 75), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 3:6:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.3.6.2-3"><i>Megillah</i> 3:7</a> (74b l. 48).</i>: “Truth and judgment of peace judge in your gates.”
Rebbi Zachariah asked before Rebbi Immi: Does one act following that Tanna, as it was stated: <sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 1:3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.1.3">Tosephta 1:6</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 6b" href="/Sanhedrin.6b">Babli 6b</a>.</i>“Rebbi Simeon ben Menassiah says, sometimes you are empowered to propose a compromise, sometimes you are not empowered to propose a compromise. How is this? Two come before a judge; before he heard their arguments, or after he heard their arguments but does not know how to correctly apply the law, he may tell them, go and work out a compromise. After you heard their arguments and know how to correctly apply the law, you may not propose a compromise, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 17:14" href="/Proverbs.17.14"><i>Prov.</i> 17:14</a>.</i>: <i>One may remove the beginning of a quarrel like water; before it becomes manifest, the quarrel may be abandoned.</i> Before the quarrel became manifest, you are permitted to abandon it; after the quarrel became manifest, you are not permitted to abandon it.” Rebbi Mattaniah said, even compromise needs intelligent decision<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">He objects to the statement that the judge should send the parties away to work out a compromise on their own; he requires the judge to guide them towards a reasonable compromise.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 1:3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.1.3">Tosephta 1:7</a>, <i>Tanhuma Mišpatim</i> 6, <i>Sheiltot Mišpatim</i> 58, and in all Medieval quotes; only in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 6b" href="/Sanhedrin.6b">Babli 6b</a> both in the Munich ms. and <i>editio princeps</i> incorrectly: R. Simeon ben Laqish.</i>“Rebbi Jehudah ben Laqish said: If two people appeared before a judge, one decent and one agressive. Before he started to hear their arguments, he may tell them, I will not hear your case, lest the agressive one lose his case and become his enemy. After he started hearing their arguments, he may not tell them, I will not hear your case, for it is said,<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 1:17" href="/Deuteronomy.1.17"><i>Deut.</i> 1:17</a>.</i> <i>do not be afraid of anybody.</i>
<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 1:4" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.1.4">Tosephta 1:8</a>.</i>“Rebbi Joshua ben Qorha says, if somebody<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">In a similar, anonymous, <i>baraita</i> in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 31a" href="/Shevuot.31a">Babli (<i>Ševuot</i> 31a</a>): A student sitting before his teacher. This probably has to be understood here.</i> was sitting next to a judge and saw a benefit for the poor and a detriment for the rich, from where that he should not keep silent? For it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 1:17" href="/Deuteronomy.1.17"><i>Deut.</i> 1:17</a>.</i>, <i>do not be afraid of anybody.</i>
<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 1:4" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.1.4">Tosephta 1:9</a>.</i> The judges have to know with Whom they judge, and the witnesses have to know before Whom they are testifying: before Him Who commanded and the world came into existence, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:17" href="/Deuteronomy.19.17"><i>Deut.</i> 19:17</a>. The verse continues: “before the priests and the judges.”</i>, <i>the two people who are quarrelling shall stand before the Eternal,</i> and it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 82:1" href="/Psalms.82.1"><i>Ps.</i> 82:1</a>.</i>, <i>the Almighty stands</i><i>in the assembly of the judges.</i> So Josaphat told the judges, <i>look what you are doing, for you do not judge for man, but for the Eternal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 19:6" href="/II_Chronicles.19.6"><i>2Chr.</i> 19:6</a>.</i>. How is it possible for flesh and blood to judge his Creator? But the Holy One, praise to Him, said: I said that Reuben should have 100 denars and Simeon nothing. You take from one and give it to the other<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Incorrectly.</i>. I have to repay it to him, and will Myself be paid by this man<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">The judge.</i>.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 1:4" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.1.4">Tosephta 1:9</a>.</i>: “Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, judgment is passed by three [judges], a compromise is made by two<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">This also is the text of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 5b" href="/Sanhedrin.5b">Babli, 5b</a>. But in the Tosephta: Just as judgment is rendered by three [judges], so compromise is made before three [judges].</i>. The compromise is stronger than the judgment in that two [judges] who judged can repeal their judgment<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Since is was rendered in regular fashion.</i> but two who negotiated a compromise cannot repeal<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">From the moment a party acquired what was awarded to him by the compromise, since this is a monetary transaction following the rules of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:4:2-6:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.4.2-6.6"><i>Qiddušin</i>1:4–6</a>.</i>.
“The rapist and the seducer,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:4:2-12" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.4.2-12"><i>Ketubot</i> 4:4</a>, explained there in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:2:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.2.5">Notes 113–116</a>. The <i>Ketubot</i> (<b>כ</b>) text is original since only there is the disagreement between Rebbis Ze‘ira and Abbahu being explained.</i> Rebbi Mana said, they disagree about the preliminarily married adolescent female. Rebbi Meïr says, she loses her <i>ketubah</i> in a court of three and is stoned in a court of 23; but the Sages say, at the same place which sentences her to be stoned she loses her <i>ketubah.</i> But in the case of the calumniator, everybody agrees that by the court in which the witnesses are stoned, the husband is flogged and pays 100 tetradrachmas. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said to him, would they differ where it was not stated? But they differ about the calumniator! Rebbi Meïr says, he is flogged and pays 100 tetradrachmas by the judgment of three and the witnesses are stoned by the judgment of 23; but the rabbis say, by the court in which the witnesses are stoned, the husband is flogged and pays 100 tetradrachmas. But in the case of the preliminarily married adolescent female, everybody agrees that at the same place which sentences her to be stoned she loses her <i>ketubah.</i> It turns out that Rebbi Mana follows Rebbi Ze‘ira and Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun follows Rebbi Abbahu.
<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">The paragraph is repeated in Halakhah 4.</i> Rebbi Abbahu asked: Following Rebbi Meïr, should an ox which is stoned<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">The animal which killed a human (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:28" href="/Exodus.21.28"><i>Ex.</i>21:28</a>).</i> have to pay damages<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Not the ox but its owner.</i> by a court of three and be stoned by 23? Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun told him, the rules of an ox which is stoned are all about money<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Since fines and corporal punishment are mutually exclusive (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Terumot 7:1:4-14" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Terumot.7.1.4-14"><i>Terumot</i> 7:1 Notes 19–70</a>; <i>Giţţin</i> 5:5 Note 136), it is clear that stoning the ox is a fine imposed on its owner.</i>; it is a decision of the verse that it should be stoned.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Whipping by three [judges]; in the name of Rebbi Ismael they said, by 23<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">The imposition of corporal punishment needs an official court of duly ordained judges. The Mishnah is a reconstruction of what was assumed to be the historic procedure; R. Ismael lived about 70 years after the removal of criminal jurisdiction from Jewish courts and R. Meïr, represented by the anonymous opinion, more than 100 years afterwards. But the prescription of the Mishnah certainly was followed by the autonomous Jewish courts under the Parthians.</i>. The lengthening of a month by three [judges]<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Whether a thirtieth day should be counted for the current month. Fixing the calendar was the sole privilege of a committee of the Patriarch’s court as a successor to the Synhedrion. The current computed calendar was promulgated by such a court in the middle of the Fourth Century (<i>Eruvin</i> 3:11 21c l. 24).</i>, the intercalation of a year by three [judges]<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">In the current calendar, the addition of 30 days to the lunar year, labelled as “First Adar.”</i>, the words of Rebbi Meïr. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, one starts with three, one discusses with five, and one votes with seven<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">A committe of three has to decide whether the year be a candidate for intercalation; an enlarged committe of five has to do the detailed computations; a further enlarged committee of seven has to confirm the computations. Intercalated months in the lunar year are necessary to keep Passover in the “month of spring” as required by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 13:4" href="/Exodus.13.4"><i>Ex.</i> 13:4</a>.<br>There is no basic disagreement between R. Meïr and Rabban Simeon, since the latter agrees that in an emergency situation, a duly empowered committee of three is competent. Since Rabban Simeon was the Patriarch of the restauration during the second half of the Second Century, his procedure was the one actually used.</i>. But if they voted with three, it is intercalated.<br>The leaning of Elders<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 4:15" href="/Leviticus.4.15"><i>Lev.</i> 4:15</a>. If the High Court realized that they had erred in a ruling and permitted something which is biblically prohibited, they have to bring a purification sacrifice and a deputation of the Court has to lean with their hands on the head of the sacrificial animal while confessing their error, as detailed in Traxtate <i>Horaiot</i>.</i> and the breaking of the calf’s neck<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">The ritual of atonement for an unsolved murder, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:1-9" href="/Deuteronomy.21.1-9"><i>Deut</i>. 21:1–9</a>, <i>Soţah</i> Chapter 9.</i> by three [judges], the words of Rebbi Simeon, but Rebbi Jehudah says, by five. <i>Ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">The ceremony by which the widow of a childless man is freed from levirate marriage, which requires involvement of “the Elders”, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:5-9" href="/Deuteronomy.25.5-9"><i>Deut.</i> 25:5–9</a>.</i> and repudiations<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">The repudiation of a marriage by an underage girl, married off by her mother or brothers after her father’s death and whose marriage during her minority is valid only rabbinically; cf. <i>Yebamot</i> Chapter 13.</i> by three [judges], [redemption of] the growth of the fourth year<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">The fruits of a tree in the fourth year after planting, the first year they are permitted as food, have to be eaten in holiness by the rules of Second Tithe (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 19:24" href="/Leviticus.19.24"><i>Lev.</i>19:24</a>; <i>Ma</i>ˋ<i>aser Šeni</i> Chapter 5). They may be redeemed under the rules of Second Tithe, the sanctity being transferred to the redemption money.</i> and Second Tithe<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <i>Ma</i>ˋ<i>aser Šeni</i> 4:2, Note 51. Second Tithe remains the farmer’s property but must be eaten in purity at the site of the Temple. If there is any danger of spoilage in transport, the produce may be redeemed and the sanctity transferred to the redemption money, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 14:22-26" href="/Deuteronomy.14.22-26"><i>Deut.</i> 14:22–26</a>; cf. Introduction to Tractate <i>Ma</i>ˋ<i>aser Šeni</i>.</i> whose value is not known by three [appraisers], also of Temple dedications<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">Property donated to the Temple which will be sold by the Temple treasurer upon appraisal by a committee of three; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27:11" href="/Leviticus.27.11"><i>Lev.</i>27:11</a>.</i> by three. Estimations of movables<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">If a person makes a vow to donate the estimated value of a person to the Temple, the amount payable is specified in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27:2-7" href="/Leviticus.27.2-7"><i>Lev.</i>27:2–7</a> depending on age and sex. If the person wants to pay with movables in lieu of money, their value has to be determined by a committee of three. These rules are detailed in Tractate ˋ<i>Arakhin</i>.</i> by three [appraisers], Rebbi Jehudah says that one of them must be a Cohen; of real estate<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27:14-25" href="/Leviticus.27.14-25"><i>Lev.</i> 27:14–25</a>. In all verses speaking of redemption of property donated to the Temple, ‘the Cohen” is mentioned in the singular.</i> nine and a Cohen. The same holds for humans<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Somebody promising to pay to the Temple the value a person would fetch if sold as a slave.</i>.<br>Capital crimes [are judged] by 23. The participants in active or passive bestiality<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">Whether human or animal; the additional statement is needed only for the animal.</i> [is judged] by 23, as it is said, <i>you shall slay the woman and the animal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:16" href="/Leviticus.20.16"><i>Lev.</i> 20:16</a>. Since woman and animal are mentioned together, the animal can be condemned only by a court empowered to judge the woman who had sex with the animal.</i>, and it says, <i>and you shall slay the animal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:15" href="/Leviticus.20.15"><i>Lev.</i> 20:15</a>, about male bestiality.</i>. The bull to be stoned<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">Which had killed a human.</i> [is judged] by 23, as it is said, <i>the bull shall be stoned, also its owner shall die</i><sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:29" href="/Exodus.21.29"><i>Ex</i>. 21:29</a>.</i>; like the owner’s death sentence so is the ox’s death sentence. The wolf and the lion, the bear, and the tiger, and the panther, and the snake are sentenced to death by 23<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">He does not need permission; it is no case for a court.</i>. Rebbi Eliezer says, anyone quick to kill them is meritorious<sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">End of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.1">Halakhah 1, Notes 103–106</a>.</i>; Rebbi Aqiba says, they are sentenced by 23.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Whipping by three [judges],” etc. Rebbi Abbahu asked: Should not a sentence of whipping be passed by 23 [judges], since sometimes he might die from the whippings, so that it is a case of potential death sentence<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">He holds that R. Ismael’s position is the only reasonable one. But since the problem is purely theoretical (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:1:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.1.9">Note 32</a>), it is not pursued further.</i>.
Bar Qappara understood everything from here: <i>May the Eternal bless you and preserve you,</i> from here that one starts with three. <i>May the Eternal illuminate His Presence for you and be gracious to you,</i> from here that one continues with five. <i>May the Eternal turn His Presence to you and give you peace,</i> from here that one finishes with seven<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">From the verses of the priestly blessings, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 6:24-26" href="/Numbers.6.24-26"><i>Num.</i> 6:24–26</a>, which have 3, 5, and 7 words respectively, one may infer that proceeding by 3,5,7 will give a blessed result. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 10b" href="/Sanhedrin.10b">Babli, 10b</a>, this argument is attributed to early Amoraïm; in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 23a" href="/Megillah.23a"><i>Megillah</i>23a</a> it is applied to the number of people called to read from the Torah.</i>.
Rebbi Joshua ben Levi understood everything from the following: <i>The chief executioner took</i> … <i>the three guards of the threshhold</i><sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 52:24" href="/Jeremiah.52.24"><i>Jer.</i> 52:24</a>.</i>, from here that one starts with three. <i>And five men from the king’s entourage</i><sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 25:19" href="/II_Kings.25.19"><i>2K.</i> 25:19</a>.</i>, from here that one continues with five. <i>And seven men from the King’s entourage</i><sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 52:25" href="/Jeremiah.52.25"><i>Jer.</i> 52:25</a>.</i>, from here that one finishes with seven<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 10b" href="/Sanhedrin.10b">Babli 10b</a>. According to Rashi <i>ad loc.,</i> the verses describe the members of king Sedekia’s court and therefore are appropriate to the determination of the calendar which is a governmental exercise.</i>.
Rebbi Jonathan said, from there the great Synhedrion of all of Israel. <i>The minister of the executioners took Seraiah the Chief Priest and Zephania the priest</i><sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 52:24" href="/Jeremiah.52.24"><i>Jer.</i> 52:24</a>.</i>, these are two. <i>And seven men from the king’s entourage</i><sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 52:25" href="/Jeremiah.52.25"><i>Jer.</i> 52:25</a>.</i>, this makes nine. <i>And sixty men from the People of the Land</i><sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 25:19" href="/II_Kings.25.19"><i>2K.</i> 25:19</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 52:25" href="/Jeremiah.52.25"><i>Jer.</i> 52:25</a>.</i>, this makes seventy minus one. <i>And from the city one eunuch</i><sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 52:25" href="/Jeremiah.52.25"><i>Jer.</i> 52:25</a>.</i>, this makes seventy. There are Tannaïm who state seventy-one: <i>The chief executioner took … the three guards of the threshhold, and seven men from the king’s entourage, and sixty men from the People of the Land, and from the city he took one eunuch,</i> this makes seventy-one. And why is he called a eunuch? Because he transposes practice<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">In rabbinic Hebrew, סרס “to castrate” is also used in the sense of “to transpose words or letters”. While in the verse he is described as minister of defense, he is taken here as president of the court who can transpose precedents to apply to other cases. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Megillah 21b:7:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Megillah.21b.7.1">Tosafot <i>Megillah</i> 21b, <i>s. v</i>. כנגד</a>.</i>.
One verse says <i>five,</i> the other verse says <i>seven.</i> The latter includes the two clerks of court.
There is no lengthening of the month, but sanctification of the month<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 10b" href="/Sanhedrin.10b">Babli 10b</a>. In the absence of a computed calendar, the lengthening of the month is automatic. If the Synhedrion does not declare the 30<sup class="footnote-marker">th</sup> of a month as the 1<sup class="footnote-marker">st</sup> of the next, the 31<sup class="footnote-marker">st</sup> automatically is the first of the next month since no lunar month has more than 30 days. Therefore, action by the Synhedrion is needed not to lengthen, but to shorten the month and to designate the 30<sup>th</sup> as a semi-holiday.</i>. Samuel says, sanctification of the month needs no less than ten [participants]<sup>120</sup><i class="footnote">To make it a public event. In contrast to the intercalation of the year, the determination of the month has to be made public as soon as possible.</i>. Should Fellows <sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Members of the Academy who are pledged to follow the rules of fellowship (cf. Introduction to Tractate <i>Demay</i>) but have not yet reached the status of rabbi.</i> be able to enter for the sanctification of the month? Rebbi Hoshaia said, I was a Fellow and Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac took me to the sanctification of the month, but I do not know whether I was counted or not. It is obvious that he was not counted<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">If the chair of the meeting had asked him for his opinion, he would have remembered.</i>, but why? Was it because he was his son-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Since relatives are barred from sitting together as judges and R. Hoshaia was R. Samuel’s son-in-law, he could not participate even if qualified.</i>, or because Fellows are nor able to enter for the sanctification of the month? Rebbi Cahana said, I was a Fellow when Rebbi Tanḥum bar Ḥiyya took me to the sanctification of the month and I was counted. This implies that Fellows enter for the sanctification of the month.
Are Fellows able to enter for the intercalation of the year? Let us hear from the following: <sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 11a" href="/Sanhedrin.11a">Babli 11a</a>.</i> It happened that Rabban Gamliel said, call seven Elders to a meeting on the upper floor, but eight entered. He asked, who is the one who entered without permission? Samuel minor<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">He is called “minor” because of all people called Samuel only the prophet of the same name reached a higher state of holiness.</i> stood up and said, I came up here without permission since I have a practical problem and I have to ask advice on it. Rabban Gamliel told him, you compare to Eldad and Medad; if I had said “two”, you would have been one of them. Nevertheless, they did not intercalate on that day but talked about themes in the Torah and intercalated the next day<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">To protect the secrecy of the algorithm with which the years of intercalation were computed. This supports the contention of the Yerushalmi Gaon Eviatar haCohen in his Epistle that during the entire time of the Second Temple the calendar was computed and testimony about the new moon was only used as confirmation of the computation (M. Gil, <i>Palestine during the first Moslem period,</i> vol. 2, Tel Aviv 1983).</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph has parallels in <i>Roš Haššanah</i> 3:1, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 9:1:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.9.1.3"><i>Sotah</i> 9:1 (Notes 18–19</a>). The two are copies of one another; the text here is a reformulation.</i> lt was stated: If the Synhedrion<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">In the other sources, “a court”. The text here is influenced by the sequel which deals with a court empowered to treat calendar matters, the Synhedrion.</i> saw the killer. Some Tannaïm state: two of them become witnesses and testify before the rest of them<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">After addition of another two judges to complete the required number of judges.</i>. There are Tannaïm who state that they all are witnesses and have to go and testify before other [judges]<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">They hold that a witness is automatically disqualified as a judge since he has an opinion about the case before the start of the proceedings.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah ben Pazi in the name of Rebbi Zeˋira: As they differ here, so they differ about testimony for the New Moon<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Whether members of the Synhedrion who saw the New Moon may act as witnesses before their colleagues.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is a parallel to the text in <i>Roš Haššanah</i> 3:1 (58d l.2), noted <b>ר</b>.</i> Why cannot always one stand up and one sit down<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Rosh Hashanah 3:1:1-10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Rosh_Hashanah.3.1.1-10">Mishnah <i>Roš Haššanah</i>3:1</a> which prescribes that if three members of the Court saw the New Moon, one of them may sit with two others as a court and the other two who saw the New Moon appear as witnesses before them. The question arises, why does one have to call two others; would one not be sufficient if alternatingly one stands up as a witness and one sits down as a judge.</i>? There is a difference because a witness cannot be a judge<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">Even if one does not hold that a potential witness be automatically disqualified as a judge, he must hold that once a person acted as a witness he is disqualified as a judge.</i>. Rav Huna knew testimony for somebody. He<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">Rav Huna knew testimony for a creditor. The debtor required that the suit be heard in Rav Huna’s court. He knew that Rav Huna, as judge, could not act as witness and was prevented from using his knowledge in his judgment. He thought it was safe to deny any debt.</i> came and wanted to have the suit judged before Rav Huna, and denied all. Rebbi Samuel ben Rav Isaac told him, because you know that (Rebbi) [Rav]<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">The correct title is in <b>ר</b>.</i> Huna is an important person<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">As Rav’s successor, he was Chief Judge of all courts under the jurisdiction of the Academy of Sura. The debtor assumed that a Chief Judge could not appear in a lower court.</i> you deny everything. What if Rav Huna went and testified against you in another court? Rav Huna asked him, does one do that? He answered, yes. Rav Huna recused himself from that suit, went, and testified before another court<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">This decides practice. A judge who knows of the case has to disqualify himself and appear as a witness in another court. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rosh Hashanah 25b" href="/Rosh_Hashanah.25b">Babli agrees, <i>Roš Haššanah</i> 25b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 90b" href="/Bava_Kamma.90b"><i>Bava qamma</i> 90b</a>.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">This decides practice. A judge who knows of the case has to disqualify himself and appear as a witness in another court. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rosh Hashanah 25b" href="/Rosh_Hashanah.25b">Babli agrees, <i>Roš Haššanah</i> 25b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 90b" href="/Bava_Kamma.90b"><i>Bava qamma</i> 90b</a>.</i> Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai stated: <i>You shall sanctify the Fiftieth Year</i><sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 25:10" href="/Leviticus.25.10"><i>Lev.</i> 25:10</a>.</i>. You shall sanctify years but not months<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">The “sanctification of the month” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:2:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.2.7">Note 119</a>) really is a sanctification of the Day of the New Moon (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 28:11-15" href="/Numbers.28.11-15"><i>Num.</i> 28:11–15</a>), not of the entire month. But the Jubilee year itself is holy.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 10b" href="/Sanhedrin.10b">Babli 10b</a>, this is in the name of R. Eliezer or R. Eleazar; in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rosh Hashanah 8b" href="/Rosh_Hashanah.8b"><i>Roš Haššanah</i>8b</a> in the name of “the rabbis.”</i>. But did we not state<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Rosh Hashanah 2:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Rosh_Hashanah.2.5.1">Mishnah <i>Roš Haššanah</i> 2:8</a>.</i>: “The president of the court says: sanctified”? What means sanctified? Confirmed<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">The day is confirmed as one of additional religious services.</i>. It was stated: For sanctifying months one starts<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Polling the judges’ opinions.</i> with the most senior person. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Ada said, the Mishnah says this: “The president of the court says: sanctified.” It was stated, for intercalation of the (month) [year]<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">The text in brackets, from <i>Roš Haššanah,</i> is the correct one. The <i>Sanhedrin</i> text, in parentheses, is a scribal error.</i> one starts from the side<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">The senior judge sat in the middle, the most junior judge sat on the last chair to his left or right. One starts polling the most junior judge.</i>. Rebbi Zebida said, but this lower house<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">The Patriarch’s court, the only one empowered to determine the calendar, was held in low esteem by him.</i> do not proceed in this way, for they did not hear what Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Marius<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">It is impossible to determine whether מרייא or מרייא is the correct reading.</i> and Rebbi Jonah, Rebbi Abba bar Ḥiyya said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: For lengthening the month one starts with the most senior person, for intercalating the year one starts from the side. When Rebbi Joḥanan was participating as the most junior person, they told him, say: “this year is sanctified in its intercalation.” He said, “this year is sanctified in intercalation.” Rebbi Jonathan said, look at the language which the smith’s son<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">R. Johanan bar Nappaha, “son of the bellows-blower.”</i> taught us. If he had said, “in its intercalation,” I would have said that this refers to the eleven days by which the solar year exceeds the lunar one, but [he said] “in intercalation”, that the Sages added thirty days to it<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Any intercalary year has an additional month of 30 days; in the computed calendar this is Adar I.</i>. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa, Rebbi Yasa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: For intercalation one follows the date of ordination. In the Academy one follows usage; each one gives his opinion at his place and sums up. For example, Rebbi Ḥanina<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">He probably is R. Hinena, the student of R. Johanan in Tiberias, not R. Hanina, his teacher at Sepphoris</i> started, Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqisch summed up. Rebbi Abba bar Zavda started, Rebbi Yasa and Rebbi Immi<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">This is the correct text, not “R. Hiyya, R. Yasa, and R. Immi” as in <i>Roš Haššanah</i> since R. Hiyya (bar Abba), while also a student of R. Yasa, is not known to have participated in an Academy with him.</i> summed up. Rebbi Ḥaggai started, Rebbi Jonah and Rebbi Yose summed up. Rebbi Cahana was ordained before Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa, but Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa participated in intercalation before Rebbi Cahana was invited. He said, the person who formulated the tradition does not respect it for himself<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">By his own teaching in the name of R. Johanan, he should have insisted that R. Cahana be invited first.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is inserted only because R. Cahana, a very minor figure, was mentioned before and there was a story known about him. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 27a" href="/Berakhot.27a">Babli, <i>Berakhot</i>27a</a>, it is told that R. Jeremiah bar Abba was praying behind Rav, and that Rav remained immovable until R. Jeremiah had finished praying, from which it is inferred that one may not walk by a person standing in silent prayer.</i> Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba was standing praying. Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">The person here must be <i>Rebbi</i> Cahana, as correctly identified in <i>Roš Haššanah,</i> not one of the <i>Rav</i> Cahanas mentioned in the Babli, one of which was a student (and possibly stepson) of Rav, one generation before R. Ḥiyya bar Abba, and the other a contemporary of Rav Ashi, five generations later. Nevertheless, this <i>Rebbi</i> Cahana is characterized as a Babylonian, first by his use of the prefix ק for the present participle and also because only Babylonian families of priests trace their family back to the priest Eli of Shiloh, whose male descendants are cursed to die young.</i> Cahana came and stood behind him in prayer. When Rebbi Ḥiyya had finished, he sat down in order not to walk by him. Rav Cahana spent a long time praying. After he finished, he told him, is that your way to make your teacher suffer? He told him, I am a descendant of the House of Eli, of whom it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 3:14" href="/I_Samuel.3.14"><i>1S.</i> 3:14</a>.</i>: <i>if the sin of the House of Eli would be atoned for by sacrifice and offering.</i> By sacrifice and offering it cannot be atoned for, but it can be atoned for by prayer<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rosh Hashanah 18a" href="/Rosh_Hashanah.18a">Babli, <i>Roš Haššanah</i> 18a</a>, the verse is applied to the family of Rabba bar Nahmani, who could prolong life by Torah study and charity work.</i>. He prayed for him, he reached old age while his fingernails remained red like those of a small child<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Translation of the text of <b>ר</b>, דקקה, rather than the text here, רקקה “exceedingly thin”.</i>.
They preferred an old man to Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish for intercalation but had to remove him by the other door<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">He turned out not to have the required qualifications.</i>. He said, this is their reward<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">The embarassment of having to remove a member of the Court is deserved punishment for the powers-that-be who neglected R. Simeon ben Laqish.</i>. Did he not hear what Rebbi Crispus<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">The form קריספדא is Babylonian. The story is anonymous in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 18b" href="/Sanhedrin.18b">Babli 18b</a>.</i> said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: It happened that the year was intercalated by three cow hands. One said, in Adar, early and late grain<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Barley and wheat.</i> sprout together. One said, in Adar the ox will die naked<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Roš Haššanah</i> בעדרייה “in its herd”. In Adar (about March) sometimes it is cold and cattle might die; sometimes it is hot, cattle look for shade under trees and rub themselves against them as if they tried to remove their hides.</i> and try to strip off his hide under the fig tree. One said, if in Adar the East wind<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">The start of the Hamsin season.</i> blows, open your jaws and go towards it. And we see that this year nothing of these applies. They intercalated the year on their word. Rebbi Ḥelbo said, because the Court agreed with them<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">The cow hands might have provided the arguments but the action was the Court’s; the story is irrelevant for R. Simeon ben Laqish’s complaint.</i>. Rebbi Zeˋira said, but they all have to agree to the same reason<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">How could they follow the cow hands if each of them gave a different reason?</i>. But since they all agree with one another it was that they all agreed as to the reason<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">All three of them agreed to all three reasons.</i>.
Why was Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish offended by this? He was worried about what Rebbi Eleazar said, since Rebbi Eleazar said<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 13:9" href="/Ezekiel.13.9"><i>Ez.</i> 13:9</a>. In the Bali, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 112a" href="/Ketubot.112a"><i>Ketubot</i> 112a</a>.</i>: <i>My hand will be against the prophets who see … vain things, in my people’s council</i><sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">Identifying biblical סוד “council” with rabbinic סוד “secret”.</i><i>they shall not be;</i> that is [the secret of]<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">From the text in <i>Roš Haššanah.</i></i> intercalation; <i>in the documents of the House of Israel they will not be inscribed;</i> that is ordination; <i>and to the earth of Israel they shall not come;</i> that is the Land of Israel. When Rebbi Eleazar came here, he said, I have one. When they ordained him, he said, I have two.When he was asked to participate in the intercalation, he said, I have all three [with me]<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">From the text in <i>Roš Haššanah.</i></i>.
Rebbi Abba bar Zavda in the name of Rav: The reason of Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Sadoq: When the Heavenly Court sees that the earthly Court sanctifies it, they also sanctify it<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">This is a slightly garbled reformulation of the corresponding paragraph in <i>Roš Haššanah</i>; it has no relevance here. The reference is to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Rosh Hashanah 2:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Rosh_Hashanah.2.5.1">Mishnah <i>Roš Haššanah</i> 2:8</a> where Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Sadoq says that the New Moon after a month of 30 days does not need sanctification by the Court since it was sanctified by Heaven. In <i>Roš Haššanah</i> one reads: When the Heavenly court sees that the Earthly Court <i>did not</i> sanctity (the 30<sup>th</sup> day), they (automatically) sanctify (the 31<sup>st</sup> day.)</i>.
Rebbi Eleazar in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina. It happened that 24 people appointed by the House of Rebbi entered to intercalate the year at Lydda when an evil eye entered with them and they all died at the same time. From that time on they removed it from Judea and established it in Galilee. They also wanted to remove the signal<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">They wanted to drop the condition of agriculture in Judea from consideration in deciding on intercalation, as described in the next paragraph.</i>. Rebbi Simon told them, do we not even want to leave a remembrance in Judea? But we find that they intercalated the year at Baˋalat. This Baˋalat is sometimes [mentioned as being] in Judea, sometimes in Dan. <i>Elteqe, and Gibbeton, and Ba</i>ˋ<i>alat</i> are from Judea<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 19:44" href="/Joshua.19.44"><i>Jos.</i> 19:44</a>, in the list of cities of <i>Dan</i>.</i>. <i>Ba</i>ˋ<i>alah, and Iyyim, and Asem</i><sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 15:29" href="/Joshua.15.29"><i>Jos.</i> 15:29</a>, in the list of cities of <i>Jehudah.</i> Probably the reference should have been to v. 24, mentioning the town of בְּעָלוֹת.</i> are from Dan, and we find that they intercalated the year at Baˋalat. Let us say that the houses were in Judea and the fields in Dan. Rebbi Jeremiah asked before Rebbi Zeˋira: Is Lydda not in Judea<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote">In post-biblical Judea; it was in biblical Benjamin (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 8:13" href="/I_Chronicles.8.13"><i>1Chr.</i> 8:13</a>).</i>? He answered, yes. Then why does one not intercalate there? He told him, because they are coarse of spirit and have little learning<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">While before the war of Bar Kokhba it was one of the main seats of learning.</i>. He turned his face and saw Rebbi Aḥa and Rebbi Judah ben Pazi<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">Rabbis of Lydda.</i>. He said to him, presently<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">Greek εἷτα. Since the word is also found in Syriac, it is not impossible that two native Babylonians used it when speaking to one another.</i> you made me insult rabbis.
<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">The following paragraphs are all in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 2:1-4" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.2.1-4">Tosephta, Chapter 2</a>, 2–11. The present paragraph and the following also are in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 11b" href="/Sanhedrin.11b">Babli, 11b</a>.</i>“For three indications one intercalates a year: because of fresh grain<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">Since the celebration of the festival of unleavened bread requires the offering of fresh barley grain in the ˋ<i>omer</i> ceremony (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 23:9-14" href="/Leviticus.23.9-14"><i>Lev.</i> 23:9–14</a>), the lunar year has to be adjusted so that Passover be celebrated in the “month of fresh grain” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 13:4-5" href="/Exodus.13.4-5"><i>Ex.</i> 13:4–5</a>).</i>, the equinox<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">As explained later, the verses <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 13:4-5" href="/Exodus.13.4-5"><i>Ex.</i>13:4–5</a> are interpreted to mean that the spring equinox must fall before Passover, but no more than 30 days earlier.</i>, and tree fruits<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">If it seems likely that the fruits will not be edible by Pentecost, the start of the season for First Fruits.</i>. One intercalates because of two of them, because of a single one does not intercalate; but if they intercalated, it is intercalated. If fresh grain was one of the reasons, everybody was happy<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">It is forbidden to eat from new grain before the ˋ<i>omer</i> ceremony, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 23:14" href="/Leviticus.23.14"><i>Lev.</i> 23:14</a>. If the year was intercalated because new grain was not ready, it imposed no restrictions on people since new grain was not available anyhow.</i>. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel said, also<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi in his Commentary wants to delete אַף “also”, since it dos not make much sense in the context. But since the text is confirmed by three sources, it cannot be deleted.</i> because of the equinox.”
“For three regions one intercalates a year, because of Judea, Transjordan, and Galilee<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">Since the ˋ<i>omer</i> can be offered from any place in the Holy Land if barley is not ripe in Judea. Transjordan is defined as that part East of the Jordan which is included in the legal definition of the Land of Israel, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sheviit 6:1:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sheviit.6.1.9"><i>Ševiˋit</i> 6:1, Notes 32–51</a>.</i>. One intercalates because of two of them, while because of one of them one does not intercalate; if they did intercalate it is not intercalated<sup class="footnote-marker">187,</sup><i class="footnote">In the Tosephta: “it is intercalated.” The sentence is missing in the Babli, which has to be read as tacit endorsement of the Tosephta (or better, the Tosephta has to be read as explaining the Babli’s position.)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">Since intercalation was the prerogative of the Synhedrion, the expression “it is not intercalated” can only mean that in this case the intercalation is revocable, in contrast to other cases where it is irrevocable once announced.</i>. If Judea was one of the reasons, everybody<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">In Judea, where one could expect cheap new grain after Passover.</i> was happy since the ˋ<i>Omer</i> was brought from there.
