<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 11a" href="/Sanhedrin.11a">Babli 11a</a>.</i>“One intercalates neither because of the cold, nor because of the rains<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">The convenience of travelers, pilgrims for the Passover festival, should not be a consideration.</i>; if they did intercalate it is not intercalated<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">Since intercalation was the prerogative of the Synhedrion, the expression “it is not intercalated” can only mean that in this case the intercalation is revocable, in contrast to other cases where it is irrevocable once announced.</i>. One intercalates neither because of kid goats nor because of pigeon chicks, nor because of milk [lambs]<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">Most private obligations of sacrifices are satisfied either with a couple of pigeons or with offerings of lambs and kid goats. It is desirable that there be an ample supply available for pilgrims at Passover time, but this is not an absolute necessity.</i>; but all of them are ancillary reasons for the year. <sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">The text of the Babli makes clear that this sentence explains what is meant by “ancillary reasons for intercalation.”</i> Rebbi Yannai<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">The Tanna.</i> said that Rabban Gamliel<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">In both Babylonian sources, Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel. The Yerushalmi version is preferable, as shown by the later text of Rabban Gamliel I’s proclamations.</i> used to say: The sheep are thin and the pigeon chicks small; it appears good in my eyes and in those of my colleagues to add thirty days to the year.”
<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 11b" href="/Sanhedrin.11b">Babli 11b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 2:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.2.2">Tosephta 2:6</a>.</i>“Rebbi Jehudah said: it happened that Rabban Gamliel and the Elders were sitting on stairs on the Temple Mount<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">Since they assembled outside the Temple precinct, the procedure is to be dated to the time of the Roman procurators who had taken over criminal jurisdiction “40 years before the destruction of the Temple” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:1:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.1.9">Note 31</a>).</i>; their scribe Joḥanan was sitting before them when Rabban Gamliel said to him, write: To our brothers in the Upper Southland and the Lower Southland<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">The grain growing areas South of Lydda, both in the hills (the Upper) and near the coast (the Lower). Heave and tithes, which have to be separated immediately after processing, have to be delivered before the holiday, and Second Tithe, in years 1,2,4,5 of the Sabbatical cycle, taken to Jerusalem for the holiday celebration.</i>, may you have much peace. We inform you that the time of liquidation has come, to deliver tithes from the sheaves of grain. To our brothers in the Upper Galilee and the Lower Galilee<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">For definition of these regions see <i>Ševi</i>ˋ<i>it</i> 9:2, Notes 40–41.</i>, may you have much peace. We inform you that the time of liquidation has come, to deliver tithes from the olive presses. To our brothers in the diaspora of Babylonia, the diaspora of Media, the diaspora of Greece, and all other diasporas of Israel, may you have much peace. We inform you that the sheep are thin, the pigeon chicks small, and springtime has not arrived; it appears good in my eyes and those of my colleagues to add thirty days to this year.”
<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 13a" href="/Sanhedrin.13a">Babli 13a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 2:3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.2.3">Tosephta 2:7</a>.</i>“One does not intercalate a year unless it be missing most of a month. How much is most of a month? 16 days<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">The version of the Tosephta implies that a month has to be added if otherwise the Spring equinox would fall on the 17<sup class="footnote-marker">th</sup> of Nisan or later, for R. Jehudah on the 22<sup class="footnote-marker">nd</sup> or later.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah says two thirds of a month, 21 days.” Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman said, only that the ˋ<i>Omer</i> should be brought at the end of Nisan of equinoxes<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">“Nisan of the equinox” is the solar period 30 days from the equinox. He is more restrictive and holds that the equinox must fall on or before (but no more than 30 days before) the 15<sup class="footnote-marker">g</sup> of the lunar Nisan. “At the end” means “after the first.” (Today’s computed calendar sometimes violates this rule.)</i>. Rebbi Yose said, before Passover<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Passover day is the 14<sup class="footnote-marker">th</sup> of Nisan, he requires the Spring equinox not to fall after this date. He is reputed to be the editor of the computed calendar, which however has come to us only through the works of authors living several hundred years later.</i>. Rav Mattaniah said, only that <i>lulav</i> be taken at the end of Tishre of equinoxes<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">He requires in addition that the fall equinox be no later than the 15<sup>th</sup> of Tishre. In our computed calendar, this rule is violated about once in a 19 year period.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 11a" href="/Sanhedrin.11a">Babli 11a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 2:4" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.2.4">Tosephta 2:8</a>. The Tosephta here follows the Yerushalmi text, which allows for a “month”, i. e., either 29 or 30 days. The Babli prescribes 30 days; it notes 29 as permissible only for Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel (II). The computed calendar in this matter follows the Babli.</i>“One intercalates a year neither less than a month, nor more than a month; if it was intercalated<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">For a different number of days.</i>, it is not intercalated.”
<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 12a" href="/Sanhedrin.12a">Babli 12a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 2:5" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.2.5">Tosephta 2:9</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nedarim 6:8:2-15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nedarim.6.8.2-15"><i>Nedarim</i>6:13</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Shekalim 1:2:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Shekalim.1.2.2-5"><i>Šeqalim</i> 1:2</a> (46a l.51). The text from here to the end of the Halakhah is essentially copied in <i>Nedarim,</i> explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:1:25-2:11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.1.25-2.11">Notes 83–141</a>. The short parallel in <i>Šeqalim</i> belongs to a different tradition. The paragraphs are alternatingly shortened and extended; they cannot be considered exact copies of one another. The Notes to the text following are restricted to indicate deviations from the text in <i>Nedarim</i>.</i>“One intercalates neither in a Sabbatical year nor the year following a Sabbatical; but if it was intercalated it is intercalated. When does one usually intercalate? The year preceding a Sabbatical.” Rebbi Zeˋira said in the name of Rebbi Abbahu, that is before Rebbi permitted to import produce from outside the Land into the Land. But since Rebbi permitted to import produce from outside the Land into the Land, there is no difference between a Sabbatical and the remaining years of the Sabbatical cycle.
<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph has been shortened and become incomprehensible. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nedarim 6:8:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nedarim.6.8.5"><i>Nedarim</i>6:13, Notes 86–88</a>. Both Talmudim always assume that a prophet by his office must have been a member of the High Court.</i> Rebbi Meïr used to say: it is said, <i>a man came from Baal Shalisha and brought to the Man of God first fruit bread, twenty loaves,</i> etc. Since the year should have been intercalated, why did Elisha not intercalate? This teaches that it was a year of famine and people were eager for threshing floors.
Some Tannaïm state: “One does not intercalate because of impurity.” Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Nedarim</i>: R. Jehudah. This seems to be the correct quote.</i> says, one intercalates, since we find that Hezekiah intercalated because of the impurity, as it is said: <i>For most of the people from Ephraim, Manasse, Issachar, and Zevulun had not been purified, for they ate the Passover contrary to what is written, for Hezekiah had prayed, saying, the Eternal, the Benevolent, will pardon this.</i> Rebbi Simeon says, even though he intercalated Nisan, it was Adar which was intercalated. Rebbi Simeon ben Jehudah said in the name of Rebbi Simeon: Hezekiah forced the community to celebrate the Second Passover.”
Some Tannaïm state: One intercalates because of impurity. Some Tannaïm state: One does not intercalate. He who says, one does not intercalate, from the following: <i>for they ate the Passover contrary to what is written.</i> How does the one who says one does not intercalate, explain <i>contrary to what is written</i>? They intercalated in Nisan but one intercalates only in Adar. This follows what Rebbi Simon bar Zavdi said: they found the skull of Ornan the Yebusite under the altar.
It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">There is no such verse in the Bible. The text is a combination of <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 30:19" href="/II_Chronicles.30.19"><i>2Chr.</i> 30:19</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezra 7:10" href="/Ezra.7.10"><i>Ezra</i> 7:10</a>.</i>: <i>With all his heart he prepared himself to seek God,</i> to act, and to teach law and justice in Israel. Rebbi Simon bar Zavdi and Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman. One said, with all he did for the purity of the Temple, he did not fully establish the purity of the Temple. One said, with all the good works he did, he did not fully do his duty for the purity of the Temple. It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 29:16" href="/II_Chronicles.29.16"><i>2Chr.</i> 29:16</a>.</i>: <i>They started on the first of the first month, and on the eighth day they entered the Eternal’s Hall and sanctified the Eternal’s House for</i> three <i>days; on the sixteenth of the month they finished.</i> Could they not have eliminated all idolatry from there in one day? Rebbi Idi said, because of Chaldean idols which were engraved in vermilion.
Six things did Hezekiah do; with three they agreed, with three they did not agree. He dragged his father’s bones on a bier of ropes, he smashed the bronze snake, and he hid the table of medicines; they agreed. He closed the upper Giḥon spring, and he cut down the Temple doors, and he intercalated Nisan in Nisan; they disagreed.
One does not intercalate before New Year’s Day; if they did intercalate it would be invalid. But for an urgent need one may intercalate immediately after New Year’s Day. Nevertheless, only Adar is intercalated. <sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">This and the following paragraphs also are found in <i>Ševi</i>ˋ<i>it</i> 10:2 (Notes 41–55) and <i>Roš Haššanah</i> 3:1 (58c l. 51).</i> Rebbi says, Nisan was never lengthened. But did we not state: “If the New Moon appeared in time”? If it would appear; it did not appear. Rav said, Tishre was never lengthened. But did we not state: “If the month was long”? If it would be, it never was.
“When they sanctified the year at Usha, on the first day Rebbi Ismael, the son of Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa, led and recited following the opinion of Rebbi Joḥanan ben Nuri. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel said, we did not follow this at Jabneh. On the second day, Rebbi Ḥananiah, the son of Rebbi Yose the Galilean, led and recited following Rebbi Aqiba. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel said, this we did follow at Jabneh.” But does this not mean that they sanctified it on the first and the second day? Rebbi Zeˋira in the name of Rav Ḥisda: That year was disorganized. What is “on the first, on the second”? Rav Abba in the name of Rav: The first year, the second year! But was it not stated: the first day, the second day?
If they sanctified it before its time or after its lengthening, should I assume it was lengthened? The verse says, <i>them, them;</i> not <i>these are My holidays</i>? Before its time, the 29<sup class="footnote-marker">th</sup> day; after its lengthening, the 32<sup class="footnote-marker">nd</sup> day. From where that one intercalates for the year because of the diaspora<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">The Babylonians who come to Jerusalem in caravans to celebrate Passover.</i> who set out but did not yet arrive? The verse says, <i>the Children of Israel.</i> Make the holidays so they can be observed by all of Israel. Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman said, only if they had reached the river Euphrates.
“One intercalates a year only in Judea, but if it was intercalated in Galilee it is validly intercalated. Ḥanina from Ono testified that, if it cannot be intercalated in Judea, one intercalates in Galilee.” One does not intercalate a year outside the Land; if it was intercalated, it is not validly intercalated. Look at it, one does not intercalate in Galilee; could one intercalate outside the Land<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">Why has the prohibition of intercalation outside the Land to be mentioned at all? Could this prohibition not be inferred from the rule for Galilee?</i>? One does not intercalate in Galilee; but if it was intercalated it is validly intercalated. One does not intercalate outside the Land; if it was intercalated it is not intercalated if it was possible to intercalate in the Land of Israel; but if one cannot intercalate in the Land of Israel, one intercalates it outside the Land.
Jeremiah intercalated outside the Land. Ezechiel intercalated outside the Land. Baruch ben Neriah intercalated outside the Land. Ḥanania the nephew of Rebbi Joshua intercalated outside the Land. Rebbi sent him three letters through Rebbi Isaac and Rebbi Nathan. In one he wrote, to His holiness Ḥanania. And in one he wrote, the kid goats you left behind became rams. And in one he wrote, if you do not accept, go to the thistle desert, do the slaughtering and let Onias sprinkle. After the first [letter], he honored them. After the second, he honored them. After the third, he wanted to disgrace them. They said to him, you cannot do that since you already did honor us. Rebbi Isaac rose and read in the Torah: These are the holidays of Ḥanania the nephew of Rebbi Joshua. They said to him, <i>the holidays of the Eternal.</i> He told them, that is with us. Rebbi Nathan rose and concluded: For from Babylonia will Torah go forth and the Eternal’s word from Nahar-Peqod. They said to him, <i>for from Zion will Torah go forth and the Eternal’s word from Jerusalem.</i> He told them, that is with us. He went to complain about them to Rebbi Jehudah ben Bathyra at Nisibis. He said to him, follow them, follow them. He said to him, I do not know whom I left there. Who would tell me that they are knowledgeable in computations as I am? If they did not know the computations, they should listen to him. Since they are knowledgeable in computations as he is, he has to listen to them. He got up and rode on a horse. Where he reached, he reached. Where he did not reach, they continued to follow the corrupt [calendar].
It is written: <i>to the outstanding Elders in the diaspora.</i> The Holy One, praise to Him, said: The Elders of the diaspora are very dear to me. But more beloved by Me is a small group in the Land of Israel than a great Synhedrion outside the Land. It is written: <i>The craftsmen and the smiths one thousand,</i> and you say so? Rebbi Berekhiah in the name of Rebbi Ḥelbo and the rabbis. Rebbi Berekhiah said, one thousand craftsmen and one thousand smiths. But the rabbis say, together one thousand. Rebbi Berekhiah in the name of Rebbi [Ḥelbo said]<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">Added from the consensus of the parallel texts, missing here.</i>, these are the Fellows; but the rabbis say, these are the councilmen.
Rebbi Hoshaia, when he received witnesses at Kallirhoë, used to say to them: you should know the importance of the testimony that comes from your mouths; how much rent money depends on your mouths. Rebbi Abuna said, if it is so, it is even a matter of criminal law. If somebody sleeps with a girl three years and one day old, he is stoned. The court decides to lengthen, if he sleeps with her he is not stoned. Rebbi Abun said, <i>I am calling to Almighty God, to the God Who decides with me.</i> If a girl is three years and one day old, if the court decides to lengthen her hymen does (not) repair itself, otherwise it does [not] repair itself<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">The text here obviously is wrong, but is correct in the parallel texts. It is talmudic doctrine that a girl becomes nubile one day after her third birthday. If she should have been raped before that day, her hymen will regrow and she remains a virgin; after that day the deflowering is definitive. It is stated that her body will follow the calendar decreed by the court.</i>.
“The leaning of Elders and the breaking of the calf’s neck by three [judges], the words of Rebbi Simeon, but Rebbi Jehudah says, by five.” <sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">A very similar text is in <i>Sotah</i> 9:1. The commentary, Notes 32–45, also applies here. In the Babli, the parallels are <i>Sanhedrin</i> 13b, <i>Sotah</i> 44b.</i> What is the reason of Rebbi Simeon? “[The Elders] shall lean,” two. No court has an even number of members; one adds another one; that makes three. What is the reason of Rebbi Jehudah? “They shall lean,” two. “The Elders,” two. No court has an even number of members; one adds one; that makes five. And for the calf whose neck is broken, <sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">The arguments of rabbis Simeon and Jehudah have to be switched; cf. <i>Sotah</i> 9:1 Note 33. The argument of R. Jehudah (attributed here to R. Simeon) is explicit in Mishnah <i>Sotah</i> 9:1. The corrected text, treating R. Jehudah’s opinion before R. Simeon’s, follows the Babli which as a matter of principle insists on strict chronological order.</i> what is the reason of Rebbi Simeon? “Your Elders,” two, “and your judges,” two. No court has an even number of members; one adds one; that makes five. What is the reason of Rebbi Jehudah? “Your elders, your judges,” two. No court has an even number of members; one adds another one; that makes three. Rebbi said, the words of Rebbi Jehudah are reasonable for the breaking of the neck, for he does not refer to “they shall go out.” The words of Rebbi Simeon are reasonable for the leaning of the hands, for he does not refer to “they shall lean.” If you would say that the words of Rebbi Jehudah are reasonable for the calf whose neck is broken, if he refers to “they shall lean”, he also should refer to “they shall go out.” It turns out that you have to say “they shall go out” two, “your Elders” two, “and your judges” two. No court has an even number of members; one adds one more; that makes seven. How does Rebbi Simeon explain “your Elders and your judges”? Your Elders who are your judges. It was stated: Rebbi Eliezer ben Jacob says “your Elders,” that is the High Court; “and your judges,” these are king and High Priest.
It was stated: Leanings by three [judges]. Is not leaning the same as leanings<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">What does the <i>baraita</i> imply that is not implied by the Mishnah?</i>? There<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia, ordination is called “leaning of the hands,” in imitation of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 27:23" href="/Numbers.27.23"><i>Num.</i>27:23</a>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 13b" href="/Sanhedrin.13b">Babli, 13b</a>, this usage is labelled as that of the Galilean R. Johanan. Modem usage naturally follows the Babli.</i>, they call ordination “leaning”.
Rebbi Abba said, in earlier times<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">Before the war of Bar Kokhba.</i>, every one was ordinating his students; for example Rabban Joḥanan ben Zakkai ordained Rebbi Eliezer and Rebbi Joshua<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">Before his time, one finds neither formal ordination nor the title “Rebbi”.</i>, Rebbi Joshua Rebbi Aqiba, and Rebbi Aqiba Rebbi Meïr and Rebbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">In the tradition of the Babli, both were ordained, together with three others, by R. Jehudah ben Bava. This tradition is questioned by the Babli itself, <i>loc. cit.;</i> its historical accuracy is in doubt since it counts among the five also R. Jehudah, who belongs to the school of R. Eliezer, not R. Joshua.</i>. He said, Rebbi Meïr shall preside; the face of Rebbi Simeon became yellow. Rebbi Aqiba told him, it is enough that I and your Creator recognize your power<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">In the tradition of both Talmudim, R. Simeon is a higher authority than R. Meïr; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Terumot 3:1:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Terumot.3.1.6"><i>Terumot</i> 3:1, Note 25</a>.</i>. They changed and honored this dynasty<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">In the time of the reconstruction after the war of Bar Kokhba, when the authority of the Patriarch became a political necessity. The dynasty is Hillel’s family, reputed to be of Davidic descent.</i>, saying: If a court ordained without the consent of the Patriarch, their ordination is no ordination, but if the Patriarch ordained without consent of the court, his ordination is ordination. They changed again<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Under Rebbi’s successors, who had neither learning nor standing to act alone.</i> and instituted that neither shall the Court ordain without consent of the Patriarch, nor the Patriarch without consent of the Court.
It was stated: From earlier times<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning that the text is traditional; its first author is unknown. The parallel in <i>Mo</i>ˋ<i>ed qatan</i> 3:5 (82a l. 48) does not have the introduction. [The text in <i>Mo</i>ˋ<i>ed qatan</i> is somewhat shortened in the Leiden ms. and <i>editio princeps</i> but the full text is in the Ashkenazic fragments published by J. Jehudah.</i>, one was writing documents of <i>ḥalîṣah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">Needed by the widow to be able to remarry in another jurisdiction.</i>: Before X and V<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">There should be three names mentioned here since the court must have three members.</i> did Z daughter of U perform <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for V son of W, by coming before us, removing his shoe from his right foot, spitting before us visible spittle on the ground, and saying: <i>So shall be done to the man unwilling to build his brother’s house</i><sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:9" href="/Deuteronomy.25.9"><i>Deut</i>. 25:9</a>.</i>.
It was stated: From earlier times<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning that the text is traditional; its first author is unknown. The parallel in <i>Mo</i>ˋ<i>ed qatan</i> 3:5 (82a l. 48) does not have the introduction. [The text in <i>Mo</i>ˋ<i>ed qatan</i> is somewhat shortened in the Leiden ms. and <i>editio princeps</i> but the full text is in the Ashkenazic fragments published by J. Jehudah.</i> one was writing documents of repudiation<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">The repudiation of a marriage by an underage girl, married off by her mother or brothers after her father’s death and whose marriage during her minority is valid only rabbinically; cf. <i>Yebamot</i> Chapter 13.</i>: Before X and Y<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">There should be three names mentioned here since the court must have three members.</i> did Z daughter of U repudiate V son of W, by coming before us: I do not like him, I do not want to stay with him, I do not agree to be married to him<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 107b" href="/Yevamot.107b">Babli, <i>Yebamot</i> 107b</a>, this is the required oral declaration of repudiation. <sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">This piece is a composite of two paragraphs in <i>Maˋaser Šeni</i> 4:3, Notes 63–68. In the order of subjects, the sources differ from one another.</i> Rebbi Joḥanan said, if somebody redeemed Temple dedications for more than their worth, it is redeemed<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">These rules are purely rabbinical in character.</i>. But if somebody redeemed Second Tithe for more than its worth, it is not redeemed. What is the difference between dedications and Second Tithe? <sup class="footnote-marker">247,</sup><i class="footnote">This is a <i>non sequitur.</i> The text in <i>Maˋaser Šeni</i> shows that the text is garbled; the text which belongs here is the other one starting with “R. La said,” with <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:2:43" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.2.43">Note 248</a>.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">This is the appropriate answer to the question following <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:2:43" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.2.43">Note 252</a>. The Temple treasurer may attach the dedicator’s property to collect the fifth; redemption of Second Tithe is a private matter.</i> Rebbi La said, dedications have claimants, Second Tithe has no claimant. Rebbi Jonah asked, that is following him who says that it is not his property<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to R. Meïr’s opinion regarding Second Tithe; cf. <i>Ma</i>ˋ<i>aser Šeni</i>4:3, Note 67.</i>. But for him who says it is his property, what is the difference between dedications and Second Tithe? Rebbi Yose said, the reason has already been explained: dedications have claimants, Second Tithe has no claimant.
<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">This belongs after the text noted <sup>248</sup> and refers to the answer given in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:2:43" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.2.43">Note 248</a> (cf. <i>Maˋaser Šeni</i> 4:3 Note 66.)</i> Rebbi Zeˋira asked before Rebbi Immi: If the person was checked and he said, that was not what I intended? He answered him, when he will be checked.
Rebbi Joḥanan said, if somebody redeemed Temple dedications without adding its fifth it is redeemed<sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote">Even though adding the fifth in general is a biblical obligation; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27:13" href="/Leviticus.27.13"><i>Lev.</i> 27:13</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27:15" href="/Leviticus.27.15">15</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27:19" href="/Leviticus.27.19">19</a>.</i>. But if somebody redeemed Second Tithe dedications without adding its fifth, it is not redeemed<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">Even though the obligation of adding a fifth to the redemption money (Mishnah <i>Maˋaser Šeni</i> 4:2) is not supported by a verse.</i>. What is the difference between dedications and Second Tithe? <sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote">If a person overpays for redemption of his Temple dedications, it is a natural thing to do. But if he overpays for Second Tithe, the amount set aside for consumption in Jerusalem would be a mixture of sacred and profane money.</i> Rebbi La said, because a person usually adds to his dedications. Rebbi Jonah asked, that is following him who says that it is not his property<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to R. Meïr’s opinion regarding Second Tithe; cf. <i>Ma</i>ˋ<i>aser Šeni</i>4:3, Note 67.</i>. But for him who says it is his property, what is the difference between Second Tithe and dedications? Rebbi Yose said, did you not already give the reason? Because a person usually adds to his dedications.
It was stated: “Temple dedications by three [appraisers].” That is, if one dedicated the body of a field. But if he said, I am vowing a mina for the Temple, <sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote">From here to the end of the Halakhah there exists a copy in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 4:4:2-8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.4.4.2-8"><i>Megillah</i> 4:4</a> (75b l. 16ff., <b>מ</b>).</i> let us hear from the following: “Appraisal of movables by three [appraisers].” Do there exist appraisals not of movables<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">By definition, “appraisals” refers to the sums of money detailed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27:1-8" href="/Leviticus.27.1-8"><i>Lev.</i> 27:1–8</a>. Money always is movable.</i>? Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa, Rebbi Simeon bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: If somebody says, I am vowing my appraisal, and comes to settle his debt by real estate, one appraises it by ten [people], by movables by three<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">This is difficult to understand; since the text is confirmed by two copies, it cannot be emended. By biblical law, a reduction of payments for the poor is mandated only for appraisals (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27:8" href="/Leviticus.27.8"><i>Lev.</i> 27:8</a>), not for dedications of specified sums. The reduction, based on what he can afford, is determined by a committee of three which must include a Cohen. If the poor person paid only part of the reduced sum and then becomes rich, the original sum is reinstated as soon as he can afford it. If the poor person made his vow (in the <i>Megillah</i> version for 100 minas) in order to induce God to make him rich so he may fulfill his vow, it might be in the interest of the Temple to wait with the collection of the debt until the person became affluent.</i>. Is one who says, I am vowing my appraisal not like one who says, I am vowing my field’s value<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">Since the rules of appraisal are the same in both categories.</i>? But if he said, I am vowing a mina for the Temple, one appraises him by three [people]. Should he become rich, he will be judged by what he can afford<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote">This is difficult to understand; since the text is confirmed by two copies, it cannot be emended. By biblical law, a reduction of payments for the poor is mandated only for appraisals (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27:8" href="/Leviticus.27.8"><i>Lev.</i> 27:8</a>), not for dedications of specified sums. The reduction, based on what he can afford, is determined by a committee of three which must include a Cohen. If the poor person paid only part of the reduced sum and then becomes rich, the original sum is reinstated as soon as he can afford it. If the poor person made his vow (in the <i>Megillah</i> version for 100 minas) in order to induce God to make him rich so he may fulfill his vow, it might be in the interest of the Temple to wait with the collection of the debt until the person became affluent.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">The origin of these paragraphs is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 11:6:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.11.6.2-5"><i>Ketubot</i> 11:6</a> (<b>כ</b>), explained there in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:2:4-9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.2.4-9">Notes 116–128</a>. The final paragraph, while also found in <i>Megillah,</i> makes sense only in <i>Ketubot.</i> The sentence in brackets is not in the text here, it is from <i>Ketubot,</i> but is necessary to provide continuity of the text.</i> It was stated: One does not make public tender for slaves, securities, and movables. [What is public tender?] Rebbi Jehudah ben Pazi said, announcement. Ulla bar Ismael said, slaves lest they flee, securities and movables lest they be stolen. Rebbi Abba bar Cohen asked before Rebbi Yose: Does this not imply that a slave be redeemed in front of three people? He answered him, yes. But did we not state: “Real estate nine and a Cohen. The same holds for humans”? He answered him, but the human here is a free person. Ḥanania bar Šelemiah in the name of Rav: A case came before Rebbi who wanted to act following the rabbis. Rebbi Eleazar ben Proteus, the grandson of Rebbi Eleazar ben Proteus, said to him: Rebbi, did you not teach us in your grandfather’s name, “except if he offered public tender”? He answered, yes, changed his mind, and acted following Rabban Gamliel.
“Capital crimes [are judged] by 23.” <sup class="footnote-marker">265</sup><i class="footnote">End of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.1">Halakhah 1, Notes 103–106</a>.</i> Rebbi Abbahu asked: Following Rebbi Meïr, should an ox which is stoned have to pay damages by a court of three and be stoned by 23? Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun told him, the rules of an ox which is stoned are all about money; it is a decision of the verse that it should be stoned.
General<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ἡγεμῶν “leader, commander.” In 19c l. 61 (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:4:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.4.7">Note 366</a>) his name is Antoninus, in 19d l. 4 (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:4:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.4.9">Note 373</a>) Antigonos. The story has many parallels in which various forms of the name appear. Jastrow and Krauss think of Quietus, a general of Trajan not likely to have conversed with a person who died under Vespasian. A Genizah text shows that אגנטוס is the correct form. {Perhaps it is not a name but a title, εὐγενής “noble, well-born.”(E. G.)}</i> אגנטוס asked Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">His title should be Rabban.</i> Joḥanan ben Zakkai: <i>the bull shall be stoned, also its owner shall die</i><sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:29" href="/Exodus.21.29"><i>Ex</i>. 21:29</a>.</i>? He answered, the robber’s<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote">Greek, λῃστής, ληϊστής.</i> partner is like the robber. When he had left, his students asked him, rabbi, this one you pushed away with a cane<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">Since the owner is not executed, the answer cannot be correct.</i>; what are you telling us? He said to them, it is written, <i>the bull shall be stoned, also its owner shall die,</i> like the owner’s death sentence so is the ox’s death sentence. Since the owner’s death sentence would be by a court of 23, investigation<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote">An exact investigation into the circumstances of the crime; the evaluation of the evidence is within the purview of the court.</i> and cross-examination<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote">The determination when, where, and how the crime was committed. Discrepancies in testimony about these questions make prosecution impossible; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.3.1">Mishnah 5:1–2</a>.</i>, so the ox’s death sentence is by a court of 23, investigation and cross-examination<sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Mekhilta dR. Simeon ben Ioḥai</i> 21:29.</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One judges neither a tribe<sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote">According to the Halakhah, either the head of the tribe or a case in which one of the parties is a tribe. The only court of 71 members was the Supreme Court, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.4.1">Mishnah 6</a>.</i>, nor a false prophet<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:20" href="/Deuteronomy.18.20"><i>Deut.</i> 18:20</a>.</i>, nor the High Priest<sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">Accused of a crime.</i>, except by the court of 71 [judges]. One may start a war of choice<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">Any war except a defensive war started by an outside attacker.</i> only by the court of 71 [judges]<sup class="footnote-marker">334</sup><i class="footnote">He is known for the correctness of his historical traditions. For the political functions of a Synhedrion, an even number of members is acceptable. The judicial functions were exercised by committees of 23 each.</i>. One may add to the City<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote">The part of Jerusalem where sacrifices may legally be eaten. Cf. Mishnah <i>Ševuot</i>2:2.</i> or to the Temple courtyards only by the court of 71 [judges]. One appoints high courts for the tribes<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote">Required by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 16:19" href="/Deuteronomy.16.19"><i>Deut.</i> 16:19</a>.</i> only by the court of 71 [judges]. One declares a town as deviant<sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote">A town collectively practicing idolatry, which must be destroyed, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:13-19" href="/Deuteronomy.13.13-19"><i>Deut.</i>13:13–19</a>.</i> only by the court of 71 [judges]; one does not declare a border town as deviant, nor three together, but one may declare one or two.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “One judges neither a tribe,” etc. Come and look: One does not try two people together<sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 6:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.6.6.1">Mishnah 6:8</a>.</i>, so much less an entire tribe? Rebbi Mattaniah said, the Mishnah speaks of the head of the tribe<sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote">A criminal trial. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 15b" href="/Sanhedrin.15b">Babli, 15b</a>, this is reported in the name of a Rav Mattanah.</i>. Rebbi Eliezer<sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote">Read: R. Eleazar.</i> said, the Mishnah speaks about a forested area between two tribes<sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote">A border dispute.</i>.
Rebbi Zeˋira said, it says here “criminal” and it says there “criminal”, <i>the prophet said it criminally</i><sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:22" href="/Deuteronomy.18.22"><i>Deut.</i> 18:22</a>, the law of the false prophet. “Here” refers to the judge who refuses to obey the rulings of the Supreme Court, who acts criminally in his disobedience and is tried before the Supreme Court, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:8-12" href="/Deuteronomy.17.8-12"><i>Deut.</i> 17:8–12</a>.</i>. Since about “criminal” used there, the verse speaks about a false prophet, also about “criminal” used here, the verse speaks about a false prophet<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">The verse does not speak about a false prophet but about a lower court judge who refuses to accept the authority of the Supreme Court. What is meant is that the procedural details given for the treatment of the rebellious judge also apply to the treatment of the false prophet. The argument is known as הֶקֵּשׁ “trap”. If the same word is used in two contexts, details found in one context and left indeterminate in the other can be transferred from one to the other. As a hermeneutic principle, <i>heqqeš</i> should be used only if the word in question is not loaded with additional meaning. But in <i>Sifry Deut.</i> 178, the expression “criminal” is interpreted to mean that the false prophet may be prosecuted only if criminal intent can be shown, not if he acted in error.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 16a" href="/Sanhedrin.16a">Babli, 16a</a>, the argument is in the name of R. Yose ben Hanina.</i>. Rebbi Ḥizqiah said, it says here “spoke” and it says there, <i>that the prophet would speak in the Eternal’s name.</i> Since about “spoke” used there, the verse speaks about a false prophet, also about “spoke” used here, the verse speaks about a false prophet.<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that the <i>heqqeš</i> should not be about the verb דִּבֵּר but the noun דָּבָר “pronouncement”, referring to the judgment of the Supreme Court in case of the rebellious judge, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:10" href="/Deuteronomy.17.10"><i>Deut.</i> 17:10</a>, and the false prophet who pronounces in the Eternal’s name, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:20" href="/Deuteronomy.18.20"><i>Deut.</i> 18:20</a>.</i>
“One may start a war of choice only by the court of 71 [judges]<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote">This probably should be deleted.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">288</sup><i class="footnote">The following four paragraphs do not refer to the quote of the Mishnah but are a commentary to Mishnah <i>Ševuot</i> 2:2: “One only adds to the city and the Temple courtyards by king and prophet, Urim and Tummim, the Synhedrion of 71 members, two thanksgiving sacrifices, and song.” Only the walled part of the city of Jerusalem counts as “before the Eternal”, where family sacrifices may be consumed (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 12:18" href="/Deuteronomy.12.18"><i>Deut.</i>12:18</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 14:23" href="/Deuteronomy.14.23">14:23</a>); the suburbs are “countryside” which does not count for pilgrimage and sacrifice. Since there were no Urim and Tummim in the Second Temple, Pharisees did not consume sacrifices in the parts of Jerusalem which were added in Hasmonean and later times (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:3:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.3.6">Note 306</a>).<br>In <i>Ševuot,</i> only beginning and end of the discussion here are quoted as a reference.</i> Rebbi Jehudah says, as at the start: <sup class="footnote-marker">289</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 24:19" href="/II_Samuel.24.19"><i>2S.</i> 24:19</a>, speaking of David going to buy the Temple area.</i><i>David ascended following Gad’s word,</i> that is king and prophet. <sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 3:1" href="/II_Chronicles.3.1"><i>2Chr.</i> 3:1</a>. The verse is misquoted in several places.</i><i>Solomon started to build the Temple of the Eternal, Israel’s God, on Mount Moriah where He had appeared to him,</i> there are Urim and Tummim. <sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 3:1" href="/II_Chronicles.3.1"><i>2Chr.</i> 3:1</a>. The verse is misquoted in several places.</i><i>To his father David,</i> this is the Synhedrion, <sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 32:7" href="/Deuteronomy.32.7"><i>Deut.</i> 32:7</a>. The persons one asks to get definitive answers to all questions of religion are the members of the High Court of 71 members.</i><i>ask your father and he will tell you, your Elders and they will speak to you.</i> Song, <i>after them went Hoshaia and half the officers of Judea</i><sup class="footnote-marker">292</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 12:32" href="/Nehemiah.12.32"><i>Neh.</i> 12:32</a>. This refers to the members of the Synhedrion walking behind the thanksgiving sacrifices (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 15b" href="/Shevuot.15b"><i>Ševuot</i> 15b</a>); the musical part of the ceremony is described in verses 41,42.</i>. Thanksgiving sacrifices, <i>I put up two large thanksgiving sacrifices being in procession going to their right on the wall going to the dung gate</i><sup class="footnote-marker">293</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 12:31" href="/Nehemiah.12.31"><i>Neh.</i> 12:31</a>.</i>. Rebbi Samuel bar Yudan said, what is written, walking? No, being in procession, only being taken by others<sup class="footnote-marker">294</sup><i class="footnote">In his opinion, the sacrifices were not walked on the wall but were carried. In the opinion of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 15a" href="/Shevuot.15a">Babli, <i>Ševuot</i> 15a</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 3:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.3.2">Tosephta <i>Sanhedrin</i> 3:4</a>, not the animals were carried but the leavened bread required for a thanksgiving sacrifice (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 7:13" href="/Leviticus.7.13"><i>Lev.</i> 7:13</a>). It is possible that this is meant here.</i>.
Rav Huna bar Ḥiyya<sup class="footnote-marker">295</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 16b" href="/Sanhedrin.16b">Babli, <i>Sanhedrin</i> 16b</a>, he is referred to as Rav Shimi bar Hiyya (in one ms. Shimi bar Ashi; this can be disregarded, replacing a <i>hapax</i> by a frequently quoted name).</i> in the name of Rav quotes it from the words of the Torah. <i>As all that I am showing you, the shape of the building and the shape … of all its vessels, so you shall execute</i><sup class="footnote-marker">296</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 25:9" href="/Exodus.25.9"><i>Ex.</i> 25:9</a>. The final clause in the sentence seems to be redundant; it is explained as referring to future buildings.</i>. So you shall execute in all generations. Moses is king and prophet. Aaron represents Urim and Tummim. <i>Assemble for me seventy men from the Elders of Israel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">297</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 11:16" href="/Numbers.11.16"><i>Num.</i> 11:16</a>.</i>, that is the Synhedrion; <i>ask your father and he will tell you,</i> etc. Song, <i>after them went Hoshaia and half the officers of Judea.</i> Thanksgiving sacrifices, <i>I put up two large thanksgiving sacrifices being in procession going to their right on the wall going to the dung gate.</i> Rebbi Samuel bar Yudan said, what is written, walking? No, being in procession, only being taken by others.
<sup class="footnote-marker">298</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 15b" href="/Shevuot.15b"><i>Ševuot</i> 15b</a>, the entire paragraph.</i> How did the processions go? The elder Rebbi Ḥiyya and Rebbi Simeon ben Rebbi. One said, one opposite the other; the other said, one after the other; both are explaining the same verse: <i>The second thanksgiving sacrifice went</i> לְמוּל <i>and I after it</i><sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 12:38" href="/Nehemiah.12.38"><i>Neh.</i> 12:38</a>, in MT למואל. According to Gesenius, one has to read מוּאל as contraction of מֵאֲוַל “not first, not with it”. This justifies both meanings quoted here, “opposite” and “after”.</i>. He who said, one opposite the other, <i>and he dwells opposite me</i><sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 22:5" href="/Numbers.22.5"><i>Num.</i> 22:5</a>.</i>. But he who said, one after the other, <i>he should break off its head behind its neck</i><sup class="footnote-marker">301</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:8" href="/Leviticus.5.8"><i>Lev</i>. 5:8</a>.</i>. For him who said, one opposite the other, it turns out that every place was purified by one thanksgiving sacrifice<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">In principle, one sacrifice would suffice if the procession went around the entire wall.</i>; for him who said, one after the other, it turns out that every place was purified by two thanksgiving sacrifices<sup class="footnote-marker">303</sup><i class="footnote">Since we do not expect two sacrifices for the same purpose, one has to find differences of purpose for the two.</i>. For him who said, one after the other, this is correct following what he had stated: “the inner one is being eaten, the outer one is being burned.<sup class="footnote-marker">304</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 3:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.3.2">Tosephta 3:4</a>, <i>Megillat Ta</i>ˋ<i>anit</i> 6. The Babli, <i>loc. cit.</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup> suggests that the first makes sacrifices possible; therefore, it has to be burned outside the Temple. The second one then is a legitimate thanksgiving sacrifice, most of which has to be eaten by the priests as public well-being sacrifice (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Zevachim 5:5" href="/Mishnah_Zevachim.5.5">Mishnah <i>Zevahim</i> 5:5</a>).</i>” For him who said, one opposite the other, what is the inner one? The one closer to the Temple. Rebbi Yasa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: It was eaten on the instruction of a prophet<sup class="footnote-marker">305</sup><i class="footnote">Who defined the meaning of “inner” and “outer”?</i>. Rebbi Zeˋira said, they state there: Since a prophet is there, for what do I need Urim and Tummim<sup class="footnote-marker">306</sup><i class="footnote">The nature of the Urim and Tummim oracle already was no longer known when the Second Temple was built; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 7:65" href="/Nehemiah.7.65">Nehemiah (7:65</a>) uses the expression “the coming of a Cohen with Urim and Tummim” assynonym with “the coming of the Messiah.” The requirement of Urim and Tummim disqualifies all parts of Jerusalem not forming part of Solomon’s city.</i>? It was found stated: Rebbi Jehudah says, Urim and Tummim are needed<sup class="footnote-marker">307</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 16a" href="/Shevuot.16a">Babli, <i>Ševuot</i> 16a</a>, it is a dispute among Babylonian Amoraïm whether Nehemiah’s ceremony, without king and oracle, was a valid dedication of the rebuilt city of Jerusalem or whether it was a token ceremony to re-establish the intrinsic sanctity of Jerusalem created by Solomon’s Temple. The quote here, from an otherwise unknown <i>baraita,</i> qualifies the second opinion as minority opinion of a Tanna.</i>.
Rebbi Abbahu said, Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqush disagreeed. One said, one builds and afterwards one dedicates<sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">One builds as if the buildings were profane. Only when the Temple enclosure is complete does one dedicate the Temple area, and when the walls of Jerusalem are rebuilt does one dedicate the city. During the building period one is not restricted by all the rules applying to the Temple area. This is possible since the dedication by Solomon was annulled by the destruction of the Temple. One has to assume that it is possible to dedicate the area of the altar and its enclosure without dedicating the Temple, as done in the time of the first return from Babylonia under Cyrus, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezra 3:3" href="/Ezra.3.3"><i>Ezra</i> 3:3</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezra 3:6" href="/Ezra.3.6">6</a>.</i>. The other one said, one dedicates and afterwards one builds<sup class="footnote-marker">309</sup><i class="footnote">He holds that the dedication by Solomon is permanent. Therefore, anybuilding must be done under restrictive rules (but it can be built in stages, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Eduyot 8:6" href="/Mishnah_Eduyot.8.6">Mishnah <i>Idiut</i> 8:6</a>). If the outline of the Temple enclosure or the original city walls was still visible in Zerubabel’s time, no rebuilding was necessary in order to restore the service of the altar.</i>. For him who says, one builds and afterwards one dedicates, one does not say that the partitions are as if built up<sup class="footnote-marker">310</sup><i class="footnote">They actually have to be restored before Temple service can be resumed whole or in part.</i>. If one desires to add to the Temple Hall, by which means does one add<sup class="footnote-marker">311</sup><i class="footnote">In imitation of the rules given for dedication of the city of Jerusalem under Nehemiah, any dedication must involve a sacrifice. The Babli, <i>loc. cit.</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup>, insists that the sacrifice be used in the place to be dedicated. This leads to a catch-22 situation since a sacrifice can be dedicated only after the dedication of the holy place. There is no reason to assume that the Yerushalmi accepts this reasoning.</i>? By the two loaves<sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote">The two loaves of leavened bread dedicated on Pentecost to permit use of new wheat, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 23:17" href="/Leviticus.23.17"><i>Lev.</i> 23:17</a>. This is in imitation of the leavened bread used for the dedication of the city, cf. <sup class="footnote-marker">295</sup>. A parallel discussion is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 15" href="/Shevuot.15">Babli, <i>Ševuot</i> 15a/b</a>.</i>. Does one dedicate on a holiday<sup class="footnote-marker">313</sup><i class="footnote">Since the dedication has far-reaching legal consequences, it has the status of an acquisition, which is not acceptable on Sabbath or holiday, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 58:13" href="/Isaiah.58.13"><i>Is.</i> 58:13</a>. In addition, the Babli points out that the dedication of the leavened breads is the slaughter of the accompanying well-being sacrifice; then the dedication would not be by bread.</i>? Then by the Shew Bread. Does one dedicate on the Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">314</sup><i class="footnote">The Shew Bread is removed from the sanctuary on the Sabbath, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 24:8" href="/Leviticus.24.8"><i>Lev.</i> 24:8</a>. It becomes available for secondary use on the Sabbath, when it cannot be so used.</i>? Then in the night<sup class="footnote-marker">315</sup><i class="footnote">The following evening, after the end of the Sabbath.</i>. Does one dedicate in the night<sup class="footnote-marker">316</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 30:2" href="/Exodus.30.2"><i>Ex.</i> 30:2</a> prescribes that the Tabernacle be erected during daytime. This rule then is extended to include all building activity of the Temple.</i>? Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, with a baked flour offering<sup class="footnote-marker">317</sup><i class="footnote">The daily flour offering of the High Priest, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 6:12-16" href="/Leviticus.6.12-16"><i>Lev.</i> 6:12–16</a>.</i>. One understands that on their return from the diaspora they sacrificed and then dedicated. When they entered the Land,<sup class="footnote-marker">318</sup><i class="footnote">When they entered the Land, they had the Tabernacle which was dedicated in the desert. What one asks here is, how was Solomon’s Temple dedicated?</i> with what did they dedicate? Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, with two thanksgiving sacrifices coming from Nob<sup class="footnote-marker">319</sup><i class="footnote">The priests’ settlement at Nob already was destroyed at the time when the priests from Nob resided at Anatot. The active place of worship was Gibeon, but “Nob and Gibeon” is used as a legal term to indicate the status of holy places after the destruction of Shiloh, before the building of the Temple; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Zevachim 14:7" href="/Mishnah_Zevachim.14.7">Mishnah <i>Zevahim</i> 14:7</a>.</i> and Gibeon.
<sup class="footnote-marker">320</sup><i class="footnote">This <i>baraita</i> exists in another three versions: <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 3:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.3.2">Tosephta 3:4</a> (T), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 15b" href="/Shevuot.15b">Babli <i>Ševuot</i> 15b (B</a>), <i>Megillat Taˋanit</i> 6 (M). A detailed discussion of all four texts, to be used with due caution, is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:1:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.1.5">Note 22</a> to volume 3 of H. Graetz’s <i>Geschichte der Juden</i>.</i>“Abba Shaul says, two subdivisions<sup class="footnote-marker">321</sup><i class="footnote">ביצין corresponds to the readings of B,T, בצעין, ביצעין, ביצועין by degeneration of the guttural. One has to accept Graetz’s derivation from בצע “to split” against Rashi’s <i>marais</i> “marsh.” M has “places on the Mount of Olives”, an emendation by a person who did not understand the text.</i> were there, the lower and the upper, whose sanctification was not complete. The lower one was dedicated with a full ceremony, but the upper one only when they came from the diaspora, without a king and without Urim and Tummim. Therefore, in the lower one the vulgar<sup class="footnote-marker">322</sup><i class="footnote">For the notions of “vulgar” and “Fellow”, cf. Introduction to Tractate <i>Demay,</i> p. 349.</i> eat family sacrifices and Second Tithe; Fellows eat there family sacrifices but not Second Tithe<sup class="footnote-marker">323</sup><i class="footnote">Since family sacrifices have more holiness than Second Tithe, one has to accept the reading of M: “family sacrifices and certainly Second Tithe.”</i>. In the upper one, the vulgar eat family sacrifices but not Second Tithe<sup class="footnote-marker">324</sup><i class="footnote">Because these were living quarters in the expanding city.</i>; Fellows eat there family sacrifices and Second Tithe<sup class="footnote-marker">325</sup><i class="footnote">Read with B,T,M: “neither family sacrifices nor Second Tithe.”</i>. Why did they not sanctify it? Because it was the vulnerable spot of Jerusalem; it could be conquered from there<sup class="footnote-marker">326</sup><i class="footnote">This defines the "upper subdivision" as the suburb between the second, Herodian wall and the incomplete third wall of Agrippas I. The lower subdivision then is the part of the old city between the Hasmonean and Herodian walls. Since the third wall could not be completed, the dedicated part of the city could not be expanded there. The subdivision is called upper because it slopes upwards from the Damascus gate to the North. The lower subdivision could have been dedicated by a ceremony imitating Nehemiah's .</i>.”
“One only appoints high courts for the tribes.” The verse says<sup class="footnote-marker">327</sup><i class="footnote">Deut. 16: 18. For the argument behind the quote, cf. Makkot 1:17 (Note 74), Babli 16b.</i>, <i>for your tribes, they shall judge</i>.
“One only declares a town to be deviant.” Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rebbi Hoshaia: <sup class="footnote-marker">328</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 16b" href="/Sanhedrin.16b">Babli, 16b</a>, the first opinion is attributed to Rav, the converse of the second to R. Simeon ben Laqish, the third opinion to R. Johanan.</i> Three Amoraïm, one says, one makes<sup class="footnote-marker">329</sup><i class="footnote">No court is empowered to declare more than one town as deviant at the same time.</i> one but not two. The other said, clusters one makes<sup class="footnote-marker">330</sup><i class="footnote">Two neighboring towns can be considered as one. There is no need to emend the Yerushalmi to follow the Babli.</i>, dispersed ones one does not make. The other said, dispersed<sup class="footnote-marker">331</sup><i class="footnote">This should read, or be interpreted as, “border town” as in the Mishnah.</i> one does not make at all, lest Gentiles spread and come to the Land of Israel; some want to say that enemies should not spread and lay waste.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The High Synhedrion<sup class="footnote-marker">332</sup><i class="footnote">As usual in rabbinic sources, the political institution of the Synhedrion is identified with the juridical of the High Court, projecting Jabneh arrangements into Temple times.</i> had 71 members and a lower one 23 members. From where that the High Court has 71 members? For it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">333</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 11:16" href="/Numbers.11.16"><i>Num.</i> 11:16</a>.</i>: <i>Assemble for me 70 men of the Elders of Israel,</i> and Moses was presiding, that makes 71. Rebbi Jehudah says, 70<sup class="footnote-marker">334</sup><i class="footnote">He is known for the correctness of his historical traditions. For the political functions of a Synhedrion, an even number of members is acceptable. The judicial functions were exercised by committees of 23 each.</i>. From where that a lower court has 23 members? For it is said, <i>the congregation shall judge, the congregation shall save</i><sup class="footnote-marker">335</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:24" href="/Numbers.35.24"><i>Num.</i> 35:24</a>,25 speaking of the trial of the homicide; cf. <i>Sifry Num.</i> #160.</i>. One congregation judges, one congregation saves, this makes twenty. And from where that a congregation consists of ten persons? As it is said, <i>how long this evil congregation</i><sup class="footnote-marker">336</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 14:27" href="/Numbers.14.27"><i>Num.</i> 14:27</a>, interpreted as speaking of the ten bad spies.</i>, without Joshua and Caleb.<br>From where that one adds another three<sup class="footnote-marker">338</sup><i class="footnote">Since Mishnah 6 established that a criminal court must have 20 judges/jurors.</i>? From the interpretation of what is said<sup class="footnote-marker">339</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:2" href="/Exodus.23.2"><i>Ex.</i> 23:2</a>: <i>Do not follow the majority to do evil; do not testify in a quarrel, to bend, to twist after the majority.</i> This is read to mean that for acquittal one vote is enough but that for conviction one needs a qualified majority even without the one judge who is voting. Cf. <i>Mekhilta dR. Ismael Mišpaṭim</i>20, <i>dR. Simeon ben Ioḥai</i> 23:2 (in the name of Rebbi.)</i>, <i>do not follow the majority to be unfavorable,</i> I understand that He said, follow them to be favorable. Then why was it said, <i>to bend after the majority</i>? Your bending to be favorable is not equal to your bending to be unfavorable. Your bending to be favorable shall be by one [vote] (witness), your bending to be unfavorable shall be by two. Since no court may be even-numbered, one adds another one to obtain 23. How many people shall live in a town that it may have a criminal court? 120. Rebbi Nehemiah said 230, that they might be commanders over tens<sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote">Since the verse requires that judges be outstanding personalities, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 18:21" href="/Exodus.18.21"><i>Ex.</i> 18:21</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 1:15" href="/Deuteronomy.1.15"><i>Deut.</i>1:15</a>, each judge must be qualified at least to be the leader of ten men.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The High Synhedrion,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote">This is not a repetition of the Mishnah. The paragraph really does not refer to the qualifications of a court but to the requirement of having 10 adult males in attendance for religious observations of a “congregation.” The paragraph is an almost complete quote from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 7:3:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.7.3.6"><i>Berakhot</i> 7:3, Notes 106–108</a>, is repeated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 4:4:2-8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.4.4.2-8"><i>Megillah</i> 4:4</a> (75b l. 7), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 23b" href="/Sanhedrin.23b">Babli 23b</a>, and is alluded to in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:8:2-9:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.8.2-9.5"><i>Sanhedrin</i>4:10</a>.</i> Rebbi Abba, Rebbi Yasa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: It says here “congregation”, and it says there “congregation”, <i>how long the evil congregation.</i> Since “congregation” there means ten, so here also ten. Rebbi Simon said, it is said here “amid”, and it is said there “amid”. Since “amid” there means ten, so here also ten. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun told him, if you want to infer from “amid”, there are too many. But it is said here “the sons of Israel”, and it is said there, “the sons of Israel”, <i>the sons of Israel came to buy grain.</i> Since “the sons of Israel” there were ten, so here also ten.
“From where that one adds another three, etc. It was stated: <sup class="footnote-marker">341</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 7:1" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.7.1">Tosephta 7:1</a>, <i>Hagigah</i> 2:9.</i> Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel said, in earlier times the <i>ketubah</i> of qualified women<sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote">Whose offspring were qualified to marry into the priesthood. In Temple times, this could serve as proof of qualification; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:4:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.4.2-3"><i>Qiddušin</i> 4:4</a>.</i> was signed only by priests, Levites, or Israel whose daughters were qualified to marry into the priesthood. <sup class="footnote-marker">343</sup><i class="footnote">Most of the following text also is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 88b" href="/Sanhedrin.88b">Babli, 88b</a>. R. Yose, the collector of most of the material of <i>Seder ˋOlam,</i> represents a very idealized past.</i> Rebbi Yose said, in earlier times there was no disagreement in Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">344</sup><i class="footnote">A patently incorrect statement. The ancient rabbinic disagreement about the treatment of private sacrifices on holidays is the topic of <i>Ḥagigah</i> 2; the statement declares all non-rabbinic sects as non-Jewish.</i> but the Synhedrion of 71 members were sitting in the free-stone hall<sup class="footnote-marker">345</sup><i class="footnote">Adjacent to the Temple, built into the Herodian Temple wall, constructed from large rectangular stones without mortar.</i>; two courts of three<sup class="footnote-marker">346</sup><i class="footnote">Read: 23. However, A. Weiss (לשאלת טיב בית דין של שבעים ואחד, ספר היובל לכ׳ לוי גינצבורג, ע׳ קץ-רטז New York 1946) insists that the only courts of 23 in Jerusalem were committees of the court of 71.</i> members each were sitting, one in the glacis<sup class="footnote-marker">347</sup><i class="footnote">The space between the Temple wall and a smaller wall surrounding the Temple areas.</i> and one on the Temple Mount<sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">Outside any enclosure.</i>; and a court of 23 was sitting in every town of the Land of Israel. If somebody had a question of religious practice, he went and asked it from the court in his town. If they had heard [the answer], they told him; otherwise he and their distinguished member went and asked a court in their neighborhood. If these had heard [the answer], they told him; otherwise he and their distinguished member went and asked from the court on the Temple Mount. If these had heard [the answer], they told him; otherwise he and their distinguished member went and asked from the court on the glacis. If these had heard [the answer], they told him; otherwise they together entered the High Court in the free-stone hall since from there instruction came accepted in all of Israel, as it is said: <i>From this place which the Eternal will choose</i><sup class="footnote-marker">349</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:10" href="/Deuteronomy.17.10"><i>Deut.</i> 17:10</a>. Disobedience of a High Court ruling is only a capital crime if the ruling was delivered from “the place”, from a court sitting in a room partially on Temple grounds. When the High Court lost its standing as court of criminal appeals (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:1:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.1.9">Note 31</a>) and left the free-stone hall, it also lost its ability to prescribe practice <i>ex cathedra</i>.</i>. Even though the Synhedrion in the free-stone hall had 71 members, those present never numbered less than 23. If one of them had to leave, he was looking around; if 23 others were present, he would leave, otherwise he would not leave<sup class="footnote-marker">350</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 45a" href="/Sanhedrin.45a">Babli <i>Soţah</i> 45a</a>.</i>. They were in session from the daily morning sacrifice to the daily evening sacrifice. On Sabbaths and holidays, they were sitting in the study hall on the Temple Mount<sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">Outside any enclosure.</i>. If a question of practice came up, if they had heard the answer, they told them; otherwise they prepared to vote. If a majority was for acquitting, they acquitted. If a majority<sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">In his theory, on appeal only a simple majority is needed.</i> was for a guilty verdict, they rendered a verdict of guilty. If a majority was for declaring pure, they declared pure. If a majority was for declaring impure, they declared impure. From the time that there were many students of Shammai and Hillel who did not study enough under their teachers, many disagreements arose and two doctrines developed<sup class="footnote-marker">352</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 47b" href="/Sanhedrin.47b">Babli <i>Soţah</i> 47b</a>.</i>. From there<sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote">The free-stone hall.</i>, they were sending to all towns in the Land of Israel; any time they found a person who was wise, meek, even-tempered, benevolent, pleasing, humble, good-hearted, with good intentions, and well endowed, they were placing him on the court of the Temple Mount<sup class="footnote-marker">354</sup><i class="footnote">In all three Babylonian texts, the person is appointed judge in his town and the appeals courts replenished from sitting judges.</i>, from there to the court on the glacis, and from there to the High Court in the free-stone hall.
The Synhedrion was like a threshing floor in the shape of a semi-circle; the president sat in the middle so they might see him and hear his voice. Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Ṣadoq said, when Rabban Gamliel was sitting at Jabneh, my father and his brother were sitting to his right and the Elders to his left, to honor the old man<sup class="footnote-marker">355</sup><i class="footnote">The “old man” was R. Sadoq, a member already of Rabban Johanan ben Zakkai’s school in pre-war Jerusalem.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">356</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:2:17" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.2.17">Halakhah 10:2 Note 214</a>. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 18a" href="/Sanhedrin.18a">Babli 18a</a>, <i>Tanhuma Mišpaṭim</i> 6 (a <i>Šeïlta</i>).</i> how many were the judges of Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">357</sup><i class="footnote">Appointed by Moses. The numbers are inexact since in no census were there exactly 600’000 men.</i>? 78’600. Appointed over a thousand, 600. Appointed over a hundred, 6’000. Appointed over fifty, 12’000. Appointed over ten, 60’000. It turns out that the judges of Israel were 78’600.
<sup class="footnote-marker">358</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is thoroughly corrupt. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 17b" href="/Sanhedrin.17b">Babli, 17b</a>, a very forced count connects the 120 men required by the rabbis to a court of 23 acting as a law school to 3•23 = 69 students. Cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 3:5" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.3.5">Tosephta 3:9</a>. If one adds to the 35 people enumerated for R. Nehemiah the 69 law students mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.8.1">Mishnah 4:10</a>, one arrives at a minimum number attributed in the Tosephta to R. Jehudah; but no emendation can be trusted.</i> What is the reason of Rebbi Nehemiah? That there should be a court of 23, and the parties, and the witnesses, and the witnesses for perjury, and the witnesses for perjury of the witnesses for perjury, and the rabbi, and the clerks of court, and the beadle. What is the reason of the rabbis? That there might be twelve courts for the twelve tribes.
“And Moses was presiding.” <sup class="footnote-marker">359</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 21" href="/Numbers.21"><i>Tanhuma Bemidbar</i> 21</a>, <i>Tanhuma Buber Bemidbar</i> 25, <i>Num. rabba</i> 4(9), shortened <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 17a" href="/Sanhedrin.17a">Babli 17a</a>.</i> Moses found a way to settle things. When the Holy One, praise to Him, told him, <i>count all male firstborns among the Children of Israel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">360</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 3:40" href="/Numbers.3.40"><i>Num.</i> 3:40</a>. The reference should have been to vv. 46,47 where Moses was commanded to collect 5 <i>šeqel per person</i> from 273 of the 22’273 firstborn of the 11 tribes. The other 22’000 were redeemed by the service of 22’000 Levites. Since he was instructed to take the 5 <i>šeqel</i> from 273 persons, he could not simply collect 1’365 šeqel from 22’273 persons.</i>, he said, who will consent voluntarily to give five sheqel per head? What did he do? He took 22’000 tickets<sup class="footnote-marker">361</sup><i class="footnote">Greek πιττάκιον “ticket, label, etc.”</i> and wrote on them “Levite” and 273 on which he wrote “five sheqel” and put all of them in an urn<sup class="footnote-marker">362</sup><i class="footnote">Greek κάλπη, “urn”.</i>. He told them, come and take your ticket. To any one who drew a ticket saying “Levite” he said, a Levite already redeemed you. To anybody who drew a slip saying “five sheqel” he said, what can I do, it is from Heaven; Rebbi Jehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">363</sup><i class="footnote">The Midrash sources make it clear that the preceding was R. Jehudah’s opinion; the following is R. Nehemiah’s. The Babli only mentions R. Jehudah’s opinion.</i>. But Rebbi Nehemiah the Tanna objected to the colleagues: If you had given me the possibility of a Levite, it would have come up for me.<sup class="footnote-marker">364</sup><i class="footnote">Since there were only 22’273 tickets, it was a mathematical necessity that 273 people would have to pay. The distribution of these was a pure matter of probabilities; there is no reason to invoke Heaven in the matter.</i> But the following is what he did. He took 22’000 tickets<sup class="footnote-marker">365</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel sources, and the paragraph after the next, make it clear that one has to read: 22’273 tickets reading “Levite”.</i> and wrote on them “Levite” and two hundred seventy three on which he wrote “five sheqel” and put all of them in an urn. He told them, come and take your ticket. To any one who drew a slip saying “Levite” he said, a Levite already redeemed you. The anybody who drew a ticket saying “five sheqel” he said, what can I do, it is from Heaven. The Tanna objected to the colleagues: Think of it, if all came up as “Levite”<sup class="footnote-marker">366</sup><i class="footnote">Assuming that the tickets in the urn are well mixed and all tickets have the same probability to be drawn, the probability that in 22’273 drawings of 22’546 tickets no slip of “5 <i>šeqel</i>” or that all of the 273 extra tickets would be drawn is practically zero. (The first probability starts with a string of 117 zeroes after the decimal point, the second with 639.) If all 273 extra tickets were actually drawn, it was a clear sign from Heaven.</i>? They told him, it was miraculous and they came up alternatingly. Rebbi Samuel said, in the opinion of the second Tanna, it was a miracle. In the opinion of the first Tanna, it was not a miracle<sup class="footnote-marker">367</sup><i class="footnote">While in the first scenario by necessity 273 tickets of “5 <i>šeqel</i>” were drawn, these slips were drawn with approximately constant frequency, about 122.6 per 10’000 draws, against the probabilistic frequency of 121.1 per 10’000. One cannot say that alternatingly “Levite” and “5 <i>šeqel</i>” were drawn since then the drawing would have ended after 546 draws.</i>. They told him, it was a miracle in any case since they came up alternatingly.
<sup class="footnote-marker">368</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Bekhorot 5a" href="/Bekhorot.5a">Babli <i>Bekhorot</i> 5a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bamidbar Rabbah 4:7" href="/Bamidbar_Rabbah.4.7"><i>Num. rabba</i> 4(7</a>).</i> General Antoninus<sup class="footnote-marker">369</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Bekhorot</i> קונטרוקוס, in <i>Num. rabba</i> הונגטיס; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:2:47" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.2.47">Note 267</a>.</i> asked Rabban Joḥanan ben Zakkai: The sum is deficient, the details are excessive. He told him, these 300 were firstborn of the priesthood; no holy one redeems a holy one<sup class="footnote-marker">370</sup><i class="footnote">In the census reported in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 3" href="/Numbers.3"><i>Num.</i> 3</a>, the families of the Levites were reported as Gershon 7’500, Qehat 8’600, Merari 6’200, for a total of 22’300. But in the summation in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 3:39" href="/Numbers.3.39">v. 39</a> only 22’000 are reported and this number reappears as the number of Levites freeing firstborns from payment. Instead of “priesthood” one has to read “Levites”.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">371</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Tanhuma Behaˋalotekha</i> 11, <i>Tanhuma Buber Behaˋalotekha</i> 22, <i>Sifry Num.</i> 95, <i>Num. rabba</i> 15(14), <i>Yalqut Šimˋony</i> 736, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 17a" href="/Sanhedrin.17a">Babli 17a</a>.</i> Similarly. <i>the Eternal said to Moses, assemble for Me seventy men of the Elders of Israel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">334</sup><i class="footnote">He is known for the correctness of his historical traditions.
