For the political functions of a Synhedrion, an even number of members is acceptable. The judicial functions were exercised by committees of 23 each.</i>. Moses said, if I am taking six per tribe, there will be 72, ten of six each and two of five, which tribe will agree to be discriminated against? What did he do? He took 70 tickets and wrote on them “Elder”, two he left blank, and put them in an urn. He told them, come and take your ticket. To any one who drew a slip saying “Elder” he said, from Heaven they appointed you. To anybody who drew a blank slip he said, what can I do, it is from Heaven; Rebbi Jehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">363</sup><i class="footnote">The Midrash sources make it clear that the preceding was R. Jehudah’s opinion; the following is R. Nehemiah’s. The Babli only mentions R. Jehudah’s opinion.</i>. But Rebbi Nehemiah the Tanna objected to the colleagues: If you had given me the possibility of an Elder, it would have come up for me.<sup class="footnote-marker">364</sup><i class="footnote">Since there were only 22’273 tickets, it was a mathematical necessity that 273 people would have to pay. The distribution of these was a pure matter of probabilities; there is no reason to invoke Heaven in the matter.</i> But the following is what he did. He took 72 tickets and wrote on them “Elder” and two blank ones and put all of them in an urn. He told them, come and take your ticket. To any one who drew a slip saying “Elder” he said, from Heaven they appointed you. The anybody who drew a blank slip he said, what can I do, it is from Heaven. The Tanna objected to the colleagues: Think of it, if all came up as “Elder”? They told him, it was miraculous and they came up alternatingly<sup class="footnote-marker">373</sup><i class="footnote">The probability of at least one of the blank tickets remaining in the urn, assuming uniform distribution (thorough mixing) of the tickets, was 0.14316.</i>. Rebbi Samuel said, I objected before Rebbi Abbahu: in the opinion of the second Tanna, it was a miracle. In the opinion of the first Tanna, it was not a miracle. He told him, it was a miracle in any case since they came up alternatingly<sup class="footnote-marker">374</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., about evenly spaced.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">375</sup><i class="footnote">A different version is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bekhorot 5a" href="/Bekhorot.5a">Babli, <i>Bekhorot</i> 5a</a>.</i> General Antigonos<sup class="footnote-marker">376</sup><i class="footnote">In G, אגנטוס, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:2:47" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.2.47">Note 267</a>.</i> asked Rabban Joḥanan ben Zakkai: Your teacher Moses either was a thief or he did not know how to compute, for it is written: <i>a beqaˋ per head</i><sup class="footnote-marker">377</sup><i class="footnote">The discussion is about <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 38:25" href="/Exodus.38.25"><i>Ex.</i> 38:25</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 38:26" href="/Exodus.38.26">26</a> (in the LXX, ed. A. Rahlfs, 39:2,3) where it is stated that the Temple tax of a <i>beqaˋ</i>, half a <i>šeqel,</i> paid by 603’550 men came to 100 <i>kikkar</i> 1775 <i>šeqel.</i> The LXX follows rabbinic tradition in identifying the <i>beqaˋ</i>, the Babylonian <i>zuz,</i> with the drachma, i. e., the <i>šeqel</i> with the <i>dupondius,</i> and the <i>kikkar</i>(Accadic <i>gaggarum</i> “disk”) with the talent of 60 minas or 6’000 drachmas, i. e. 3’000 <i>šeqel</i> (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:3:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.3.4"><i>Qiddušin</i> 1:1, Note 122</a>.) But in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:3:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.3.4"><i>Qiddušin</i> 1:3 Note 339</a> it is declared that any <i>šeqel</i> mentioned in the Torah is a Roman tetradrachma. Then the silver contributed should have been twice the recorded amount, 201 talents 550 <i>šeqel</i>.</i>. If you make the <i>centenarius</i> 100 pounds,<sup class="footnote-marker">378</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>libra</i> weighing 100 <i>drachmae</i> is the natural weight equivalent of the Greek <i>mina</i> in coin. The <i>centenarius,</i>“hundredweight”, 100 pounds, is taken as the equivalent of the talent. But if by <i>šeqel</i> a tetradrachma is meant, a talent should have been 120 <i>mina,</i> not 60 as usual, and not 100 as presumed here. Computed from above, one-sixth is missing in the latter, half in the former case.</i> he stole one sixth. If you make it 60 pounds, he stole half. He answered him, our teacher Moses was a trustworthy treasurer expert in computations. He answered him, is it not written, <i>they contributed bronze twenty talents</i><sup class="footnote-marker">379</sup><i class="footnote">A scribal error; in the verse (and G): 70 talents. The total recorded was 70 talents, 2’400 <i>šeqel</i>.</i>; for us that makes 96 pounds<sup class="footnote-marker">380</sup><i class="footnote">Since 25 <i>tetradrachma</i> make a <i>mina,</i>2’400 <i>drachma</i> are 96 <i>mina.</i> Nevertheless, the verse mentions <i>šeqel,</i> not <i>mina.</i></i> and he mentions them in detail. He answered back, because it does not add up to a <i>centenarius</i>; if you would say that it added up to a <i>centenarius,</i> he would have stolen half. He told him, but it is written <i>1’775,</i> would that not make 71 pounds<sup class="footnote-marker">381</sup><i class="footnote">@ 25 <i>tetradrachma</i> each.</i> and he mentions it in detail. He answered back, if you would say that it added up to a <i>centenarius,</i> he would have stolen half. He told him, but it is written, <i>the sheqel is 20 gera, twenty sheqel, twenty-five sheqel, twenty-five sheqel the maneh</i><sup class="footnote-marker">382</sup><i class="footnote">The Babylonian <i>mina</i>.</i><i>shall be for you</i><sup class="footnote-marker">383</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 45:12" href="/Ezekiel.45.12"><i>Ez.</i> 45:12</a>; the correct text, intended here, is: <i>20 šeqel, 25 šeqel, 15 šeqel make a maneh,</i> for a total of 60. Therefore, it is impossible to identify the Greek <i>mina</i> as 25 <i>šeqel.</i> Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:2:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.2.9"><i>Qiddušin</i> 1:2 Note 204</a>.</i>; the talent of the Holy One, praise to Him, was double. He answered back, he<sup class="footnote-marker">384</sup><i class="footnote">Read with G: “Your teacher Moses.”</i> was a trustworthy treasurer and expert in computations.

Chapter 2



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The High Priest judges and one judges him; he testifies and one testifies against him<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">These statements are only necessary as contrast to the rules for the king, to whom they do not apply (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 2:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.2.3.1">Mishnah 3</a>).</i>. He gives <i>ḥalîṣah</i> and one gives <i>ḥalîṣah</i> to his wife, and one marries his wife in levirate marriage<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">If his brother dies childless, he gives <i>halîsah</i> to his sister-in-law, which will be allowed to marry anybody but a Cohen. If he dies childless, any brother not appointed High Priest in his stead may marry his widow.</i>. But he may not marry in levirate marriage since a widow is forbidden to him.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:14" href="/Leviticus.21.14"><i>Lev.</i> 21:14</a>.</i> If a family member of his dies, he cannot follow the bier but if they<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The people carrying the bier. The High Priest may never be seen together with them.</i> are unseen he can be seen; if they are seen he must be unseen. He leaves with them up to the city gate, the words of Rebbi Meïr; Rebbi Jehudah said, he does not leave the Temple since it is said: <i>The Sanctuary he shall not leave</i><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:12" href="/Leviticus.21.12"><i>Lev</i>. 21:12</a>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The High Priest judges and one judges him,” etc. One understands that he judges. Why does one judge him<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Why can he be compelled to appear in court in person?</i>? Can he not appoint a plenipotentiary<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">In G אנטליר which S. Lieberman (<i>Greek and Hellenism in Jewish Palestine,</i> Jerusalem 1963, pp. 10–11) reads as <i>antellar</i> as a composite of Greek ἐντέλλω “enjoin, command, invest with legal powers” with Latin suffix <i>-arius</i> “belonging to, invested with,” etc.</i>? Think of it, if an oath should be imposed on him, may a plenipotentiary take the oath? His monetary suits are heard by how many? By 23, as we understand from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Tosephta 2:15.</i>: “The king may not sit in the Synhedrion, neither king nor High Priest may participate in intercalations.” Rebbi Ḥanina<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">In G correctly Hananiah, the contemporary of R. Mana II.</i> and Rabbi Mana, one said the king does not sit in the Synhedrion because of suspicion<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">That the judges do not dare to voice an opinion contradicting the king.</i>; he cannot participate in intercalations because of suspicion<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Since the king can be expected to favor adding a 13<sup class="footnote-marker">th</sup> month every year so that all contracts for services which his government has concluded will be extended for another month without him having to pay for it.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The second opinion is missing here. In G it is extended for three lines but no intelligible text can be extracted from the few remaining words. G in all cases says “the king of Israel”.</i> Neither king nor High Priest may participate in intercalations since it is not to the king’s honor to sit with seven, so much less with three. This implies that his monetary suits are heard by 23<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">This is unknown to the Babli.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">There exists a copy of this paragraph in <i>Horaiot</i> 3:2 (<b>ה</b>). It is missing in the Yerushalmi reproduced in the <i>editio princeps</i> of the Babli. A different version is in <i>Midrash Samuel</i> 7(5).</i> Rebbi Eleazar said, if a High Priest sinned, one whips him but does not remove him from his elevated status<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">This is unknown to the Babli.</i>. Rebbi Mana said, it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:12" href="/Leviticus.21.12"><i>Lev</i>. 21:12</a>.</i>: <i>For the crown of his God’s ointment is on him, I am the Eternal</i>; if one could compare it, just as I am in My Sanctity, so Aaron is in his sanctity<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">The two other sources read: I in My Greatness, also Aaron in his greatness. R. Abun said (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:8" href="/Leviticus.21.8"><i>Lev.</i> 21:8</a>), <i>holy he shall be to you,</i> if one could compare it, as I Am in My Holiness, so Aaron is in his holiness.</i>. Rebbi Ḥanina the scribe, Rebbi Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: if a High Priest sinned, one whips him<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">In the two other sources: by a court of three judges. The sequel requires this text.</i>. If you would say by 23, his elevation would be his degradation<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Since so many people would sit in judgment over him.</i>. And Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, if a patriarch sinned, one whips him by a court of three [judges]. Does one return him? Rebbi Haggai said, by Moses, if one would return him, he would kill them. Rebbi Jehudah the Prince<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">R. Jehudah II.</i> heard this and became angry. He sent Goths<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Following the reading of the other two sources. Krauss conjectures that the inserted <b>נ</b> indicates nasal pronunciation, but by the evidence of the other two sources <b>גנתון</b> instead of <b>גותיין</b> seems to be a scribal error. [Instead of Goths they might have been <i>Gaetuli,</i> a people from Northwestern Africa (E. G.).]</i> to catch Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish. They beat him. He fled to Magdala, some say to Kefar Ḥiṭṭim<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Magdala is on Lake Genezareth, Kefar Hittim in the hills overlooking Tiberias.</i>. The next day, Rebbi Joḥanan went to the assembly hall, when Rebbi Jehudah the Prince also went to the assembly hall. He<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">R. Jehudah the Prince.</i> said to him, why is the master not<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Translated following G.</i> telling us words of instruction? He<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">R. Johanan.</i> started clapping with one hand. He<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">R. Jehudah the Prince.</i> asked, does one clap with one? He<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">R. Johanan.</i> answered him, no, but without ben Laqish there is nothing<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Following the text of the other two sources. The text of the Leiden ms. is unintelligible.</i>. He<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">R. Jehudah the Prince.</i> told him, I shall free him. He<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">R. Johanan.</i> said to him, in Magdala. He<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">R. Jehudah the Prince.</i> told him, tomorrow I and you will go out to meet him. Rebbi Joḥanan sent to Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish, prepare<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Translated following G. The text of the other two sources, “get rich”, does not make much sense.</i> for yourself some words of instruction since the Patriarch will go out to meet you. He went out to meet them and said, your example is similar to that of your Creator. For when the Merciful went to liberate Israel [from Egypt]<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Added from the other two sources.</i>, He sent neither messenger nor angel but He went Himself, as is written: <i>I shall pass through the Land of Egypt</i><sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:12" href="/Exodus.12.12"><i>Ex.</i> 12:12</a>.</i>, He and all His Court<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Translated following Eliahu Fulda and H. L. Fleischer in Levy’s Dictionary. A similar explanation of the verse is found in the Passover Haggadah (<i>Mekhilta dR.Ismael,</i> ed. Horovitz-Rabin, p. 23; cf. H. Guggenheimer, <i>The Scholar’s Haggadah</i> pp. 298–299.)<br>Here ends the Geniza fragment. The text in <i>Horaiot</i> has additions both at this point and at the end of the paragraph which, while relevant, in the absence of a confirming Genizah text cannot be added here.</i>. He asked him, why did you say these things<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">About whipping the Patriarch.</i>? He told him, what are you thinking? That for fear of you I would refrain from the teachings of the Merciful? As Rebbi Samuel ben Rav Isaac said, <i>No my sons, because the reputation is not good</i><sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 2:24" href="/I_Samuel.2.24"><i>1S.</i> 2:24</a>. The explanation of the verse is missing; it is given in <i>Horaiot.</i> The verse about the misdeeds of Eli’s sons ends, מַעֲבִיריִם עַם יי [<i>the information</i>]<i>spread about by the Eternal’s people,</i> which he interprets as <i>being removed by the Eternal’s people,</i> implying that the High Priest has to be removed if he sins.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">This and the following paragraphs refer to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Horayot 3:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Horayot.3.3.1">Mishnah <i>Horaiot</i> 3:6</a>; the origin is to be found there in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:5:2-16" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.5.2-16">Halakhah 3:6</a> (<b>ה</b>). The Yerushalmi printed in the Babli <i>editio princeps</i> from a ms. different from the Leiden one, only quotes the first sentence; it eliminated the remark “continue in Sanhedrin.” The paragraph also appears in <i>Moˋed qatan,</i> copied twice in the Leiden ms. The text there is a reformulation, not a copy.<br><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Horayot 3:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Horayot.3.3.1">Mishnah <i>Horaiot</i> 3:6</a> reads: “The High Priest tears his clothes below, the simple priest above. The High Priest officiates when he is a fresh mourner but may not eat; the simple priest neither officiates nor eats.” The High Priest is forbidden to let his hair grow or tear his clothes (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:10" href="/Leviticus.21.10"><i>Lev.</i> 21:10</a>). R. Meïr interprets the verse to mean that in mourning he may not tear his garment in the way other people do [<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Section 2 3" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Section_2.3"><i>Sịfra Emor Parashah</i> 2(3</a>)]. The Mishnah is R. Meïr’s. It is obvious that one speaks here of the High Priest’s personal belonging, not his robes of office, which may not be torn (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 28:32" href="/Exodus.28.32"><i>Ex.</i> 28:32</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 29:23" href="/Exodus.29.23">29:23</a>).</i> Rebbi Eleazar in the name of Cahana: On top, high starting with the seam<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">He insists that a valid tear in mourning must sever the thread of the seam. If the cloth of the garment is folded over and then sewn, the tear must reach the place where the cloth is only a single layer.<br>In Babylonia, the Palestinian קָנֶה שָׂפָה was understood as קַמֵּי שָׂפָה “in front of the seam” (<i>Moˋed qatan</i> 22b), correctly interpreted in the Rashi commentary edited by E. Kupfer (Jerusalem 1961). Cf. <i>Horaiot</i>3:6, Note 201.</i>, below, low starting with the seam. Rebbi Joḥanan said, really low<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Without any minimal depth.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan was going up the mountain<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">From Tiberias below Sea level to Sepphoris on a hilltop.</i> to visit Rebbi Ḥanina; on the road he heard that he had died. He sent, brought his good Sabbath garment, and tore it. Rebbi Joḥanan disagrees with Rebbi Jehudah in two things, but Rebbi Eleazar in the name of Cahana follows Rebbi Jehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">R. Jehudah does not require tearing one’s clothing in mourning except for his parents, but if one tears he requires severing the seam.</i>. If following Rebbi Jehudah, he should not tear at all! This refers only to his father or mother, following Rebbi Meïr, as it was stated: One tears the seam for nobody who died except for father and mother, the words of Rebbi Meïr. Rebbi Jehudah says, any tear which does not completely sever the seam is a frivolous tear. How is that? It is a stringency for the High Priest that he shall sever the seam completely<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">This is the text here, in <i>Horaiot,</i> and in the first version of the Halakhah in <i>Moˋed qaṭan</i> 3:8, but in the second version and in <i>editio princeps</i> one reads: “that he may not sever the seam completely.” This seems to be the correct version. The point is made that <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:10" href="/Leviticus.21.10"><i>Lev.</i> 21:10</a> does not use the frequently used verb קרע “to tear” but the infrequent פרם “to tear in little pieces”. The is interpreted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Section 2 3" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Section_2.3"><i>Sifra Emor Parashah</i> 2(3</a>) to mean that the High Priest is not totally forbidden to rend his garments, only he may not do what everybody does. If he rends it, it may only be at the bottom, where few people will notice, and it may not be deep.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Zevachim 11:2" href="/Tosefta_Zevachim.11.2">Tosephta <i>Zevahim</i> 11:3</a>.</i>“The High Priest sacrifices while in deep<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">“Deep sorrow” is the period between the death of a close relative and his burial. This is a period of biblically mandated mourning in which consumption of sanctified food is forbidden, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 26:14" href="/Deuteronomy.26.14"><i>Deut.</i> 26:14</a>. A simple priest, who is required to defile himself for the burial of a close relative, automatically is barred from the holy precinct until he is purified from the impurity of the dead. The High Priest is prohibited from defiling himself and from leaving the holy precinct (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:12" href="/Leviticus.21.12"><i>Lev.</i> 21:12</a>). The question remains, what is his status on that day?</i> sorrow but does not eat, the words of Rebbi Meïr; Rebbi Jehudah says, the entire day<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Everybody agrees that if a High Priest is engaged in Divine Service when he is informed of the death of a close relative, he finishes his task. R. Simeon requires that upon completion he leave immediately; if he was informed while idle he also must leave immediately. R. Meïr holds that if he was in the precinct, he can start sacrificing even after being informed but then has to leave; if he was outside he cannot enter. R. Jehudah does not require him to leave.</i>. Rebbi Simeon says, he completely finishes the service he is engaged in and then leaves.” Between Rebbi Meïr and Rebbi Simeon there is one [difference], between Rebbi Jehudah and Rebbi Simeon there is one [difference]<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">For R. Jehudah, he does not have to leave after finishing his task. In fact, there are two differences since for R. Jehudah he is permitted to start after being informed of the death, but not for R. Simeon.</i>. Between Rebbi Meïr and Rebbi Jehudah is entering<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Whether he has to leave after finishing. The verse seems to support R. Jehudah, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:12" href="/Leviticus.21.12"><i>Lev.</i> 21:12</a>: <i>The holy precinct he may not leave</i>.</i>. Rebbi Jacob ben Dositheos: interruption is between them. Rebbi Meïr says, if he was inside, he leaves; if he was outside, he did [not]<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Reading from <i>Horaiot</i>.</i> enter. Rebbi Jehudah says, if he was inside, he enters<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">If he was in the Temple precinct, he may start serving; if he was outside, he may not enter, since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:12" href="/Leviticus.21.12"><i>Lev.</i> 21:12</a> does not apply to his situation.</i>; if he was outside, he did not enter. Rebbi Simeon says, he completely finishes the service he is engaged in and then leaves. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun in the name of Rav Huna: a <i>baraita</i> is from Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Horaiot</i>: R. Simeon. The name tradition here is quite corrupt. R. Yose bar Abun of the last generation of Galilean Amoraïm was a student of R. Jacob bar Dositheos. Also he cannot speak in the name of the second generation Babylonian Rav Huna; one has to read <i>Rebbi</i> Huna against both mss. sources. R. Simeon ben Laqish cannot formulate a <i>baraita</i>: neither <i>baraita</i> nor Mishnah address R. Simeon’s opinion.</i>: <sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">A similar text is in <i>Sifra Emor Parashah</i> 2(8).</i><i>The Sanctuary he shall not leave,</i> he may not leave with them, but he may leave after them. If they<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The people carrying the bier. The High Priest may never be seen together with them.</i> are unseen he can be seen; he leaves with them up to the city gate, the words of Rebbi Meïr; Rebbi Jehudah said, he does not leave the Temple since it is said: <i>The Sanctuary he shall not leave</i><sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:12" href="/Leviticus.21.12"><i>Lev</i>. 21:12</a>.</i>. If he left, he may not return.”
<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">In addition to the parallel in <i>Horaiot,</i> there exists one in <i>Pesahim</i> 8:7 36a l. 76 ff. (פ).</i> Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: “Deep sorrow”<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">In its legal implications, that the person not only be forbidden to eat sanctified food but also cannot be counted in a quorum for religious services; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:1:10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.1.10"><i>Berakhot</i>3:1, Note 42</a>.</i> is only for the dead, for it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 3:26" href="/Isaiah.3.26"><i>Is.</i> 3:26</a>. The gates of Jerusalem are in sorrow because all its men are dead.</i>: <i>Its gates are in deep sorrow and mourning.</i> Ḥiyya bar Ada objected: Is it not written<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 19:8" href="/Isaiah.19.8"><i>Is.</i> 19:8</a>. The fishermen are in <i>deep sorrow</i> (and they <i>mourn</i> as quoted in the two parallel texts) because the Nile dried up. This proves that both terms used for the religious obligations of a person whose close relative died are used in the Bible also to describe other situations.</i>: <i>the fishermen are in deep sorrow</i>? Rebbi Ḥanina said, so is the <i>baraita</i>: there is no deep sorrow in impurity except for the dead. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Zevachim 100b" href="/Zevachim.100b"><i>Babli Zevaḥim</i> 100b</a>; a suspect text in <i>Semahot</i> 4:4.</i>: “What is deep sorrow? From the moment of death until the moment of burial, the word of Rebbi. But the Sages say, the entire day.” It turns out that one describes leniencies and stringencies following Rebbi, leniencies and stringencies following the rabbis. What is the difference between them? If he died and was buried within the hour. Following the rabbis, he is forbidden the entire day; following Rebbi he is forbidden only that hour. If he died and was buried after three days. Following the rabbis, he is forbidden the entire day; following Rebbi he is forbidden up to three days. There came Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, and Rav Ḥisda, both of whom said that Rebbi agrees with the Sages that he is forbidden only during the first day, as it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Zevachim 100b" href="/Zevachim.100b"><i>Babli Zevaḥim</i> 100b</a>.</i>: Rebbi said, you know that deep mourning in the night is not biblical, since they said<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Pesachim 8:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Pesachim.8.8.1">Mishnah <i>Pesahim</i> 8:8</a>. This naturally presupposes that the person was not defiled by the impurity of the dead; otherwise, he would have to observe a seven day cleansing period. If he had no occasion to be near the corpse, the biblical prohibitions upon the deep mourner lapse at sundown.</i>, “the deep mourner immerses himself and eats his Passover sacrifice in the evening.” But they said, deep mourning [during daytime]<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Inserted from the parallel sources, necessary for understanding the text.</i> is biblical. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun in the name of Rebbi Huna: Explain it<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah in <i>Pesahim</i> only refers to the unlikely case that the deep mourner was not defiled with the impurity of the dead in a case in which both Rebbi and the Sages will agree on the duration of the deep sorrow.</i> that he was buried close to sundown [and one cannot infer anything.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Inserted from the parallel sources, necessary for understanding the text.</i>]

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If he<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The High Priest makes a visit of condolence.</i> consoles others, common behavior requires the people to come in single file and the executive officer<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">The organizer of the Temple service walks to his left; all other people are required to make a single file to the organizer’s left, to make sure that nobody touch the High Priest and defile him.</i> becomes a partition between himself and the people. If he is consoled by others, everybody tells him, we are his<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning “your.”</i> atonement; he answers them, may you be blessed by Heaven. If one brings him the first meal<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Mourners are not permitted to prepare their own first meal after the burial. The people who bring him the food are supposed to eat with him. This is an Amoraïc statement in the Babli (<i>Moˋed qatan</i> 27b) but is implied as an ancient custom in <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 3:35" href="/II_Samuel.3.35"><i>2S.</i>3:35</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 24:17" href="/Ezekiel.24.17"><i>Ez.</i> 24:17</a>.</i>, the people sit in a circle on the ground and he sits in their circle on a footstool<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>subsellium.</i> Probably the vocalization should be סֻפּסֶל.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If he consoles others,” etc. This implies that a footstool is not meant by “overturning the couch.” The High Priest is obligated to overturn his couch<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">The mourner is not permitted to sit comfortably on a couch; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:1:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.1.9"><i>Berakhot</i> 3:1, Notes 36–41</a>. The prestige of the High Priest’s office does not permit him to sit on the floor.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">From here to the end of the Halakhah, the text is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:2:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.2.2-5"><i>Berakhot</i> 3:2, Notes 123–135</a>. The last two paragraphs have been shortened to become partially unintelligible; they are intended to refer the student to the text in <i>Berakhot.</i></i> It is stated: “One does not take the dead for burial close to the recitation of the <i>Shemaˋ</i> unless one do it one hour in advance or one hour afterwards, so that they may recite and pray.” But did we not formulate: “When they buried the dead and returned”? Explain it for those who thought that they had a free period but they did not have a free period.
It is stated: The eulogizer and all who participate in a eulogy interrupt for the recitation of <i>Shemaˋ</i> but do not interrupt for prayer. It happened that our teachers interrupted for the recitation of <i>Shemaˋ</i> and prayer. Did we not state: “If they are able to start and finish”? Our Mishnah refers to the first day; that the Tanna stated for the second day.
Rebbi Samuel ben Eudaimon said: He who enters the synagogue and finds them standing and praying; if he knows that he could start and finish before the reader starts, so that he may answer “Amen”, he may pray, otherwise he should not pray. About which “Amen” did the speak? Two Amoraïm, one says the Amen of “the Holy King”, the other says the Amen of “Who listens to prayer.” <sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">A sentence has been omitted: R. Phineas said, the Amen of “the Holy King” refers to the Sabbath, that of “He Who listens to prayer” refers to <i>weekdays.</i> Only the last word was left.</i> On weekdays.
It is stated: Rebbi Jehudah says, if they are all standing in one row, those who are standing because of honor are obligated, those because of mourning are exempt. When they descend for a eulogy, those who see inside are exempt, those who do not see inside are obligated. It would be what we stated: “If he consoles others, the people come in single file and the executive officer becomes a partition between himself and the people,” the first teaching<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">Half a paragraph has been omitted (<i>Berakhot loc. cit.</i> Notes 132–133) that practice had changed in Mishnaic times. The practice of Temple times is not necessarily relevant for later generations.</i>. And what we stated: “the innermost are exempt and the outer ones obligated,” is the first teaching. Rebbi Ḥanina said: Originally, all families were standing still and the mourners passed between them. When competition increased in Sepphoris, Rebbi Yose ben Ḥalaphta instituted that the families should pass by and the mourners stand still. Rebbi Samuel Sofefta said: Matters returned to their original state.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The king does not judge<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">In the theory of the Yerushalmi this is biblical law, even though historically the administration of justice was the hallmark of kingship. Historically, the explanation of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 19a" href="/Sanhedrin.19a">Babli (19a</a>) has much to recommend it, that the Mishnaic theory of kingship, positing total separation of the executive from the judiciary, is a reaction to the misrule of the later Hasmoneans and the Herodians.</i>, nor may one judge him;<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">This would be too dangerous for judges and witnesses.</i> he does not testify, nor may one testify against him; he does not give <i>ḥalîṣah,</i> nor does one give <i>ḥalîṣah</i> to his wife<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">The ceremony would not be consistent with the dignity of his office/</i>. He does not marry in levirate, nor may one marry his wife in levirate. Rebbi Jehudah says, if he wants to give <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or marry in levirate, let his good deeds be remembered. They told him, even if he wants to, one does not listen to him<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">The king is obliged to sustain his dignity.</i>. One may not marry his widow; Rebbi Jehudah says, a king may marry a king’s widow<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">This seems to have been Solomon’s interpretation when he ordered Adoniah killed for asking Avishag’s hand (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 2:22" href="/I_Kings.2.22"><i>1K.</i> 2:22</a>).</i>, since we find that David married Saul’s widow, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 12:8" href="/II_Samuel.12.8"><i>2S.</i> 12:8</a>.</i>: <i>I gave your master’s house to you and your master’s wives on your breast</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The king does not judge, nor may one judge him;” etc. But is it not written<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 8:15" href="/II_Samuel.8.15"><i>2S.</i> 8:15</a>.</i>: <i>David administered justice and charity for his entire people,</i> and you say so? One has to say that he judged by the law, cleared the innocent and condemned the guilty. <sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 6b" href="/Sanhedrin.6b">Babli 6b</a>, the statements to the end of the paragraph. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Devarim Rabbah 5:3" href="/Devarim_Rabbah.5.3"><i>Deut. rabba</i> 5(3</a>).</i> If a poor person was found liable, he paid from his own money; in that he was administering justice for one party and charity for the other. Rebbi said, if somebody judged, cleared the innocent and condemned the guilty, the Omnipresent will credit him with acting charitably with the guilty by taking the ill-gotten goods out of his hand<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi (in <i>Deut. rabba</i> Rav Nahman) objects to the first explanation since essentially it is a dishonest way of solving disputes. He declares correct judgment in money matters to be an exercise in charity. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:1:25" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.1.25">Chapter 1, Note 82</a>.</i>.
“One may not judge him.” Because <i>from You my judgment will come</i><sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 17:2" href="/Psalms.17.2"><i>Ps.</i> 17:2</a>. Only God judges the king.</i>. Rebbi Isaac in the name of Rebbi: <i>To provide the judgment of His servant and the judgment of His people Israel day by day</i><sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 8:59" href="/I_Kings.8.59"><i>1K.</i> 8:59</a>.</i>.
“Rebbi Jehudah says, if he wants to give <i>ḥalîṣah</i> or marry in levirate, let his good deeds be remembered.” They told him, if you say so, you injure the king’s prestige.
One marries neither the king’s widow nor his divorcee, because <i>they were secluded to the day of their death, living in widowhood</i><sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 20:3" href="/II_Samuel.20.3"><i>2S.</i> 20:3</a>, speaking of David’s concubines with whom Absalom had slept in public.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah bar Pazi in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: This teaches<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">He reads צְרוּרוֹת not as “bound” but “tied, braided”.</i> that David had them braided and adorned, and brought them before himself every day and told his evil inclination, you desire something which is forbidden to you;<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Since the concubines were not legally his wives, Absalom sinned by raping them, but they remained permitted to David by rabbinic rules. It was voluntarily that David refrained from sleeping with them.</i> by your life, I shall make you desire what is permitted to you. The rabbis of Caesarea said, they actually were forbidden to him. If a private person’s vessel used by a private person is forbidden for the king’s use<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Since the king is prohibited from marrying his childless brother’s widow, it follows that the only women permitted to a king are either virgins or widows and divorcees of kings.</i>, <i>a fortiori</i> the king is forbidden to use the king’s vessels which were used by a private person.
“Rebbi Jehudah says, a king may marry a king’s widow, since we find that David married Saul’s widow, as it is said: <i>I gave your master’s house to you</i><i>and your master’s wives on your breast</i>.” This refers to Riṣpah<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">Saul’s concubine, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:4:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.4.9"><i>Yebamot</i> 2:4, Note 116</a>.</i>, Abigail and Batseba<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">These two examples refer to the preceding paragraph and show that the argument of the rabbis of Caesarea is wrong. David married Abigail, Nabal’s widow, when already he claimed kingship (in the interpretation of the next paragraphs) and Batseba, Uriah’s widow, when actually he was king.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is inserted as preface to the story about Nabal and David, induced by the mention of Abigail in the preceding sentence.</i>Ḥeṣron had three sons, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">A shortened quote from <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 2:9" href="/I_Chronicles.2.9"><i>1Chr.</i> 2:9</a>.</i>: <i>The sons of Ḥeṣron Yeraḥmeël, and Ram, and Kelubai</i><sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">He is Kaleb ben Hesron, presumed ancestor of Nabal.</i>. Yerahmeël should have been first,<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">As the firstborn, he should be first in the genealogical list, but his descendants are listed last, vv. 25 ff. The role of firstborn was taken over by Ram, the ancestor of David.</i> but he married a Gentile woman to crown himself with her, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 2:26" href="/I_Chronicles.2.26"><i>1Chr.</i> 2:26</a>.</i>: <i>Yerahmeël had another</i><sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Interpreting “another” as “foreign”.</i><i>wife; her name was Crown, she is the mother of Onam,</i> for she brought deep sorrow to his house<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Deriving אוֹנָם from the root אנה “to be in deep sorrow”.</i>. <i>And Ram fathered Amminadav, Amminadav fathered Naḥshon, Naḥshon fathered Salma, Salmon fathered Boaz</i><sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ruth 4:19-21" href="/Ruth.4.19-21"><i>Ru.</i> 4:19–21</a>, but probably <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 2:10-11" href="/I_Chronicles.2.10-11"><i>1Chr.</i>2:10–11</a> was intended.</i>, and Boaz married Ruth.
<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">A Hebrew version of most of the story is in <i>Midrash Samuel</i> (ed. Buber) 25.</i> This Nabal<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">“Scoundrel”. But the name seems to be Arabic نبل “possessed of superior qualities, generous, noble.”</i> was a descendant of Kelubai. Nabal said, nobody in Israel comes from a better family than I. That is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:2" href="/I_Samuel.25.2"><i>1S.</i> 25:2</a>.</i>: <i>A man from Maˋon had his business in Karmel; the man was exceedingly rich, a Kalebite,</i> a descendant of Kelubai. <i>David heard in the prairie that Nabal was shearing</i><sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:4" href="/I_Samuel.25.4"><i>1S</i>. 25:4</a>.</i>. <i>Tell him, to life</i><sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:6" href="/I_Samuel.25.6"><i>1S.</i> 25:6</a>.</i><i>!</i> For long life. <i>Peace be with you,</i> etc. Rebbi Justus from Sunem said, they formed a camp<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">This is a side remark; it is more explicit in <i>Erubin</i> 1, 19c l. 75. In v. 4, it is stated that David sent 10 men to Nabal; in v. 6 it is stated <i>they encamped.</i> He concludes that the legal definition of a camp (for the religious obligations in wartime) refers to a minimum of 10 men.</i>. <i>Nabal answered David’s servants</i><sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:10" href="/I_Samuel.25.10"><i>1S.</i> 25:10</a>.</i>, etc. From where that in criminal trials the voting starts from the side? Samuel the Elder stated before Rebbi Aḥa: <i>David told his men</i><sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:13" href="/I_Samuel.25.13"><i>1S.</i> 25:13</a>. The argument is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 36a" href="/Sanhedrin.36a">Babli, 36a</a>, in the name of R. Johanan. The verse explains that David told his men to gird their swords; he girded his sword last. This is read to mean that he first polled his men whether Nabal should be executed for the crime of lèse-majesty; he gave his vote last.</i><i>,</i> etc. <i>He flew at them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:14" href="/I_Samuel.25.14"><i>1S.</i> 25:14</a>.</i><i>.</i> What means <i>he flew at them</i>? He made them fly with words<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Rashi quotes this in his Commentary to the verse.</i>. <i>Now know this and consider what to do</i><sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:17" href="/I_Samuel.25.17"><i>1S.</i> 25:17</a>.</i>. <i>She fell in with them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:20" href="/I_Samuel.25.20"><i>1S.</i> 25:20</a>.</i>, she bared her thigh and they walked by its light<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Since in <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:3" href="/I_Samuel.25.3">v. 3</a> she is described as a radiant beauty.</i>. <i>She fell in with them,</i> they all were recognizable<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">In the dark of the night.</i>. <i>[David] said, was it in vain that I watched</i><sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:21" href="/I_Samuel.25.21"><i>1S.</i> 25:21</a>.</i>, etc.? <i>Pissing on a wall</i><sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:22" href="/I_Samuel.25.22"><i>1S.</i> 25:22</a>.</i>; why does he refer to the dog pissing on a wall? Even with the dog I shall not have mercy. <i>Abigail saw David</i><sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:23" href="/I_Samuel.25.23"><i>1S.</i> 25:23</a>.</i>, etc. She told him, my lord David, what did I do, what did my children do, what did my animals do? He answered her, because he insulted the kingdom of David. She asked him, are you a king? He told her, did not Samuel anoint me as king? She answered him, our Lord’s Saul‘s coin<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>moneta</i>.</i> is still circulating. <i>And I am your servant</i><sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:25" href="/I_Samuel.25.25"><i>1S.</i> 25:25</a>.</i>; this proves that he asked her for sex<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Since in each sentence she repeats that she only is his servant, she has to emphasize that she is not going to be his companion.</i>. Immediately, she brought out her stains<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">Indicating that she was not available since she was menstruating, and treating him as a rabbi, competent to decide whether blood was menstrual or not (cf. Introduction to Tractate <i>Niddah</i>.)</i> and showed him. He said, does one investigate stains in the night? She retorted, may your ears hear what your lips say! Stains one does not investigate in the night, does one judge capital cases in the night? He answered, his sentence was already passed in daytime. She retorted, <i>may this not be</i> <i>פוּקָה</i> <i>for you</i><sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:31" href="/I_Samuel.25.31"><i>1S.</i> 25:31</a>.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">A paragraph inserted to discuss the meaning of the <i>hapax</i> פּוּקָה. It is assumed that the root פק is the same which appears reduplicated in the rabbinic Hebrew verb פקפק (“to doubt”, Arabic “to dote”). In the Babli, a parallel argument is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 14b" href="/Megillah.14b"><i>Megillah</i>14b</a>.</i> Rebbi Eleazar said, matters of reproach are there. Rebbi Levi was reviewing the lesson, when Rebbi Zeˋira commanded the colleagues to come and hear the voice of Rebbi Levi sermonizing, for it was impossible that the lesson would be finished without new insight. He came and told them, <i>not be</i>; Rebbi Zeˋira heard it and said, even in his <i>aggadah</i> there is new insight. לְפוּקָה matters of reproach are there.
She told him, when you emerge from your tribulations, one will say of you that you that you are a murderer. <i>And a stumbling block for sin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">112,</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:31" href="/I_Samuel.25.31"><i>1S.</i> 25:31</a>.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">In the verse: <i>a stumbling block of my lord’s heart</i>.</i>. You are set up to stumble over a married woman, better one than two. In the future it will be enough to bring one, and not to add <i>spilling blood.</i> Are you ready to rule over Israel when they will say about you that you were a spiller of blood? Even though anybody who curses the dynasty of David incurs the death penalty<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">In imitation of Roman law; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 14a" href="/Megillah.14a">Babli <i>Megillah</i> 14a</a>.</i>, still you are missing the throne. <i>But remember your servant</i><sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:31" href="/I_Samuel.25.31"><i>1S.</i> 25:31</a>.</i>, this proves that she showed herself licentious<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">She indicated her desire to be his wife when she still was married to Nabal.</i>. Since she showed herself licentious, the verse damaged her. In all verses one reads Abigail, except for this verse<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:32" href="/I_Samuel.25.32"><i>1S.</i> 25:32</a>.</i>: <i>David said to Abigal, praised be the Eternal,</i> etc., <i>to come into blood guilts,</i> the blood of menstruation and the spilling of blood<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:33" href="/I_Samuel.25.33"><i>1S.</i> 25:33</a>; explaining the plural “bloods” used in the verse. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Megillah 14b" href="/Megillah.14b">Babli <i>Megillah</i>14b</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If a relative of his<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">The king’s.</i> died, he does not leave his palace<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>palatium,</i> “palace”. The ending <i>-orium</i> may have been added in parallel to <i>praetorium</i> “official residence of the governor of a province”.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah says, if he wants to follow the bier, he may follow it, as we find that David followed Abner’s bier, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote"><i>2S</i>.3:31.</i>: <i>King David followed</i><i>the bier.</i> They told him, this was only to quiet<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">To quell rumors that the king was involved in Abner’s murder.</i>. When one brings him the first meal<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">Mourners are not permitted to prepare their own first meal after the burial. The people who bring him the food are supposed to eat with him. This is an Amoraïc statement in the Babli (<i>Moˋed qatan</i> 27b) but is implied as an ancient custom in <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 3:35" href="/II_Samuel.3.35"><i>2S.</i>3:35</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 24:17" href="/Ezekiel.24.17"><i>Ez.</i> 24:17</a>.</i>, the people sit in a circle on the floor and he sits in their circle on a couch<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">For the particular kind of couch mentioned here; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:1:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.1.8"><i>Berakhot</i> 3:1, Note 31</a>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If a relative of his died, he does not leave his palace.” This implies that a <i>dargesh</i> is included in overturning one’s bed<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">Since it is mentioned that the king is required to sit on a <i>dargesh</i> when receiving condolence visits, one implies that no other mourner may sit on this kind of couch since the king in mourning is not required to sit or sleep on an overturned coach. However, it is spelled out elsewhere (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:1:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.1.8"><i>Berakhot</i> 3:1 Note 31</a>, <i>Moˋed qaṭan</i> 5:1 83a l. 11, <i>Nedarim</i> 7:5 Note 49; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 20a" href="/Sanhedrin.20a">Babli <i>Sanhedrin</i> 20a</a>) that a <i>dargesh</i> is turned 90° in contrast to other couches which are turned upside down.</i>. The king is not required to overturn his bed.
Some Tannaïm state<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 17(13).</i>: Women go first<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">In a funeral procession, they precede the bier.</i>, after them men. But some Tannaïm state: Men first, women after them. He who says women first, since they caused death to the world. He who says men first, for the honor of the daughter of Israel, lest people<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">The onlookers.</i> look at women. But was it not written: <i>King David followed the bier</i><sup class="footnote-marker">121,</sup><i class="footnote"><i>2S</i>.3:31.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">In v. 32 it says that David cried at Abner’s grave, and so did the entire people; <i>entire</i> includes women. But it still is undecided who went first. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 20a" href="/Sanhedrin.20a">Babli, 20a</a>, the verse is quoted as proof that the women must have preceded the bier since the king immediately followed it.</i>. They said, this was only to quiet. Whoever was calming the women was calming the men, and whoever was calming the men was calming the women.
<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">A somewhat more explicit version of this is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sukkah 5:4:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sukkah.5.4.2-4"><i>Sukkah</i> 5:4</a> (55c l. 7); a different version of this and the following paragraphs is found in the last part of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bamidbar Rabbah 4" href="/Bamidbar_Rabbah.4"><i>Num. rabba</i> 4</a>.</i> It is written: <i>David turned</i><sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 16:43" href="/I_Chronicles.16.43"><i>1Chr.</i> 16:43</a>. Probably what was intended was <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 6:20" href="/II_Samuel.6.20"><i>2S.</i> 6:20</a> (correctly quoted in <i>Sukkah</i>), the end of the story of the transfer of the Ark to the City of David.</i>. Who are the “empty ones”<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 6:20" href="/II_Samuel.6.20"><i>2S.</i> 6:20</a>, where Michal criticizes David for dancing in the street.</i>? Rebbi Abba bar Cahana said, the most empty one, that is the dancer<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ὀρχηστής, οῦ, ὁ.</i>. She told him, today the honor of my father’s house became obvious. One said about the family of Saul that one never saw a heel or a thumb of them. That is what is written: <i>He came to the sheep fences</i><sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 24:3" href="/I_Samuel.24.3"><i>1S</i>. 24:3</a>.</i>. Rebbi Abun ben Rebbi Eleazar: That was a fence inside a fence<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">This explains the plural used in the verse and shows that Saul went to relieve himself in the cave guarded from the outside by a double fence. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 62b" href="/Berakhot.62b">Babli, <i>Berakhot</i>62b</a>, this is quoted as tannaitic text.</i>. <i>Saul came to spread his feet</i><sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 24:3" href="/I_Samuel.24.3"><i>1S</i>. 24:3</a>.</i>. He saw him how he lifted a little and covered a little. He said, one who would touch such modesty would be cursed. That is what he told him, <i>behold, what your eyes saw today</i><sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 24:10" href="/I_Samuel.24.10"><i>1S</i>. 24:10</a>.</i>, etc. Is it not written “I had mercy on you” but <i>it had mercy on you</i><sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 24:10" href="/I_Samuel.24.10"><i>1S</i>. 24:10</a>.</i>, your modesty had mercy on you. <i>David told Michal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 6:21" href="/II_Samuel.6.21"><i>2S</i>. 6:21</a>.</i>, etc. <i>With the servant girls you mentioned, with them I shall be honored</i><sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 6:22" href="/II_Samuel.6.22"><i>2S</i>. 6:22</a>.</i>, for they are not servant girls but mothers. How was she punished? <i>Michal, Saul’s daughter, had no child</i><sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 6:23" href="/II_Samuel.6.23"><i>2S</i>. 6:23</a>. The verse ends: <i>up to the day of her death,</i> implying that she died in childbirth.</i>, But is it not written: <i>The sixth Yitreˋam, of his wife Calf</i><sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 3:5" href="/II_Samuel.3.5"><i>2S</i>. 3:5</a>. Only Michal is called “David’s wife” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:44" href="/I_Samuel.25.44"><i>1S</i>. 25:44</a>). The problem that Yitreˋam was born in Hebron is not addressed; it is discussed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 21a" href="/Sanhedrin.21a">Babli, 21a</a>.</i>. She mood like a calf and died.
<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Since the preceding paragraph speaks of the introduction of the Ark into Jerusalem, one continues with sermons about the Ark.</i> no person in Israel was abasing himself before the Commandments more than David. Why was he abasing himself before the Commandments? Because people were looking at the Ark and dying, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 6:19" href="/I_Samuel.6.19"><i>1S.</i> 6:19</a>. There, it is stated explicitly, <i>because they were staring at the Eternal’s ark.</i></i>: <i>He smote of the people of Bet Shemesh,</i> etc. Rebbi Ḥanina and Rebbi Mana<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">A different interpretation is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 35b" href="/Sotah.35b">Babli, <i>Sotah</i> 35b</a>, also by Galilean Amoraim.</i>. One said, <i>He smote among the people seventy men,</i> that is the Synhedrion. And <i>50’000 men</i><sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">The conjunction ו is not in the masoretic text. The quote is correct in the existing mss. (Munich and Rome) of Babli <i>Sotah,</i> incorrect in the Bomberg Babli of 1520–23.</i><i>,</i> for they were worth 50’000. The other said, <i>He smote among the people seventy men,</i> that is the Synhedrion. And <i>50’000 men</i> from the people of the Land. It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">143a</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 131" href="/Psalms.131"><i>Ps</i>. 131</a>.</i>: <i>A song of ascent of David. O Eternal, my heart was not haughty</i> when Samuel anointed me; <i>my eyes were not overbearing</i> when I slew Goliath; <i>and I did not decide on matters too great</i> when I brought up the Ark; <i>and wonderful for me,</i> when He brought me back to my kingdom. But <i>rather I prayed, and silenced my soul like a baby by its mother, like a baby my soul is for me.</i> Like a baby delivered from his mother’s womb is my soul for me.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> He goes to a war of choice<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Any war which is not purely defensive.</i> by the word of the Court of 71<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">A misnomer for the Synhedrion, the High Priest's Council when the latter was head of the Commonwealth. The confusion in terminology was caused by the Court of Jabneh which took over the name of Synhedrion.</i>. He breaches fences on his way and one may not protest against him. The king’s highway has no measure<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 6:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.6.4.1">Mishnah <i>Bava batra</i> 6:7</a>.</i>. When all people plunder<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">In war, if orders are given to plunder the enemy.</i>, it is put before him and he selects his part first.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “He goes to a war of choice,” etc. For it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 27:21" href="/Numbers.27.21"><i>Num.</i> 27:21</a>. The verse subordinates the political leader, Joshua, to the High Priest, Eleazar. It is presumed that the High Priest act on advice of his Council.</i>: <i>on his saying they shall go out, on his saying they shall return.</i> “He breaches fences on his way,” for it is written: <i>they drove before [this] flock and said, this is David’s booty</i><sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 30:20" href="/I_Samuel.30.20"><i>1S.</i> 30:20</a>. What the verse really proves is that the total booty is called “the king’s booty”, implying that he has the right to first select his share.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">Parallel texts are in <i>Ruth rabba</i> 5(1), <i>Midrash Samuel</i> 10(1), <i>Yalqut Samuel</i> #165.</i><i>He was with David at Efes Dammim</i><sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 11:13" href="/I_Chronicles.11.13"><i>1Chr.</i> 11:13</a>. In the entire section, the verses are not quoted exactly.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, at the red field<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">He explains the reading of the masoretic text, פַּס דַּמִּים “a red strip.”</i>. But Rebbi Samuel said, from there the money stopped.<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">He reads אֶפֶס דָּמִים “no money” in rabbinic Hebrew, to explain that the king does not pay for damage he inflicts on private property in the course of his activities on behalf of the people in war or peace. The storytelling is incidental to the attempt to find biblical justification for the rules of the Mishnah. There is no claim of historical validity.</i> <i>The Philistines assembled</i><sup class="footnote-marker">151,</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 11:13" href="/I_Chronicles.11.13"><i>1Chr.</i> 11:13</a>. In the entire section, the verses are not quoted exactly.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 23:11" href="/II_Samuel.23.11"><i>2S.</i> 23:11</a>.</i>, etc. Rebbi Jacob from Kefar Ḥanan said, they were lentils but a kernel was as good as a barley grain. Rebbi Levi said, this describes the Philistines who came straight as barley and went away low as lentils, as one verse says, <i>there was a field full of barley</i><sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 11:13" href="/I_Chronicles.11.13"><i>1Chr.</i> 11:13</a>. In the entire section, the verses are not quoted exactly.</i><i>,</i> and one said, <i>full of lentils</i><sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 23:11" href="/II_Samuel.23.11"><i>2S.</i> 23:11</a>.</i>. Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman said, it was one year but concerning two fields, one of barley and one of lentils. It was obvious to him that he might destroy it and pay for the damage. Perhaps it was obvious to him<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">To David, who would be incapable of doing anything unlawful. The Mishnah does not address the problem of indemnity for the exercise of the power of eminent domain.</i> that he might destroy it and not pay for the damage? Which one might he destroy and for which one would he have to pay? For the one of lentils or the one of barley? For the one of lentils grows human food, the one of barley animal feed. The one of lentils will not be obligated for <i>ḥallah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">The heave required to be taken from bread dough; cf. Introduction to Tractate <i>Hallah</i>.</i>, barley will be obligated for <i>ḥallah.</i> The <i>ˋomer</i> comes from barley<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">The flour offering permitting the use of new grain. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 23:9-14" href="/Leviticus.23.9-14"><i>Lev</i>. 23:9–14</a>.</i>; <i>ˋomer</i> cannot be brought from lentils. But the rabbis said, it was one field and two years. Does one infer from last year, or does one not infer from one year to the next? <i>They stood up in the property and saved it</i><sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 11:14" href="/I_Chronicles.11.14"><i>1Chr</i>. 11:14</a>.</i>. One verse says, <i>they saved it,</i> and one says, <i>he saved it</i><sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 23:12" href="/II_Samuel.23.12"><i>2S</i>. 23:12</a>.</i>. This shows that he returned it to its owner and it was dear to him as if it had been a field of saffron.
It is written: <i>David had a desire and said, who would give me to drink from the cistern of Bethlehem</i><sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 23:15-16" href="/II_Samuel.23.15-16"><i>2S</i>. 23:15–16</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 11:17-18" href="/I_Chronicles.11.17-18"><i>1Chr</i>. 11:17–18</a>.</i>, etc. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said, he questioned practice<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">One of the rules of the Mishnah. to ask the opinion of the Sages of a mythical Bethlehem. Rabbinic interpretation systematically reduces David to a rabbi, negates all qualities of a warrior, and tries to eliminate all memories of a warlike past.</i>. <i>Three broke through.</i> Why three? For no practice can be elucidated by less than three [opinions]. <i>But David refused to drink.</i> David did not want that the practice would be attached to his name<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">Since the rules of the Mishnah are all anonymous.</i>. <i>He poured it out for the Eternal,</i> he fixed it as a tractate for all generations, “he breaches fences on his way.”
Bar Qappara said, it was the feast of Tabernacles, the time of water libations<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">The water libation at Tabernacles (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sukkah 4:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sukkah.4.7.1">Mishnah <i>Sukkah</i> 4:9</a>), a purely pharisaic practice without biblical sanction, to ask for ample rains in the winter season. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 2:5:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.2.5.4">Note 161</a>.</i>, and a time when private altars were permitted<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">After the destruction of Shiloh, before the building of the Temple in Jerusalem, there was no central sanctuary which could claim exclusivity by deuteronomic rules. According to all opinions, private altars were biblically permitted in that period (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Zevachim 14:7" href="/Mishnah_Zevachim.14.7">Mishnah <i>Zevahim</i> 14:7</a>). The pharisaic water libation was a public offering not appropriate for a private altar. It has to be assumed that in this interpretation David acted as king; his altar could represent the nation by public offerings.</i>. <i>Three broke through.</i> Why three? One was slaying, one was removing the corpses, and the third brought the flask in purity.
One verse says, <i>he made a libation for the Eternal,</i> but another verse says, <i>he covered.</i> He who says ויסך, supports Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">He does not read the masoretic וַיַּסֵּךְ from the root נסך “to pour, offer a libation” but וַיָּֽסֶךְ, root סכך “to cover”.</i>. He who says, <i>he made a libation,</i> supports Bar Qappara. Rebbi Huna in the name of Rebbi Yose: He had a problem with the rules of captives<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">Probably what is the prerogative of the king in appropriating female prisoners of war. Rabbinic theory explains that Tamar was not David’s daughter but the daughter of David’s wife Maˋakha from the time before the latter was taken prisoner by David and forcibly converted by the rules of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:10-14" href="/Deuteronomy.21.10-14"><i>Deut.</i> 21:10–14</a> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 21a" href="/Sanhedrin.21a">Babli 21a</a>); therefore, she was unrelated to Amnon who could have married her under rabbinic rules.</i>. Rebbi Simeon ben Rebbi said, he desired to build the Temple<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">It is unclear to what this may refer, but in any case it would be a case for the Sages of Bethlehem before the capture of Jerusalem.</i>

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> <i>He shall not add wives</i><sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:17" href="/Deuteronomy.17.17"><i>Deut.</i> 17:17</a>.</i>, only eighteen<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">This is the number of wives David could have had, as explained in the Halakhah.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah says, he may have many on condition that they not deflect his mind<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:17" href="/Deuteronomy.17.17"><i>Deut.</i> 17:17</a> reads: <i>And he shall not add wives, lest his mind be deflected</i> (from his religious duties.) If the prohibition were absolute, it would not need a rationale.</i>. Rebbi Simeon says, he should not marry even one if she deflects his mind<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">R. Simeon in principle objects to R. Jehudah’s argument. For him, every biblical commandment has a rationale indicated in the text, even if it is not explicit (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 21a" href="/Sanhedrin.21a">Babli 21a</a>). Therefore, <i>lest his mind be deflected</i> is a commandment in itself. Hence, 18 wives is the maximum permitted to a king under any circumstances.</i>. Then why was it said, <i>he shall not add wives</i>? Even one like Abigail<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">Who prevented David from sinning, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 2:3:2-10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.2.3.2-10">Halakhah 3</a>. Since she predicted that David would be king, she is counted as a prophetess (<i>Seder Olam</i> Chap. 2).</i>.<br><i>He shall not add horses</i><sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:16" href="/Deuteronomy.17.16"><i>Deut.</i> 17:16</a>.</i>, over and above what he needs for his chariots. <i>And silver and gold he shall not add excessively</i><sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:17" href="/Deuteronomy.17.17"><i>Deut.</i> 17:17</a>.</i>, over and above what he needs for his payroll<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ὀψώνιον, Latin <i>obsonium,</i>“victuals, allowance, gratuity”, here taken as allowances for everybody on the king’s payroll.</i>. <i>And he shall write a Torah scroll</i><sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:18" href="/Deuteronomy.17.18"><i>Deut.</i> 17:18</a>.</i> for himself. If he goes to war, it is with him; if he returns, it is with him; if he sits in court, it is with him; if he sits down for dinner, it is with him, as it is said: <i>It shall be with him, and he shall read in it all the days of his life</i><sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:19" href="/Deuteronomy.17.19"><i>Deut.</i> 17:19</a>.</i>.<br>One does not ride on his horse, nor does one sit on his throne, nor does one use his scepter. One may not see him when he is barbered, nor when he is naked, nor when he is in the bath, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:15" href="/Deuteronomy.17.15"><i>Deut.</i> 17:15</a>.</i>: <i>You certainly shall put a king over you,</i> that his fear be upon you.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “He shall not add wives,” etc. Rav Cahana said<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 21a" href="/Sanhedrin.21a">Babli 21a</a>.</i>, because of <i>the sixth Yitream by Egla</i><sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 3:5" href="/II_Samuel.3.5"><i>2S</i>. 3:5</a>. Only Michal is called “David’s wife” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:44" href="/I_Samuel.25.44"><i>1S</i>. 25:44</a>). The problem that Yitreˋam was born in Hebron is not addressed; it is discussed in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 21a" href="/Sanhedrin.21a">Babli, 21a</a>.</i>. What is written there? <i>At least, I shall give you twice as many</i><sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 12:8" href="/II_Samuel.12.8"><i>2S.</i> 12:8</a>. The verses <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 3:2-5" href="/II_Samuel.3.2-5"><i>2S.</i> 3:2–5</a> prove that David had six wives in Hebron. The prophet Nathan then told David that God would have given him an addition of twice as many wives, for a total of 3×6=18, had he not sinned with Batseba. Therefore, 18 wives for a king have Divine sanction.</i>.
“<i>He shall not add horses</i> over and above what he needs for his chariots.” As in <i>David destroyed all the chariots</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 8:4" href="/II_Samuel.8.4"><i>2S.</i> 8:4</a>. As usual, the argument is about the part of the verse which is not quoted: <i>but he reserved from them 100 chariots.</i> This shows that chariots and horses needed for the army are permitted.</i> etc. “<i>And silver and gold he shall not add excessively</i> over and above what he needs for his payroll.” Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, but only for this year’s payroll.
Rebbi Aḥa said: Solomon said, three things I desecrated where I got the better of the law<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Kohelet Rabbah 2:3" href="/Kohelet_Rabbah.2.3"><i>Eccl.</i> <i>r</i>. 2(3</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 16:1-18:30" href="/Leviticus.16.1-18.30"><i>Tanhuma Aḥare Mot</i> 1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 16:1-18:30" href="/Leviticus.16.1-18.30"><i>Tanhuma Buber Ahare</i> <i>Mot</i> 2</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 16:1-18:30" href="/Leviticus.16.1-18.30"><i>Pesiqṭa dR. Cahana</i>(Buber) <i>Ahare Mot</i> 168b–168a</a>.<br>Most of the verses quoted in these paragraphs are also quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 21b" href="/Sanhedrin.21b">Babli, 21b</a>. Cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shir HaShirim Rabbah 1:10" href="/Shir_HaShirim_Rabbah.1.10"><i>Cant. rabba</i> 1(10</a>).</i>. <i>He shall not add wives,</i> and it is written: <i>King Solomon</i><i>loved foreign women</i><sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 11:1" href="/I_Kings.11.1"><i>1K</i>. 11:1</a>.</i>. Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai said, he really made love to them immorally<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">He did not marry them but slept with them unmarried to increase his sexual enjoyment.</i>. Ḥananiah, Rebbi Joshua’s nephew, says, because <i>you shall not intermarry with them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 7:3" href="/Deuteronomy.7.3"><i>Deut</i>. 7:3</a>. He agrees with R. Simeon ben Iohai and notes that by behaving immorally he avoided violating the law. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bamidbar Rabbah 10:8" href="/Bamidbar_Rabbah.10.8"><i>Num</i>. r. 10(8</a>) only Hanania and R. Yose are mentioned.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, to draw them to the words of the Torah and bring them under the Wings of the Divine Presence<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">He married all those women with good intentions but violated <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:17" href="/Deuteronomy.17.17"><i>Deut</i>. 17:17</a>. The expression “to take shelter under the Wings of the Divine Presence” for “to convert to Judaism” is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ruth 2:12" href="/Ruth.2.12"><i>Ru</i>. 2:12</a>.</i>. Rebbi Eliezer said, because <i>also the foreign wives made him sin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 13:26" href="/Nehemiah.13.26"><i>Neh.</i> 13:26</a>. He violated <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 2:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.2.6.1">Mishnah 7</a> according to all authorities quoted there.</i>. It turns out that one may say that Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai, Ḥananiah, and Rebbi Eliezer mean the same. Rebbi Yose disagrees with all three of them.
<i>He shall not add horses</i>, and it is written: <i>Solomon had 40’000 horse stables for his chariot, and 12’000 riders</i><sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 5:6" href="/I_Kings.5.6"><i>1K</i>. 5.6</a>.</i>. They were idle<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">If all of the chariots and horses had been for military purposes, it would not have been sinful. A Genizah fragment inserts a rhetorical question. Were the 40’000 stables not adequate since it also is written (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 4:20" href="/I_Kings.4.20"><i>1K</i>. 4:20</a>) that Israel were <i>many, like the sand at the seashore</i>? The answer is that the horses and carriages were sinful since the riders were idle most of the time.</i>.
