A private person is permitted all of these<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">Wives, horses, and money are limited only for a king.</i>.
<i>And silver and gold he shall not add excessively</i>, and it is written: <i>The king made silver in Jerusalem to be like stones</i><sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 10:27" href="/I_Kings.10.27"><i>1K</i>. 10:27</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 1:15" href="/II_Chronicles.1.15"><i>2Chr</i>. 1:15</a>.</i>. Were they not stolen? Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, they were stones of ten cubits and eight cubits<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">A silver block of 8 cubits side length would weigh 1.7 metric tons.</i>. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish stated: In Solomon’s times, even weights were not of silver but of gold. Why? <i>Silver was not valuable in Solomon’s times</i><sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 10:21" href="/I_Kings.10.21"><i>1K</i>. 10:21</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 9:27" href="/II_Chronicles.9.27"><i>2Chr</i>. 9:27</a>.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Kohelet Rabbah 2:3" href="/Kohelet_Rabbah.2.3"><i>Eccl.</i> <i>r</i>. 2(3</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 16:1-18:30" href="/Leviticus.16.1-18.30"><i>Tanhuma Aḥare Mot</i> 1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 16:1-18:30" href="/Leviticus.16.1-18.30"><i>Tanhuma Buber Ahare</i> <i>Mot</i> 2</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 16:1-18:30" href="/Leviticus.16.1-18.30"><i>Pesiqṭa dR. Cahana</i>(Buber) <i>Ahare Mot</i> 168b–168a</a>.<br>Most of the verses quoted in these paragraphs are also quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 21b" href="/Sanhedrin.21b">Babli, 21b</a>. Cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shir HaShirim Rabbah 1:10" href="/Shir_HaShirim_Rabbah.1.10"><i>Cant. rabba</i> 1(10</a>).</i> It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 2:2" href="/Ecclesiastes.2.2"><i>Eccl.</i> 2:2</a>.</i>: <i>To amusement I said, be praised</i>. The Holy One, praise to him, said to Solomon: What is this crown on your head? Descend from My throne! Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, at that moment an angel came down looking like Solomon, removed him from his throne, and sat in his stead. He was going around in synagogues and houses of study, saying <i>I am Ecclesiastes, I used to be king over Israel in Jerusalem</i><sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 1:12" href="/Ecclesiastes.1.12"><i>Eccl.</i> 1:12</a>.</i>. They were telling him, the king sits on his chair of honor<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>bisellium</i>; cf. Löw in Krauss’s <i>Lehnwörter</i>.</i> and you say, <i>I am Ecclesiastes</i>? They hit him with a stick and brought a dish of split beans before him. At that moment, he said: <i>that is my part</i><sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 2:10" href="/Ecclesiastes.2.10"><i>Eccl.</i> 2:10</a>.</i>. Some say, a staff. Others say, a rod. Others say, with his belt. <sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Cant. r. ad</i> 5:10, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Vayikra Rabbah 19:2" href="/Vayikra_Rabbah.19.2"><i>Lev</i>. <i>r</i>. 19(2</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shemot Rabbah 6:1" href="/Shemot_Rabbah.6.1"><i>Ex</i>. <i>r</i>. 6(1</a>). Solomon is accused of wanting to remove the imperative from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:17" href="/Deuteronomy.17.17"><i>Deut</i>. 17:17</a>.</i> Who had accused him? Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, י in יַרְבֶּה<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 23:15-16" href="/II_Samuel.23.15-16"><i>2S</i>. 23:15–16</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 11:17-18" href="/I_Chronicles.11.17-18"><i>1Chr</i>. 11:17–18</a>.</i> accused him. Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai stated: The book Deuteronomy ascended, bowed down before the Holy One, praise to Him, and said to Him: Master of the Universe, You wrote in Your Torah that any disposition<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Greek διαθήκη “will, disposition”.</i> which is partially invalid is totally invalid, and now Solomon wants to uproot a י from me! The Holy One, praise to Him, said to it: Solomon and a thousand like him will disappear but nothing from you will disappear.
Rebbi Huna in the name of Rebbi Aḥa: The י which the Holy One, praise to Him, lifted from our mother Sarah was given half to Sarah and half to Abraham<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">In the Alexandrian system, the numerical value of י is 10, that of ה is 5. Therefore, the <i>gematria</i> of the two former names אברם שרי of Abraham and Sarah is identical to that of the new names אברהם שרה.</i>. Rebbi Hoshaiah stated: The י ascended, bowed down before the Holy One, praise to Him, and said to Him: Master of the Universes, you uprooted me from this just woman<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">By changing שָׂרַי into שָׂרָה.</i>! The Holy One, praise to Him, said to him: leave. In the past you were the last letter of a woman’s name. By your life, I shall make you the first letter of a man’s name. That is what is written: <i>Moses called Hoshea bin Nun Yehoshua</i><sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 13:16" href="/Numbers.13.16"><i>Num</i>. 13:16</a>.</i>.
<i>And he shall write a Torah scroll for himself</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 21b" href="/Sanhedrin.21b">Babli 21b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 4:4-5" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.4.4-5">Tosephta 4:7</a>.</i> That he should use neither his father’s not his teacher’s. One proofreads it from the Temple scroll under the supervision of the court of 71<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">In the Tosephta: It is proofread first by priests, then by Levites, then by Israel whose daughters are qualified to marry priests.</i>.
“If he goes to war, he carries it with him for it is said: <i>It shall be with him, and he shall read in it all the days of his life</i>. Is there not an inference <i>de minore ad majus</i>? Since for a king of Israel, who was occupied by the needs of Israel, is it said that <i>he shall read in it all the days of his life</i>, a private person so much more. Similarly, it was said to Joshua: <i>You shall meditate about it day and night</i><sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 1:8" href="/Joshua.1.8">Jos. 1:8</a>.</i>. Is there not an inference <i>de minore ad majus</i>? Since for Joshua, who is occupied by the needs of Israel, it is said: <i>you shall meditate about it day and night</i>, then certainly a private person.
<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">An abbreviated version of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 4:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.4.2">Tosephta 4:2</a>.</i> One does not ride on a horse of a king of Israel, nor does one sit in his chair<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>bisellium</i>; cf. Löw in Krauss’s <i>Lehnwörter</i>.</i>, nor does one use his crown or his scepter, or any of his personal utensils. When he dies, all these are burned before him, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 34:5" href="/Jeremiah.34.5"><i>Jer</i>. 34:5</a>.</i>: <i>You shall die in peace and like the burnings of your forefathers they will burn for you</i>.
One may not see him when naked, nor when he is being barbered, nor when he is in his bath, because <i>your eyes shall see the king in his beauty</i><sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 33:17" href="/Isaiah.33.17"><i>Is.</i> 33:17</a>. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 22b" href="/Sanhedrin.22b">Babli, 22b</a>, infers from the verse that a king has to get a haircut every day.</i>. Rebbi Ḥanina went to visit Rebbi Jehudah the Prince<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi’s grandson.</i>. He came to meet him dressed in sail-cloth. He told him, go and wear your <i>lagin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ὀθονή “sail-cloth”.</i>, because of <i>your eyes shall see the king in his beauty</i><sup class="footnote-marker">210,</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>lacinia, ae,</i> “edge, corner of garment, garment with fringes, ornament”, generally “garment” (E. G.).<br>(In other occurrences the word לגין means “bottle”, Greek λάγυνος, λάγηνος.)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">The Patriarch, as member of the Davidic dynasty, should uphold the dignity of his family at all times.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan went to visit Rebbi Jehudah the Prince. He came to meet him dressed in a linen gown. He told him, go and wear your woolen gown, because of <i>the king in his beauty</i>. When he left, he told him, bring <sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">The meaning and etymology of this word is totally unknown. The commentators see a connection with the word טעם “taste”. It may have been a question about politics since the verse quoted is explained in <i>Midrash Prov</i>. as referring to good political advice. Menahem Ptolemy is only mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kohelet Rabbah 5:10" href="/Kohelet_Rabbah.5.10"><i>Eccl.</i> <i>r</i>. <i>ad</i> 5:10</a>, in a discussion with R. Ḥanina, noting that good-looking food tastes better than undistinguished food, therefore it is possible to read the passage as an exhortation to the Patriarch to also show his status by his table.</i>עטעמה. He answered, send and get Menaḥem Ptolemy, for it is written: <i>Graceful teaching is on her tongue</i><sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 31:26" href="/Proverbs.31.26"><i>Pr</i>. 31:26</a>.</i>. Leaving, he saw Rebbi Ḥanina bar Sisi splitting wood. He told him, Rebbi, that is not fitting for you. He answered, what can I do? I have nobody to serve me. He retorted, if you have nobody to serve you, you should not have accepted ordination<sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote">An ordained rabbi should at all times uphold the dignity of the office. Similarly, the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 70a" href="/Kiddushin.70a">Babli (<i>Qiddušin</i> 70a</a>) frowns upon an ordained rabbi engaged in bodily labor in public.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">A similar paragraph is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 80:1" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.80.1"><i>Gen. r.</i> 80(1</a>).</i> Yose from Maon interpreted<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">In the Talmudim, תרגם is only used for interpretation or translation of Scripture. One has to assume that Yose from Maon was reading <i>Hos.</i> 5 as <i>Hafṭara</i> to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 34" href="/Genesis.34"><i>Gen.</i> 34</a> in the Palestinian 3½ year cycle of Torah reading (cf. J. Mann, <i>The Bible as Read and Preached in the Old Synagogue I</i>, Cincinnati 1940). One also has to assume that the Aramaic translator of the <i>Hafṭara</i> had the freedom to expound upon the verses read, similar to what is described in the New Testament (<i>Luke</i> 4:17–20).</i> in the synagogue of Tiberias: <i>Listen to this, you priests</i><sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Hosea 5:1" href="/Hosea.5.1"><i>Hos</i>. 5:1</a>.</i>, why do you not study Torah? Did I not give you 24 gifts<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">The 24 emoluments of priesthood; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Challah 4:4:17" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Challah.4.4.17"><i>Hallah</i> 4:11 (Note 146</a>) and the sources quoted there.</i>? They told him, they do not give us anything. <i>And hearken, House of Israel</i>, why do you not give the 24 gifts which I commanded you at Sinai? They told him, the king<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">The Patriarch was responsible for collecting the taxes due from the Jewish population in Palestine; there is an intentional ambiguity whether <i>king</i> refers to the Roman Emperor or the Davidic Patriarch.</i> takes everything. <i>Listen, king’s court, for yours are legal proceedings,</i> for you I did say, <i>these are the priests’ legal rights</i><sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:3" href="/Deuteronomy.18.3"><i>Deut</i>. 18:3</a>.</i>; in the future I shall sit in judgment over you, to stop them and to eliminate them from the world. Rebbi Jehudah the Prince heard this and became angry. He<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Yose the Maonite.</i> was afraid and fled. Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish went to appease him. They told him, Rabbi, he is a great man. He<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">The Patriarch.</i> asked them, would it be possible that he<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">Yose the Maonite.</i> could answer any question which I would ask him? They told him, yes. He asked him: What is that which is written<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Hosea 2:7" href="/Hosea.2.7"><i>Hos</i>. 2:7</a>.</i>: <i>For their mother whored</i>? Was our mother Sarah a whore? He answered, like daughter like mother<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">The text is confirmed by a Genizah fragment (M. Sokoloff, <i>The</i> <i>Genizah Fragments of Bereshit Rabba</i>, Jerusalem 1982, p. 167.) The reading in the printed editions of <i>Gen. rabba</i> הָכָא אָמְרֵי “here, they say” has to be rejected as <i>lectio facilior</i>.</i>, <i>like mother like daughter</i>, like generation like the prince, like the prince like the generation, like the altar like its priests. Cahana used to say<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">The text is confirmed by a Genizah fragment (M. Sokoloff, <i>The</i> <i>Genizah Fragments of Bereshit Rabba</i>, Jerusalem 1982, p. 167.) The reading in the printed editions of <i>Gen. rabba</i> הָכָא אָמְרֵי “here, they say” has to be rejected as <i>lectio facilior</i>.</i>, like the garden like its gardener. He told them, not only did he curse me once in my absence, but he cursed me three times in my presence! He asked him, what is that which is written<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">The Genizah fragment shows that instead of “like daughter like mother”, the text read כְּבַיִת כְּאוּמָּא “like dynasty like people, like generation like Prince” with the quote from the verse missing, a much more insulting formulation.</i>: <i>Anybody wanting to formulate a simile about you will state as follows: like mother like daughter;</i> was our mother Leah a prostitute since it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 16:44" href="/Ezekiel.16.44"><i>Ez</i>. 16:44</a>.</i>, <i>Dinah went out</i>? He told him, for it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 34:1" href="/Genesis.34.1"><i>Gen</i>. 34:1</a>, the starting verse for the sermon. In both Galilean and Babylonian Aramaic is the prostitute called נַפְקַת בָּרָא “the one who goes out.”</i>, <i>Leah went out towards him</i>. One identifies <i>going out with going out</i>.
Rebbi Ḥizqiah was walking on a road when he met a Samaritan who asked him, Rabbi, are you not the head of the Jews? He answered him, yes. He said to him, look what is written: <i>You certainly shall put a king over yourself</i><sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:15" href="/Deuteronomy.17.15"><i>Deut.</i> 17:15</a>.</i>. It does not say “I shall put”, but “you shall put”, you appoint him over yourself<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">For him the role of king and all appointed officers, including rabbis, is one of human convention, without religious meaning.</i>.

Chapter 3



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Money matters by three [judges]. Each party selects one judge and both together select a third, the words of Rebbi Meïr<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The “court” is a panel of arbitration. The parties have the option to go before the permanent court of the community but are not required to do so.</i>. But the Sages say, the two judges together select a third.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Money matters by three,” etc. Rebbi Zeˋira said, because he selected him, he will take care of his interests<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The arbitration judgment will be acceptable to all parties since each party expects his point of view to be forcefully represented. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 23a" href="/Sanhedrin.23a">Babli, 23a</a>, holds that the judgment will be just since each party is represented in the panel of arbitrators.</i>. What is Rebbi Meïr’s reason? So that all three should be chosen unanimously. What is the rabbis’ reason? “I do not trust you to select and let me sit with whom you want, but I and you shall select and empanel whom we want.<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The judges cannot be forced to sit with a third judge who is not agreeable to them.</i>” It is difficult for the rabbis: If one of them<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">If one of the original judges dies after the third has been chosen, his replacement who is chosen by one party only and is forced upon the two judges already empaneled. The situation preferred by Rebbi Meïr may develop also if the rabbis are followed.</i> dies, will not all three have been chosen through the choice of one person?

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Each of them disqualifies the other’s judge, the words of Rebbi Meïr. But the Sages say, when is this? If he brings proof that they are relatives<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Anybody not acceptable as a witness in a case is unacceptable as a judge; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.6.1">Mishnah 7</a>.</i> or disqualified<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">A felon or a person disqualified under the rules of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.5.1">Mishnah 6</a>.</i>. But if they are unexceptionable or qualified by the court<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">He passed bar examinations.</i> he cannot disqualify them.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Each of them disqualifies the other’s judge,” etc. So is the Mishnah: Each of them disqualifies the <i>other’s</i> judge, but not his own. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, they spoke about Syrian courts<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ἀρχεῖον, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 1:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.1.4.1"><i>Giṭṭin</i> 1:5, Note 107</a>.</i>, but not about following Torah law<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ad hoc</i> courts formed by ignorant people.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, even following Torah law<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">In a court of arbitration it makes no difference whether a judge be learned in the law or not.</i>. How was this said? Two people had a case in Antioch. One said to the other, I am accepting everything which Rebbi Joḥanan will decide<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Implying that he wants the case to be tried before the permanent court of the Academy in Tiberias.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan heard it and said, he is not empowered to tear apart his opponent<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">By forcing him to spend money and time in travelling from Antioch to Tiberias.</i>, but they shall hear their arguments there and if need be they should write and send the case before the rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">If one party wants to try a case out of town, the other party can appeal to the local permanent court to try the case in town, subject to submitting arguments in dispute to an out-of-town court of appeals; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 31b" href="/Sanhedrin.31b">Babli 31b</a>.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar said, if one says in Tiberias, but the other said in Sepphoris, one listens to the one who says in Tiberias<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Between the court of the Academy in Tiberias and the local court in Sepphoris, precedence must be given to the court of the Academy.</i>.
Can he forever disqualify and have the other appoint [a replacement]<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">According to R. Meïr, cannot one party endlessly drag out the case by objecting to the other’s choice of judges?</i>? Rebbi Zeˋira said, they taught this about subsidiaries<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">R. Meïr permits rejections without cause only for judges not learned in the law. The other party can cut short the selection process either by appointing a judge learned in the law or by removing the case to the permanent local court.</i>. Rebbi La said, what Rebbi Eleazar said about “one said in Tiberias, but the other said in Sepphoris,” is about those who live at the same place<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">And their village had no permanent local court.</i>, from where to [Sepphoris] it is seven <i>mil</i>, but from there to [Tiberias] it is nine <i>mil</i><sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">A small inconvenience must be accepted in order to bring the case before the most competent court nearby.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, one understands from this, that if two people had a case in Tiberias; one of them said in the permanent court, but the other said in an <i>ad hoc</i> court; one listens to the one who said in the permanent court<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Even though the Mishnah prescribes <i>ad hoc</i> courts of arbitration for monetary disputes, the party who wants to bring the case before the permanent rabbinic court of the community can force the opposing party to agree to his choice.</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Each of them disqualifies the other’s witnesses, the words of Rebbi Meïr. But the Sages say, when is this? If he brings proof that they are relatives<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Anybody not acceptable as a witness in a case is unacceptable as a judge; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.6.1">Mishnah 7</a>.</i> or disqualified<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">A felon or a person disqualified under the rules of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.5.1">Mishnah 6</a>.</i>. But if they are unexceptionable or qualified by the court<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">He passed bar examinations.</i> he cannot disqualify them.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Each of them disqualifies the other’s witnesses,” etc. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, so is the Mishnah: “His witness,” but not his witnesses<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Since a single witness is never decisive, one of the parties can claim that a single witness appearing for one of the parties was unacceptable as a witness (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.5.1">Mishnah 6</a>) without presenting formal proof. But if two witnesses are appearing together, only formal proof of ineligibility is admissible since “two or three witnesses are sufficient to confirm anything” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:15" href="/Deuteronomy.19.15"><i>Deut</i>. 19:15</a>).</i>. But Rebbi Joḥanan said, even his witnesses<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Even the credibility of a pair of witnesses can be attacked, under the conditions spelled out later in the Halakhah.</i>, as it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that a text similar to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 6:5-6" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.6.5-6">Tosephta 6:4</a> is intended. That Tosephta states first that “One always may add judges until judgment is rendered.” If after hearing the case, the arbitration panel is split, one judge voting for each side, but the third cannot decide how to vote, then each of the parties has to select an additional judge. In case of an evenly split court one always adds two new judges until a majority verdict is reached. After a lengthy discussion of the deadlines to be imposed for the presentation of witnesses, the Tosephta concludes: “Witnesses can always change their testimony before being cross-examined; after they were cross-examined they can no longer change their testimony; this is a matter of principle.” R. Johanan holds that as long as witnesses may change their testimony, their credibility can be attacked.</i>: “One always adds judges until judgment is rendered, and the judges may change their opinions. After judgment is rendered they may no longer change their opinions.” Rebbi Joḥanan agrees, that if these were the only ones<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">If the other side’s case depends on the testimony of one pair of witnesses, the other party has a monetary interest in seeing them disqualified. Therefore, the party to the dispute is barred from appearing as a witness against any of the witnesses since his testimony would be tainted (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 23b" href="/Sanhedrin.23b">Babli 23b</a>).</i>, he cannot disqualify them. Zeˋira said, he and a person from the street can team up to disqualify this testimony<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Zeˋira (in the Babli he is called <i>Zeˋiri</i>) explains what it means that “a party to a suit may disqualify the other side’s witness.” He and another witness may appear before the permanent communal court as witnesses to ask for a judgment which will disqualify the witness for the other side. Even if the other side has alternative witnesses, one should disqualify the party as a tainted witness. He is admitted only because the opposing party, by presenting a multitude of witnesses, cast doubt on the reliability of their own witnesses.</i>. Rebbi Ḥanina asked, does not one witness force an oath everywhere<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">Since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:15" href="/Deuteronomy.19.15"><i>Deut</i>. 19:15</a> spells out that “a single witness is insufficient for any conviction,” instead of saying that “a single witness is unacceptable,” it follows that a single witness is acceptable for anything short of a conviction. In money matters this implies that a single witness to a claim can force a party to swear to dispute the claim (<i>Sifry</i> <i>Deut</i>. 188; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 87b" href="/Ketubot.87b">Babli <i>Ketubot</i> 87b</a>).</i>? Rebbi Zeˋira said, by disqualification one can only be disqualified by a court<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">Only a permanent communal court is qualified to bar a person from being a witness, based on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.6.1">Mishnah 7</a>.</i>. A relative does not have to be disqualified by the court<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">A person can be an acceptable witness for anybody but his close relatives. This case of disability is a matter of showing facts; it does not need the formal proclamation of a court.</i>. Rava bar Binah said in the name of Rav: Three are like final judgment<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">This has nothing to do with the Mishnah; it refers to the Tosephta quoted earlier, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:3:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.3.2">Note 22</a>. As soon as a verdict is reached, one can no longer add judges. A verdict is rendered by three voting judges.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody said, I am accepting my father; I am accepting your father<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">These are disqualified by biblical law to serve as judges. They may be accepted on an arbitration panel as free choice of the parties.</i>; I am accepting three cowboys<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">They are illiterate and ignorant of the law.</i>; Rebbi Meïr says, he may change his opinion, but the Sages say, he may not change his opinion.<br>If one was obligated to swear to another, who asked him to make a vow “by his life”<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">He asked him to replace the oath by a vow not subject to dissolution. The claimant was afraid to be guilty of “putting a stumbling stone in the path of a blind man” if the other party was making a false oath because of him.</i>, Rebbi Meïr says, he may change his opinion<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">And require a formal oath.</i>, but the Sages say, he may not change his opinion.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “I am accepting my father,” etc. If somebody said, I am accepting your father, <sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">The discussion is based on R. Meïr’s point of view.</i> if he accepted in the presence of two others, he may retract<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">This is an agreement which according to R. Meïr can be rescinded.</i>; in the presence of three<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">If these three are persons qualified to act as judges, they act as a court and once a panel of arbitration is empanelled by a court it cannot be changed.</i>, he may not retract. Samuel said, as long as he did not take from one and give to the other<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">The context requires that one read: “but if he took from one and gave to the other, he may <i>not</i> retract.” This is Samuel’s opinion in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 24b" href="/Sanhedrin.24b">Babli, 24b</a>.</i>; but if he took from one and gave to the other, he may retract. Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish say even if he took from one and gave to the other, he may retract<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Their opinion is not mentioned in the Babli.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence is corrupt, and probably belongs to the next Halakhah.<br>A similar text is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 5:1" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.5.1">Tosephta 5:1</a>: “If somebody became obligated to swear and the other party instead required him to make a vow for his life, or by קייטא ובמקייטא דנקיטי R. Meïr and the Sages disagree whether he may retract his agreement.” D. Pardo declares the Tosephta text as unintelligible. <i>Arukh s.v</i>. קטו points to <i>Thr. r</i>. 1(30) <i>ad</i> 1:3 where קטו or קטיתא means “a bat”. This would give as meaning of the Tosephta: “be exposed to <i>the mace and the bat</i> in my hands.” The explanations in the standard commentaries are pure conjectures.</i>“If he hit him with a mace that he should agree; if he accepted he may renege.”
“If one was obligated to swear to another,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.4.1">Mishnah 4</a>.</i> Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said, if he told him, let your father tell it to me, then I shall have no claim on you<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The claimant tells the defendant that if the defendant’s father states that his son owes nothing, he will retract his suit. R. Meïr lets him change his mind.</i>. But if he told him: Let you father tell it, then I shall accept it; he seeks a pretext to confess to him<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">The defendant tells the claimant that if the claimant’s father states that the sum is due to his son, the defendant will pay. R. Hiyya sees this as a confession cloaked in a face-saving device; R. Meïr will agree with the Sages that this is irrevocable.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, even if he told him, let you father tell it to me, then I shall accept it. We never find that testimony be accepted from the mouth of a relative<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">While R. Hiyya bar Abba’s argument may be correct, his conclusion is not, since as a matter of principle we never accept a relative’s testimony to be determining in law.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The following are disqualified: The dice-player<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Since the player with honest dice will lose as often as he wins, he cannot possibly live off the income from his wagers. A gambler living off his gambling by necessity must be dishonest.</i>, the lender on interest<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">The lender on interest to Jews shows that he is willing to break the law for monetary gain; he will be willing to commit perjury for a fee.</i>, participants in pigeon contests<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Or any sport where money is made by betting.</i>, dealers in sabbatical produce<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">He is willing to break the law for monetary gain.</i>, and slaves<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Since a slave has no <i>persona</i> in law, he could commit perjury with impunity.</i>. Rebbi Simeon said, earlier they were listing harvesters of sabbatical produce; but since the increase of oppressors they returned to list only dealers in sabbatical produce<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Biblical law requires that the produce of fields in a Sabbatical year be abandoned, available to anybody. Therefore, originally the owner of a field who harvested the field for his own use was branded as a scofflaw disqualified as witness or judge. But when Palestine was turned into a Roman province and, after the war of Bar Kokhba, the <i>annona</i>, contribution of produce, was imposed yearly, it was necessary to permit harvesting in the Sabbatical year in order to deliver the <i>annona</i> and prevent confiscation of the land by the government. Therefore, only actual trade in sabbatical produce was sinful, not harvesting.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah said, when? If he has no profession but this; but if he has another profession, he is qualified<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">An occasional gambler and occasional trader in sabbatical produce are qualified.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The following are disqualified: The dice-player,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Parallels to the first part of this Halakhah are found in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Rosh Hashanah 1:7:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Rosh_Hashanah.1.7.2-6"><i>Roš Haššanah</i> 1:9</a> and <i>Ševuot</i> 7:4.</i> The dice player is the one who plays with small stones<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ψῆφος “pebble, cube; the stones used for mosaics and tokens used in elections.” Rashi defines as “marbles”.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Similar texts are in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 25b" href="/Sanhedrin.25b">Babli 25b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 5:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.5.2">Tosephta 5:2</a>.</i>“Not only the player with stones, even one who plays with shells of nuts or pomegranates is not accepted unless he break his stones or tear up his IOU’s<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">This should be part of a separate sentence, as in the parallel Yerushalmi texts, Babli, and Tosephta.<br>The lender on interest cannot repent unless he tear up his IOU’s and repent in complete repentance.</i>, and be checked out and repent in complete repentance.”
“Participants in pigeon contests.<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel sources show that there is a sentence missing here: “This is one who bets on pigeons.” Organizing pigeon contests is not dishonest, but making a living by betting on animal contests would be impossible for honest betters.</i>” <sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Similar texts are in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 25b" href="/Sanhedrin.25b">Babli 25b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 5:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.5.2">Tosephta 5:2</a>.</i> Whether one bets on pigeons or bets on any other domesticated animal, wild animal, or bird, he is not accepted unless he break his tools of the catch and repent in complete repentance.
“Dealers in sabbatical produce.” <sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Similar texts are in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 25b" href="/Sanhedrin.25b">Babli 25b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 5:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.5.2">Tosephta 5:2</a>.</i>“Who is a dealer in sabbatical produce? One who sits idle all the years of a sabbatical cycle. As soon as the sabbatical year starts, be becomes active and trades in sabbatical produce. One does not accept them before another sabbatical year starts and he can be checked out that he repented in complete repentance.” It was stated: Rebbi Yose says, two sabbatical periods. <sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 5:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.5.2">Tosephta 5:2</a>.</i>“Rebbi Nehemiah says, repentance in money, not repentance in words; that he say to them, here are 200 denars, distribute them to the poor, for I earned them from forbidden produce.” <sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">A similar text in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 25b" href="/Sanhedrin.25b">Babli, 25b</a>.</i> They added shepherds, extortionists, and any who are suspect in money matters, that their testimony be invalid. Rebbi Abbahu said, only shepherds of small animals<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Sheep and goats which are destructive of vegetation in agricultural areas. Herders of sheep and goats are acceptable only in regions devoid of agriculture. The Babli notes that robbers and other felons are excluded by biblical law (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:2" href="/Exodus.23.2"><i>Ex</i>. 23:2</a>). It concludes that Mishnah and <i>baraitot</i> refer to actions classified as extortion or robbery only by rabbinical standards.</i>.
Rav Huna said: Who is the Tanna of “participants in pigeon contests”? Rebbi Eliezer, as we have stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Eduyot 2:7" href="/Mishnah_Eduyot.2.7">Mishnah <i>Idiut</i> 2:7</a>, formulated as testimony in R. Aqiba’s court in the name of R. Eliezer.</i>: “Participants in pigeon contests are disqualified from testimony.” Rebbi Mana said before Rebbi Yose: Is that statement in <i>Sanhedrin</i> Rebbi Eliezer’s<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">If this represents a minority opinion, it should have been labelled as such.</i>? He told him, it is everybody’s opinion. <sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">There is a sentence missing here. found in <i>Roš Haššanah</i>: What is meant by “it is everybody’s opinion? That is what R. Yose meant to say:”. It makes clear that one refers to the statement of the Amora R. Yose. The entire discussion does not refer to the Mishnah in <i>Sanhedrin</i> but the one in <i>Roš Haššanah</i>. The text in <i>Roš Haššanah</i> has to be considered as the original.</i> So said Rebbi Yose: We knew that he was disqualified for testimony in money matters. What does he<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">The witnesses mentioned in the Mishnah <i>Roš Haššanah</i>.</i> come to testify about? For as he is disqualified in money matters, so he is disqualified to testify in criminal trials. The witnesses for the New Moon are held to the standards of criminal trials, as we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Rosh Hashanah 1:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Rosh_Hashanah.1.7.1">Mishnah <i>Roš Haššanah</i> 1:10</a>.</i>: “This is the principle: Any testimony for which a woman is not qualified, they<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">The people disqualified in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.5.1">Mishnah <i>Sanhedrin</i> 3:6</a>.</i> are not qualified for.” Who stated this? The rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">In the anonymous Mishnah.</i>! Do the rabbis follow Rebbi Eliezer? They agree with him and disagree with him. Rebbi Huna<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Roš Haššanah</i>: R. Jonah. In <i>Ševuot</i>: R. Huna.</i> in the name of Rav Huna said: It follows Rebbi Eliezer in everything. It turns out that this disagreement<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">R. Eliezer and the rabbis, R. Meïr and R. Yose (the Tanna).</i> parallels another disagreement, as it was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Makkot 1:6" href="/Tosefta_Makkot.1.6"><i>Tosephta Makkot</i> 1:11</a>, in the name of R. Jehudah (student of R. Eliezer’s student.)</i>: A perjured witness is disqualified for any and all testimony required by the Torah, the words of Rebbi Meïr. Rebbi Yose said, when has this been said? When he was found perjured in criminal matters. But if he was found perjured in money matters, he is disqualified only from that particular testimony. It turns out that Rebbi Yose parallels the rabbis and Rebbi Meïr Rebbi Eliezer.
<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">This and the following paragraphs are from <i>Ševiˋit</i> 4:2, Notes 20–34. A few passages are reformulated.</i>“Rebbi Simeon says, earlier they were listing harvesters of sabbatical produce; but since the increase of oppressors they returned to list only dealers in sabbatical produce. Rebbi Jehudah said, when? If he has no profession but this; but if he has another profession, he is qualified.” How is this implemented? If he was sitting idle all the years of the sabbatical cycle but when the Sabbatical began he became active and traded in sabbatical produce. If at the same time he is engaged in another occupation, he is qualified; otherwise he is disqualified. But if he was working in his profession all the years of the sabbatical cycle and when the Sabbatical began he became active and traded in sabbatical produce, even if he has no other profession on the side he is qualified. Rebbi Abba bar Zavda, Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: Practice follows Rebbi Jehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 26b" href="/Sanhedrin.26b">Babli 26b</a>.</i> of our Mishnah. Rebbi Abba bar Zavda was praised for formulating the tradition in the name of a person younger than himself.
Rebbi Ḥiyya stated restrictively. How is this implemented? If he was working in his profession all the years of the sabbatical cycle but when the Sabbatical began he became active and traded in sabbatical produce. Even if he has another profession on the side he is disqualified. This is not what Rebbi Abba bar Zavda, Rebbi Abbahu said in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: Practice follows Rebbi Jehudah of our Mishnah. Rebbi Abba bar Zavda was praised for formulating the tradition in the name of a person younger than himself. Here also should it be so? Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, there the government is not oppressive, here the government is oppressive.
When the government was oppressing the first time, Rebbi Yannai instructed to plough a single ploughing<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 26a" href="/Sanhedrin.26a">Babli 26a</a>. This dates the change in Roman taxation policy to the end of the Severan dynasty. For הסטו cf. <i>Ševiˋit</i> 4:3, Note 23.</i>. An apostate was passing by; he saw the putting up of the harrow. He said to them, hey you! Is it permitted for you to plough? Is it permitted for you to put up the harrow?
Rebbi Jacob bar Zavdi said, I asked before Rebbi Abbahu: Did not [Rebbi] Zeˋira and Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rebbi Yannai, Rebbi Jeremiah, Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Yehoṣadaq, say that they voted on the upper floor of the Niṭzah house in Lydda: About all the Torah, if a Gentile tells a Jew to transgress any commandment of the Torah except those concerning idolatry, incest and adultery, and murder, he should transgress and not be killed<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 74a" href="/Sanhedrin.74a">Babli 74a</a>.</i>. That is in private, but in public he should not follow him even for the slightest commandment, as exemplified by Pappos and his brother Julianus to whom they gave water in a colored glass and they did not accept. He said, they do not intend to lead you to apostasy, they only want to collect <i>annona</i>. What means “in public”? The rabbis of Caesarea say ten, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:32" href="/Leviticus.22.32"><i>Lev</i>. 22:32</a>.</i>: <i>I shall be sanctified in the midst of the Children of Israel</i>.
They saw the young Rebbi Bina collecting donkey’s dung on the Sabbath. Rebbi Jonah and Rebbi Yose permitted baking for Ursicinus on the Sabbath. Rebbi Mana said, I asked before my father Rebbi Jonah, did not Rebbi Zeˋira and Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rebbi Yannai, Rebbi Jeremiah, Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Yehoṣadaq, say that they voted on the upper floor of the Niṭzah house in Lydda, etc.? He said, he did not intend to lead you to apostasy, he only wanted to eat warm bread.. What means “in public”? The rabbis of Caesarea say ten, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:32" href="/Leviticus.22.32"><i>Lev</i>. 22:32</a>.</i>: <i>I shall be sanctified in the midst of the Children of Israel</i>.
Rebbi Abinna asked Rebbi Immi: Are Gentiles required to sanctify the Name? He answered him: <i>I shall be sanctified in the midst of the Children of Israel</i>. Israel are required to sanctify the Name; the Gentiles are not required to sanctify the Name. Rebbi Nissai in the name of Rebbi Eleazar understood it from the following: <i>May the Eternal forgive His servant for this</i>, etc. Israel are required to sanctify the Name; the Gentiles are not required to sanctify the Name.
Rebbi Abba bar Zemina was working as a tailor for somebody in Rome. He brought him carcass meat and told him to eat. He said to him, I will not eat. He said to him, eat! Otherwise I shall kill you. He said to him, if you have to kill, kill, for I shall not eat carcass meat. He said to him, certainly you should know that I would have killed you, had you eaten. Either one is a Jewish Jew or an Aramean Aramean. Rebbi Mana said, if Rebbi Abba bar Zemina had understood the words of the rabbis, he would have been gone.
<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">The paragraph is a reformulation of one in <i>Ševiˋit</i> 4:2, Notes 35–37. The prohibition to work after the Sabbatical a field which was improved in the Sabbatical is purely rabbinical.</i> If somebody improved [his field] today, what is the rule? Rebbi Jeremiah was of the opinion that when the reason disappeared, the ordinance is void. Rebbi Yose was of the opinion that even if the reason disappeared, the ordinance stands until another court abolishes it. <sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Ševiˋit</i> 4:2, Note 43, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:3:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.3.2"><i>Ketubot</i> 9:3 Notes 109–110</a>. The connection with the preceding is a leniency of R. Jeremiah opposed by R. Yose.</i> Similarly, how does an owner acquire his own produce in a Sabbatical year? Rebbi Jeremiah wanted to say, from the moment he put it into his vessel. Rebbi Yose was of the opinion that even if he put it into his vessel he did not acquire, for he thinks that it is his but it is not his.
When Proclus<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Grätz (Geschichte der Juden<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup> p. 314) reads <i>Proculus</i> and identifies him as an officer of Ursicinus’s army (under the emperor Gallus.)</i> entered Sepphoris, Rebbi Mana instructed the bakers to present their wares in the market. The rabbis of Newe<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Sometimes called <i>Niniveh,</i> a place <i>Nova</i> in the Golan.</i> instructed to bake leavened on Passover.
<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">The old Midrashim, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Vayikra Rabbah 33:6" href="/Vayikra_Rabbah.33.6"><i>Lev. r</i>. 33:6</a>, shorter <i>Cant. r. ad</i> 2:14, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kohelet Rabbah 8:2" href="/Kohelet_Rabbah.8.2"><i>Eccl.</i> <i>r</i>. <i>ad</i> 8:2</a> quote this in the name of the older R. Levy. Possibly there is no claim of originality asserted here for R. Yose ben R. Abun, three generations after R. Levy, but the sermon is quoted as objection to the lenient rulings mentioned before.</i> Rebbi Yose ben Abun said: <i>I shall keep the King’s sayings</i><sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 8:2" href="/Ecclesiastes.8.2"><i>Eccl.</i> 8:2</a>.</i>, Who told me at Sinai <i>I am the Eternal, your God</i><sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 20:2" href="/Exodus.20.2"><i>Ex</i>. 20:2</a>.</i>, <i>on the pronouncement</i><sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 8:2" href="/Ecclesiastes.8.2"><i>Eccl.</i> 8:2</a>.</i>, <i>you shall not have other gods before Me</i><sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 20:3" href="/Exodus.20.3"><i>Ex</i>. 20:3</a>.</i>, <i>of God’s oath</i><sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 8:2" href="/Ecclesiastes.8.2"><i>Eccl.</i> 8:2</a>.</i>, <i>do not take the Name of the Eternal, your God, in vain</i><sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 20:7" href="/Exodus.20.7"><i>Ex</i>. 20:7</a>.</i>. In this matter we come together, this man<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">The speaker.</i> and this dog<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Nebuchadnezzar, who is said to have barked like a dog during his spell of insanity, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Vayikra Rabbah 33:6" href="/Vayikra_Rabbah.33.6"><i>Lev. r</i>. 33(6</a>).</i> are both equal.
Rav Jehudah in the name of Rav: Practice follows Rebbi Jehudah.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The following are the relatives:<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Since women are barred from giving formal testimony, only the males are enumerated.</i> His brother, his father’s brother and his mother’s brother<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">The father’s brother is a relative; so is the father himself. He is mentioned in some Mishnah mss.</i>, his sister’s husband, his father’s sister’s husband and his mother’s sister’s husband, his father-in-law, and his brother-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">אֲגִיס is the Syriac form; the usual Babylonian is גִּיס. In Syriac the word denotes the wife’s sister’s husband. This is the meaning presumed in the Halakhah, but here it includes the wife’s brother.</i>; these, their sons and sons-in-law, but his steps<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">His wife’s son from a previous marriage.</i> alone. Rebbi Yose said, this is Rebbi Aqiba’s teaching; but the original Mishnah was: His uncle and his uncle’s son<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Quoted as relative <i>par excellence</i> in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 25:29" href="/Leviticus.25.29"><i>Lev</i>. 25:29</a>.</i>, and anybody in line to inherit from him, and any related to him at that moment<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Any man married to a woman who is a possible heir (as defined in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 8:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.8.1.1">Mishnah <i>Bava batra</i> 8:1</a>) is barred to act as witness. At the dissolution of the marriage, by death or divorce, the relationship is terminated.</i>. If he had been related but became unrelated, he is qualified. Rebbi Jehudah says, even if his daughter had died but he had children from him, he remains a relative<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Since the grandchildren are possible heirs, they are barred from being witnesses, and so is their father. This holds true even if the grandchildren all are female.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The following are the relatives,” etc. Since we have stated “his brother,” why does one have to state “his father’s brother”<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Two unexpressed principles are underlying the discussion. The first is symmetry: If A is disqualified for B, then B is disqualified for A. The second one is that for the definition of “relative”, there is no difference between male and female.<br>[It has to be noted that for the definition of incestuous relations, both principles are accepted by Sadducees and rejected by Pharisees. The father’s sister is biblically forbidden (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:12" href="/Leviticus.18.12"><i>Lev</i>. 18:12</a>); the brother’s daughter, for whom the husband would be the father’s brother, is biblically forbidden by Sadducees and Karaites, permitted (and recommended) by Pharisees and rabbinic Jews. The Midrash which asserts that Sarah was not Abraham’s paternal half-sister but his niece (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:7:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.7.8"><i>Yebamot</i> 10:17 Note 210</a>) is more an anti-Sadducee polemic than a genuine interpretation of the biblical text.]<br>Since the Mishnah states that sons and in-laws of disqualified relations are also disqualified, the mention of the brother implies that the nephew is also disqualified. But for the nephew, the original person is the father’s brother; why does he have to be mentioned?</i>? To include the son-in-law’s son-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah by implication disqualifies the cousin (or cousin’s husband); this disqualification is not implied by the disqualification of the brother (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 28a" href="/Sanhedrin.28a">Babli 28a</a>).</i>.
“His father’s brother”. Since we have stated “his father’s brother,” why does one have to state “his mother’s brother”<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 28a" href="/Sanhedrin.28a">Babli, 28a</a>, the mention of the mother’s brother is taken as proof of the second rule of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.6.1">Note 92</a>. The same is implied here.</i>? To include the son-in-law’s son-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">The same argument as before, to disqualify cousins from the mother’s side.</i>.
“His mother’s brother”. Since we have stated “his sister’s husband,” why does one have to state “his father’s sister’s husband”<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">This question presupposes that any person disqualified for A also is disqualified for A’s son (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 28a" href="/Sanhedrin.28a">Babli 28a</a>). A’s sister’s husband is the father’s sister’s husband for A’s son.</i>? To include the son-in-law’s son-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">The same argument as before, to disqualify cousins from the mother’s side.</i>.
“His father’s sister’s husband”. Since we have stated “his father’s sister’s husband,” why does one have to state “his mother’s sister’s husband”? To include the son-in-law’s son-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">This probably is a scribal error, copied from the preceding paragraph. The only reasonable answer would be: to show that in matters of disqualification as witnesses, relations by females are the equivalent of relations by males.</i>.
“His mother’s sister’s husband”. But did we not state: “his stepson alone”<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Excluding the stepson’s wife and his descendants and in-laws.</i>? Rav said, if his mother-in-law’s son-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Husband of his father-in-law’s stepdaughter.</i> is forbidden, then certainly his stepdaughter’s husband<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Since it was established that females be treated like males in this matter, the status of the mother-in-law is that of the father-in-law, and her children and children-in-law also are disqualified. Let A be the person in question, W his wife, F, M, his father and mother, D the mother-in-law’s daughter from another man, and H the daughter’s husband. The relationship between A and H can be given by a diagram:<br>&lt;figure_pg125_01&gt;<br>On the other hand, the relationship between a man and his stepdaughter’s husband can be described by<br>&lt;figure_pg125_02&gt;<br>This graph clearly is a subgraph of the preceding (up to labelling, replacing F,M by A,W). Therefore, if the first graph describes a disqualifying relationship, <i>a fortiori</i> the second also describes one.</i>. Explain it that she has sons and sons-in-law from him<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Since the preceding argument leads to a result contradicting the Mishnah, the premiss of the argument is shown to be false. The only siblings of a person’s wife disqualified as witnesses are her full or paternal siblings. “She” in this sentence is the mother-in-law.</i>.
“His brother-in-law”. Some Tannaïm state: Including sons and sons-in-law; but some Tannaïm state: Excluding sons and sons-in-law. He who said, including sons and sons-in law, from her<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">His wife’s sister.</i>. But he who said, excluding sons and sons-in law, from another family<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Another wife. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 28b" href="/Sanhedrin.28b">Babli, 28b</a>, there is a dispute whether “he alone” refers to the stepson or <i>any</i> brother-in-law.</i>.
Rav went to sell hides<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Text and meaning are in doubt. One might read מֵיתְרֵי מְשָׁכִין “to span hides”; this does not make much sense. <i>Nimmuqe Yosef</i>(Commentary to Alfasi, 6b in the Wilna ed.) reads נְפַק לְמַזְבַּן מַשְׁכּוֹן “went to sell a pledge”. This agrees with the following possessive, לר׳ חייה. The parallel source in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 28" href="/Sanhedrin.28">Babli, 28a/b</a> reads: רב איקלע למזבן גוילי “Rav happened to be selling parchment.”</i> for the elder Rebbi Ḥiyya. He passed by a place where he found Rebbi Joḥanan sitting and asking: We have stated, “his stepson alone.” What is the situation of his stepson’s wife, his stepdaughter’s husband? A woman is like her husband and the husband is like his wife<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 28b" href="/Sanhedrin.28b">Babli 28b</a> treats the two statements as different; one does not necessarily imply the other.</i>. Therefore, the situation of his stepson’s wife is that of his stepson, and the husband is like his wife<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">A person is disqualified from being a witness for or against his stepson’s wife or stepdaughter’s husband, but not for or against the stepchild’s children or children-in-law.</i>.
Rav Ḥisda asked: If the third generation permitted the first generation’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">The brother’s children are disqualified by the Mishnah. What about the grand-children?</i>? Is Phineas’s wife permitted to Moses<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">The question is formulated as one of permitted marriages. This does not fit the context, since that problem was discussed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:4:2-10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.4.2-10"><i>Yebamot</i> 2:4</a>. With all commentators one has to read the question whether Moses be qualified to testify for the wife of Phineas, his brother’s grandson.</i>? Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, one accepts the second and third generations with difficulty<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">A court will accept testimony from persons one generation removed from the Mishnaic disqualifications only if no other witnesses are available.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, even with ease<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">Any testimony not disqualified by the Mishnah is qualified.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the last part of the Mishnah, the statement of R. Jehudah.</i> As the following: A brother-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">The husband of one of Rav Huna’s sisters and one of the sisters had died. He had been a relative but now became unrelated.</i> of Rav Huna’s had a case with some person. He said, I am accepting anything which Rav Huna will decide<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Since Rav Huna was no longer a relative, he was qualified to be a judge.</i>. Rav Huna heard it and said, this is it<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">The statement of the Mishnah.</i>. I know that just as they said for the preceding generations, so it is for the following<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah refers to the relation between a person and his son-in-law, two different generations. Since R. Jehudah states that if there be grandchildren, the son-in-law remains related, it follows that the anonymous Tanna holds that in all cases the son-in-law becomes unrelated at the moment his marriage is dissolved by death or divorce.</i>. Rav Jehudah in the name of Rav: Practice follows Rebbi Jehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">This is also quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 28b" href="/Sanhedrin.28b">Babli, 28b</a>, as Rav’s opinion. The school of Samuel, represented by Rav Nahman, holds that practice does not follow R. Jehudah. Rav Nahman’s rulings have the status of Supreme Court decisions in Babylonia.</i>.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah is a continuation of R. Jehudah’s statement.</i> The lover and the hater<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Are disqualified as witnesses.</i>. The lover, that is the best man. The hater, anyone who did not talk to him for three days because of ill-will. They told him, Israel are not suspected of this<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">To testify falsely because of this. But a judge emotionally involved with one of the parties is disqualified (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 29a" href="/Sanhedrin.29a">Babli 29a</a>).</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The lover and the hater,” etc. Rebbi Tevelai, Rebbi Abinna in the name of Rav: They stated this for the seven days of wedding festivities<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">The best men are disqualified only during the festivities. Rav’s opinion is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 29a" href="/Sanhedrin.29a">Babli, 29a</a>, where a later authority restricts R. Jehudah’s rule to the wedding day only.</i>.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> How does one check out the witnesses? One brings them to court and instills fear into them<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Since witnesses are not interrogated under oath, they have to be informed of the gravity of the crime of perjury.</i>, then removes them<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">This also is the reading of Alfasi and Rosh. Maimonides and the Venice text of the Babli read: One removes everybody.</i> but retains the greatest among them<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">The witnesses are interrogated separately.</i>. One says to him, tell why you know that this person owes to the other one. If he said, he himself confessed to me that he owes the money<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">He might have said this either to establish credit or to publicize his needy status in order that no public service should be required of him.</i>, or another person told me that he owes it<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">Hearsay has to be disregarded.</i>, he did not say anything until he says, before us<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">At least two witnesses, whose word confirms everything by biblical standards.</i> he confessed to him that he owed him 200 denar.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “How does one check out the witnesses,” etc. Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Johanan: If he had intended to appoint them as witnesses, their testimony is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">Testimony that the debtor admitted to the debt (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.8.1">Note 126</a>) is to be accepted if the debtor explicitly stated that he made the statement to his listeners for the purpose of testimony. There must be two listeners (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:2:12" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.2.12">Halakhah 10, Note 180</a>).</i>.
How does one judge? The judges are sitting<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">They have to sit during the entire proceedings.</i>, the parties are standing, and the claimant starts first with his words, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">A misquote from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 24:14" href="/Exodus.24.14"><i>Ex.</i> 24:14</a>.</i>: <i>He who has something to say shall present before you</i><sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 6:3-4" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.6.3-4">Tosephta 6:3</a>.</i>.
From where that the burden of proof is on the claimant? Rebbi Crispus in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel: <i>Shall present before you</i>, shall present his proofs<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 46b" href="/Bava_Kamma.46b">Babli <i>Bava qamma</i> 46b</a>.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">A slight reformulation of a text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 12:6:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.12.6.3"><i>Yebamot</i> 12:7, Notes 123–124</a>.</i> Rebbi Joḥanan asked, in the case of a sister-in-law, who runs after whom? Rebbi Eleazar answered: <i>His sister-in-law shall come to the gate</i><sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:7" href="/Deuteronomy.25.7"><i>Deut</i>. 25:7</a>.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, Rebbi Eleazar taught me correctly.
Rebbi Berekhiah and Rebbi Ḥelbo, Rebbi Abba in the name of Rebbi Yannai: The claimant claims, the respondent responds, and the judge decides. Rebbi Simon said, the judge has to repeat their arguments<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">To give each party the opportunity to complain that its arguments were not understood correctly by the judges.</i>, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 3:23" href="/I_Kings.3.23"><i>1K</i>. 3:23</a>.</i>: <i>The king</i><sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Solomon, acting as judge.</i> <i>said, this one says, my son is the living and yours is the dead one,</i> etc.
When Rav Huna saw that witnesses said exactly the same, he was investigating<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">Witnesses using exactly the same language either bear false witness or they went over their testimony beforehand. Then they can be counted only as one witness, not as the biblically required two.</i>. When he saw them essentially identical, he determined the common element<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">He summarized the common points.</i>. Rav Huna made light of a judge who said, “accept a single witness,” but they should say it themselves<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">Two independent witnesses are absolutely necessary only in criminal trials. Civil suits may be determined on the basis of documents or, with the agreement of the parties, single witnesses. But accepting a single witness cannot be suggested by the court.</i>. When Rav Huna realized an argument in favor of a person who himself did not know it, he guided him<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Since the parties are not supposed to consult lawyers, the judge may by a Socratic dialogue with the parties steer one of the parties to a certain argument which the latter did not see before.</i>, following<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 31:8" href="/Proverbs.31.8"><i>Prov</i>. 31:8</a>.</i> <i>open your mouth for the dumb</i>.
Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: He who hides his witnesses behind a wall did not do anything<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 29a" href="/Sanhedrin.29a">Babli 29a</a>.</i>. As in this case: A man happened to prepare food for a meal<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ἄριστον.</i>. He said to another, give me what you owe me. That one answered, yes. When he rose, he told him, I do not owe you anything. He answered, I have witnesses. The other said, I said that only in order not to spoil your food. The case came before Rebbi Immi, who said, this is what Rebbi Joḥanan said, he who hides his witnesses behind a wall did not do anything<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">What a person says not in the presence of witnesses must be interpreted following the speaker’s explanation.</i>.

Halakhah 9

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One calls in the second [witness] and examines him. If their testimonies are found consistent, one argues the case. Two<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Of the judges.</i> say not guilty<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">Since one deals with civil cases, this means that the claim is rejected.</i> and one says guilty, he is not guilty. Two say guilty and one says not guilty, he is guilty. One says not guilty, one says guilty, and one says “I do not know”, they shall add judges. Even if two say not guilty or guilty but one says “I do not know”, they shall add judges<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">Since the judge who does not vote is considered absent, judgment cannot be given by two judges. There must be three voting judges for the verdict to stand..</i>
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “One calls in the second [witness],” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">There are two parallels to this text. The one in <i>Ševuˋot</i> 4:1 is almost identical with the present text; the one in <i>Yoma</i> 6:1 is slightly rewritten (or changed in transmission.) The <i>Ševuˋot</i> text seems to be the original of most of the Halakhah.<br>As explained in the author’s <i>Logical problems in Jewish tradition</i> (in: Confrontations with Judaism, ed. Ph. Longworth, London 1966, pp. 171–196, mainly p. 174), talmudic interpretation of pentateuchal verses operates on a <i>principle of definiteness</i>: The language always is definite. Since the sequence of integers has a smallest but no largest element, an indefinite plural means “two”. Therefore, the explicit mention of “two” always implies some special meaning.</i><i>Rams</i><sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 16:5" href="/Leviticus.16.5"><i>Lev</i>. 16:5</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 16:7" href="/Leviticus.16.7">7</a>,8 speaking of the rams used in the service of the Day of Atonement.</i>, the minimum of rams are two. Why does the verse say <i>two</i>? That both be equal<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 62b" href="/Yoma.62b">Babli <i>Yoma</i> 62b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Acharei Mot" href="/Sifra,_Acharei_Mot"><i>Sifra</i> <i>Ahare Parašah</i> 2(1</a>).</i>.
<i>Sheep</i>, the minimum of sheep are two. Why does the verse say <i>two</i>? That both be equal<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">The daily sacrifice required <i>two sheep</i> (<i>Ex</i>. 27:38, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 28:3" href="/Numbers.28.3"><i>Num</i>. 28:3</a>). In both verses, the numeral is שְׁנַיִם (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 62b" href="/Yoma.62b">Babli <i>Yoma</i> 62b</a>).</i>.
The minimum of <i>birds</i> are two. Why does the verse say <i>two</i>? that both be equal<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">The birds required for the purification of the person healed from skin disease, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 14:4" href="/Leviticus.14.4"><i>Lev</i>. 14:4</a>. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 62b" href="/Yoma.62b">Babli <i>Yoma</i> 62b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Negaim 14:1" href="/Mishnah_Negaim.14.1">Mishnah <i>Negaˋim</i> 14:1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Braita d'Rabbi Yishmael 11" href="/Sifra,_Braita_d'Rabbi_Yishmael.11"><i>Sifra</i> <i>Meṣora</i>ˋ Introduction 11</a>.</i>. The minimum of <i>trumpets</i> are two. Why does the verse say <i>two</i>? that both be equal<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">The trumpets to be sounded at the time of sacrifices, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 10:2" href="/Numbers.10.2"><i>Num</i>. 10:2</a>. <i>Sifry</i> <i>Num</i>. 74.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥaggai objected to Rebbi Yasa. Is there not written: <i>The two men shall stand</i><sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:17" href="/Deuteronomy.19.17"><i>Deut</i>. 19:17</a>. The verse can be read either as referring to the parties in a lawsuit or to the witnesses in a civil or criminal suit. Cf. Babli <i>Ševu</i>ˋ<i>ot</i> 30a.</i>? Now, is not two the minimum of “men”? Why does the verse say <i>two</i>? That both be equal? But it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:17" href="/Deuteronomy.24.17"><i>Deut</i>. 24:17</a>.</i>: <i>Do not bend the lawsuit of the proselyte, the orphan</i>, … That means that a proselyte can have a lawsuit against one who is not a proselyte, an orphan may have a lawsuit against one who is not an orphan. Then why is there written <i>two</i>? It is free to be combined and to infer from it an <i>equal cut</i><sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:1:20" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.1.20"><i>Berakhot</i> 1:1 Note 70</a>, <i>Nedarim</i> 1 Notes 18,159, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nazir 4:1:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nazir.4.1.4"><i>Nazir</i> 4:1 Note 23</a>, <i>Logical problems</i> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:9:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.9.2">Note 150</a>) pp. 185–186. Two identical expressions, written in two different connections, each of which is <i>free</i>, i. e., not used for an inference not otherwise possible, can be used to transfer rules from one connection to the other. This hermeneutical principle is accepted by all rabbinic schools.</i>. It is said here <i>two</i> and it is said there <i>two men were left</i><sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 11:27" href="/Numbers.11.27"><i>Num.</i> 11:27</a>. Since Eldad and Medad are mentioned by name in the verse, it is obvious that two men are meant.</i>. Since there one speaks of men but not women, also here men but not women nor underaged.<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Only people potentially acceptable for Moses’s council of 70 Elders.</i> From this we learn that a woman may not be a judge<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 30a" href="/Shevuot.30a">Babli <i>Ševuˋot</i> 30a</a>, <i>Sifry</i> <i>Deut</i>. 190.</i> and may not be a witness.
Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun in the name of Rav Joseph. It is said here <i>two</i> and it is said there<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:15" href="/Deuteronomy.19.15"><i>Deut</i>. 19:15</a>. The verse explicitly speaks of witnesses.</i> <i>two</i>. Since there it must be by the testimony of two witnesses, also here by the testimony of two witnesses. Then why does the verse say <i>two</i>? Lest one of them be standing while the other be sitting; one says everything he has to say, but to the other one says, make your statement short<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 30a" href="/Shevuot.30a">Babli <i>Ševuˋot</i> 30a</a>, <i>Sifry</i> <i>Deut</i>. 190.</i>.
