Rebbi Jehudah said, I heard that if the judge wants to let both of them sit, he may tell them to sit down<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 30a" href="/Shevuot.30a">Babli <i>Ševuˋot</i> 30a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 6:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.6.2">Tosephta <i>Sanhedrin</i> 6:2</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Kedoshim, Chapter 4 4" href="/Sifra,_Kedoshim,_Chapter_4.4"><i>Sifra</i> <i>Qedošim</i> <i>Pereq</i> 4(4</a>).</i>. Rebbi Ismael says, one says to him,<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">A person appearing in court dressed better than usual.</i> either you dress as he is dressed or pay him to be dressed as you are.
Rebbi Abba said in the name of Rav Huna: The witnesses have to stand while testifying, for it is said: <i>the two men shall stand</i>. Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: Also the parties have to stand at the moment the verdict is given, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:17" href="/Deuteronomy.19.17"><i>Deut</i>. 19:17</a>. The verse can be read either as referring to the parties in a lawsuit or to the witnesses in a civil or criminal suit. Cf. Babli <i>Ševu</i>ˋ<i>ot</i> 30a.</i>: <i>who have the quarrel before the Eternal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 30a" href="/Shevuot.30a">Babli <i>Ševuˋot</i> 30a</a>.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">This section also has an almost identical copy in <i>Ševuot</i> 4:1.</i> It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:16" href="/Deuteronomy.24.16"><i>Deut</i>. 24:16</a>.</i>: <i>Fathers shall not be killed because of sons</i>. Is it not already written, <i>each one should be killed for his own crime</i><sup class="footnote-marker">167,</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:16" href="/Deuteronomy.24.16"><i>Deut</i>. 24:16</a>.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">A slight misquote.</i>? Why does the verse say, <i>fathers shall not be killed because of sons</i>? Fathers shall not be killed on the testimony of sons, and sons shall not be killed on testimony of fathers<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 17b" href="/Sanhedrin.17b">Babli 17b</a>, <i>Sifry</i> <i>Deut</i>. 280.</i>. From here<sup class="footnote-marker">169a</sup><i class="footnote">Read with <i>Ševuot</i> 4:1 מכן for מניין.</i> that witnesses shall not be relatives of the accused.
From where that witnesses may not be relatives of one another? Think of it, if they be found perjured, would they not be killed by their testimony<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 9:7:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.9.7.4"><i>Gittin</i> 9:8, Note 128</a>. Formal perjury, “plotting”, is testimony which is impossible, i. e., where it was proven that the witnesses were not at the place about which they testify at the time they assert to have seen the object of their testimony. If only one witness was perjured, there is only one valid witness and his testimony is worthless by biblical standards; for worthless testimony there can be no biblical punishment. Therefore, if the two perjured witnesses were related, each would be convicted by his relatives’ testimony; this is forbidden by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:16" href="/Deuteronomy.24.16"><i>Deut</i>. 24:16</a>. But testimony which would not expose the witnesses to the penalty of perjury is worthless. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 28a" href="/Sanhedrin.28a">Babli, 28a</a>, points out that this argument also eliminates a single relative among the witnesses.</i>? From where that witnesses may not be relatives of the judges? Think of it, if one of them be found perjured, he could not be killed unless the other also was found perjured. If you say so, would he not be killed by his sentence<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 9:7:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.9.7.4"><i>Gittin</i> 9:8, Note 128</a>. Formal perjury, “plotting”, is testimony which is impossible, i. e., where it was proven that the witnesses were not at the place about which they testify at the time they assert to have seen the object of their testimony. If only one witness was perjured, there is only one valid witness and his testimony is worthless by biblical standards; for worthless testimony there can be no biblical punishment. Therefore, if the two perjured witnesses were related, each would be convicted by his relatives’ testimony; this is forbidden by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:16" href="/Deuteronomy.24.16"><i>Deut</i>. 24:16</a>. But testimony which would not expose the witnesses to the penalty of perjury is worthless. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 28a" href="/Sanhedrin.28a">Babli, 28a</a>, points out that this argument also eliminates a single relative among the witnesses.</i>?
From where that judges may not be relatives of one another? The Torah said, kill on the testimony of witnesses, kill on the sentence of judges. Since witnesses may not be relatives of one another, neither may judges be relatives of one another<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:16" href="/Deuteronomy.24.16"><i>Deut</i>. 24:16</a> is indeterminate enough to include both testimony and sentence by relatives.</i>.
So far<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:16" href="/Deuteronomy.24.16"><i>Deut</i>. 24:16</a>.</i> only fathers and sons; from where the other relatives? Rebbi Zeˋira sais, <i>and sons</i> includes the remaining relatives.
So far according to Rebbi Aqiba<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote">Who will consider any <i>prefixed</i> ו which is not 100% necessary for the understanding of the text as an addition which invites extension of the rules. The statement attributed here to the late Amora R. Zeˋira is formulated in <i>Sifry</i> <i>Deut</i>. 280 as tannaïtic, representing R. Aqiba’s opinion.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">A slightly changed parallel is in <i>Ševuˋot</i> 4:1.</i> From where following Rebbi Ismael? Rebbi Ismael stated: <i>The congregation shall judge</i><sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:24" href="/Numbers.35.24"><i>Num</i>. 35:24</a>, about the trial of the homicide who fled to a city of asylum. R Ismael objects to R. Aqiba’s inferences from additional את ,ו etc. and insists that any interpretations of verses conform to the plain sense of the verse within the purview of his hermeneutical rules.</i><i>; the congregation shall save</i><sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:25" href="/Numbers.35.25"><i>Num</i>. 35:25</a>.</i>. The congregation be neither relatives of the murderer nor relatives of the murdered. Rebbi Yose said, otherwise you would say that the court is engaged in vendetta<sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">This gives the missing argument in R. Ismael’s statement.</i>. This implies that the judges may not be related to the accused. And from where that the witnesses may not be related to the accused? The Torah said, kill on the testimony of witnesses, kill on the sentence of judges. Since judges may not be related to the accused, neither may witnesses be related to the accused. From where that witnesses may not be relatives of one another<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:16" href="/Deuteronomy.24.16"><i>Deut</i>. 24:16</a> is indeterminate enough to include both testimony and sentence by relatives.</i>? Think of it, if they be found perjured, would they not be killed by their testimony<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 9:7:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.9.7.4"><i>Gittin</i> 9:8, Note 128</a>. Formal perjury, “plotting”, is testimony which is impossible, i. e., where it was proven that the witnesses were not at the place about which they testify at the time they assert to have seen the object of their testimony. If only one witness was perjured, there is only one valid witness and his testimony is worthless by biblical standards; for worthless testimony there can be no biblical punishment. Therefore, if the two perjured witnesses were related, each would be convicted by his relatives’ testimony; this is forbidden by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:16" href="/Deuteronomy.24.16"><i>Deut</i>. 24:16</a>. But testimony which would not expose the witnesses to the penalty of perjury is worthless. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 28a" href="/Sanhedrin.28a">Babli, 28a</a>, points out that this argument also eliminates a single relative among the witnesses.</i>?
<sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote">These paragraphs all start with quotes from Mishnah <i>Ševuˋot</i> 4:1; they are copied from the Halakhah there. The object of discussion is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:1" href="/Leviticus.5.1"><i>Lev.</i> 5:1</a>: <i>If a person sinned when he heard the sound of an imprecation, being a witness, either having seen or known, if he does not tell he has to bear his punishment.</i> If one of the parties in a civil suit adresses a potential witness and by an oath tells him to appear as a witness in court, if the person so addressed refuses to appear or to testify he has to confess his sin (5:5) and bring a sacrifice graded according to his means (5:6–13). Mishnah <i>Ševuˋot</i> 4:1 details the rules under which a person may be declared guilty of violating the oath put on him.</i>“Qualified one but not disqualified one.” For it is said, <i>if he does not tell, he has to bear his punishment</i>. If he told, the other would have to pay money. This excludes one where the other would not have to pay money even if he told<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote">A person disqualified as witness never has to appear in court. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shevuot 30a" href="/Shevuot.30a">Babli <i>Ševuˋot</i> 30a</a>.</i>.
“Before the court.” To exclude a single witness. If they told him that they would accept his word as if there were two [witnesses], would he be guilty? The verse says, <i>if he had seen or known</i>. One who is qualified to testify according to biblical standards; this excludes a single witness who is not qualified to testify according to biblical standards<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:15" href="/Deuteronomy.19.15"><i>Deut</i>. 19:15</a>.</i>.
“Outside of court.” <i>If he does not tell, he has to bear his punishment.</i> If he told, one would have to pay money. This excludes outside of court where the other would not have to pay money even if he told.
From where two witnesses<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">The sacrifice for disregarding an imprecation is due only if two witnesses can testify that the potential witness acknowledged the oath put on him.</i>? He and another make two<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">This is R. Aqiba’s argument. Since it is written in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:1" href="/Leviticus.5.1"><i>Lev</i>. 5:1</a> <i>and</i> <i>he is a witness</i>, the copula implies the existence of a counterpart, a second witness.</i>. Or following Rebbi Ismael, as Rebbi Ismael said, any place where the Torah mentions a witness without further determination it implies two witnesses<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">Since a single witness is declared insufficient in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:15" href="/Deuteronomy.19.15"><i>Deut</i>. 19:15</a>, any mention of valid testimony in the biblical text must refer to two witnesses; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 6:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.6.2.2"><i>Sotah</i> 6:2 Note 23</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 30a" href="/Sanhedrin.30a">Babli 30a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 31b" href="/Sanhedrin.31b">31b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 2b" href="/Sotah.2b"><i>Soṭah</i> 2b</a>.</i> unless the verse informs you that a single witness is meant. It was found stated in the name of Rebbi Ismael: Can a single witness be found guilty of a blurted oath<sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:4" href="/Leviticus.5.4"><i>Lev</i>. 5:4</a>: <i>Or a person who blurts out swearing from his lips, to worsen or to improve, for anything a human might blurt out in an oath, and it slipped his mind but then he remembered and became guilty of one of these</i>. A blurted oath is one which could have been avoided by some reflection.</i>? Since it is possible to say that another person could team up with him, then he would be subject to the oath of testimony, how could you find him guilty of a blurted oath<sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">By its nature, a blurted oath is totally disconnected from any judicial precedure.</i>?
Should a relative be found guilty of a blurted oath<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">If only two witnesses are known to the party putting an imprecation on those who would not testify and one of these is a relative who could not testify, is the imprecation a blurted oath?</i>? Does it follow what Rebbi Abba said (ben) [in the name of]<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">From the text in <i>Ševuˋot</i>. Samuel only had daughters.</i> Samuel: <sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">Since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:4" href="/Leviticus.5.4"><i>Lev</i>. 5:4</a> sanctions only future-directed thoughtless oaths, <i>to worsen or to improve</i>, in Samuel’s opinion oaths that refer to past acts only are not included in the category of blurted oaths. They are meaningless oaths which might not be reparable by a sacrifice.</i>“An oath that X gave a <i>mina</i> to Y,” and it turns out that X had not given; since there is nothing in the future there is nothing in the past. Or the following: <sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Ševuˋot</i> 8:3. The person spoken to was an unpaid keeper responsible only if he appropriated another’s property for his own use, not if it was otherwise lost (<i>Bava mesiˋa</i> 7:9).</i>“One said to another, ˋwhere is my ox?’ He responded, ˋI do not know what you are referring to.’ It so happened that it had died, or was wounded, or captured, or lost. ˋI require you to swear;’ the other said ˋAmen’. He is not liable.<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">If the keeper maintains that he never received the ox when he had in fact received it, but it died or was lost under circumstances which do not make the keeper responsible for the loss, he does not have to bring the sacrifice for a false oath since his lie did not result in monetary loss to another person.</i>” Rav said, he is not liable for a keeper’s oath<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">Since he could have told the truth and still not be liable for damages.</i> but is liable because of a blurted oath<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Since what he pronounced was an oath which resulted from speaking before thinking.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, since it is a religious duty to appease him<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">The keeper is under a religious obligation to tell the truth to the ox’s owner.</i>, he is not liable because of a blurted oath. In Rav’s opinion, is there no religious duty to appease him? One appeases with truthful statements, not with lies.
Rebbi Ismael stated: <i>He has to bear his punishment</i><sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:1" href="/Leviticus.5.1"><i>Lev</i>. 5:1</a>.</i>, a sacrifice<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">This supports Rav, that a sacrifice is due for any untruthful oath.</i>. From where that one needs a court<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">That a sacrifice is required only for oaths connected with judicial proceedings.</i>? One learns “telling, telling<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">The only <i>legal</i> texts in the Pentateuch which use the root נגד are <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:1" href="/Leviticus.5.1"><i>Lev</i>. 5:1</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:9-11" href="/Deuteronomy.17.9-11"><i>Deut</i>. 17:9–11</a>. The latter text contains the rules of the Supreme Court and the punishment for disobeying its rulings.</i>”. Since <i>telling</i> mentioned there is before a court, also telling here is before a court.
<sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote">This text is an incomplete copy of a text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 1:1:10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.1.1.10"><i>Sotah</i> 1:1, Notes 56–71</a> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 2:4:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.2.4.2-7"><i>Ketubot</i> 2:4</a>, <i>Ševuˋot</i> 4:1).</i> Or like the following. “One accepts the witnesses’ testimony only if they saw it together. Rebbi Joshua ben Qorḥa says, even if they saw it one after the other.” Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rav: The Sages agree with Rebbi Joshua ben Qorḥa with regard to witnesses of firstlings and witnesses of squatters’ rights. Rebbi Abba in the name of Rebbi Jeremiah: the same holds for testimony regarding signs. In that case, it is obvious if one says, I saw two hairs on his back and the other says, I saw two hairs on his side. If one says, I saw one hair on his back and the other says, I saw one hair on his belly, that is nothing; so much more his back and his side. Two are saying, we saw one hair on his back; and two are saying, we saw one hair on his belly. Rav Yose and Rav Hoshaia ben Rav Shammai, one said, it is invalid, but the other said, it is valid. He who says it is invalid considers him as one who testifies to half a sign. He who says it is valid? I say, maybe they were rubbed off. One says, two hairs on his back; and one says, two on his belly<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">It is obvious that one has to read with the <i>Sotah</i> text: <i>Two</i> say <i>one</i> hair.</i>. Rebbi Abba said, everybody agrees that this is valid. Rebbi Ḥaggai said, everybody agrees that this is invalid [testimony]. Rebbi Yose said, this is in disagreement. Rebbi [Yose]<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote">From the text in <i>Sotah</i>, missing here.</i> said to Rebbi Ḥaggai, does not Rebbi Yudan follow my opinion? He answered, I am disagreeing with his teacher, so much more with him. Rebbi Mama said, Rebbi Ḥaggai was correct. If a document was signed by four seals, if one person verified the signature of two [witnesses], and another those of the other two, and the document was attacked, is that worth anything? Does not every single signature need two witnesses? And here, every single hair needs two witnesses. Rebbi Ḥinena learns it (because of)<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Text here, to be replaced by the <i>Soṭah</i> text in brackets.</i> [from the years of] squatting rights. If one [witness] testified that he ate from the property the first, second, and third years and another testified that he ate it the fourth, fifth, and sixth years, is that worth anything? Does not every single year need two witnesses? And here, every single hair needs two witnesses.
<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">From here on, there is no parallel in <i>Ševuˋot</i>. The entire story is told in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 30" href="/Sanhedrin.30">Babli, 30 a/b</a>, about R. Johanan instead of R. Jonathan.</i> And the following. One does not listen to the witnesses unless they come together; Rebbi Nathan says, one listens to the first and when the second comes, one listens to what he has to say. Rebbi Jonathan was sitting and asking, maybe somebody is here who heard that practice follows Rebbi Nathan? Rebbi Yose bar Ḥanina told him, that is Rebbi Simeon ben Yaqim. He said, may he come up<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">Sit with the ordained judges.</i>. When he came up, he asked him, did you hear that practice follows Rebbi Nathan? He answered, I heard that Rebbi Joshua ben Qorḥa agrees with Rebbi Nathan. He said, do we need this<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">This is obvious since R. Joshua ben Qorha does not require the witnesses to testify from the same point of view. Since he accepts testimonies which are consistent but not identical, he also must accept testimonies that are not synchronous.</i>? He said, Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina only intended to elevate Rebbi Simeon bar Yaqim because he was an important person.
Rav Ḥisda asked: May one receive witnesses not in the presence of one of the parties? Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">Probably one should read <i>Yasa</i> for <i>Yose</i>; cf<i>. Diqduqe Soferim Bava qamma</i> p. 136b, Note 2.</i> in the name of Rebbi Sabbatai: One may receive witnesses not in the presence of the parties and even issue a decision, but if [the absent party] appeals, their appeal must be heard. If a person was summoned by the court three times and did not appear, Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said that one may receive witnesses not in the presence of the parties and issue a decision<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli restricts hearing witnesses not in the presence of both parties to this and similar cases; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 112b" href="/Bava_Kamma.112b"><i>Bava qamma</i> 112b</a>.</i>. As the following: Cahana<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">A Babylonian without relatives in Galilee.</i> died and had willed his estate to Rebbi Joshia. Rebbi Eleazar heard witnesses<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">That Cahana’s will conformed to the law of death-bed wills which supersedes the rights of heirs.</i> not in the presence [of the heirs] and handed the estate to Rebbi Joshia. Not only that, but the estate contained Torah scrolls. Rebbi Eleazar wrote to his heirs<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia.</i>: Scrolls won by the Land of Israel cannot be taken outside. Rebbi Nissai in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: If they were written for export, they can be exported. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba asked before Rebbi Yasa: May one export? He asked him, do you ask me in a practical case? He answered, no<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">R. Yasa did not answer a purely theoretical question. Therefore, we do not know whether the other students of R. Eleazar accepted R. Eleazar’s position.</i>. Rebbi Zeˋira was dissatisfied<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">R. Hiyya bar Abba’s student and successor.</i> that he had not asked in a practical case, to know what he would have said.
Rebbi Jeremiah<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">A born Babylonian.</i> had a suit against a certain person. They accepted testimony not in the presence of Rebbi Jeremiah, and decided against Rebbi Jeremiah. He was sitting despondent; is it possible that one accepts witnesses not in the presence of the parties? Rebbi Hina, Rebbi Phineas, and Rebbi Ḥizqiah from Ḥuqoq did not go to the lecture<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">During the half-yearly study sessions.</i> on that day, but Rebbi Huna pushed, went in, and found Rebbi Jeremiah despondent; is it possible that one accepts witnesses not in the presence of the parties even if they are present with them in the same city? He told him, this is seen to be the rabbis’ opinion<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">Since the decision always could be reversed on appeal and the rabbinic court anyhow acted only as an arbitration panel, in contrast to Babylonia where most of the time the rabbinic court had government backing in civil cases. Cf. the Introduction to Tractate <i>Neziqin</i>, pp.3–4.</i>.

Halakhah 10

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> When they have come to a decision, they bring the parties in. The chief judge says, Mr. X, you are not guilty, Mr. X, you are guilty. From where that afterwards, one may not say, I had found for you but my colleagues found you guilty, but what can I do since they were a majority against me? On such a one it was said: <i>The gossip uncovers secrets</i><sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 11:13" href="/Proverbs.11.13"><i>Prov.</i> 11:13</a>. Since this is from the Hagiographs, it does not have the force of a Torah verse.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “When they have come to a decision,” etc. Rebbi Joḥanan said, one forces the one who finds guilty to write “not guilty.<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote">The decision has to be signed by all three judges, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 30a" href="/Sanhedrin.30a">Babli 30a</a>.</i>” Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish says, the one who finds guilty, writes “guilty”; the one who finds not guilty, writes “not guilty”<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">The dissenter may write a dissenting opinion, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 30a" href="/Sanhedrin.30a">Babli 30a</a>.</i>. The Mishnah disagrees with Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: “From where that afterwards, one may not say, I had found for you but my colleagues found you guilty.” What does Rebbi Joḥanan do with this? That nobody could say, I really wanted to justify X in his suit but they did not let me do it<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">His rule enforces the Mishnah.</i>. What is Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish’s reason? That no other person should come, reason as he did, and say, also that one was there and he erred<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">The dissenting opinion might in the course of history become the majority opinion; then its author should get due credit.</i>.

Halakhah 11

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Any time one produces a proof he may demand a new trial<sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">The person who lost a civil suit may request a new trial based on new documentary evidence (“proof”) or new witnesses.</i>. If they told him, produce all your proofs within thirty days, if he produced within thirty days, he gets a new trial, after thirty days he does not get a new trial. Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel said, what can one do if he did not find within thirty [days] but found after thirty [days]<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">He is entitled to a new trial if he can explain the delay. In general, practice follows Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel in the Mishnah.</i>? 
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Any time one produces a proof,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">The discussion of Mishnah 12 is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:12:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.12.2-4">Halakhah 13</a>. Therefore, the indication of a new Halakhah here is erroneous; the reference still is to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:10:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.10.1">Mishnah 11</a>, in reference to a split decision of the court.</i> Rebbi Oshaiah said, there<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.5.1">Mishnah 5:7</a>, referring to criminal proceedings. If the court has the maximum number of members, 71, and 35 each are for conviction and acquittal while one is undecided, they have to continue to argue until the undecided judge makes up his mind.</i>, where it is possible to add, they continue to argue. But here it is impossible to add<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">He holds that in civil trials one never adds judges. Therefore, even if there are only three judges, they have to continue to argue among themselves until each one has made up his mind.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish both teach that even here it is possible to add<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">They hold that the rules of adding judges are identical for civil and criminal trials (Maimonides, <i>Hilkhot</i> <i>Sanhedrin</i> 8:2).</i>.

Halakhah 12

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If they told him, produce witnesses; he said, I have no witness; produce proofs; he said, I have no proofs. If later he found a proof, or he found witnesses, this is irrelevant<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">The court has to assume that the documents are forged and the witnesses false.</i>. Rabban Gamliel said, what should he do who did not know that he had witnesses but found witnesses; he did not know that he had proof, but he found proof<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the last case in Mishnah 12. Late submissions must be accepted if the litigant can prove that he had no knowledge of the witnesses or documents within the period allotted him by the court.</i>? If they told him, produce witnesses; he said, I have no witness; produce proofs; he said, I have no proofs; when he saw that the decision would go against him he said, X and Y shall come and testify for me, or he produced proof from his money belt, this is irrelevant<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">The court has to assume that the documents are forged and the witnesses false.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel said,” etc. Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rav Hoshaiah: Three Amoraïm<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">They explain Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel’s words.</i>. One said, any time he brings proof he can demand a new trial. The other said, if he brought within 30 days<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Of judgment rendered.</i>, he can demand a new trial, after 30 days he cannot demand a new trial. The other said, he never can demand a new trial unless he prove that he absolutely had no knowledge of it<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the last case in Mishnah 12. Late submissions must be accepted if the litigant can prove that he had no knowledge of the witnesses or documents within the period allotted him by the court.</i>. But did we not state: “Rabban Gamliel said, what should he do who did not know that he had witnesses but found witnesses; that he had no proof, but found proof?” Rebbi La and Rebbi Zeˋira: One said, unless he voided his proofs<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel will agree that he is restricted in asking for a new trial if he himself had belittled the possibility of finding other proof in a statement before the court.</i>; the other said, until he disclaimed his proofs<sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote">He had affirmed before the court that there was nothing to be added.</i>.
Rebbi Levi had a suit against a certain person about houses; they had it judged before Rebbi Eleazar. After a decision was reached he presented proof. He<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">R. Eleazar.</i> asked Rebbi Joḥanan, who told him, any time one brings proof<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">Since in the next case, the same expression of “proof” is used in connection with witnesses, it seems that it refers not to the actual proof submitted to the court but to the justification, submitting proof that the new material was unknown to the litigant during the trial.</i> he can demand a new trial. Rebbi Eumachos had a suit against a certain person about mills; they had it judged before Rebbi Eleazar. After a decision was reached he presented witnesses. He asked Rebbi Joḥanan, who said to him, is that still a problem for you? Any time one brings proof he can demand a new trial. Why did it need two cases? In Rebbi Levy’s case, no formal verdict had been rendered, in Rebbi Eumachos’s case, a formal verdict had been rendered<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.5.1">Mishnah 5:7</a>, referring to criminal proceedings. If the court has the maximum number of members, 71, and 35 each are for conviction and acquittal while one is undecided, they have to continue to argue until the undecided judge makes up his mind.</i>.
Does a judicial confirmation need a court<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">A mortgage foreclosure was certified by a certain court which confirmed the genuineness of document and claim. The property to be foreclosed was in the domain of another court. Does the second court have to ascertain that the certification be genuine or do we assume that court documents cannot be forged and the second court has to authorize the foreclosure?</i>? Rebbi Hoshaia in the name of Samuel, Rav Bannai in the name of Samuel. One said, it should be confirmed either by the handwriting of the witnesses or the handwriting of the judges<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">Either the genuineness of the mortgage or the genuineness of the judicial endorsement has to be determined.</i>; the other said, even with one handwriting and one judge<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">Two signatures have to be confirmed, but it may be the signature of one witness and one judge since the judges by their endorsement become witnesses to the genuineness of the document. This is the final determination of the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 21a" href="/Ketubot.21a">Babli, <i>Ketubot</i> 21a</a>.</i>.

Chapter 4



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Both civil suits and criminal suits require cross-examination and investigation<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Cross-examination is the interrogation of witnesses which changes from trial to trial. Investigation is the determination of answers to the obligatory questions enumerated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.1.1">Mishnah 5:1</a>.</i>, as it is said: <i>One set of rules shall be for you</i><sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">This is the opposite of rigidity. The understanding of Torah and with it the entire code of behavior required by it is a function of time. While precedents should be overthrown only for very weighty reasons, no rule is invariable for all times.</i>. What is the difference between civil suits and criminal suits? Civil suits are tried before three judges, criminal suits before 23. In civil suits one starts with arguments either for acquittal or conviction; in criminal courts one starts with arguments<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">In the discussion by the judges after all evidence was presented.</i> for acquittal but not for conviction.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Both civil suits,” etc. Rebbi Joḥanan said, to protect Israel’s money they said, “tell why you know that this person owes the other.<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">While the Mishnah requires the same kind of cross-examinations and determinations in civil as in criminal cases, R. Johanan holds that by rabbinic <i>fiat</i>, witnesses in civil cases are not to be subjected to cross-examinations that stray from the main topic. While it is necessary in criminal trials to disqualify any witness whose testimony is not 100% consistent (since God has promised to punish every evildoer who escapes human justice,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:7" href="/Exodus.23.7"><i>Ex</i>. 23:7</a>), excessively rigid standards in civil cases would prevent most owners of capital from lending it, therefore leading to the ruin of the poor. It is in the public interest that claims be swiftly and easily adjudicated. The question quoted (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.8.1">Mishnah 3:9</a>) is the paradigm for any questions to be asked.</i>” Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba asked before Rebbi Yasa<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">One has to read יסא for יוסי. R. Hiyya bar Abba was R. Yasa’s student and R. Yose’s teacher’s teacher.</i>: What does one do in practice? He answered, following Rebbi Joḥanan, as Rebbi Joḥanan said, to protect Israel’s money they said, “tell why you know that this person owes the other.” Ze‘ir bar Ḥinena in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina and Rav Jehudah, one said: <i>You shall cross-examine, investigate, and inquire well</i><sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:15" href="/Deuteronomy.13.15"><i>Deut</i>. 13:15</a>, referring to a criminal case.</i>. The other said, <i>equity, equity you shall pursue</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 16:20" href="/Deuteronomy.16.20"><i>Deut</i>. 16:20</a>, referring to all judicial proceedings.</i> How is that? If you see that the verdict will be the truth, investigate it<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">In criminal cases, there is an obligation on the judges to ascertain the truth as well as possible. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 32a" href="/Sanhedrin.32a">Babli, 32a</a>, the duty to careful investigation is emphasized in all cases where the judges suspect foul play by one of the parties; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:1:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.1.2">Note 10</a>.</i>; otherwise, act in equity.<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">In civil cases, the judges have to ascertain that the judgment be equitable.</i>
<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.3">Halakhah 3:9, Notes 139–140</a>.</i> When Rav Huna saw that witnesses said exactly the same, he was investigating. When he saw them essentially identical, he determined the common element.
How does one start for acquittal? One says, is it possible that this one be a murderer<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">If the judges in their discussions say this, after the evidence was heard, nothing bad can be said. R. Yose reads the question as one directed towards eye witnesses to a murder. An intimation by the judges that they do not believe the witnesses may lead them to lie to exonerate the murderer; this would make the judges accomplices of the murderer after the fact.</i>? Rebbi Yose said, if this is so, if one of the witnesses said, I have something to say in his defense, and his colleague comes to support him, is that support? If you say so, would you not put guilt on the judges, to lead witnesses to lie?
Rebbi Joḥanan said, anybody who cannot argue for the crawling animal to make it pure a hundred times cannot start arguing for acquittal<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 17a" href="/Sanhedrin.17a">Babli, 17a</a>, Rav states that anybody who cannot argue for the purity of crawling animals is not a candidate for membership in the Synhedrion. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 11:29-38" href="/Leviticus.11.29-38"><i>Lev.</i> 11:29–38</a> describes the impurity of eight particular crawling animals (mostly reptiles). The list includes the rat. (For some reason, the commentator to the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 91a" href="/Sanhedrin.91a">Babli 91a</a>, probably Rashi’s son-in-law Jehuda ben Nathan, defines עַכְבָּר as <i>écureuil</i>, “squirrel”.) All other crawling animals, including snakes (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 11:42" href="/Leviticus.11.42"><i>Lev</i>. 11:42</a>), are forbidden as food but their carcasses are not impure.</i>. How does one argue about a crawling animal? Rebbi Joḥanan said, since a snake which kills<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">It kills both humans and domestic animals, thereby causing the severe impurities of corpses and animal carcasses. For logical consistency, the agent of impurity should be impure; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Eruvin 13b" href="/Eruvin.13b">Babli <i>Eruvin</i> 13b</a>.</i> is pure, a rat which does not kill logically should be pure. Since a rat which does not kill is impure, a snake which kills logically should be impure. Rebbi Phineas objected: Is there not the scorpion which kills and is pure? It was found that a Tanna said, snake and scorpion both follow the same rules.
<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Eruvin 13b" href="/Eruvin.13b">Babli <i>Eruvin</i> 13b</a>, Rebbi <i>Johanan</i> said, Rebbi <i>Meïr</i> had a student by the name of Symmachos who could give 49 reasons for everything pure and 49 reasons for everything impure. [In <i>Midrash Tehillim</i>, ed. Buber p. 108 Note 37, it is R. Aqiba’s student Rebbi Meïr.] Since Symmachos is praised, the stories are not parallel and the names cannot be copied. It is clear that the second “Rebbi” needs to be followed by a name.<br>The same Babli also quotes a <i>baraita</i> that at Jabneh there was a self-confident (واشق ותיק) student who could give 150 reasons for the purity of crawling animals. This is the parallel to the <i>baraita</i> here.</i> Rebbi said, Rebbi [ ] had a self-confident student who was arguing for purity or impurity of the crawling animal a hundred times. They said, this student never could instruct<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">A Sophist cannot come to a clear decision of what is right.</i>. Rebbi Jacob bar Dositheos said, this student was cut-off from Mount Sinai<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">Even though all future Jewish souls, including proselytes, participated in receiving the Torah at Mount Sinai, that student was excluded as not being Jewish. (Cf. H. Guggenheimer, <i>The Scholar’s Haggadah</i>, Northvale NJ 1995, p. 308–309.)</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Civil suits are decided<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">The use of the verb נטה “to bend” referring to judicial decision is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:2" href="/Exodus.23.2"><i>Ex</i>. 23:2</a>.</i> by one witness<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">This is a rather frequent scribal error (including the <i>editio princeps</i> of Maimonides’s Code) induced by the common expression “one witness”. Decisions are not made by witnesses but by votes of judges. The word “witness” has to be deleted both times (cf.<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 87" href="/Sanhedrin.87"><i>Diqduqe Soferim Sanhedrin</i> p. 87, Note 1</a>.)</i> whether for credit or debit; criminal suits are decided by one witness<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">This is a rather frequent scribal error (including the <i>editio princeps</i> of Maimonides’s Code) induced by the common expression “one witness”. Decisions are not made by witnesses but by votes of judges. The word “witness” has to be deleted both times (cf.<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 87" href="/Sanhedrin.87"><i>Diqduqe Soferim Sanhedrin</i> p. 87, Note 1</a>.)</i> for acquittal and two for conviction<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">If 12 judges vote for conviction and 11 for acquittal, it is a potential mistrial. A difference of two votes between those voting for conviction or acquittal is possible only if an odd number of judges abstain.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Civil suits are decided,” etc. Rebbi Yannai said, if the Torah had been given decided<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">חתך “to cut” in this connection is a translation of Latin <i>decidere</i> (literally “to cut off; settle, decide.) There is no reason why R. Yannai could not have acted as a Roman Judge, just like his contemporary R. Jonathan (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Batra 3:4:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Batra.3.4.2-3"><i>Bava batra</i> 3:4</a> and <i>Introduction to Tractate Neziqin</i>.) R. Yannai counts it as an advantage that the Torah is formulated as a set of potentially ambiguous principles rather than a collection of court decisions which would represent unchangeable precedents.</i>, no foot could stand. What is the reason? <i>The Eternal spoke to Moses</i><sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">. <i>Qorban He`edah</i> takes this as a reference to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:1" href="/Exodus.12.1"><i>Ex</i>. 12:1</a>, where v. 2 continues: <i>This month is for you the beginning of months; first it shall be for you of the year’s months</i>. The two clauses in the verse have different status. In the first part, God designated the first month of the year of the Exodus. In the second part, Moses and his successors are commanded to determine every year which month should be “first”. The Torah does not give an algorithm to determine which lunar month has to serve as “Spring Month” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 13:4" href="/Exodus.13.4"><i>Ex</i>. 13:4</a>). Any calendar system agreed to by Moses’s successors has divine sanction. (The current method, concentrating on designating the seventh month, from time to time yields rather questionable results.)</i>. He said before Him: Master of the Universe, inform me what is the practice. He told him, <i>to bend</i><sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">This is the opposite of rigidity. The understanding of Torah and with it the entire code of behavior required by it is a function of time. While precedents should be overthrown only for very weighty reasons, no rule is invariable for all times.</i> <i>after the majority</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">The use of the verb נטה “to bend” referring to judicial decision is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:2" href="/Exodus.23.2"><i>Ex</i>. 23:2</a>.</i> If there was a majority for acquitting, they acquitted; if there was a majority for convicting, they convicted; so that the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">That means, every precept in the Torah can be explained as having 49 different negative and 49 different positive aspects.</i> could be explained in 49 ways impure and 49 ways pure, the numerical value of<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Song of Songs 2:4" href="/Song_of_Songs.2.4"><i>Cant</i>. 2:4</a>: “His banner over me is love.” The numerical value is 6+4+3+30+6 = 49.</i> ודגלו. And so it says<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 12:7" href="/Psalms.12.7"><i>Ps</i>. 12:7</a>. “Sevenfold” is interpreted as 7<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup> = 49.</i>: <i>the commands of the Eternal are pure sayings; molten silver in an earthenware crucible, refined sevenfold.</i> And it says<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Song of Songs 1:4" href="/Song_of_Songs.1.4"><i>Cant</i>. 1:4</a>. Since מישרים is a plural, it indicates that the Torah has a plurality of straightforward interpretations.</i>, <i>the straightforward love You</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Civil suits can be retried<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:9:2-12:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.9.2-12.4">3:10–13</a>, civil suits can be re-opened if new documents or new witnesses become available.</i> both for credit and for debit. Criminal suits can be retried for acquittal<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">Appeals and retrials are possible only after conviction but never after acquittal.</i> but not for conviction.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Civil suits can be retried both for credit and for debit,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 33b" href="/Sanhedrin.33b">Babli 33b</a>, <i>Mekhilta dR. Ismael Mišpatim</i> 20 (p.327–328), <i>dR. Simeon ben Iohai</i> 23:7; shortened <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 144.</i> If he left the court being acquitted, and they found reasons for conviction, could I understand that one returned him? The verse says<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:7" href="/Exodus.23.7"><i>Ex</i>. 23:7</a>.</i>, <i>do not slay the acquitted</i>. If he left the court being convicted, and they found reasons for acquittal, could I understand that one should not return him? The verse<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:7" href="/Exodus.23.7"><i>Ex</i>. 23:7</a>.</i> says, <i>but do not slay the innocent</i>. I could think that if he is acquitted in your court, he is acquitted in My court; the verse<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:7" href="/Exodus.23.7"><i>Ex</i>. 23:7</a>.</i> says, <i>I shall not acquit the wicked</i>. Rebbi Isaac said, Rebbi Yose told me: There is no difference; if the acquittal was in error<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">For example, if the clerk of court made an error in tallying the votes. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 33b" href="/Sanhedrin.33b">Babli, 33b</a>, holds that a retrial is possible if an acquittal was in clear violation of a biblical verse.</i>, one retries him.
“In civil suits, anybody may argue for credit or debit,” etc. Rebbi Immi asked before Rebbi Joḥanan: Even an adulterer and an adulteress<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">It is obvious that this Halakhah does not refer to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.4.1">Mishnah 4</a>. From the parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 33b" href="/Sanhedrin.33b">Babli, 33b</a>, where R. Ḥiyya bar Abba asked and received an insulting answer, one might refer to the preceding statement in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:3:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.3.2">Halakhah 3</a>, whether adulterers who were acquitted after the adultery was proven may be retried. This interpretation requires one to adopt the Babli’s explanation of R. Yose’s statement.<br>If the Halakhah belongs to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.4.1">Mishnah 5</a>, the question might be whether a judge who argued for acquittal in the case of an adulterer may argue for conviction in the following trial of the adulteress. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:7:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.7.6">Halakhah 9</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 7:2-3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.7.2-3">Tosephta 7:2</a> prescribe that adulterer and adulteress have to be tried separately on different days.</i>? He told him, your patch came off<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">The question is stupid; it is as if you had a hole in your pants.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> In civil suits, anybody<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Every judge.</i> may argue for credit or debit. In criminal suits, anybody may argue for acquittal but not everybody may argue for conviction<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.4.1">Mishnah 5</a>.</i>.<br>In civil suits, one who argued for credit may argue for debit and one who argued for debit may argue for credit; but in criminal suits one who argued for conviction may argue for acquittal but one who argued for acquittal is barred from arguing for conviction.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “In civil suits, one who argued for credit,” etc. Rebbi said, if they only miss saying, Mr. X, you are acquitted, or you are convicted; it does not apply to the discussion<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">A judge who argued for acquittal during the discussion is barred from voting for conviction during the final vote but a judge originally arguing for acquittal may change his mind during the discussion and later argue for conviction. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 34b" href="/Sanhedrin.34b">Babli, 34b</a>, Rav reads the Mishnah as implying that during the discussion, a person arguing for acquittal cannot then argue for conviction but the next day he may vote for conviction.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, it also applies to the discussion<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">A judge originally arguing for acquittal cannot later argue for conviction.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Civil suits are tried during the day and may be decided in the night but criminal suits are tried during the day and decided during daytime.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Civil suits are tried during the day,” etc. From where this? <i>They judged the people at all times</i><sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 18:26" href="/Exodus.18.26"><i>Ex</i>. 18:26</a>.</i>. But this is a verse about what happened<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Information about what Moses had people do in the desert is quite different from prescription of future organization of courts. The context makes it clear that courts organized on Jethro’s suggestion only handled civil suits <i>between a man and his neighbor</i>.</i>! Rav Samuel<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">The name must be either <i>Rebbi</i> Samuel bar Rav Isaac or Rav <i>Naḥman</i> bar Rav Isaac; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 9:1:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.9.1.3"><i>Bava qamma</i> 9:1, Note 12</a>.</i> ben Rav Isaac said: so is the <i>baraita</i>: If they erred and judged in the night, their judgment stands, as the verse said: <i>they shall judge the people at all times</i><sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 18:22" href="/Exodus.18.22"><i>Ex</i>. 18:22</a>, the prescription of future organization. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 34b" href="/Sanhedrin.34b">Babli, 34b</a>, disagrees and permits only finishing a trial which started during daytime.</i>. He<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The person who had raised the objection in the first place. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 9:1:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.9.1.3"><i>Bava qamma</i> 9:1 (Note 16</a>) the expression is used by Rav Nahman bar Jacob.</i> said, that is a statement<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">A true statement. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Yevamot 104a:6:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Yevamot.104a.6.1">Tosaphot <i>Yebamot</i> 104a <i>s. v</i>. מר</a> feel forced to emend the text. This is unnecessary.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Civil suits are decided on the same day, whether for credit or debit. But criminal suits are decided the same day for acquittal, the next day<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">If there be a majority for conviction, one puts off the final vote for reasons for acquittal might be found in the meantime.</i> for conviction. Therefore one does not judge on Sabbath eve or holiday eve<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Neither judgment can be rendered nor the judgment executed on a Sabbath or holiday. The possibility of a trial taking longer than one day is not contemplated.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Civil suits are decided on the same day,” etc. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">A similar <i>baraita</i> is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 33b" href="/Sanhedrin.33b">Babli, 33b</a>, where, however, a dissent is noted.</i>: A witness may not argue either for acquittal or conviction<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">In the formulation of the Babli: A witness cannot turn judge.</i>. From where this? <i>A witness shall not argue about anybody on trial for his life</i><sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:30" href="/Numbers.35.30"><i>Num</i>. 35:30</a>. In the Babli, R. Yose ben Jehudah reads the verse only as prohibiting a witness from arguing for conviction.</i>. And from where that he himself may not argue either for acquittal or conviction? The verse says, one <i>shall not argue about anybody on trial for his life</i><sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">This is not a verse. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:30" href="/Numbers.35.30"><i>Num</i>. 35:30</a> reads: <i>A single witness may not argue</i> … This is split into two sentences: A witness may not, a single person may not.</i>. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, sometimes a person sees himself set up by perjured witnesses and he speaks much lest he be put to death<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">While in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 34a" href="/Sanhedrin.34a">Babli, 34a</a>, R. Simeon ben Laqish is quoted as sustaining the opinion that the accused may not testify for himself since he is party to the proceedings, here it seems clear that he gives the accused the right to point out to the judges the fact that he is accused because of perjured (or otherwise tainted) testimony.</i>.
From where that one needs two consecutive days<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Mishnah requires sentence to be passed on the day immediately following, there should be some biblical justification. The continuation of the argument shows that a reference is missing which would imply that justice delayed is justice denied.</i>?
<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">The same text is found in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 1:1:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.1.1.8"><i>Ketubot</i> 1:1 (Notes 43–46</a>,כ) and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Beitzah 5:2:2-16" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Beitzah.5.2.2-16"><i>Besah</i> 5:2</a> (64 l. 59,ב ).</i> Rebbi Ḥizqiah, Rebbi Aḥa, said in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: It is forbidden to judge money matters on Friday. Does not a Mishnah object: “Therefore one does not judge [criminal matters] on Sabbath eve or holiday eve”? Hence, one judges money matters! Also, Rebbi Ḥiyya stated thus: One judges money matters on Friday but not criminal matters. One is for practice, the other for action<sup class="footnote-marker">53a</sup><i class="footnote">“Practice” means “code of practice”, “action” means actual procedure. The parallel sources read: “one is for practice, the other for words of Torah”, meaning that in theory one may judge but in practice one does not.</i>.
Could one not judge him on Fridays, pass sentence on the Sabbath, and execute him after the Sabbath? If you say so, it turns out that his judgment is delayed<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">This argument really implies that capital crimes be tried only by the Supreme Court whose decrees are final.</i>. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish asked, could he not be judged on the Sabbath, have his sentence passed on the Sabbath, and be executed on the Sabbath? Temple service, which supersedes Sabbath prohibitions<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">The Sabbath Temple service, as prescribed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 28:10" href="/Numbers.28.10"><i>Num</i>. 28:10</a>, requires slaughtering and burning. For any other purpose, these are deadly sins and capital crimes if done on the Sabbath.</i>, is pushed aside by obligatory executions, since it is said, <i>from My altar take him to be executed</i><sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:14" href="/Exodus.21.14"><i>Ex</i>. 21:14</a>. The verse is read, not as a denial of asylum for any murderer, but as a commandment to immediately execute a Cohen even if he was officiating when convicted of murder. (The non-Cohen would commit a deadly sin by touching the altar.)</i>. Therefore the Sabbath, which is pushed aside by Temple service, logically should be pushed aside by obligatory executions<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">The argument deserves no refutation since the relation “stronger than” underlying an argument <i>de minore ad majus</i> is not transitive (<i>a</i> stronger than <i>b</i>, <i>b</i> stronger than <i>c</i> does <i>not</i> imply <i>a</i> stronger than <i>c</i>. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 132b" href="/Shabbat.132b">Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 132b</a>; cf. H. Guggenheimer, <i>Logical Problems in Jewish Tradition</i>, in: Confrontations with Judaism, London 1967, pp. 182–183.) The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 35b" href="/Sanhedrin.35b">Babli, 35b</a>, disproves the argument at length.</i>. Rebbi La in the name of Rebbi Yannai: This<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.5.1">Mishnah 6</a>.</i> implies that courts may not sit on the Sabbath; what is the reason? It is said here, <i>in all your dwellings</i><sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 35:3" href="/Exodus.35.3"><i>Ex</i>. 35:3</a>, the prohibition to start a fire on the Sabbath.</i>, and it is said there, <i>these shall be for you legal procedures for your generations in all your dwellings</i><sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:29" href="/Numbers.35.29"><i>Num</i>. 35:29</a>, the law of homicide and murder. The argument (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 35b" href="/Sanhedrin.35b">Babli 35b</a>) goes as follows. Some capital crimes are punished by burning. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 35:3" href="/Exodus.35.3"><i>Ex</i>. 35:3</a>, which has been shown to be applicable to court proceedings, forbids executing a convicted criminal who has to be burned. Therefore no capital punishment can be executed on the Sabbath.</i>. Since there the verse refers to courts, so also here the verse refers to courts.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> In cases of money matters, purity, and impurity, one starts with the greatest<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">The most respected among the judges is requested to give his opinion first.</i>. In criminal cases, one starts from the side<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">In criminal cases, the most respected judge has to give his opinion last, lest the junior members of the court be influenced by the authoritative voice.</i>. Everybody is qualified to judge money matters but not everybody is qualified to judge criminal matters, but only Cohanim, Levites and Israel whose daughters may marry into the priesthood<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">None of whose known ancestors are bastards or desecrated priests.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “In cases of money matters, purity, and impurity,” etc. Rebbi says, <i>do not argue about a quarrel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:2" href="/Exodus.23.2"><i>Ex</i>. 23:2</a>.</i>. It is written <i>against the greatest</i><sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">The word is written defective. The masoretic text follows the Talmudim in this (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 36a" href="/Sanhedrin.36a">Babli 36a</a>). It is difficult to decide whether the pronunciation of “the greatest” was רִבּ or רָב.</i>, that one does not argue after the greatest, only prior to the greatest. Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, <i>do not argue about a quarrel</i>. It is written <i>before the greatest</i>, that one does not argue prior to the greatest, only after the greatest<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">Depending on how one understands the word עַל, one comes to opposite conclusions. R. Yose ben Hanina denies that there be a difference in procedures between civil and criminal cases.</i>. Rav said, <i>do not argue</i>, even after a hundred<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">He denies that the verse has any relevance for judicial procedures; he reads it as an injunction not to change one’s mind even in the face of a hundred opposing opinions unless one is convinced that his earlier opinion was incorrect.</i>, the words of Rebbi Phineas<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">No Tanna “R. Phineas” is known, nor any such Amora in the first generation. Either the name has to be deleted or the reference is to R. Phineas ben Yaïr.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥilqiah in the name of Rebbi Simon: Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish disagreed<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">A more complete list of names is in the parallel, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Esther 1:13" href="/Esther.1.13"><i>Midrash Esther ad</i> 1:13</a>.</i>. One said, our procedures are like their procedures, and one said, our procedures are not like their procedures<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">Whether in Gentile courts the presiding judge also votes last in criminal proceedings.</i>. He who said, our procedures are like their procedures, is understandable. He wo said, our procedures are not like their procedures, how does he understand <i>Jehudah said</i><sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">When the brothers discussed what to do with Joseph, Jehudah volunteered his plan not to kill Joseph (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 37:26" href="/Genesis.37.26"><i>Gen</i>. 37:26</a>) even though he was the fourth of the brothers (but the oldest, Reuben, was absent.) Since this happened before the revelation of Sinai, one has to assume that the brothers followed general Noahide rules.</i>, <i>Memukhan said</i><sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Esther.1.13" href="/Esther.1.13"><i>Esth.</i> 1:13</a> In the trial of Washti, the last named of the Persian grandees gave his opinion first.</i>? They agreed with what Jehudah said, they agreed with what Memukhan said<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">Since in both cases no other opinions are recorded, we do not know in which order they spoke. Only the opinion which was agreed to in the end is mentioned.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">This is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 2:3:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.2.3.8">Halakhah 2:3 (Note 98</a>).</i> From where that in criminal trials the voting starts from the side? Samuel the Elder stated before Rebbi Aḥa: <i>David told his men, each gird his sword</i><sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 25:13" href="/I_Samuel.25.13"><i>1S</i>. 25:13</a>.</i>, and after this<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">When everybody had given his opinion that Nabal should be killed, David girded his sword in assent.</i>, they were sitting in judgment about Nabal. Rebbi Thema bar Pappaias in the name of Rav Hoshaia: Also when disqualifying families<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">A determination that daughters of a certain family cannot be married either by born Jews since they are descended from a bastard, or by priests since they are descended from a desecrated priest or a woman desecrated by a priest. All restrictions of criminal cases apply here, in the only cases heard by Amoraic courts in Palestine under the rules of criminal trials.</i> one starts from the side.
“Anybody is qualified to judge money matters.” Rebbi Jehudah says, even bastards<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 36b" href="/Sanhedrin.36b">Babli, 36b</a>, this is a statement of <i>Rav</i> Jehudah.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah says, one does not investigate about libation wine<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Wine used in a pagan libation ceremony. The statement is out of place here; it is included as one of R. Jehudah’s lenient rulings.<br>The rules of Gentile wine are the main topic of Tractate ˋ<i>Avodah zarah</i>. Wine used in a pagan ceremony, even only an invocation at a pagan dinner, is forbidden biblically for all usufruct. All other Gentile wine is only forbidden rabbinically. Since the wine is forbidden anyhow, R. Jehudah states that one does not have to investigate whether the rigid biblical rules apply to a given wine; one follows the rabbinic rules unless it be known that the wine is biblically forbidden.</i>.
“The Synhedrion was like a semicircular threshing floor,” etc. It is written: <i>Do not bend your destitute’s proceeding in his trial</i><sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:6" href="/Exodus.23.6"><i>Ex</i>. 23:6</a>. The protection accorded defendants in criminal trials cannot be made dependent on the defendant’s status.</i>. In <i>his</i> trial you do not bend; you may bend in the ox’s trial<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">While the ox who killed a human is on trial for its life, the rules are those of civil suits since the ox represents its owner’s money.</i>. Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: But only in those rules which are different for civil and criminal suits. How many are these? We have stated nine<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.6.1">Mishnaiot 1–7</a>. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 36b" href="/Sanhedrin.36b">Babli, 36b</a>, points out that there is another difference stated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.7.1">Mishnah 8</a>, but the exclusion of bastards is implicit already in the choice of 23 judges since these judges must in theory be qualified to serve in Moses’s council.</i>; Rebbi Ḥiyya stated eleven. Which rules are the last two? The castrate and one who never had children<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 36b" href="/Sanhedrin.36b">Babli, 36b</a>, also excludes men too old to remember the trouble they had in raising their children, who also would be inclined to cruelty.</i> is qualified to judge civil suits but not criminal suits. Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Also one who is less than twenty years of age or who does not have two pubic hairs<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">Although he is past age 20 he still is infantile; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:8:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.8.4"><i>Yebamot</i> 10:17 Notes 221–227</a>.</i> is qualified to judge civil suits but not criminal suits. Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said thirteen. Which rules are the last two? One judges two civil suits on one day but one does not try two criminal suits on one day. Rebbi Abin said, even adulterer and adulteress<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Where the proof of guilt of one person equally applies to the other. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 46a" href="/Sanhedrin.46a">Babli, 46a</a>, Rav Ḥisda restricts this to the case where the statutory punishments are different, such as adultery with a Cohen’s daughter, where the adulterer is strangled but the adulteress burned. There is no reason to transfer this statement to the Yerushalmi. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:3:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.3.3">Note 35</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The Synhedrion was like a semicircular threshing floor<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">Not to mention the objectionable word “amphitheater”. It is not clear whether this applies only to the original Synhedrion, the High Priest’s council, or to any court empowered to try capital cases. It did apply to the Academy of Jabneh, constituted by Rabban Johanan ben Zakkai after the destruction of Jerusalem, but probably not to any of its successor academies.</i>, so that they could see one another. Two court reporters were standing before them, one to the right and one to the left, and they wrote down the arguments of those who argued for acquittal and those who argued for conviction. Rebbi Jehudah says, there were three. One wrote the arguments for conviction, one wrote the arguments for acquittal, and one wrote the arguments for acquittal and for conviction.<br>Three rows of students of the Sages<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">Each criminal court was supposed to function as a law school.</i> were sitting before them; each one of them knew his place<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">Determined by their standing in examinations.</i>. If they needed to ordain,<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">If there was a vacancy on the bench.</i> they ordained one from the first row. One of the second row came to sit in the first, and one of the third came to sit in the second<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Not that he came by himself but was promoted by the court according to his standing.</i>. They chose a person from the general public and placed him in the third row; he did not sit in the place of the one promoted but in the place befitting him<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">By the result of the entrance examination.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Three rows of students of the Sages,” etc. Rebbi Abba (bar) [Rebbi]<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">This is a quote from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.4.1">Halakhah 1:6, Note 338</a>. One has to read with the text there, R. Abba, R. Yasa, rather than introduce an otherwise unknown R. Abba bar Yasa. In the opinion of the Babli, the law school had room for 3 times 23 students. It seems that the Yerushalmi agrees; therefore the derivation of the number 23 of members of the court is hinted at by the quote of its first sentence.</i> Yasa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: It says here <i>congregation</i>, and it says there <i>congregation</i>. Rav brought it from a Mishnah; the Mishnah says “be a tail of lions and not a head of jackals.<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Pirkei Avot 4:15" href="/Pirkei_Avot.4.15"><i>Avot</i> 4:15</a>.</i>” The parable says, be a head of jackals but not a tail of lions. But we have stated: “If they needed to ordain, they ordained one from the first row.<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah does not require that the occupant of the first seat of the first row be ordained; it could be anyone from the first row. Therefore, the last seat in the first row is better than the top seat in the second row.</i>”

Halakhah 9

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> How does one instill fear in witnesses in criminal cases<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">A criminal trial is one where the punishment is either death or flogging. Flogging is potentially life-threatening. A crime for which the punishment is a fine is tried as civil infraction under the rules of civil suits.</i>? One brings them in and instills fear in them. Maybe you would testify by a guess, or by a rumor, or from the mouth of a witness, or you heard it from a trustworthy source<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">This still is hearsay evidence which is inadmissible.</i>, or maybe you do not know that we shall examine you by cross-examination and interrogation<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Cross-examination is the interrogation of witnesses which changes from trial to trial. Investigation is the determination of answers to the obligatory questions enumerated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.1.1">Mishnah 5:1</a>.</i>. You should know that criminal trials are not like civil trials. In civil trials a person<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">On whose incorrect testimony another person was found owing money.</i> pays money and is forgiven. In criminal trials, his blood and the blood of all his descendants hang in the balance, to the end of all generations. So we find when Cain slew his brother, it is said: <i>The sounds of your brother’s bloods cry to me from the earth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 4:10" href="/Genesis.4.10"><i>Gen</i>. 4:10</a>; cf. <i>Gen. rabba</i> 22(21).</i>. It does not say <i>your brother’s blood</i> but <i>your brother’s bloods</i>, his blood and that of his descendants. Another explanation<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">This is a possible correct interpretation of the verse, not to be used as sermon in court. Cf. <i>Gen. rabba</i> 22(22).</i>: <i>Your brother’s bloods</i>, the blood was splashed on trees and stones.<br>Therefore man was created single in the world to teach that for anybody who destroys a single life it is counted as if he destroyed an entire world, and for anybody who preserves a single life it is counted as if he preserved an entire world. And because of peace among men, that nobody could say to another, my father was greater than your father. And that sectarians<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">In general, מין denotes a Jewish Christian. If Jesus was identical in nature with God, he could not have been created or born. If Jesus was similar in nature to God, his creation would contradict the thesis of unique creation of man. If Jesus was simply referring to himself as God’s son in the meaning of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 11:1" href="/Deuteronomy.11.1"><i>Deut</i>. 11:1</a>, he is no power in Heaven.</i> could not say, there are a plurality of powers in Heaven.<br>And to proclaim the greatness of the King over kings of kings, the Holy One, praise to Him.
