For a man coins many coins with one die; they are one like the other. But the King over kings of kings, the Holy One, praise to Him, stamps every man with the stamp of the first man, but no one is like any other. Therefore, everybody is required to say, the world was created for me.<br>Maybe you will say, why should we go to all this trouble? There already is written: <i>If he is a witness, or saw, or knew</i><sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:1" href="/Leviticus.5.1"><i>Lev</i>. 5:1</a>. As usual, the implication is from the part of the verse which is not quoted: <i>If he do not tell, he has to bear his sin.</i></i>, etc. Maybe you will say, why should we be guilty of this man’s blood? There already is written: <i>In destruction of evildoers is clamor</i><sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 11:10" href="/Proverbs.11.10"><i>Prov</i>. 11:10</a>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “How does one instill fear,” etc. What is meant by a guess? <sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 37b" href="/Sanhedrin.37b">Babli 37b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 8:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.8.2">Tosephta 8:3</a>.</i>“Do not say, we saw him with a sword in his hand running after another person. He entered a ruined building after him; we entered after him and found him slain. We saw him coming out and his sword was dripping blood<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">A death sentence can never be pronounced on circumstantial evidence.</i>. Simeon ben Sheṭah<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">The head of the Synhedrion under his sister Queen Salome (Shalomsion).</i> said: May I not see consolation<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., may I not have part in the Future Life if …</i> if I did not see one running after another person into a ruined building. I entered after him and found him slain while the other left with his sword dripping blood. I said to him, may I not see consolation if you did not kill him. But what can I do since your blood is not delivered into my hands. But He Who knows thoughts may collect from that person. He did not manage to leave before a snake bit him and he died.
“Therefore man was created,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 38a" href="/Sanhedrin.38a">Babli 38a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 8:3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.8.3">Tosephta 8:4</a>.</i>“Man was created single in the world because of the families, lest they should attack one another. Is that not argument <i>de minore ad majus</i>? Since now that they are all descendants of one father they attack one another, if they had been descendants of two not so much more? Another explanation: The just ones should not say, we are the descendants of a just man, but you are the sons of evildoers<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">There is no predestination, genetic or otherwise.</i>.”
“And to proclaim the greatness of the King over kings of kings, the Holy One, praise to Him,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">There is no predestination, genetic or otherwise.</i> To proclaim the greatness of the King over kings of kings Who from one die coins all seals and no one is like the other, as it is said: <i>The seal turns around like clay</i><sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 38:15" href="/Job.38.15"><i>Job</i> 38:15</a>; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kilayim 9:3:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kilayim.9.3.3"><i>Kilaim</i> 9:4 Note 78</a>.</i>. Why did He change their looks<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Greek πρόσωπος.</i>? That no man should jump and go to another’s wife or another’s field. It was stated in the name of Rebbi Meïr: Three things did the Holy One, praise to Him, diversify in humans: looks of the face, understanding, and voice. Looks and understanding because of the robbers, voice because of forbidden women. Rebbi Isaac said, even a fig tree or a wheat plant is not identical to any other. Man was created Sabbath Eve so from the start he should enter with a commandment<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">To celebrate the Sabbath.</i>. Another explanation: Why was he created last? A parable of a king who made a banquet. After he had ordered the meal, he invited the guests. <sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 9:1" href="/Proverbs.9.1"><i>Prov</i>. 9:1</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 9:2" href="/Proverbs.9.2">2</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 9:4" href="/Proverbs.9.4">4</a>.</i><i>So wisdom built her house</i>, that is the Holy One, praise to Him, Who created the world in wisdom, as it is said, <i>the Eternal in wisdom based the earth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 3:19" href="/Proverbs.3.19"><i>Prov</i>. 3:19</a>.</i>, etc. <i>She quarried its seven pillars</i>, these are the seven days of creation. <i>She slaughtered her slaughtering, mixed her wine</i>, these are seas and rivers and all the needs of the world. <i>Any silly one shall come here</i>, that is Adam and Eve.
“Maybe you will say, why should we go to all this trouble,” etc. It is written: <i>The clamor erupted in the camp</i><sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 22:36" href="/I_Kings.22.36"><i>1K.</i> 22:36</a>.</i>. What is “the clamor”? Quiet<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">According to N. Brüll, <i>Jahrbuch für</i> <i>jüdische Geschichte und Literatur</i> 1, p. 134, this is Greek εὶρήνη “peace, quiet”. Cf. also <i>Pesiqta dR. Cahana</i> 20 (ed. S. Buber p. 141a Note 10, as explanation of the verbal form רָנִּי, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 54:1" href="/Isaiah.54.1"><i>Is</i>. 54:1</a>). The death of the evil king Ahab (v. 35) brought quiet to everybody.</i>. And so it says, <i>when they went in front of the armed forces</i><sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 20:21" href="/II_Chronicles.20.21"><i>2Chr</i>. 20:21</a>. The argument is from the part of the verse which is not quoted. When the Levites went before the army against the Moabites and Edomites, they sang: <i>give praise to the Eternal, for His Grace is forever</i>, intentionally changing the traditional text (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 118:1" href="/Psalms.118.1"><i>Ps</i>. 118:1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 136:1" href="/Psalms.136.1">136:1</a>), <i>give praise to the Eternal</i> for He is good, <i>for His Grace is forever</i>.</i>, to teach that even the downfall of the evildoers is no joy before the Omnipresent.

Chapter 5



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">0</sup><i class="footnote">For this Chapter and the next, there exists a Genizah text, published by M. Assis in <i>Tarbiz</i> 47 (1977) 29–90, 321–329, compared to the Leiden text. Additions from this text will be denoted G.</i> They were investigating him in seven ways<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">The number seven may be taken from Roman law, formulated in Quintilian’s hexameter which enumerates the questions to be answered in a trial: <i>Quis, quid, ubi, quibus auxiliis, cur, quomodo, quando?</i> “Who? What? Where? By means of what? For what purpose? How? When?” But questions 4,5,6 are reserved for cross-examination, not investigation (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:9:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.9.1">Chapter 4, Note 1</a>) (E. G.).</i>: In which Sabbatical period, in which year<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">In the Sabbatical period. It is clear from this Mishnah that for capital crimes there is no statute of limitations.</i>, in which month, which day of the month, which day, which hour, at which place<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah is a direct continuation of the preceding Chapter. Testimony is acceptable in court only if given under the possible penalties of perjury. But the only way the biblical penalties can be imposed is that the witnesses are proven not to have been at the indicated place of the crime at the time indicated. Therefore, exact determination of time and place are prerequisites to the trial.</i>? Rebbi Yose said, which day, which hour, which place<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">He has only three questions before the actual crime is investigated.</i>, do you recognize him, and did you warn him<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">A conviction in biblical law is possible only if criminal intent is proven. This is provable only by two witnesses who testify that they saw the defendant intent on committing a crime and informed him that his intended action was prohibited and that he exposed himself to such and such penalties.</i>? If one worshipped idols, what did he worship and how did he worship<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Actions which imitate worship of Heaven or are specific for a certain deity are capital crimes; any other actions are punishable only by whipping or not at all (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:9:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.9.1">Mishnah 7:12</a>).</i>?
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “They were investigating him in seven ways,” etc. But we did not state, in which Jubilee period? For that is not current<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Jubilee was not observed during Second Temple times (cf <i>Ševiˋit</i> 1:1 <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:1:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.1.2">Note 7</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:2:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.2.6"><i>Qiddušin</i> 1:2 Notes 190–191</a>) except possibly for the determination of Sabbatical periods, one cannot assume that the witnesses were able to determine the year by its position in a Jubilee period.</i>. It was found stated: Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai says, also in which Jubilee period<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 40b" href="/Sanhedrin.40b">Babli 40b</a>.</i>? We confirmed that in a year which started or concluded [a Jubilee period]<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">At least during the existence of the Temple, close to the beginning or the end of a Jubilee period everybody can be assumed to be alerted to the change in computation of Sabbatical periods induced by the (not observed) Jubilee. Everybody agrees that after the destruction of the Temple, the determination of the Jubilee period was meaningless. Therefore, the Mishnaiot dealing with procedures in criminal trials are attempts of reconstruction of Hasmonean or even earlier procedures.</i>.
From where the seven investigations? Samuel the Elder stated before Rebbi Aḥa: <i>You shall inquire, investigate, ask in depth, and behold, the matter is well founded</i><sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:15" href="/Deuteronomy.13.15"><i>Deut</i>. 13:15</a>. The judicial inquiry is described by seven words.</i>. He told him, this verse does not work<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">At least another word has to be added to reach the next dividing accent; stopping at נָכוֹן is unjustified. On the other hand, the two words דָּרַשׁתָּ הֵיטֵב represent a single notion.</i>; but: <i>you shall inquire, investigate, ask in depth; it will be told to you, you shall listen, ask in depth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:4" href="/Deuteronomy.17.4"><i>Deut</i>. 17:4</a>.</i>. In depth, in depth for an equal cut, to require in each case listening, asking, inquiry, and investigation<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">Both verses 13:15 and 17:4 mention five notions each of inquiry; eliminating the words appearing twice one is left with seven different words. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 40a" href="/Sanhedrin.40a">Babli 40a</a>, <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 93.</i>. Rebbi Isaac asked about this: If they caught an armed robber in Tiberias and said, this is the murderer, this is the murdered; why does this need seven investigations<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Is the situation not obvious?</i>? Issi said, any time that the witnesses could not be proven perjured, the murderer cannot be executed on that testimony<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Since perjured witnesses in a capital case can be executed if it was shown that they could not have seen the act since at the pretended time they were at another place, a criminal trial can proceed only if the witnesses can be made to testify about the exact time and place where the observed criminal act took place.</i>.
“Do you recognize him?” Who was he, a Gentile<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Then it would be a case for the king’s court, not the Sanhedrin.</i> or an Israel? Let us hear from what Rebbi Joḥanan said: If he was slain between Tiberias and Sepphoris, it is <i>prima facie</i> evidence that he was an Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">In order to remove the case to a police court, the defendant would have to prove that the slain person was a Gentile. As a practical matter, an unknown corpse found on the road between Tiberias and Sepphoris is a <i>corpse of obligation</i> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nazir 7:1:2-22" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nazir.7.1.2-22"><i>Nazir</i> 7:1</a>).</i>.
“Did you warn him?” From where warning? Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman in the name of Rebbi Jonathan: <sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:17" href="/Leviticus.20.17"><i>Lev</i>. 20:17</a>. In a slightly different setting, this paragraph also is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 11:1:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.11.1.5"><i>Yebamot</i> 11:1, Notes 25–26</a>. Incest with one’s sister is criminal (although by the earthly court only punishable by flogging) while it was permitted to earlier generations. Therefore, it cannot be assumed that everybody knows it to be prohibited. People found engaged in incestuous acts cannot be prosecuted unless before the act informed of its criminality.</i><i>A man who would take his sister</i> …, <i>it is</i> ḥesed. Rebbi Bun said, Cain married his sister, Abel married his sister. <i>It is charitable</i>, I was charitable with the first generations so the world could be inhabited; <i>I said, the world was to be built on</i> ḥesed<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 89:3" href="/Psalms.89.3"><i>Ps</i>. 89:3</a>.</i>.
It was stated: Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai said, <i>by the mouth of two witnesses</i> <i>shall the dead die</i><sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:6" href="/Deuteronomy.17.6"><i>Deut</i>. 17:6</a>. In the Babli, this is an Amoraic argument. The verse is read as: <i>by the mouth of two witnesses shall the dead kill himself</i>, i. e., in the presence of two witnesses he accepts to be killed.</i>. Does he die when dead? But to tell him by which kind of death he will be executed. It was stated: Rebbi Jehudah ben Rebbi Illai said, <i>and if a man intentionally kill his neighbor knowingly</i><sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:14" href="/Exodus.21.14"><i>Ex</i>. 21:14</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 41a" href="/Sanhedrin.41a">Babli 41a</a>. Babli and <i>Mekhiltot</i> read the verse as freeing the mentally disabled from prosecution.</i>; they shall inform him by which kind of death he will be executed.
If his death should have been a severe one<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah 7:1, Note 1.</i> but they warned him about an easy one. He could say that had he known that his death was to be severe, he would not have committed that crime. If his death should have been an easy one but they warned him about a severe one; in the opinion of Rebbi Jehudah ben Rebbi Illai they have to inform him by which kind of death he will be executed<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">R. Jehudah finds the warning deficient, preventing the imposition of a death sentence. By contrast, in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 80b" href="/Sanhedrin.80b">Babli, 80b</a>, it is stated as commonly accepted that a warning about a painful death implies the same of an easy one.</i>.
“If they warned him and he remained silent, they warned him and he nodded his head, even if he said, I know, he cannot be prosecuted unless he say: for that purpose I am doing it.<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 11:1" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.11.1">Tosephta 11:2</a>. Cf. also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:1:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.1.6">Note 20</a>.</i>” “If they saw him spilling blood; they told him, know that he is a son of the Covenant<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">A Jew.</i> and the Torah said, <i>he who spills a man’s blood, by man his blood shall be spilled</i><sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 9:6" href="/Genesis.9.6"><i>Gen</i>. 9:6</a>. The quote seems to be slightly out of place since it is directed at Gentile criminal courts which are not under the severe restrictions imposed at Torah courts.</i>, even if he said, I know, he cannot be prosecuted unless he say: for that purpose I am doing it<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 11:1" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.11.1">Tosephta 11:4</a>.</i>.” “If they saw him desecrating the Sabbath; they told him, know that today is Sabbath and the Torah said, <i>its desecrators shall be put to death</i><sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 31:14" href="/Exodus.31.14"><i>Ex</i>. 31:14</a>.</i>, even if he said, I know, he cannot be prosecuted unless he say: for that purpose I am doing it<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 11:1" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.11.1">Tosephta 11:3</a>.</i>.”
Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Gamda asked<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">His question is about the degree of specificity required in the warning delivered to a person ready to commit a crime punishable by death. Is it sufficient to deliver a general warning as described in the preceding paragraph (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:1:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.1.8">Note 27</a>) or does one have to specify the exact paragraph of the law being violated? In the case of the Sabbath, is it enough to warn a person not to do any work or does he have to be warned about which of the 39 prohibited types of work he is going to perform? The biblical evidence about the gatherer (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:32-36" href="/Numbers.15.32-36"><i>Num</i>. 15:32–36</a>) shows that the Tosephta was correct in requiring only a general warning.</i>: What was the gatherer’s guilt? Because of tearing off or because of reaping<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">In the list of the forbidden categories of work (Mishnah <i>Šabbat</i> 7:2–4) only reaping is mentioned, which means cutting off the produce from its root. All forms of harvesting are forbidden as derivatives of reaping. The question remains whether a warning about tearing off from the ground would also cover reaping; a warning about reaping certainly covers all forms of harvesting.</i>? Let us hear from the following: <i>The Children of Israel were in the desert when they found</i> … This teaches that he was tearing wood off the ground<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sifry Num</i>. 113.</i>.
Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Gamda asked: How was the gatherer put to death<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">According to R. Jehudah, he could not be put to death if the specific way of execution was not known even though the fact that violating the Sabbath was known to be a capital crime.</i>? By stoning. Let us hear from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Section 14 5" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Section_14.5"><i>Sifra Emor Parashah</i> 14(5</a>).</i>: “They knew that the gatherer should be executed but they did not know how he should be put to death.” It was found that Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: <i>Take the blasphemer outside the camp</i><sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 24:14" href="/Leviticus.24.14"><i>Lev</i>. 24:14</a>. This proves that from the pentateuchal stories nothing can be inferred for the rules of procedure required at later times. While it was known that a Sabbath infraction was punishable by death (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:1:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.1.8">Note 28</a>), nothing was known about the penalty for blasphemy. Therefore, the first time these crimes occurred after the epiphany on Sinai, the law was only being formed; it was not yet consolidated (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 78b" href="/Sanhedrin.78b">Babli 78b</a>).</i>. How was he put to death? By stoning.
“What did he worship?” <i>Peor</i> or Mercury<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:9:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.9.1">Mishnah 7:12</a>, the worship of <i>Baˋal Peˋor</i> was by defecating in front of his statue; the worship of <i>Mercurius</i>, the Greek <i>Hermes</i>, was by throwing an additional stone on the heap surrounding the <i>Hermes</i>, the pillar representing the divinity. Both forms of worship would be an insult if performed for any other idol and, therefore, not punishable.</i>? “And how did he worship?” In its proper worship or the worship of Heaven<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">Any imitation of Temple worship for an idol is a capital crime. Any other sort of worship is punishable only if ordinarily it was performed for that idol.</i>? Let us hear from the following: It happened that two [witnesses] came and said, we saw that this one was worshipping idols, but we do not know whether it was <i>Peor</i> or Mercury<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Clearly, this is inadmissible testimony.</i>. One judges him for both and for the one in which he was found innocent one lets him go<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Since the accused must be found innocent of one of two mutually exclusive allegations, one may accept the witnesses by basing a trial on their testimony even if a not-guilty verdict is a foregone conclusion.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Anybody who adds inquiries<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">About the details of the crime which are investigated after time and place have been established.</i> is praiseworthy. It happened that Ben Zakkai<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">According to the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 41" href="/Sanhedrin.41">Babli, 41a/b</a>, it is possible that he is Rabban Johanan ben Zakkai. During the time that capital jurisdiction was still in the hands of a Jewish court, not yet in that of the Roman governor, he was not yet the head of the Synhedrion and, therefore, had no title.</i> cross-examined about fig stalks. What is the difference between investigations and cross-examinations? In investigations, if one said “I do not know”, their testimony is worthless<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">As testimony which cannot be shown to be perjured.</i>. In cross-examinations, if one said “I do not know”, or even two say “we do not know,” their testimony remains valid<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">The credibility of the witnesses may be impaired. This is a matter to be decided by the judges, not an absolute obstacle.</i>. Both in investigations and cross-examinations, if they contradict one another their testimony is worthless<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">A conviction requires testimony by two witnesses. If there are conflicting testimonies and the judges believe one of them, no conviction could result since it would be based on the word of one witness alone.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Anybody who adds inquiries,” etc. How did he pluck them<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">An example of Ben Zakkai’s inquiry; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 41a" href="/Sanhedrin.41a">Babli 41a</a>.</i>? He plucked them with their stalks. How did he eat them? With their pits<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Referring to olives.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">Parallel texts to this and the following paragraphs are in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 15:5:3-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.15.5.3-4"><i>Yebamot</i> 15:5 (Notes 115–134</a>) and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nazir 3:7:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nazir.3.7.2">Nazir 3:7 (Notes 110–112</a>).</i> There, we have stated: “If two groups of witnesses were testifying against a person, one group say that he vowed <i>nazir</i> twice, the others say that he vowed <i>nazir</i> five times. The House of Shammai say, the testimony is split and there is no <i>nezirut</i> there. But the House of Hillel say, five contains two; he should be a <i>nazir</i> twice.” Rav said, they differ in the overall testimony. But in detail, everybody agrees that the testimony is split. Rebbi Joḥanan said, they differ in counting. But in an overall testimony, everybody agrees that five contains two. What is overall and what is counting? Overall, this one says two, the other one says five. Counting, this one says one, two, the other one says three, four.
Rav said, if testimony was contradictory in its essence, the testimony is not void. Rebbi Joḥanan said, if testimony is contradictory in itself, the testimony is void. In the opinion of everybody, if testimony was contradictory in aspects that belong after the fact, the testimony is not void. The strength of Rebbi Joḥanan is consistent with what Rebbi Abba bar<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Read with the parallel sources: R. Abba, R. Hiyya.</i> Ḥiyya said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, if it was agreed that he counted but one [witness] said, he counted from a wallet, and the other said, he counted from a bundle, that contradicts the essence of the testimony, and Rav will agree that the testimony be void. Where do they disagree? If there were two groups of witnesses, one says he counted from a wallet and the other says he counted from a bundle. That contradicts the essence of the testimony: the testimony is void, but according to Rav, the testimony is not void. One said, he counted into his bosom, but the other said, he counted into his money-belt: everybody agrees that this contradicts the essence of the testimony but the testimony is not void. If one [witness] said, he killed him with a sword, the other [witness] said, he killed him with a mace, that contradicts the essence of the testimony; Rav will agree that the testimony be void. Where do they disagree? If there were two groups of witnesses, one says he killed him with a sword and the other says, he killed him with a mace. That contradicts the essence of the testimony, the testimony is void, but according to Rav, the testimony is not void. One says, he turned to the North and one says, he ran away to the South, everybody agrees that the testimony was contradictory in aspects that belong after the fact, and the testimony is not void. The strength of Rav comes from what we have stated there: “Rebbi Jehudah and Rebbi Simeon say, since both agree that he is not alive they can be remarried.” He did not hear that Rebbi Eleazar said, Rebbi Jehudah and Rebbi Simeon concede in the case of witnesses. What is the difference between witnesses and the co-wife? They do not consider the co-wife’s words compared to those of her companion. Rebbi Joḥanan said, if Rebbi Eleazar said this, he said it because he had heard it from me. The Mishnah disagrees with Rav: “Both in investigations and cross-examinations, if they contradict one another their testimony is worthless.” What does Rav do with this? Rebbi Mana said, Rav will explain it as referring to single witness against single witness. Rebbi Abun said, even if you say groups and groups. There is a difference in criminal cases, as it is written: <i>Justice, justice you shall pursue</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One says, on the second of the month, but the other says, on the third of the month<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">In the investigation of the date on which the alleged crime was committed.</i>, their testimony may be valid, since one knew about the addition to the month but the other did not know<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">In the absence of a published calendar, one cannot assume that everybody knew when a thirtieth day was added to a month. In the published calendar used today, only the eighth and ninth months are variable but the Mishnaic calendar (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Arakhin 8b-10a" href="/Arakhin.8b-10a">Babli <i>Arakhin</i> 8b–10a</a>) admitted up to four variable months. It is up to the court to determine whether the witnesses intended to testify about one and the same day.</i>. One says on the third, the other says on the fifth, their testimony is invalid<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">Two days’ difference cannot be explained away.</i>. One says, at two hours<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">The time between sunrise and sunset is divided into 12 hours. At all calendar dates, 6 hours is about noontime. At the equinoxes, 2 hours is 8 am, 3 hours 9 am, 5 hours 11 am, 7 hours 1 pm.</i> but the other said at three hours, their testimony is valid<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">From people who have no watches.</i>. One says at three but the other says at five, their testimony is invalid; Rebbi Jehudah says it is valid. One says at five but the other says at seven, their testimony is invalid since at five hours the sun is in the East but at seven in the West<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">The last statement is needed only for R. Jehudah. R. Jehudah does not accept testimony that differs by two hours in all cases; he notes that daylight between 9 am and 11 am is not very different; but the shadows are quite different between am and pm hours.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “One says, on the second of the month,” etc. Until when<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">May one assume that people do not know which day of the month a given day is.</i>? Rebbi Yasa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Up to the greater part of the month<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">After the 16<sup class="footnote-marker">th</sup>, everybody knows how the month was determined.</i>. Rebbi Yose said, e. g., those village dwellers<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">They have a need to know the day of the week, but not of the month.</i>. But the Sages say, it is nothing<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">It is unclear whether the Sages object to the Mishnah or to R. Johanan’s statement. From R. Yasa it seems that they object to R. Johanan.</i>, and Rebbi Yasa said, for example I, who never in my life prayed <i>musaf</i><sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">The additional prayer which distinguishes the morning service of the New Moon from the weekday services.</i>, since I do not know when the month starts<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">He and his colleague Immi (Ammi) never were part of the Academy of Tiberias; it seems that they never were invited to the meetings at which the calendar was determined. This was his way of protesting.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">Most of this text belongs to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Pesachim 1:4:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Pesachim.1.4.2-7"><i>Pesahim</i> 1:4</a>. The scribe of the Leiden ms., after the text translated here in the first 5 paragraphs, wrote: “one continues in <i>Sanhedrin</i> until ˋthe sun never starts setting’.” The corrector who prepared the ms. for the Venice printer added the omitted portion; his text differs from the one given here by both an addition and a lacuna. It is impossible to decide whether the corrector’s <i>Pesahim</i> text is copied from a different ms. or represents the corrector’s emendations of the Sanhedrin text. In neither text is the use of references “here” and “there” (either <i>Pesaḥim</i> or <i>Sanhedrin</i>) completely consistent.</i> Rebbi Meïr says, from noontime on it is from their words; Rebbi Jehudah says, from noontime on it is biblical<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">The main topic of the following section is the prohibition of leavened matter on Passover. It is agreed by everybody that leavened matter must be disposed of by noontime (the end of the sixth hour) of the 14<sup class="footnote-marker">th</sup> of Nisan. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Pesachim 1:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Pesachim.1.4.1">Mishnah <i>Pesahim</i> 1:4</a>, R. Meïr states that “one eats [leavened bread] during all of the fifth hour (between 10 and 11 am local time) and burns the remainder at the start of the sixth hour (shortly after 11 am). R. Jehudah says, one eats during the entire fourth hour (9 to 10 am local time), one suspends leavened matter during the fifth hour and burns the remainder at the start of the sixth. (“Suspending” means that eating leavened matter is forbidden but usufruct is permitted.)<br>The anonymous majority in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:3:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.3.2-5"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 5:3</a> is presumed to represent R. Meïr’s opinion. The question now remains whether the disagreement between R. Meïr and R. Jehudah in <i>Sanhedrin</i> is the same as in <i>Pesahim</i> or not.</i>. What is Rebbi Meïr’s reason? <i>Only on the first day</i><sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:15" href="/Exodus.12.15"><i>Ex</i>. 12:15</a>: <i>Seven days you shall eat mazzot</i>; <i>only on the first day you shall eliminate sour dough from your houses</i> …  אַךְ might also be translated as “certainly”.</i>, that is the fifteenth<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:14" href="/Exodus.12.14"><i>Ex</i>. 12:14</a> states: <i>This day shall be a remembrance for you</i>; <i>you shall keep it as a holiday of pilgrimage for the Eternal</i> … <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 28:15-16" href="/Numbers.28.15-16"><i>Num.</i> 28:15–16</a> require that the 14<sup class="footnote-marker">th</sup> of Nisan be <i>pesah</i> for the Eternal; starting from the 15<sup class="footnote-marker">th</sup> for seven days it is the holiday of <i>mazzot.</i> Since <i>pesaḥ</i> (i. e., the day of the slaughter of the <i>pesah</i> sacrifice) is connected inextricably with the holiday of <i>mazzot</i>, the reference in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 28:14" href="/Numbers.28.14">v. 14</a> to the “first day” is intrinsically ambiguous, whether it refer to <i>pesaḥ</i> or to the holiday.</i>. I could think at nightfall; the verse says <i>only</i>, to separate<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">A similar argument is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 4b" href="/Pesachim.4b">Babli, <i>Pesaḥim</i> 4b</a>, <i>Mekhilta</i> <i>dR</i>. <i>Ismael</i> (ed. Horovitz-Rabin p. 28), <i>Mekhilta</i> <i>dR</i>. <i>Simeon</i> <i>b</i>. <i>Ioḥai</i> (ed. Epstein-Melamed p. 17).</i>. How is this? Give it one hour before sundown<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., the only biblical requirement is that all leavened matter be completely disposed of before the holiday at sundown.</i>. What is Rebbi Jehudah’s reason? <i>Only on the first day</i><sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:15" href="/Exodus.12.15"><i>Ex</i>. 12:15</a>: <i>Seven days you shall eat mazzot</i>; <i>only on the first day you shall eliminate sour dough from your houses</i> …  אַךְ might also be translated as “certainly”.</i>, that is the fourteenth. I could think the entire day; the verse says <i>only</i>, to separate. Half for leavened matter, half for <i>mazzah</i>. Rebbi Meïr’s argument seems inverted. There, he said <i>only</i> to add; here he said <i>only</i> to diminish<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that this refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:16" href="/Exodus.12.16"><i>Ex</i>. 12:16</a>: … <i>no work shall be done</i>[<i>on the holidays</i>], only <i>what may be eaten by any soul</i>,<i>it alone may be made by you.</i> Everybody agrees that food may be prepared on a holiday. According to R. Meïr (i. e., the anonymous opinion in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 1:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.1.6.1">Mishnah <i>Megillah</i> 1:8</a>) <i>only</i> food may be prepared, not preparations necessary for the preparation of food. According to R. Jehudah (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 1:6:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.1.6.2-5"><i>Megillah</i> 1:8</a>), anything that in the end leads to preparation of food is permitted on a holiday. R. Meïr reads <i>only</i> as a restriction in v. 16 and as an addition in v. 15!</i>. Rebbi Samuel bar Eudaimon said, he diminished, lest it be for<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">Read with the <i>Pesahim</i> text בחמץ instead of מחמץ. The extension of a prohibition parallels the restriction of a permission.</i> leavened matter. Rebbi Meïr said, <i>do not eat leavened matter with it</i><sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 16:3" href="/Deuteronomy.16.3"><i>Deut</i>. 16:3</a>, referring to the <i>pesah</i> sacrifice which is slaughtered on the afternoon of the 14<sup class="footnote-marker">th</sup> and eaten in the night of the 15<sup class="footnote-marker">th</sup>.</i>, while it is eaten. Rebbi Jehudah said, <i>do not eat leavened matter with it</i>, while it is prepared<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">In the afternoon of the 14<sup>th</sup>. This supports R. Jehudah’s contention that leavened matter is biblically forbidden in the afternoon of the 14<sup>th</sup>; <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 130.</i>.
Rebbi Jehudah has both a positive and a negative commandment concerning its eating<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">“It” here refers to <i>mazzah</i>.</i>, a positive and a negative commandment concerning its<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">“It” here refers to leavened matter.</i> removal. A positive commandment concerning its eating, <i>seven days you shall eat unleavened bread for it</i><sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 16:3" href="/Deuteronomy.16.3"><i>Deut</i>. 16:3</a>, referring to the <i>pesah</i> sacrifice which is slaughtered on the afternoon of the 14<sup class="footnote-marker">th</sup> and eaten in the night of the 15<sup class="footnote-marker">th</sup>.</i>, not leavened. Any prohibition which is implied by a positive commandment has the status of positive commandment<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">It is not an indictable offense; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bikkurim 1:5:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bikkurim.1.5.4"><i>Bikkurim</i> 1:5, Note 103</a>. If a positive commandment is in conflict with a negative one (a prohibition), the positive is stronger. But an obligation which is both positive and negative is stronger than anything else.</i>. A negative commandment concerning its eating, <i>do not eat leavened</i><sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 16:3" href="/Deuteronomy.16.3"><i>Deut</i>. 16:3</a>; the word עָלָיו is missing here, supplied in <i>Pesahim</i>.</i>. A positive commandment concerning its removal, <i>seven days</i> … <i>you shall remove sour dough from your houses</i><sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:15" href="/Exodus.12.15"><i>Ex</i>. 12:15</a>: <i>Seven days you shall eat mazzot</i>; <i>only on the first day you shall eliminate sour dough from your houses</i> …  אַךְ might also be translated as “certainly”.</i>. A negative commandment concerning its removal, <i>for seven days sour dough shall not be found in your houses</i><sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:19" href="/Exodus.12.19"><i>Ex</i>. 12:19</a>.</i>.
Now Rebbi Meïr says, after noontime it is forbidden because of their words. The <sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">The numerals in parentheses are from <i>Sanhedrin</i>; those in brackets are the corrected ones from <i>Pesaḥim</i>. For R. Meïr, the biblical prohibition of leavened matter starts at the 11<sup class="footnote-marker">th</sup> hour (5 pm local time). The earlier afternoon hours, including the 7th, are rabbinically forbidden as a “fence around the law”. Then it is difficult to understand why leavened matter has to be burned <i>at the start</i> of the 6<sup class="footnote-marker">th</sup>, extending the rabbinic prohibition for another hour as a fence around the fence, a practice generally rejected.</i>(sixth) [seventh] hour it is forbidden because of a fence. Why the (fifth) [sixth]? Because of a fence. Is there a fence around a fence? But the (fifth) [sixth] may be confounded with the seventh<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">It is not a fence around a fence but consistent with the opinion of the Sages (R. Meïr) in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:3:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.3.2-5"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 5:3</a>. In a society without watches the difference between 11am and 12am is not generally recognized; a prohibition enforced after noontime must practically be enforced starting from 11am.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah’s argument seems inverted. There<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">This is here, in the Mishnah <i>Sanhedrin</i>. R. Jehudah agrees that while without watches people cannot distinguish between two morning or two afternoon hours, he explicitly agrees that people distinguish between fifth (10–11am) and seventh (12am–1pm).</i>, he says that the fifth cannot be confounded with the seventh. But here<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Pesahim</i> he requires one to stop eating leavened matter two hours before the start of the seventh hour when the biblical prohibition begins.</i>, he says that the fifth can be confounded with the seventh. Rebbi Yose said, there<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Pesaḥim</i> one speaks of household chores.</i> the matter is given over to women who are lazy, here<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Sanhedrin</i> the Mishnah does not require the court to accept any testimonies where the witnesses differ widely in fixing the time of a crime; R. Jehudah admonishes the court under certain circumstances to investigate whether the witnesses do not in reality testify about the same time; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 12b" href="/Pesachim.12b">Babli <i>Pesaḥim</i> 12b</a>.</i> the matter is given over to the court who is careful. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, there<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Sanhedrin</i> the Mishnah does not require the court to accept any testimonies where the witnesses differ widely in fixing the time of a crime; R. Jehudah admonishes the court under certain circumstances to investigate whether the witnesses do not in reality testify about the same time; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 12b" href="/Pesachim.12b">Babli <i>Pesaḥim</i> 12b</a>.</i> it is a matter between the beginning of the fifth and the end of the seventh hour. Here<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Pesahim</i> he requires one to stop eating leavened matter two hours before the start of the seventh hour when the biblical prohibition begins.</i> it is between the end of the fifth and the start of the seventh<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Pesahim</i> the period of doubt is little more than 60 min., in <i>Sanhedrin</i> close to 180 min. The apparent inconsistency is due to the informal use of “hour.”</i>. It also was stated thus<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">A similar <i>baraita</i> is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 12b" href="/Pesachim.12b"><i>Pesahim</i> <i>12b</a></i>.</i>: At the start of the fifth hour, the sun is in the East, and the end of the seventh the sun is in the West. The sun never starts setting before the end of the seventh hour.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> They brought in the second [witness] and examined him. If their testimonies were coherent, one starts with arguing for acquittal<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.1.1">Mishnah 4:1</a>.</i>. If one of the witnesses said, I have an argument for his acquittal<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">A witness for the prosecution who argues for acquittal undermines his own testimony. Anyhow, no witness can become judge in the same case (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:5:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.5.2-3">Halakhah 5</a>).</i>, or one of the students said, I have an argument for his conviction, one forces them to be silent. If one of the students said, I have an argument for his acquittal, one brings him up and lets him sit among them<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">The judges.</i>. He was not demoted from there the entire day; if his argument has substance, one listens to him. Even if he<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">The accused.</i> said, I have to argue for my acquittal, one listens to him if there is substance to his words.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> <i class="footnote">In the Tosephta: "They tell him, consider your earlier argument." This is understood here .</i> They brought in the second,” etc. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Tosephta 9:1.</i>: “If they found him innocent, they freed him; otherwise they hold his case over, split into groups of two, eat little and refrain from wine, and discuss during the entire night. The next morning they start early, the beadles of the synagogues come for them. They ask, Mr. X [ben Mr. Y. He says, present.]<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Addition from the Genizah text (Note 0); not absolutely necessary for the understanding of the text and not in the Tosephta.</i> I was for conviction and I still am for conviction; or I was for acquittal and I still am for acquittal; I was for conviction and now I am for acquittal; one accepts his vote. I was for acquittal and now I am for conviction; argue as before.<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">In the Tosephta: "They tell him, consider your earlier argument." This is understood here .</i>” It was stated: If one of the judges erred, the clerks of court remind him. If he was for conviction, they tell him, argue as before.
Rabbi La said, why does one record the argument of him who argues for acquittal? Because of him who argues for conviction, maybe his memory will fail him. If he switches his argument, they could say to him, this you said, this you did not say. [Does this mean] that it needs two [groups of] witnesses<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">The text in brackets is from the Genizah; it is not a better text. The Leiden text seems to follow R. Jehudah (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.8.1">Mishnah 4:9</a>) who requires that the arguments of each judge be recorded by two scribes, i. e., two witnesses who may prevent him from changing his mind. The Genizah text asks whether if an acquitting judge now wants to vote for conviction one has to start the entire proceedings anew. This would preclude pronouncing sentence on that day and would amount to forbidden procrastination in administering justice.</i>? It would mean that the trial would be extended. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, because of him who argues for acquittal<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.5.1">Mishnah 5</a> alone is justification enough.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If they found him innocent, they free him. Otherwise they hold his case over to the next day, split into groups of two, eat little and refrain from wine the entire day, and discuss during the entire night<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">The topic of discussion is not mentioned; it seems to be the case under consideration. In the Tosephta, the judges are required to review the legal background, if a murder case the laws of murder, if an incest case the laws of incest.</i>. The next morning they start early. One who voted for acquittal says, I am for acquittal and I remain for acquittal. One who voted for conviction says, I am for conviction and I remain for conviction. He who voted for conviction may vote for acquittal; but he who voted for acquittal may not change and vote for conviction. If they erred in the matter, the two clerks of court will remind them.<br>If they found him innocent, they free him; otherwise they tally the vote. If twelve are for acquittal and eleven for conviction, he is found innocent. If twelve are for conviction and eleven for acquittal<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">A criminal conviction needs a qualified majority of at last two (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.2.1">Mishnah 4:2</a>). Since there was no majority for acquittal, the accused is neither acquitted nor convicted; this is a case of a hung court.</i>, or even twenty-two are for acquittal or conviction and one says, I do not know<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">A judge who abstains in the final vote is counted not present. Then the court is no longer composed of 23 members; there is a mistrial.</i>, they shall add judges.<br>Up to what number does one add? [One adds] two and two up to 71<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">The size of the Supreme Court is the upper limit for the size of any court.</i>. If 36 vote for acquittal and 35 for conviction, he is found innocent. If 36 vote for conviction and 35 for acquittal<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">The size of the Supreme Court is the upper limit for the size of any court.</i>, they have to continue to argue with one another until one of the voters for conviction is convinced by the arguments of those in favor of acquittal.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If they found him innocent, they free him,” etc. It was stated: If one of the witnesses said, I have an argument for his acquittal, and another came to support him, (and another came to support him,)<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">Corrector’s addition, to be deleted.</i> whom do you co-opt<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Following Mishnah 4 which, however, speaks of law students, not of witnesses. Only R. Yose ben R. Jehudah admits pleading by a witness (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 9:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.9.2">Tosephta 9:4</a>).</i>? Let us hear from the following of Rebbi Joḥanan: If somebody was acquitted following his own pleading, one does not place him with the judges. Therefore, if he was acquitted following (his own)<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">This must read: “the witness”.</i> pleading, then one person would be simultaneously witness and judge. We do not find that anybody can be both witness and judge.
In civil suits one declares the judgment as definitive<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">A strictly literal translation would be: “the judgment became old.” The interpretation of this otherwise unknown expression follows Rav Ashi in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 42a" href="/Sanhedrin.42a">Babli, 42a</a>. The case can neither be appealed nor retried.</i> [but in criminal suits one does not declare the judgment as definitive.]<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Addition also found in the Babli, implied by the preceding sentence. As long as a criminal sentence was not executed, the trial may be re-opened at any time if a new argument for acquittal can be presented.</i> The greatest among the judges declares the judgment as definitive <sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 42a" href="/Sanhedrin.42a">Babli 42a</a>.</i>.
“Up to what number does one add,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">This and the next paragraph refer to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:3:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.3.2">Halakhah 3:3</a>; the subject is civil suits.</i> It was stated: Why does one add judges? For if there were two of the original judges voting affirmatively<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">Even if two judges vote for the claimant but the third abstains, no judgment can be rendered by a court of two.</i>, together with one of the later ones judgment will be rendered by three. Rebbi La said, since the judgment can be rendered by four, one does not render it by three<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Although only one additional judge is needed, one always adds two. If only one judge were added, he would be unable to change the outcome; he is not really a judge of equal standing with the others. But two judges could force the addition of another two by voting for the defendant.</i>.
Rebbi Yose said, one understands from here: <sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">This is from <i>Ševi</i>ˋ<i>it</i> <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:4:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.4.4">10:3, Note 91</a> where <i>prozbol</i> is explained. The text there and in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 22a" href="/Ketubot.22a">Babli, <i>Ketubot</i> 22a</a>, is in the name of the earlier Amora R. Abba.</i> If three sat in judgment and one of them died, two sign and note: Even though we are two who sign, we were three in judging. Rebbi Ḥaggai said, a Mishnah implies this: “The judges sign at the bottom or the witnesses.” Does one learn court documents from <i>prozbol</i>? It was found stated: This about court documents he inferred from the rules of <i>prozbol</i>.
If nobody changes his opinion<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the Mishnah. If no one voting for conviction changes his mind, at the end of the day judgment must be rendered. What is the practical consequence of 36 votes for conviction, 35 for acquittal?</i>? Rebbi Joḥanan said, he is acquitted<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Since the votes for conviction fall short of the majority required, it is an automatic acquittal (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 42a" href="/Sanhedrin.42a">Babli 42a</a>).</i>. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, he is convicted<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">Since there is a majority for conviction, there can be no acquittal. R. Simeon ben Laqish will agree that if it is a capital case, the accused cannot be executed except the missionary for idolatry (Tosephta 10:12).</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said to him, is he not acquitted<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.2.1">Mishnah 4:2</a>.</i>? Why do they have to continue to argue with one another? So the judgment should not be in question<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">To discourage any attempt at a retrial.</i>.

Chapter 6



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If sentence was passed<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">If in a capital case the accused was condemned to death. In the list of biblical death penalties (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.1.1">Mishnah 7:1</a>) stoning is mentioned first; therefore, the details of the stoning procedure are explained first.</i>, one brings him out to be stoned. The place for stoning was outside the court as it is said: <i>Bring the blasphemer outside the camp</i><sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 24:14" href="/Leviticus.24.14"><i>Lev</i>. 24:14</a>. A walled city is the equivalent of the desert “camp”; the execution took place outside the city walls (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:4:12" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.4.12"><i>Ketubot</i> 4:6, Note 132</a>). However, the unfaithful preliminarily married virgin was stoned in front of her parents’ house (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:21" href="/Deuteronomy.22.21"><i>Deut</i>. 22:21</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 10:4" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.10.4">Tosephta 10:10</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 45b" href="/Sanhedrin.45b">Babli 45b</a>) and the idolator at his place of worship (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:5" href="/Deuteronomy.17.5"><i>Deut</i>. 17:5</a>; <i>Sifry</i> <i>Deut</i>. 148; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 45b" href="/Ketubot.45b">Babli <i>Ketubot</i> 45b</a>).</i>. One person was standing outside the court building with towels in his hand<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>sudarium</i>, -<i>i</i>,<i>n</i>.; in the Talmudim used for any rectangular piece of cloth too small to cover the body. Here it is used for signal flags.</i>; a horse<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Meaning: a man on a horse.</i> was standing ready at a distance but so he could see him<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">The horse was stationed on the road to the place of execution as far away as possible so that the rider still could see the person holding the signal flags.</i>. If one said<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">One of the judges or of the law students remaining in the court building.</i>, I have an argument in his favor, that one waves his towels, the horse gallops and stops him<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The procession to the place of execution cannot start until the judges reassemble and decide whether the new argument is weighty enough to restart the deliberations towards a new vote.</i>. Even if he himself says, I have an exculpatory argument for myself, one returns him<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">To the court building to present his case to the judges.</i> even four or five times, on condition that his argument be substantial.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If sentence was passed,” etc. The Mishnah<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah has a blanket statement which treats all kinds of stoning in the same way (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 6:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.6.1.1">Note 2</a>). While it is not specified where the stoning takes place, it is clear that it cannot be in front of the court building, where the rabbis require the idolator to be stoned.</i> either follows Rebbi or the rabbis in a Gentile city<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The rabbis agree that in a city whose majority population is Gentile and idolatrous, a stoning for idolatry must take place in the Jewish quarter [<a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 10:1-3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.10.1-3">Tosephta Chapter 10</a> in the <i>editio princeps</i> (10:4 in the Wilna ed.), missing in Zuckermandel’s edition, Halakhah 10:10.]</i>. As we have stated: Rebbi said<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">A similar text is anonymous in <i>Sifry</i> <i>Deut</i>. 148.</i>, <i>at your gates</i><sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The paragraph about punishment for idolatry (D<i>eut.</i> 17:2–7) mentions that idolatry was practiced <i>at your gates</i> (v. 2) and that the idolator should be stoned <i>at your gates</i> (v. 5). The context indicates that the first <i>gate</i> is the place of worship, the second the place of execution. But the talmudic doctrine of unique meaning of lexemes requires that <i>at your gates</i> have the same meaning in both cases. Either the meaning in v. 5 is induced by that of v. 2 (Rebbi) or that in v. 2 by v. 5 (the rabbis). On methodological grounds, Rebbi’s position is preferred in the Babylonian sources (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 45b" href="/Ketubot.45b"><i>Ketubot</i> 45b</a> and <i>Sifry</i>).</i>, at the gate they were found. You are saying so, or maybe at the gate they were judged? It is said here, <i>at your gates</i>, and it says there, <i>if there be found in your midst, at one of your gates</i><sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:2" href="/Deuteronomy.17.2"><i>Deut</i>. 17:2</a>.</i>. Since <i>gates</i> mentioned there refers to the gate where he was found, <i>gates</i> mentioned here also refers to the gate where he was found. But the rabbis say, <i>at your gates</i>, at the gate where he was judged. You are saying so, or maybe at the gate were he was found? It is said here, <i>at your gates</i>, and it says there, <i>take this man or this woman</i> … <i>to your gates</i><sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:5" href="/Deuteronomy.17.5"><i>Deut</i>. 17:5</a>.</i>. Since <i>gates</i> mentioned there refers to the gate where he was judged, <i>gates</i> mentioned here also refers to the gate where he was judged.
Rebbi Joḥanan said, the first time one listens to him whether or not his arguments are substantial<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 9:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.9.2">Tosephta (9:4</a>): The first three times. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 45a" href="/Sanhedrin.45a">Babli (45a</a>) Rav Pappa’s statement parallels that of R. Joḥanan here.</i>. After that, if his arguments are substantial<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">As the Babli points out, this implies that some persons learned in the law are always near the condemned for preliminary evaluation of his arguments.</i> one listens to him, otherwise one does not listen to him. They said, only if his later arguments are substantial<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The statement of the Mishnah that the court is reconvened only if the arguments presented be substantial, refers only to the second and following times, not to the first appeal.</i>. Ḥizqiah asked: If he was led out to be executed when he became paralyzed, do we say that had he not become paralyzed, he would have argued for his acquittal? Rebbi Joḥanan heard this and said, this is a donkey’s question<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">It is stated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 6:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.6.2.1">Mishnah 2</a> that the entire world is invited to present exculpatory arguments. Do we say that because somewhere in the world a person may be paralyzed now, one can never execute anybody? (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 43a" href="/Sanhedrin.43a">Babli 43a</a> in the name of Babylonian scholars.)</i>. But it must be: If he was led out to be executed and said, I have to argue for my acquittal: when he became paralyzed, do we say that had he not become paralyzed, he would have argued for his acquittal? He said, that is a statement<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Hizqiah agrees with the reformulation and its consequence, <i>viz</i>., that the execution cannot proceed. The Babli leaves it as an open question.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If they found him innocent<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">Upon reconsideration.</i>, they free him, otherwise he is led to be stoned. The herald<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Greek κῆρυξ.</i> goes before him: “X ben Y is led to be stoned because he committed crime Z; U and V testified against him<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The call is for witnesses who can prove the original witnesses to be perjured.</i>. Anybody who knows of his innocence shall come and argue.”
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If they found him innocent,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Better versions of this paragraph are in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:5:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.5.3">10:8 Note 337</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 4:8:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.4.8.2"><i>Bava qamma</i> 4:9 Notes 122–125</a>.</i> It was stated: If a bull was led out to be stoned when its witnesses were found to be perjured, Rebbi Joḥanan said, the first to come acquires it; Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, it was a false declaration of ownerlessness<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">This is Babylonian spelling. The Yerushalmi form is הבקר.</i>. Similarly, if a slave was led out to be stoned when his owner dedicated him to the Temple<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">One has to read with the parallel sources: When his witnesses were found perjured. At the moment the slave is condemned to death, he loses all value for his owner; valueless objects cannot be dedicated. Therefore the dedication is the equivalent of declaring the slave ownerless.</i>, Rebbi Joḥanan said, he acquired himself; Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, it was false despair.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Ten cubits’ distance from the place of stoning one tells him: confess! So is the way of any dying person to confess, since anyone who confesses has part in the World to Come. For so we find about Achan towhom Joshua said, <i>my son</i>, <i>honor</i> <i>the Eternal</i>, <i>the God of Israel, confess to Him, and tell me what you did, do not hide it from me</i>. <i>Achan answered Joshua and said, in fact I sinned against the Eternal, the God of Israel, and such and such I did</i><sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 7:19-20" href="/Joshua.7.19-20"><i>Jos</i>. 7:19–20</a>.</i>. From where that his confession atoned for him? For it is said, <i>Joshua said to him</i>, <i>how did you devastate us</i>; <i>may the Eternal devastate you on this day</i><sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 7:25" href="/Joshua.7.25"><i>Jos</i>. 7:25</a>.</i>. This day you are devastated; you are not devastated in the Future World.<br>If he does not know how to confess, one tells him, say: “My death shall be atonement for all my sins.” Rebbi Jehudah said, if he knows that he was the victim of perjurers, he says: “My death shall be atonement for all my sins except this one.<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">For which he is being stoned.</i>” They told him, if so, everybody would say so to declare themselves innocent<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">And to declare the witnesses perjured and the judges bribed or incompetent.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Ten cubits’ distance from the place of stoning,” etc. You find that when Achan stole from the ban, Joshua started supplicating before the Holy One, praise to Him, and said: Master of the Universe, inform me who is the man. The Holy One, praise to Him, answered: I never publicize any creature. In addition, would I not be guilty of slander<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 11a" href="/Sanhedrin.11a">Babli 11a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 43b" href="/Sanhedrin.43b">43b</a>. An expanded version in <i>Tanhuma</i> <i>Masˋe</i> 5.</i>? But go and let Israel stand up by its tribes and throw lots, then immediately I shall draw him out. That is what is written: <i>Joshua got up early in the morning and summoned Israel by its tribes. Achan ben Karmi ben Zeraḥ from the tribe of Jehudah was caught</i><sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 7:16" href="/Joshua.7.16"><i>Jos</i>. 7:16</a>.</i>. Achan told him, how? Do you catch me by lots<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The entire procedure described in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 7:16-26" href="/Joshua.7.16-26"><i>Jos</i>. 7:16–26</a> cannot be justified either in pentateuchal or in rabbinic law.</i>? There is nobody more pious in the present generation than you or Phineas. Let lots be thrown between you, certainly<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Greek πάντως. The outcome of drawing of lots is essentially predetermined by the set from which the lot is drawn.</i> one of you will be caught. Not only this, but your teacher Moses died only 30 or 40 days ago. Did not our teacher Moses instruct us: <i>By the testimony of two witnesses</i><sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:15" href="/Deuteronomy.19.15"><i>Deut</i>. 19:15</a>.</i>? You started erring. At that moment did Joshua have a vision by the holy spirit how he distributes the Land to Israel by lots. That is what is written: <i>Joshua threw lots for them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 18:10" href="/Joshua.18.10"><i>Jos</i>. 18:10</a>.</i>. This means, we are giving lots a bad name. Not only this, but if lots are confirmed now, all of Israel will say, since the lots were true in criminal matters, so much more in money matters. But if they are repudiated now, all of Israel will say, since the lots were repudiated in criminal matters, so much more in money matters. At that moment, Joshua started supplicating Achan, entreated him in the name of Israel’s God, and said to him: <i>my son</i>, <i>honor the Eternal</i>,<i>the God of Israel</i>, … <i>Achan answered Joshua and said, in fact</i><sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 7:19-20" href="/Joshua.7.19-20"><i>Jos</i>. 7:19–20</a>.</i>. What means אָמְנָה? Truth<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Deriving אמנה from the root אמן.</i>. <i>I sinned against the Eternal, God of Israel</i>. He told him, I asked you for one and you are answering me two<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Referring to the doubling <i>such and such</i> in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 7:20" href="/Joshua.7.20">v. 7:20</a>.</i>? he answered, I stole from the ban of Midian and the ban of Jericho. Rebbi Tanḥuma said, he stole from four bans: The ban of the Phoenician, king of Arad, the ban of Siḥon and Og, the ban of Midian, the ban of Jericho. From where that his confession atoned for him? It is said<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">The assassin of king Ela, <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 16:10" href="/I_Kings.16.10"><i>1K</i>. 16:10</a>. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 7:19" href="/Joshua.7.19"><i>Jos</i>. 7:19</a>, the son of Zerah and father of Carmi is called <i>Zavdi</i>, not <i>Zimri</i>. This underlies the talmudic doctrine that all of Chronicles is to be explained alegorically.</i>, <i>the sons of Zeraḥ</i>: <i>Zimri and Ethan</i>, etc. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, Zimri is Achan who behaved like Zimri<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The assassin of king Ela, 1K. 16:10. In Jos. 7:19, the son of Zerah and father of Carmi is called <i>Zavdi</i>, not <i>Zimri</i>. This underlies the talmudic doctrine that all of Chronicles is to be explained alegorically.</i>. Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman said, <i>Heman</i><sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Aramaic הֵימָן is Hebrew נֶאֱמָן, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 6:3:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.6.3.2">Note 34</a>.</i> that is Achan, <i>omna</i> I sinned. <i>Altogether five</i>. Did I not know that they were five<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">Since the verse enumerates five sons of Zerah.</i>? But it teaches that Achan also has part in the World to Come<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Since he is counted together with Ethan and Heman, the composers of psalms. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 9:3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.9.3">Tosephta 9:5</a>.</i>.
“If he does not know how to confess,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 44b" href="/Sanhedrin.44b">Babli 44b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 9:3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.9.3">Tosephta 9:5</a>.</i>“It happened that one was led out to be executed. They told him, say: ˋMy death shall be atonement for all my sins.’ He said, ˋmy death shall be atonement for all my sins except for this sin; if I committed it, He<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">God.</i> should never forgive me, but the court of Israel is innocent.’ When the case came before the Sages, their tears flowed. They said, it is impossible to reopen the case<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Since the statement was not accompanied by any argument or proof of perjury. The Babli version is very difficult at this point.</i>, since it would never end. But this person’s blood hangs on the witnesses’ necks.”
“At a distance of four cubits from the place of stoning,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Makkot 5b" href="/Makkot.5b">Babli <i>Makkot</i> 5b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chagigah 16b" href="/Chagigah.16b">Hagigah 16b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 6:6" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.6.6">Tosephta 6:6</a>. The text is badly truncated; following the parallel sources it should read approximately:<br>Jehudah ben Ṭabbai said, may I never see consolation if I did not execute a perjured witness, for the Sadducees were saying, a perjured witness is not executed unless the accused was executed, as it is said, <i>a life for a life</i>. Simeon ben Shetah told him, may I never see consolation if it is not held against you that you spilled innocent blood since no perjured witness is executed unless both of them are shown to be perjured. At that time, he took it upon himself not to teach except what he heard from Simeon ben Sheṭaḥ.<br>This is the first of a series of treatments of the Simeon ben Shetaḥ legend (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 6:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.6.6.1">Mishnah 8</a>) before one returns to a discussion of the Mishnah.<br>If only one of the witnesses is found perjured, neither his testimony nor that of the other witness can be used against the accused since both are testimonies of single witnesses unsupported by a second witness. The case against the accused has to be dismissed; there is no case.</i>“Rebbi Jehudah ben Ṭabbai said, may I never see consolation if I did not execute a perjured witness, for they were saying, until he was executed, as it is said, <i>a life for a life</i>. Simeon ben Shetaḥ told him, may I never see consolation if it is not held against you that you spilled innocent blood. At that time, he took it upon himself not to teach except what he heard from Simeon ben Sheṭaḥ.”
Simeon ben Sheṭaḥ’s hands were hot<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">He was quick in persecuting persons not conforming to pharisaic standards (cf. H. Graetz, <i>Geschichte der Juden</i> 3–1<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup>, p. 146).</i>. There came a group of scoffers who said, let us take counsel, testify against his son, and kill him. They testified against him. He was sentenced to be executed. When he was taken to be killed, they told him, our Master, we are liars<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">They could confess their perjury with impunity. By Sadducee standards, a false witness in a capital case cannot be punished as long as the victim was not executed. By Pharisaic standards, no self-incrimination is admissible in court.</i>. His father wanted to return him<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">To have the conviction overturned, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 6:1:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.6.1.2-3">Halakhah 1</a>.</i>; he told him, my father, if you want that salvation come through you<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">By strict pharisaic (rabbinical) rules, witnesses cannot change their story once the phase of testimony was concluded and deliberations started (<i>Bava mesia`</i> 1:2 Note 30; <i>Ševi`it</i> 10:5 Note 96). By the strict letter of the law, there was no ground for reconsideration.</i>, treat me as a target<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Greek σκοπός, Latin <i>scopus</i>, “goal, target” (E. G.).</i>.
“The place of stoning was two man-sizes high,” etc. It happened that a pious man was walking on the road when he saw two people having sex with a bitch.
