They said, we know that this is a pious man, he will go, testify against us, and our lord David will kill us<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Which the king by his police powers could do on the information of one witness.</i>. Therefore, we shall be quicker than him and testify against him. They testified against him and he was sentenced to be executed. That is what David said<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 22:21" href="/Psalms.22.21"><i>Ps</i>. 22:21</a>.</i>, <i>Rescue my soul from the sword, From the dog my only one! From the sword</i>, Uriah’s sword. <i>From the dog</i>, the pious man’s dog.
Rebbi Jehudah ben Pazi went to the upper floor of the House of Study and saw two men in homosexual activity. They said to him, Rebbi! Realize that you are one and we are two!

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> At a distance of four cubits from the place of stoning one removes his clothes. One covers a man in front, a woman one covers front and back, the words of Rebbi Jehudah; but the Sages say, a man is stoned naked<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Except for a loin cloth.</i>, but no woman is stoned naked<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">She may not be touched by men.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">For the rest of this Chapter, Mishnaiot and Halakhot do not fit together in the ms. and <i>editio princeps</i>. The quotes at the start refer to the Mishnaiot indicated by the Halakhah; the text has been placed after the Mishnah to which it belongs. The text in this Halakhah is essentially a copy from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 1:5:5-6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.1.5.5-6.1"><i>Sotah</i> 1:5, Notes 226–232</a>.</i>“Rebbi Eliezer said,” etc. The argument of Rebbi Jehudah seems inverted. There, he says: “If her hair was beautiful, he did not uncover it.” And here, he says so? Here, anyhow she goes to her death, but there, maybe she will be found to be pure and the young priests would attack her. The argument of the rabbis seems inverted. There<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">This should be “here”, showing that the original is in <i>Sotah</i>.</i>, they say: “A man is stoned naked, but no woman is stoned naked.” And here<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">This should be “there”.</i>, they say so? Here, <i>you shall love your neighbor as yourself</i>, choose for him a decorous death. But here, <i>all women should be taught</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The place of stoning was two man-sizes high; one of the witnesses pushed him at his hips<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">As both Talmudim state, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 19:13" href="/Exodus.19.13"><i>Ex</i>. 19:13</a> implies that throwing down is part of stoning.</i>. If he fell on his breast, he turns him around on his back. If he died from this, it is sufficient; otherwise he takes the stone<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">According to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 9:3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.9.3">Tosephta 9:6</a>, a stone which needed two people to be lifted.</i> and puts it on his breast. If he died from this, it is sufficient; otherwise the second witness takes the stone and puts it on his breast<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence is missing in all parallels; it may be a case of dittography.</i>. If he died from this, it is sufficient; otherwise the stoning is on all of Israel as it is said: <i>The witnesses</i>’ <i>hand shall be first on him to kill him</i>,<i>the hand of the entire people afterwards</i><sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:7" href="/Deuteronomy.17.7"><i>Deut</i>. 17:7</a>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “All those stoned are hanged, the words of Rebbi Eliezer,” etc. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 45a" href="/Sanhedrin.45a">Babli, 45a</a>, and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 9:3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.9.3">Tosephta 9:6</a>, the height of the fall is 3 = 2+1 man-sizes.</i>: “Adding his own height, these are five.” Here you say, adding his own height, these are five. But for a pit in matters of damages, you say even ten handbreadths<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">A pit 10 handbreadths deep (1 2/3 cubits) already is life-threatening (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 5:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.5.6.1">Mishnah <i>Bava qamma</i> 5:7</a>).</i>. One cannot compare one who falls consciously, and one who falls accidentally. Rebbi Jonathan ben Ḥali, Rebbi Eudaimon the son of Rebbi Tabi’s daughter, in the name of Rebbi Josia: Those who throw down an ox with all their might<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">Cattle is slaughtered lying down. To push down an ox for slaughter may need great force; does one have to limit the force for fear of causing injuries to the ox, which would make it unfit as food?</i> do not cause any of its limbs to break<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 51b" href="/Chullin.51b">Babli <i>Hulin</i> 51b</a>.</i>. In the days of Rebbi Phineas they threw down an ox with all their might. He told them, By yourlives, free it. They freed it, it got up and fled. He said, praised be He Who selected the Sages and their pronouncements, for they say, those who throw down an ox with all their might not cause any of its limbs to break.
<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 45a" href="/Sanhedrin.45a">Babli 45a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 18:1-20:23" href="/Exodus.18.1-20.23"><i>Mekhilta dR</i>. <i>Ismael Yitro</i> 3 (p. 212</a>); <i>Mekhilta dR</i>. <i>Simeon ben Johai Yitro</i> p. 141.</i> From where that he needs to be stoned? For it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 19:13" href="/Exodus.19.13"><i>Ex</i>. 19:13</a>.</i>, <i>by stoning he be stoned</i>. From where that he needs to be pushed? For it is said, <i>by pushing he be pushed</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallel sources: From where that is is sufficient if he dies from being pushed? In the opinion of <i>Pene Moshe</i>, the second pushing is the turning on his back if he lands on his face.</i> From where that he needs two pushings? The verse says, <i>to be pushed</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Anyone who was stoned is hanged<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:22" href="/Deuteronomy.21.22"><i>Deut</i>. 21:22</a> is read as a requirement that the corpse of the criminal be hanged after execution, not as recognizing hanging as a legitimate form of execution.</i>, the words of Rebbi Eliezer. But the Sages say, only the blasphemer and the idolator are hanged. A man is hanged face to the people and a woman face to the pole, the words of Rebbi Eliezer. But the Sages say, a man is hanged<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">Since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:21" href="/Deuteronomy.21.21"><i>Deut</i>. 21:21</a> refers to <i>a man</i> being executed.</i>, a woman is not hanged.<br>Rebbi Eliezer said, it happened that Simeon ben Shetaḥ hanged women in Ascalon. They told him, he hanged eighty women, but one does not try two on the same day<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">In addition, he used hanging as a form of execution, which is forbidden.</i>.
Quel est le motif de R. Eliézer? Comme le blasphémateur, après être lapidé doit être pendu, de même on pendra tous les condamnés à la lapidation. Les autres sages au contraire disent: la Bible prescrit la pendaison pour le blasphémateur seul, parce qu’il touche à la question essentielle du culte (à la croyance en Dieu); aussi cette nouvelle pénalité est seulement applicable aux criminels de cet ordre (soit l’idolâtre outre le blasphémateur) –<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">Tout le reste du est traduit (Hagiga 2, 2).</i>.
Some Tannaïm state: Jehudah ben Ṭabbai was president; some Tannaïm state, Simeon ben Sheṭaḥ was president<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Chagigah 2:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Chagigah.2.2.1">Mishnah <i>Hagigah</i> 2:2</a> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Chagigah 16b" href="/Chagigah.16b">Babli <i>Hagigah</i> 16b</a>) where early disagreements between the presidents of the Supreme Court and their deputies over an aspect of Temple service are reported. The paragraph shows that this and the following paragraphs are originally from <i>Hagigah</i> (77d l. 33). In the Babli, Joshua ben Perahia everywhere replaces Jehudah ben Tabbai.<br>The Aramaic of the following texts shows that one deals with popular tales.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">This is a short excerpt of the text in <i>Hagigah</i>; the full text is given in G. But since the introductory sentence makes sense only in <i>Hagigah</i>, it may well be that the short reference here is original since the interest of the Halakhah is in the Simeon ben Sheṭaḥ story, and the Genizah text is an enlargement. Therefore, each text is presented separately.</i> What happened in Alexandria supports him who said, Jehudah ben Ṭabbai was president, since the people from Jerusalem did write: From the great Jerusalem to the small Alexandria: How long still will my husband live in your midst and I am sitting sorrowful in my house?
What happened in Ascalon supports him who said, Simeon ben Sheṭaḥ was president. Two students were in Ascalon. They ate together, drank together, and studied Torah together. One of them died, and nobody attended his funeral. The son of Ma`yan<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">“The source”, a symbolic name to contrast with the punishment of his son by eternal thirst.</i> the publican died; the entire city stopped working to attend his funeral. The other student started crying and said woe, do the haters of Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., the Jews. It is common that bad things should be said of your enemies, not of yourself.</i> have no hope? It was shown to him in his dream and said, do not denigrate your Master’s children. This one did one good deed and died with it, the other one committed one sin and died with it<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">It is a general answer to the question צדיק ורע לו רשע וטוב לו “why do the just suffer and the wicked enjoy their lives?” that the wicked enjoy the rewards for their few good deeds and the just are punished for their few sins in this world, to create a clean slate for reward and punishment in the World to Come.</i>. What sin did he commit? Far be it that he committed a sin, but once he put on his head phylacteries before his arm phylacteries<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 13:9" href="/Exodus.13.9"><i>Ex</i>. 13:9</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 13:16" href="/Exodus.13.16">16</a> require that the sign (<i>tefillin</i>, phylacteries) carried by the faithful be on the arm before being put on the head. The repetition emphasizes the importance of this feature.</i>. What good deed did the son of publican Ma`yan do? Far be it that he committed a good deed, but once he prepared a breakfast for the city council but they did not show up. He said, let the poor come and eat it, so it should not go to waste. Some say, he was walking in the street, having a loaf under his shoulder. It fell down<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">And he would not have eaten it afterwards.</i> and a poor person picked it up. He did not say anything in order not to embarrass him. This student saw gardens and water sources. He saw the son of Ma`yan the publican standing on the river bank trying in vain to reach the water. He also saw Miriam, Onion-leaf’s daughter, hanging on her breast nipples; but some say, the door of Hell was fixed in her ear. He asked, [why? They told him, because she fasted and made herself famous among her neighbors. Some say, she fasted one day and was dissolute two days. He asked them]<sup class="footnote-marker">G</sup> for how long? They told him, when Simeon ben Sheṭaḥ comes, we shall remove it from her ear and put is in his ear. He asked them, what is his misdeed? They told him, because he made a personal vow that if he were elected president, he would kill all sorcerers. But now he was made president and he did not kill them. In fact, there are eighty women in the cave of Ascalon who hurt the world; go and tell him! He told them, he is an important personality, he will not believe me. They told him, he is very meek and will believe you. In case that he will not believe you, take out one of your eyes and put it in your hand. He took out one of his eyes and put it in his hand. They said, return it; it was even with the other. He went and told him. He wanted to perform his miracle before him, but he told him, you do not need to. I know that you are a pious person. Even though I intended so in my thoughts, I never spoke it with my mouth<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">He never made a vow valid in the eyes of the earthly court; he understood that the Heavenly Court uses other yardsticks for pious people. Since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:22" href="/Deuteronomy.23.22"><i>Deut</i>. 23:22</a> declares an unfulfilled vow to fill the vower with sin; the fear of accidental, undeclared vows underlies a number of Jewish rituals.</i>. It was a day of rainstorms. He took eighty select men in clean garments and took with them eighty amphoras<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., he took 80 fresh garments in 80 amphoras to protect them from the rain.</i>. He told them, when I whistle once, put on your garments. When I whistle for the second time, come. When he came to the cave of Ascalon, he said אוים, אוים<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">The meaning of these words is unknown. Neither Rapoport’s ἅγιον, ἅγιον (holy, holy) nor Levy’s ὸμοία,ὸμοία (equals, equals), nor Dalmann’s ὠή or Jastrow’s εὔαν (hallo!) make any sense in the context. But compare Greek εὐοῖ, Latin <i>euhoe, euoe, ēvoe</i>, shout of joy at the festivities of Dionysos-Bacchus, possibly intended for emphasis on the idolatrous aspects of sorcery (E. G.). If the witches spoke Phoenician or Hebrew, the expression could be part of a Semitic oath formula from the root ימין like أيمزللَه “by God”.</i>, open for me, I am one of yours. When he entered, one said what she said and produced bread. One said what she said and produced a dish. One said what she said and produced wine. They asked him, what can you do? He told them, when I whistle twice, I shall bring here eighty select men in dry garments for your pleasure and entertainment. They told him, we desire them. When he whistled, they put on their garments; when he whistled for the second time, they all entered together. He made them a sign for each one to grab one of them and lift her from the earth<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">Their witchcraft was an expression of chthonic powers which were only active while they were in connection with the earth. This in itself is proof of forbidden sorcery.</i>. Then they did not succeed in what they were trying to do. He told the one who brought bread, bring bread! She did not succeed. He said, take her to be crucified<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Which is not a form of execution sanctioned by the Torah.</i>. Bring a dish! She did not succeed. He said, take her to be crucified. Bring wine! She did not succeed. He said, take her to be crucified. This he did to all of them. That is what we have stated: “Simeon ben Shetaḥ hanged eighty women in Ascalon, but one does not try two on the same day.” But the hour needed it<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">He acted under the king’s police powers, disregarding all judicial rules.</i>.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> How does one hang him? One sinks a stake into the ground, wood is sticking out from there. One binds both hands, one on top of the other, and hangs him. Rebbi Yose says, the beam is leaning on the wall<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">He rejects a form which might resemble a Roman cross. He requires the corpse to he hung from a horizontal beam like an animal carcass.</i>; one hangs him in the way butchers do. One hangs him and takes him down immediately; if he were left overnight, one would transgress a prohibition, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:23" href="/Deuteronomy.21.23"><i>Deut</i>. 21:23</a>.</i>: <i>Do not leave his corpse on the wood overnight, but certainly bury him on the same day, for a hanged person is blasphemy</i>. This means, why was he hanged? Because he blasphemed; it turns out that the name of Heaven would be desecrated<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">This is the rabbis’ reason to restrict hanging to the blasphemer and those guilty of related crimes (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 6:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.6.6.1">Mishnah 7</a>, Halakhah 9, <i>Sifry</i> <i>Deut</i>. 221). The verse is read following the Roman custom of noting the condemned person’s crime on his cross, restricting hanging to crimes having an element of blasphemy.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Here starts the discussion of the duty to see to the immediate burial of a corpse, and the difficulty of reconciling this biblical duty with king David’s conduct in the matter of the Gibeonites and king Saul’s sons (<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 21" href="/II_Samuel.21"><i>2S</i>. 21</a>). The argument in the following text is a shortened and partially elliptic rewriting of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:1:2-16" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.1.2-16"><i>Qiddušin</i> 4:1</a>. The commentary for the full text of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.4.1"><i>Qiddušin</i> 4:1 (Notes 46–85</a>) may serve here also. Other parallels are <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 78b-79a" href="/Yevamot.78b-79a">Babli <i>Yebamot</i> 78b–79a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bamidbar Rabbah 8:4" href="/Bamidbar_Rabbah.8.4"><i>Num. rabba</i> 8(4</a>), <i>Midrash Samuel</i> 28(5).</i> It was stated: Rebbi Eliezer ben Jacob said, this is worse for the desecrator<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">The person who desecrates the Name of God; he committed the one sin which in Judaism can only be atoned for by death (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 87a" href="/Yoma.87a">Babli <i>Yoma</i> 87a</a>).</i> than for the blasphemer and worse for the blasphemer than the desecrator. About the blasphemer it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:23" href="/Deuteronomy.21.23"><i>Deut</i>. 21:23</a>.</i>: <i>Do not leave his corpse on the gallows overnight</i>. But about the desecrator it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote"><i>2S</i>.20:10.</i>: <i>Riṣpa bat Aya took sackcloth and spread it on the rock from the start of harvest until water</i><i>was poured on them</i>. This teaches that they were hanging from the sixteenth of Nisan to the seventeenth of Marḥeshwan.
It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 9:27" href="/Joshua.9.27"><i>Jos</i>. 9:27</a>.</i>: <i>At that moment Joshua dedicated them as hewers of wood and drawers of water for the congregation</i>. One understands “for the congregation.” But “for the Eternal’s altar”? But Joshua kept them in limbo. He said, I shall [neither]<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Added from the <i>Qiddušin</i> text.</i> exclude nor include them. But he who sometime in the future will build the Temple, if he wants to include he may include, if he wants to exclude he may exclude. David came and excluded them as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 21:1-2" href="/II_Samuel.21.1-2"><i>2S</i>. 21:1–2</a>.</i>: <i>But the Gibeonites are not part of the Children of Israel</i>. Why did he exclude them? Because <i>there was a famine in David’s time, three years year after year</i>. David said, for three sins the rains are locked away: Foreign worship, incest and adultery, and murder. Foreign worship, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 11:16-17" href="/Deuteronomy.11.16-17"><i>Deut</i>. 11:16–17</a>.</i>: <i>Beware, lest you be seduced</i> and next to it, <i>He locks the sky up</i>. Incest and adultery, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 3:2-3" href="/Jeremiah.3.2-3"><i>Jer</i>. 3:2–3</a>.</i> <i>Rain-showers were withheld, there was no late rain, for you had the forehead of a whoring woman</i>. Murder, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:33" href="/Numbers.35.33"><i>Num</i>. 35:33</a>.</i>: <i>Because blood will distort the Land</i>. Some say, also those who publicly promise money for welfare but do not pay, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 25:14" href="/Proverbs.25.14"><i>Prov</i>. 25:14</a>.</i>: <i>Clouds and wind but no rain means the man who boasts with lying gifts</i>. David checked on all his ways and did not find any of them. He turned to ask the Urim and Tummim. That is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 21:1-2" href="/II_Samuel.21.1-2"><i>2S</i>. 21:1–2</a>.</i>: <i>David asked before the Eternal</i>. Rebbi Eleazar said, it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Zephaniah 2:3" href="/Zephaniah.2.3"><i>Zeph</i>. 2:3</a>.</i>: <i>Ask the Eternal, all the meek of the Land, who execute His Law</i>, etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 21:1-2" href="/II_Samuel.21.1-2"><i>2S</i>. 21:1–2</a>.</i><i>The Eternal said, because of Saul and the House of blood-guilt, for he had killed the Gibeonites. Because of Saul</i>, whom you did not grant the last favor, <i>and because of the House of blood-guilt, for he had killed the Gibeonites</i>. David sent and called them. He asked them, what is between you and the House of Saul? They told him, because he killed seven of our men, two hewers of wood, two drawers of water, a scribe, a religious leader, and a beadle. He asked them, what do you want now? They said to him, <i>May there be given to us seven men … and we shall hang them before the Eternal in Gibeon</i><sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 21:6" href="/II_Samuel.21.6"><i>2S</i>. 21:6</a>.</i>. He said to them, what use is it to you that they be killed? Take silver and gold for yourselves! But they answered, <i>there is no silver or gold for us from Saul and his house</i><sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 21:6" href="/II_Samuel.21.6"><i>2S</i>. 21:6</a>.</i>. He said, maybe they are afraid one of the other; he dealt which each of them separately, trying to mollify him by himself, but nobody accepted it. That is what is written, <i>there is no silver or gold for us</i>, it is written <i>for me</i>. At this moment, David said that the Holy One gave three good gifts to Israel: They are decent, merciful, and charitable. Decent, for it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 20:20" href="/Exodus.20.20"><i>Ex</i>. 20:20</a>.</i>: <i>that His fear be on your faces</i>. Merciful, for it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:18" href="/Deuteronomy.13.18"><i>Deut</i>. 13:18</a>,</i>: <i>He gave you mercy, had mercy on you and increased you</i>. Charitable, for it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 7:12" href="/Deuteronomy.7.12"><i>Deut</i>. 7:12</a>.</i>: <i>The Eternal, your God, kept for you covenant and charity</i>. But these, nothing of this is found in them; he excluded them: <i>But the Gibeonites are not of the Children of Israel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 21:1-2" href="/II_Samuel.21.1-2"><i>2S</i>. 21:1–2</a>.</i>. And Ezra also excluded them, as it is said:<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 3:26" href="/Nehemiah.3.26"><i>Neh</i>. 3:26</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 11:21" href="/Nehemiah.11.21">11:21</a>.</i> <i>And the dedicated ones dwelt in the Ophel; Ziha and Gishpa were of the dedicated ones</i>. Also in the future, the Holy One, praise to Him, will exclude them as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 48:19" href="/Ezekiel.48.19"><i>Ez</i>. 48:19</a>.</i>: <i>The city worker will cultivate it, from all tribes of Israel</i>. He will eliminate them from all tribes of Israel.
<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">Several passages in this paragraph are truncated; refer to the <i>Qiddušin</i> text.</i><i>The king said, I shall give</i><sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 21:6" href="/II_Samuel.21.6"><i>2S</i>. 21:6</a>.</i>. <i>The king took the two sons of Riṣpah bat Ayah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 21:8" href="/II_Samuel.21.8"><i>2S</i>. 21:8</a>.</i>. <i>Michal, Saul’s daughter, did not have a child</i><sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 6:23" href="/II_Samuel.6.23"><i>2S</i>. 6:23</a>.</i>, and you say so? Say now that they were sons of Merab but Michal raised them, so they were named after her. <i>The king gave them into the hand of the Gibeonites who hanged them on the mountain before the Eternal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 21:9" href="/II_Samuel.21.9"><i>2S</i>. 21:9</a>.</i>. <i>All seven</i> is written defective of one letter. That refers to Mephiboshet, for whom David prayed and whom the altar received. He told them, I let them pass by the altar and anyone whom the altar receives will be his, because of Mephiboshet who was great in Torah. He let him pass by the altar, which received him. Rebbi Avin said, <i>I shall call to the Most High God, to the Power Who has the ultimate decision over me</i><sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 57:3" href="/Psalms.57.3"><i>Ps</i>. 57:3</a>.</i>. For the Holy One, praise to Him, agreed with David. <i>They were killed on the day of harvest …at the start of the barley harvest</i><sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 21:9" href="/II_Samuel.21.9"><i>2S</i>. 21:9</a>.</i>. <i>Riṣpah bat Ayah took a garment and laid it out on the rock</i><sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 21:10" href="/II_Samuel.21.10"><i>2S</i>. 21:10</a>.</i>. What means <i>on the rock</i>? Rebbi Hoshaia said, she was reciting: <i>The rock, perfect is His action</i><sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 32:4" href="/Deuteronomy.32.4"><i>Deut</i>. 32:4</a>.</i>. Rebbi Abba bar Zamina in the name of Rebbi Hoshaia: Sanctification of the Name is greater than desecration of the Name. Referring to sanctification of the Name it is written: <i>Do not leave his corpse overnight</i><sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:23" href="/Deuteronomy.21.23"><i>Deut</i>. 21:23</a>.</i>. But referring to desecration of the Name it is written that they were left hanging <i>until water was poured on them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 21:9" href="/II_Samuel.21.9"><i>2S</i>. 21:9</a>.</i>. This teaches that they were hanging from the sixteenth of Nisan to the seventeenth of Marḥeshwan. The passers-by were saying: How did these people sin that the rules of justice were changed for them? They were answered: Because these had attacked cursed proselytes. Is that not an argument <i>de minore ad majus</i>? Since even for those who did not convert for the sake of Heaven, the Eternal avenged their blood; if one would convert for the sake of Heaven not so much more? Many converts were converted at that time; that is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 2:16-17" href="/II_Chronicles.2.16-17"><i>2Chr</i>. 2:16–17</a>.</i>: <i>Solomon counted all proselytes … and appointed from them 70’000 carriers</i>, etc.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Rebbi Meïr said: When a human suffers, how does the Divine presence<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">The <i>Šekhinah</i> is God’s Presence among men, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 29:46" href="/Exodus.29.46"><i>Ex</i>. 29:46</a>.</i> express Itself? If it could be said<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">The usual expression to justify an anthropomorphism. We know that human behavior cannot be attributed to the <i>Šekhinah</i>, but if it could, one could say …</i>, my head is light, my arm is light<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">This translation is tentative; see the Halakhah.</i>. If Scripture says so, I am suffering about the blood of evildoers, so much more if blood of the just is spilled.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Rebbi Meïr said,” etc. We have stated קַלֵּינִי. Some Tannaïm state קַל אָנִי. <sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that one should follow R. David Fraenckel and switch the references. This also would follow Talmudic style: readings AB are discussed as BA: “He who says קַל אָנִי (I am light) uses an expression of lightness. He who says קַלֵּינִי (קַל אֵינִי I am not light) uses a language of load.”<br>The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 46b" href="/Sanhedrin.46b">Babli, 46b</a>, only discusses the second alternative, or a possibility of deriving the expression from the root קלל “to curse.”</i> He who says קַלֵּינִי uses only an expression of lightness. He who says קַל אָנִי uses a language of load.
The Mishnah does not follow Rebbi Meïr because he said, also for the blasphemer one violates a prohibition<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">It is a question of interpretation of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:23" href="/Deuteronomy.21.23"><i>Deut</i>. 21:23</a>: <i>Do not leave his corpse on the gallows overnight</i> (a prohibition), <i>but burying you shall bury him on the same day</i> (a positive commandment). It is agreed that the positive commandment applies to all burials (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 6:9:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.6.9.1">Mishnah 11</a>). The question is the domain of applicability of the prohibition.<br>In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 6:7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.6.7.1">Mishnah 9</a>, the rabbis hold that only people attacking the essence of the faith are hanged. The question remains what their position is about witnesses who falsely accuse somebody of blasphemy. It may be that <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 221, which excludes the perjured witnesses from being hanged, represents R. Meïr’s position, which is not documented elsewhere. Then the sentence should be read: <i>Only for the blasphemer does one violate the prohibition</i> …, since only concerning the blasphemer there is a duty to hang his corpse.</i>.

Halakhah 9

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Not only this, but anybody who leaves his dead<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">Any deceased whose burial is his personal responsibility.</i> overnight violates a prohibition. If he left him overnight for his honor, to provide him with a coffin and shrouds<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">These are examples rather than an exhaustive list of reasons for a delayed funeral.</i>, he does not violate a prohibition in his regard. They did not bury them<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">People executed by a court verdict.</i> in their family graves, but two graves<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote">In all printed Babli editions בתי קברות “cemetaries”. This reading has no parallel in Babli mss. (<i>Diqduqe Soferim</i> 36a Note ל). Maimonides’s autograph Mishnah text has קבורות, read קְבוּרוֹת “burial sites”. This seems to be the best reading.</i> were prepared, one for those stoned or burned, the other for those beheaded or strangled<sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote">The sins of those executed by the two cruel methods are incomparably worse than those of persons executed by the two swift methods.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Not only this,” etc. It was stated: <sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">The Halakhah really belongs to the next Mishnah, which refers to collecting bones. The text as it stands here is missing a few lines which in part make it incomprehensible. The origin is in <i>Mašqin</i> (<i>Mo`ed qatan</i>) 1:5 (80d ll. 1–14); it also is found in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Pesachim 8:7:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Pesachim.8.7.2-3"><i>Pesahim</i> 8:7</a> (36b ll. 22–37).</i> If somebody transports a coffin from one place to the other, the rules of collecting bones do not apply<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to Mishnah <i>Mo`ed qaṭan</i> 1:3: “R. Meïr says, a person may collect his parents’ bones on a semi-holiday because it makes him happy; R. Yose says, it is an occasion of mourning. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 6:10:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.6.10.2-4">Halakhah 12</a> (<i>Mo`ed qatan</i> 1:5) determines that the day of collecting the bones (transferring them from burial in the ground to an ossuary to be stored in a cave) is a day of mourning (prohibited one a semi-holiday) but the day following is a holiday since the person is assured that his parents were freed from punishment in the world of souls. [Only extremely vicious souls are punished in eternity, cf. Chapter 10. For all other evildoers, the punishment in hell is for 12 months or until the flesh has disappeared from the bones, whichever comes sooner. For this reason, a mourner may not recite the prayer for the dead (customary since the last millennium) for more than 11 months; if he did recite it in the 12th month he would declare his parent an evildoer, in itself a sin.]</i>. Rebbi Aḥa said, this means in a marble<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallels: stone.</i> coffin. But in a wooden coffin, the rules of collecting bones do apply. Rebbi Yose said, even for a wooden coffin the rules of collecting bones do not apply. What is “collecting bones”<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">The missing answer, found in the parallels, is: One transports them in an ἐπικάρσιον (“cloth hanging down”, used for striped cloth) from place to place.</i>?
Rebbi Ḥaggai said, only if he heard it the next day. But on the same day notice must be taken of collecting bones<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">The text to which this remark belongs again is missing. It starts with the sentence of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 6:9:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.6.9.4">Note 144</a>.<br>In case of a death, the relatives near the deceased have to see to his burial and start the mourning rites immediately. Those farther away have to start when they are informed. There is a difference in the rules between “recent information” (within 30 days of the death) or “distant information” (after 30 days). The same is true for collecting the bones. Not only the person actually collecting the bones has to observe the rites of mourning, but all his close relatives who in theory also could have collected the bones. But since the day following already is a day of joy (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 6:9:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.6.9.2">Note 136</a>), only information which reaches the relative on the day itself forces the recipient to observe mourning.</i>. Nikomachos stated before Rebbi Zeˋira: Collecting bones has no [minimal] amount<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Mourning while collecting the bones is required even for a single bone. In the parallels, this is the answer to the question: Is there a minimal amount required when collecting bones?</i>. Rebbi Mani instructed Rebbi La from Kufra<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallels: R. Mana instructed R. Hillel from Kifra.</i> to tear his garment and mourn following Rebbi Aḥa<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">Transporting a wooden coffin is subject to all rules of mourning.</i>, not to pollute himself following Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">A Cohen is not permitted to transport a wooden coffin, even if it is for one of the close relatives for whom he is obligated to pollute himself.</i>.
It was stated: Collecting bones, following the information<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 6:9:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.6.9.3">Note 139</a>.</i>. What is collecting bones? One collects every single bone after the flesh has rotted away<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">The missing answer, found in the parallels, is: One transports them in an ἐπικάρσιον (“cloth hanging down”, used for striped cloth) from place to place.</i>.
It was stated: When collecting bones one does not recite lamentations and wailing, nor the benediction of mourners, nor consolation of mourners. The benediction of mourners, what is said in the synagogue. Consolation of mourners, what is said in the row<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">After burial, the participants in the funeral form two rows; the mourners walk in between while the participants recite formulas of consolation; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.2.1"><i>Berakhot</i> 3:2, Note 121</a>.</i>. It was stated: But one spoke words on the occasion. What are words? The rabbis of Caesarea said, eulogies<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Praises of the deceased. According to H. L. Fleischer, this word קילוס, which also exists in Syriac, and a related verb in Arabic are derived from Greek καλῶς! “beautiful, excellent.”</i>.

Halakhah 10

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If the flesh has rotted away, one collects the bones and buries them at their place<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Praises of the deceased. According to H. L. Fleischer, this word קילוס, which also exists in Syriac, and a related verb in Arabic are derived from Greek καλῶς! “beautiful, excellent.”</i>. The relatives come<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Immediately after the execution.</i> and greet the witnesses and judges, implying that “we hold no grudge against you because you delivered a true judgment.” They did not mourn but were in deep sorrow<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote">The day of execution itself, when the deep mourner is barred from all religious acts (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 26:14" href="/Deuteronomy.26.14"><i>Deut</i>. 26:14</a>). Mourning rites only start after burial.</i>, since deep sorrow is only in the mind.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If the flesh has rotted away,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel is in <i>Mašqin</i> (<i>Mo`ed qatan</i>) 1:5 (80c l. 74). The subject is a common person, not a criminal.</i> It was stated: In earlier times, they were collecting the bones after burying them in ditches<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">The translation is tentative; the word appears only in this <i>baraita</i> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 140:11" href="/Psalms.140.11"><i>Ps</i>. 140:11</a>.</i>. When the flesh had rotted away, they collected them and buried them in cedar wood. On the day itself he was mourning, the day after he was happy<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 6:9:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.6.9.2">Note 136</a>. In the Babli, <i>Mo`ed qatan</i> 8a, the quote appears in a different context.</i>, implying that his parents were at rest<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">Reading נינוחו with the parallel text.</i> from judgment.
<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the end of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 6:9:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.6.9.1">Mishnah 11</a>.</i> Not only this, but they were buried separately, those stoned with the burned, those beheaded with the strangled. This as what David said<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 26:9" href="/Psalms.26.9"><i>Ps</i>. 26:9</a>.</i>, <i>Do not</i><i>collect my soul with sinners</i>, those stoned or burned; <i>nor my life with men of blood guilt</i>, those beheaded or strangled.
An accident happened to Rebbi Abbahu; he lost a baby. Rebbi Jonah and Rebbi Yose ascended<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">They came from Tiberias below sea level to Caesarea Philippi in the foothills of the Golan Heights to offer their condolences.</i> to visit him. Out of respect for him,<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">The great man of the generation of their teachers.</i> they did not speak to him words of Torah. He told them, would the rabbis think saying a word of Torah? They answered, think of it, our teacher. He said to them: If about a terrestrial authority, where one finds lies, and untruth, and misleading statements, and favoritism, and bribery, and they are here one day and gone the next, it was said: “the relatives come and greet the judges and witnesses, implying that we hold no grudge against you because you delivered a true judgment,” the Heavenly authority, before which there are no lies, no untruth, no misleading statements, no favoritism, and no bribery, and He exists forever in all worlds, so much more are we obligated to accept His judgment. And it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:18" href="/Deuteronomy.13.18"><i>Deut</i>. 13:18</a>,</i>, <i>May He give you mercy, have mercy on you, and make you increase as He has sworn to your ancestors</i>.

Chapter 7



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Four kinds of execution was the court empowered to impose: Stoning, burning, decapitation, and strangling. Rebbi Simeon says: Burning, stoning, strangling, and decapitation<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">They differ in the evaluation of which type of execution inflicts more pain on the condemned, starting with the worst and ending with the easiest.</i>. The preceding was prescribed for stoning.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Four kinds of execution was the court empowered to impose,” etc. But to the government<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">The Roman Imperial government. When Caracalla extended Roman citizenship to all free inhabitants of the empire, he thereby abolished crucifixion (except for slaves).</i> only decapitation was given. From where stoning? <i>You shall stone them with stones that they die</i><sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:5" href="/Deuteronomy.17.5"><i>Deut</i>. 17:5</a>.</i>. Burning, for it is written, <i>in fire you shall burn him and them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:14" href="/Leviticus.20.14"><i>Lev</i>. 20:14</a>.</i>. Avenging is written here<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:20" href="/Exodus.21.20"><i>Ex</i>. 21:20</a>. The slave slain by his master shall be avenged. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 52b" href="/Sanhedrin.52b">Babli 52b</a>; the Babli text in <i>Mekhilta dR. Ismael</i> p. 273, <i>dR. Simeon bar Iohai</i> p. 175.</i>, and there it is written: <i>I shall bring over you a sword which avenges the vengeance of the Covenant</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 26:25" href="/Leviticus.26.25"><i>Lev</i>. 26:25</a>.</i>. Since avenging mentioned there is by the sword, also avenging mentioned here is by the sword. Strangling? You do not find it<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">It is not mentioned anywhere in biblical literature as a recognized form of execution. The Babli’s discussion, 52b, is inconclusive.</i>. You say that for any death penalty mentioned in the Torah with no particular indication, you are not empowered to make it more stringent, but only to make it less so; they assigned this to strangling.
Rebbi Simeon says, burning is worse than stoning, but the rabbis teach that stoning is worse than burning. Rebbi Simeon says, strangulation is worse than decapitation; but the rabbis teach that decapitation is worse than strangulation<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">They differ in the evaluation of which type of execution inflicts more pain on the condemned, starting with the worst and ending with the easiest.</i>. Rebbi Simeon explained that any reference to “Cohen’s daughter” implies burning, but the rabbis teach that any reference to “preliminarily married” implies stoning<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Adultery by a preliminarily married virgin is punishable by stoning (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:24" href="/Deuteronomy.22.24"><i>Deut</i>. 22:24</a>), by a definitively married woman by “death” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:10" href="/Leviticus.20.10"><i>Lev</i>. 20:10</a>), which by the preceding argument means the least painful of the four kinds of execution. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:9" href="/Leviticus.21.9"><i>Lev</i>. 21:9</a> prescribes death by burning for the whoring daughter of a Cohen. The status (unmarried, preliminarily or definitively married) of the Cohen’s daughter is not spelled out. Since sexual activity of an unmarried woman is nowhere in the Bible classified as a capital crime [<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Chapter 1 15" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Chapter_1.15"><i>Sifra Emor Pereq</i> 1(15</a>)], it is assumed that the Cohen’s daughter mentioned in the verse cannot be unmarried (virgin or widowed). The problem remains whether <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:9" href="/Leviticus.21.9"><i>Lev</i>. 21:9</a> refers to a preliminarily or definitively married woman.<br>For R. Simeon, who holds that burning is more painful than stoning, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:9" href="/Leviticus.21.9"><i>Lev</i>. 21:9</a> refers to any adulterous daughter of a Cohen, irrespective of the status of her marriage (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 50a" href="/Sanhedrin.50a">Babli 50a</a>). For the rabbis who hold that stoning is more painful than burning, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:9" href="/Leviticus.21.9"><i>Lev</i>. 21:9</a> cannot refer to a preliminarily married maiden since then it would treat a Cohen’s daughter more leniently than an Israel’s, which contradicts the entire tenor of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:1-9" href="/Leviticus.21.1-9"><i>Lev</i>. 21:1–9</a>.<br>The formulation of the rabbis’ position is not quite correct since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:24" href="/Deuteronomy.22.24"><i>Deut</i>. 22:24</a> applies only to a preliminarily married maiden (between the ages of 12 and 12 years 6 months; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:2:10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.2.10"><i>Yebamot</i> 1:3, Notes 159–160</a>). In the text following, “preliminarily married” means “preliminarily married maiden”; “definitively married” means “definitively married or adult preliminarily married”.</i>. Rebbi Simeon explained: The Torah was stringent with a Cohen’s daughter and ordered that as preliminarily married she be burned, but was lenient with the definitively married one that she be stoned<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">This statement contradicts the assertion in the previous paragraph that R. Simeon applies <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:9" href="/Leviticus.21.9"><i>Lev</i>. 21:9</a> to any married daughter of a Cohen; it also contradicts both the principles that (1) penalties must be spelled out in Scripture, cannot be inferred by hermeneutical rules, and (2) in any argument <i>de minore ad majus</i> only the data of the rules which are compared can be used; only identical terms can be transferred. Both objections again lead to the conclusion that R. Simeon cannot differentiate between a preliminarily and a definitively married daughter of a Cohen.</i>. The Torah was lenient with the preliminarily married daughter of an Israel and ordered that she be stoned; it is logical that we be lenient with the definitively married one that she be decapitated<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">This is no logical argument at all but a clear reference to biblical verses; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.5.1">Note 8</a>. The only inference is that for R. Simeon the standard method of execution must be beheading.</i>. But the rabbis explain, since the Torah was stringent with the preliminarily married daughter of an Israel and ordered that she be stoned, it was lenient with her in her definitively married status to be burned<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">A clear scribal error; it must be “strangled” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.5.1">Note 8</a>).</i>. The Torah was lenient with the daughter of a Cohen in her pleliminarily married status and ordered that she be burned; it is logical that we be lenient with her in her definitively married status that she be strangled<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">This proves that at the end of the preceding sentence one has to read “strangled”.</i>.
Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina: Anyone who is executed less cruelly than her father’s death is by burning<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The discussion follows the rabbis, for whom stoning is more severe than burning. The statement is a little more explicit in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 51a" href="/Sanhedrin.51a">Babli, 51a</a>.<br>A definitively married Israel woman who commits adultery is strangled, except that if she commit incest with her father both are burned (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:14" href="/Leviticus.20.14"><i>Lev</i>. 20:14</a>). As a preliminarily married maiden she would be stoned. Therefore, it is clear that for the rabbis the daughter of a Cohen is burned only if either she commits incest with her father or adultery when definitively married.</i>. As long as she is with her father, with her father she is burned, with her father-in-law stoned. <i>With her father she is desecrating, in fire she should be burned</i><sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:9" href="/Leviticus.21.9"><i>Lev</i>. 21:9</a>, reading אֶת as “with”. The quote with the following two sentences is a <i>baraita, Sifra Emor Pereq</i> 1(19); <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 14:4" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.14.4">Tosephta 14:17</a>.</i>. Rebbi Eliezer says, with her father she is burned, with her father-in-law stoned<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:12" href="/Leviticus.20.12"><i>Lev</i>. 20:12</a>. From <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:27" href="/Leviticus.20.27"><i>Lev</i>. 20:27</a>: <i>they shall be put to death, by a stone they shall be stoned, their blood be on them</i>, it is inferred that any expression “their blood be on them” means execution by stoning. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 54a" href="/Sanhedrin.54a">Babli 54a</a>.</i>. She by burning, her paramour not by burning<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">The singular used in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:9" href="/Leviticus.21.9"><i>Lev</i>. 21:9</a> implies that only she is executed by burning; her paramour is punished, like any adulterer with a married woman, by strangulation (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 51a" href="/Sanhedrin.51a">Babli 51a</a>).</i>. She by burning, her perjured witnesses not by burning. Similarly by burning, she and they by burning. Simnilarly by stoning, she and they by stoning. Similarly by strangulation, they by burning but he by strangulation<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The last three sentences are repeated as last sentences of this Tractate, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 11:6:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.11.6.2-5">Halakhah 11:8</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 14:4" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.14.4">Tosephta 14:17</a>. “They” are perjured witnesses who falsely accuse her. If they accuse her of adultery as a definitively married woman, then the perjured witnesses are strangled, the prescribed punishment of the paramour. If they accuse her of incest with her father, they are burned, the prescribed punishment of her father. If they accuse her of adultery as preliminarily married maiden, they are stoned, the prescribed punishment both of her and her paramour.<br>The last sentence cannot stand as it appears here. In Chapter 11, one reads כְּיוֹצֵא בָהֶן בְּחֶנֶק הִיא וְהֵן בְּחֶנֶק “similarly by strangulation, she and they by strangulation.” In the Tosephta כְּיוֹצֵא בָהֶן בְּחֶנֶק הוּא בִּשְׂרֵיפָה וְהֵן בְּחֶנֶק “similarly by strangulation, he is burned and they by strangulation.” One sees that none of the scribes understood what he was writing. One may read in Chapter 11 “<i>he</i> and they by strangulation,” or in the Tosephta “<i>she</i> is burned and they strangled”. In the text here, one has to read: “<i>she</i> by burning but he (or <i>they</i>) by strangulation.”</i>.
Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina: The rabbis explain that the inhabitants of a seduced city<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">A city which by vote of city council and population decides to become pagan. Its inhabitants have to be killed by the sword (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:13-19" href="/Deuteronomy.13.13-19"><i>Deut</i>. 13:13–19</a>). Individual apostates to paganism have to be stoned (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:5" href="/Deuteronomy.17.5"><i>Deut</i>. 17:5</a>).</i> should have been included in the category of idolaters, by stoning. They were treated to a less painful way of execution; that should be by burning<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">Just one degree less than stoning.</i>. It is not enough that you decree for them an easier death by burning, but should you have them judged by the easiest way, by strangulation<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">This is the rabbis’ argument to prove that beheading is worse than strangulation. If the punishment of the inhabitants of the seduced city were the easiest way of execution, the verse simply should have decreed the unspecified death penalty. Since beheading was specified, it must be worse than the unspecified death penalty.<br>The reason behind the argument is R. Ismael’s tenth hermeneutical principle [<i>Sifra Wayyiqra Pereq</i> 1(2)], that special treatment for a crime already treated in general always expresses a leniency, not greater strictness.</i>? Rebbi Simeon explained: The false prophet<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:2-6" href="/Deuteronomy.13.2-6"><i>Deut</i>. 13:2–6</a>. He is described as a missionary for paganism; his sentence is “death” which means strangulation for the rabbis and beheading for R. Simeon.</i> should have been included in the category of idolaters, by burning<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">This makes no sense since it contradicts <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:5" href="/Deuteronomy.17.5"><i>Deut</i>. 17:5</a>. The first two sentences of the argument attributed to R. Simeon are simply taken from the rabbis’ argument with stoning and burning switched, even though the argument is irrelevant.</i>. He was treated to a less painful way of execution, which should be by stoning. It is not enough that you decree for them an easier death by stoning, but you have him judged by the easiest way, by beheading<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">Since the rabbis must agree that the false prophet be executed in the least painful way, they agree that once a punishment is reduced, it may be reduced to the lowest level; the rabbis’ argument in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:1:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.1.5">Note 20</a> is contradicted. The mention of death by the sword in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:16" href="/Deuteronomy.13.16"><i>Deut</i>. 13:16</a> may be an example of the third hermeneutical rule, “a general principle exemplified once”.</i>.
Rebbi Samuel ben Sosartai in the name of Rebbi Abbahu switches the arguments. The rabbis explained: The rabbis explain that the false prophet should have been included in the category of idolaters, by stoning. He was treated to a less painful way of execution, [this should have been] by burning. It is not enough that you decree burning for them, but you have him judged by the easiest way, by strangulation<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">This adapts for the rabbis the argument ascribed to R. Simeon in the preceding paragraph.</i>.
Rebbi Simeon explained: The inhabitants of a seduced city should have been included in the category of idolaters, by burning. They were treated to a less painful way of execution; that should be by stoning<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">This makes no sense since it contradicts <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:5" href="/Deuteronomy.17.5"><i>Deut</i>. 17:5</a>. The first two sentences of the argument attributed to R. Simeon are simply taken from the rabbis’ argument with stoning and burning switched, even though the argument is irrelevant.</i>. This is not enough for you but you have them judged by the easiest way, by beheading<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">In this version, the arguments of both parties are completely parallel; each one is consistent within its own system. Both systems are compatible with the biblical verses.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The order of burning: One makes him sink into manure up to his knees<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">To make the condemned lose partial consciousness from the methane gas coming from the manure.</i>, puts a stiff cloth into soft ones and winds them around his throat. One person draws in his direction, the other draws in his direction until he opens his mouth<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">The two witnesses stand to either side of the condemned and choke him to force him to open his mouth. The coarse cloth is the one which chokes; the soft cloth is to shield the skin from injury. The entire procedure is modelled on the death of Nadab and Abihu (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 10:1-6" href="/Leviticus.10.1-6"><i>Lev</i>. 10:1–6</a>) which is called “burning” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 10:6" href="/Leviticus.10.6">v. 6</a>) but whose bodies were not injured externally (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 10:5" href="/Leviticus.10.5">v. 5</a>), and similarly the deaths of the 250 followers of Korah (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 16:35" href="/Numbers.16.35"><i>Num</i>. 16:35</a>); <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 52a" href="/Sanhedrin.52a">Babli 52a</a>.</i>. Then one lights a wick<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">Not really a wick but either liquid metal (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 52a" href="/Sanhedrin.52a">Babli 52a</a>) or burning oil.</i> and throws it into his mouth that it enters his innards and chars his intestines. Rebbi Jehudah says, in that case, if he would die in their hands they would not have fulfilled the duty of burning<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">By refusing to open his mouth, the condemned could force his executioners to choke him to death, which is considered the least painful kind of execution.</i>; one opens his mouth forcefully with tongs, lights a wire and throws it into his mouth that it enters his innards and chars his intestines. Rebbi Eleazar ben Ṣadoq said, it happened that a Cohen’s daughter whored; they surrounded her with firewood and burned her. They told him, because the court at that time was incompetent<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">Not incompetent but Sadducee (or in any case anti-Pharisee).</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The order of burning,” etc. Why does one not use the hard cloth alone? One said, that he should not die<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">To avoid strangling him.</i>; as we find that when Hezekias closed the waters of the upper Giḥon spring<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 32:2" href="/II_Chronicles.32.2"><i>2Chr</i>. 32:2</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 32:4" href="/II_Chronicles.32.4">4</a>.</i>, he stopped it with soft clothing.
<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">From here to the middle of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:5:2-9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.5.2-9">Halakhah 5</a> there exists a (frequently lacunary) Genizah text (G) in pure Galilean spelling (L. Ginzberg, <i>Yerushalmi Fragments</i>, pp. 258–259).</i> Rebbi Crispus in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The Mishnah speaks of a <i>ba `aṣ</i><sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">Usually, בעץ is translated as “tin.” But since the pure metal appears in the text under its Greek name, the Hebrew word (and its Aramaic counterpart אֲבָצָא) denote the commercial product, a lead-tin alloy.</i> wire. What is a <i>ba `aṣ</i> wire? The rabbis of Caesarea say, a mixture of lead and tin<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Greek κασσίτερος, ὁ, “tin”. In G: וקסיטיר.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, this follows him who said, “one lights a wire and throws it into his mouth.” But for him, who says, “it enters his innards and chars his intestines,” the Mishnah speaks of a wick of Naphtha<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 52a" href="/Sanhedrin.52a">Babli, 52a</a>, only recognizes a wire of lead.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.1">Halakhah 1:1, Notes 31–35</a>.</i> It was stated: Forty years before the Temple was destroyed, criminal jurisdiction was removed from Israel, and in the days of Simeon ben Ioḥai civil jurisdiction was removed from Israel. Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai said, praised be the Merciful, for I am not wise enough to judge.
“Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Ṣadoq said, I was a child riding on my father’s shoulder when I saw the daughter of a Cohen who had whored; they surrounded her with firewood and burned her. They told him, you were a child; a child cannot testify.”<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 52b" href="/Sanhedrin.52b">Babli 52b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 9:3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.9.3">Tosephta 9:11</a>.</i> When he saw this, he<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">This is rather old for a child riding on his father’s shoulder. Probably it means “older than 5 years.” [More than 150 years separate the burning reported by R. Eleazar ben R. Sadoq I from R. Eleazar ben R. Sadoq II accompanying Rebbi.]</i> was no less than ten years old. When he walked with Rebbi, he must have been no less than thirty years old since it is not fitting for a great personality to be accompanied by anybody less than thirty years of age. As we have stated: “Rebbi said, I was coming from bet Sirin with Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Ṣadoq when we ate figs and grapes outside the tabernacle<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">On Tabernacles, only full meals have to be eaten in the <i>sukkah</i>; snacks may be eaten outside.</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The order of beheading. They were chopping off his head with a sword just as the [Roman] government does. Rebbi Jehudah says, this is ugliness but one puts his head on the block and cuts it with a butcher knife. They told him, there is no death uglier than this.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The order of beheading,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 52b" href="/Sanhedrin.52b">Babli 52b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 9:3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.9.3">Tosephta 9:11</a>.</i>“Rebbi Jehudah agrees that there is no death uglier than this but the Torah said<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:3" href="/Leviticus.18.3"><i>Lev</i>. 18:3</a>.</i>, <i>in their statutes you shall not walk</i>.” Rebbi Joḥanan said, also it was stated thus: <i>One shall murder the murderer</i><sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:30" href="/Numbers.35.30"><i>Num</i>. 35:30</a>: <i>Any homicide; following witnesses one shall murder the murderer</i>.</i>, the way he murdered. I could think that if he killed with a sword, one should kill him with a sword, with a rod one should kill him with a rod? Avenging is written here<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:20" href="/Exodus.21.20"><i>Ex</i>. 21:20</a>. The slave slain by his master shall be avenged. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 52b" href="/Sanhedrin.52b">Babli 52b</a>; the Babli text in <i>Mekhilta dR. Ismael</i> p. 273, <i>dR. Simeon bar Iohai</i> p. 175.</i>, and there it is written: <i>I shall bring over you a sword which avenges the vengeance of the Covenant</i><sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 26:25" href="/Leviticus.26.25"><i>Lev</i>. 26:25</a>.</i>. Since avenging mentioned there is by the sword, also avenging mentioned here is by the sword. I could think that he<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">The avenger.</i> should kill him between the arms? It is said here<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:19" href="/Deuteronomy.19.19"><i>Deut</i>. 19:19</a>. Since this refers to perjured witnesses, it includes all kinds of death penalties.</i>, <i>you shall eliminate the evil from your midst</i>, and it is said there<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:9" href="/Deuteronomy.21.9"><i>Deut</i>. 21:9</a>.</i>, <i>you shall eliminate the innocent blood from your midst</i>. Elimination, elimination; breaking the neck, breaking the neck<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">By the doctrine of invariability of lexemes the meaning of “elimination” must be the same in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:19" href="/Deuteronomy.19.19"><i>Deut</i>. 19:19</a> and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:9" href="/Deuteronomy.21.9"><i>Deut</i>. 21:9</a>. That of “breaking the neck” in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:4" href="/Deuteronomy.21.4"><i>Deut</i>. 21:4</a> is defined by “neck” in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:8" href="/Leviticus.5.8"><i>Lev</i>. 5:8</a>. Since elimination in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21" href="/Deuteronomy.21"><i>Deut</i>. 21</a> is by breaking the neck, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:19" href="/Deuteronomy.19.19"><i>Deut</i>. 19:19</a> also must refer to the neck. Since strangulation is not mentioned in the Pentateuch, the only method of execution to which this may refer is beheading.</i>. Since elimination here is at the neck, also there it is at the neck. Since breaking the neck there implies chopping off the head, also here chopping off the head.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The order of the strangled: One makes him sink into manure up to his knees<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">To make the condemned lose partial consciousness from the methane gas coming from the manure.</i>, puts a stiff cloth into soft ones and winds them around his throat. One person draws in his direction, the other one draws in his direction until he expires.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The order of the strangled,” etc. Strangling? You do not find it<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">It is not mentioned anywhere in biblical literature as a recognized form of execution. The Babli’s discussion, 52b, is inconclusive.</i>. This refers to death penalty in the Torah. For any death penalty mentioned in the Torah with no particular indication, you are not empowered to try to make it more stringent, only to make it less so, the words of Rebbi Josia. Rebbi Jonathan said to him, not because it is the least painful, but because it is mentioned in the Torah with no specific indication. For any death penalty mentioned in the Torah with no particular indication, you are not empowered to try to make it more stringent but only to make it less so; they ascribed this to strangling.
You said, the order of strangling is the following: “One person draws in his direction, the other one draws in his direction.” Cahana asked before Rav: There<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Zavim 3:2" href="/Mishnah_Zavim.3.2">Mishnah <i>Zavim</i> 3:2</a>. The sufferer from gonorrhea causes impurity to everything he sits on and everything which is moved either by his force or on which he sits (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 15:10" href="/Leviticus.15.10"><i>Lev</i>. 15:10</a>). For example, a sufferer from gonorrhea and a pure person sit in the same boat but do not touch at all. The moment the boat moves, the pure person and his garments become impure. This impurity is known as מִדְרָס “[caused by] stepping upon.” The Mishnah refers to two persons, one suffering from gonorrhea and one pure, who together are splicing the same rope, working at different ends. Since each of them moves the rope in his direction, the pure person and his garments become impure the moment the impure person moves the rope while the pure one is holding it.</i>, you say, “one draws in <i>one</i> direction, the other draws in <i>one</i> direction.” But here, you say, “one draws in <i>his</i> direction, the other draws in <i>his</i> direction.<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Why the change in language?</i>” He told him, there one is in front, the other in the back. But here, one is on one side, the other one is on the other side.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The following are stoned: A male having sexual relations with the mother, or the father’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote">Even if she is not his mother, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:11" href="/Leviticus.20.11"><i>Lev</i>. 20:11</a>. One infers from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:27" href="/Leviticus.20.27"><i>Lev</i>. 20:27</a> that <i>their blood be on them</i> means that the punishment is stoning (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:7:2-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.7.2-6">Halakhah 9</a>).</i>, or the daughter-in-law, or a male, or an animal; or a female bringing an animal onto herself<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:12" href="/Leviticus.20.12"><i>Lev</i>. 20:12</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:13" href="/Leviticus.20.13">13</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:15" href="/Leviticus.20.15">15</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:16" href="/Leviticus.20.16">16</a>.</i>. Also the blasphemer<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 24:23" href="/Leviticus.24.23"><i>Lev</i>. 24:23</a>. It is a capital crime only if the Divine Name (which today is unknown) was used in the blasphemy.</i>, the worshipper of idols<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:5" href="/Deuteronomy.17.5"><i>Deut</i>. 17:5</a>.</i>, he who gives one of his descendants to the Moloch<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:2" href="/Leviticus.20.2"><i>Lev</i>. 20:2</a>.</i>, and the necromancer, and the medium<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:27" href="/Leviticus.20.27"><i>Lev</i>. 20:27</a>. The necromancer is the person who raises the spirits of the dead; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 28" href="/I_Samuel.28"><i>1S</i>. 28</a>. The medium is one who incorporates a spirit which predicts the future, speaking from the medium’s body, not his mouth.</i>. Also one who desecrates the Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:36" href="/Numbers.15.36"><i>Num</i>. 15:36</a>.</i>, or who curses father or mother<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:9" href="/Leviticus.20.9"><i>Lev</i>. 20:9</a>.</i>, or who has sexual relations with a preliminarily married maiden<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Adultery by a preliminarily married virgin is punishable by stoning (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:24" href="/Deuteronomy.22.24"><i>Deut</i>. 22:24</a>), by a definitively married woman by “death” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:10" href="/Leviticus.20.10"><i>Lev</i>. 20:10</a>), which by the preceding argument means the least painful of the four kinds of execution. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:9" href="/Leviticus.21.9"><i>Lev</i>. 21:9</a> prescribes death by burning for the whoring daughter of a Cohen. The status (unmarried, preliminarily or definitively married) of the Cohen’s daughter is not spelled out. Since sexual activity of an unmarried woman is nowhere in the Bible classified as a capital crime [<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Chapter 1 15" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Chapter_1.15"><i>Sifra Emor Pereq</i> 1(15</a>)], it is assumed that the Cohen’s daughter mentioned in the verse cannot be unmarried (virgin or widowed). The problem remains whether <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:9" href="/Leviticus.21.9"><i>Lev</i>. 21:9</a> refers to a preliminarily or definitively married woman.<br>For R. Simeon, who holds that burning is more painful than stoning, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:9" href="/Leviticus.21.9"><i>Lev</i>. 21:9</a> refers to any adulterous daughter of a Cohen, irrespective of the status of her marriage (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 50a" href="/Sanhedrin.50a">Babli 50a</a>). For the rabbis who hold that stoning is more painful than burning, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:9" href="/Leviticus.21.9"><i>Lev</i>. 21:9</a> cannot refer to a preliminarily married maiden since then it would treat a Cohen’s daughter more leniently than an Israel’s, which contradicts the entire tenor of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:1-9" href="/Leviticus.21.1-9"><i>Lev</i>. 21:1–9</a>.<br>The formulation of the rabbis’ position is not quite correct since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:24" href="/Deuteronomy.22.24"><i>Deut</i>. 22:24</a> applies only to a preliminarily married maiden (between the ages of 12 and 12 years 6 months; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:2:10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.2.10"><i>Yebamot</i> 1:3, Notes 159–160</a>). In the text following, “preliminarily married” means “preliminarily married maiden”; “definitively married” means “definitively married or adult preliminarily married”.</i>, or who leads astray<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">The missionary for another faith who addresses individuals in private; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:11" href="/Deuteronomy.13.11"><i>Deut</i>. 13:11</a>, cf. Mishnah 16.</i>, or who seduces<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">He acts in public; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:12:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.12.2-3">Halakhah 16</a>.</i>, or the sorcerer<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:13:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.13.2-7">Halakhah 19</a>.</i>, or the deviant and rebellious son<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:21" href="/Deuteronomy.21.21"><i>Deut</i>. 21:21</a>.</i>.
