<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The following are stoned,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">This Halakhah refers more to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Keritot 1:1" href="/Mishnah_Keritot.1.1">Mishnah <i>Keritut</i> 1:1</a> (for which no Yerushalmi exists) than to the present Mishnah which rather serves as a header for the following Mishnaiot (6–19) which take up all cases mentioned in the Mishnah. Since the rules of evidence essentially guarantee that nobody can be executed, it is asserted, and shown in detail in the following Halakhot, that a criminal who escapes the earthly court is condemned by the Heavenly court to extirpation. If a sin punishable by extirpation was committed inadvertently, it can be atoned for by a purification sacrifice. (No sin committed intentionally can be atoned for by a sacrifice.) <i>Keritut</i> 1:1 contains a list of 36 sins punishable by extirpation, including those mentioned in the Mishnah here. That the number 36 is mentioned in the Mishnah is interpreted to mean that for each category a separate sacrifice is needed. For example, a person who inadvertently sleeps with a woman who is his mother married to his father has to bring two sacrifices, one for sleeping with his mother and one for his father’s wife.</i> It is necessary in one forgetting<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">It is emphasized repeatedly (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 4:13" href="/Leviticus.4.13"><i>Lev</i>. 4:13</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:2" href="/Leviticus.5.2">5:2</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 4:3" href="/Leviticus.4.3">3</a>) that an inadvertent sin, for which atonement by a sacrifice is possible, must involve an element of forgetting, either of the law which forbids the action, or of the identity of the person with whom the forbidden act was committed; this includes ignorance of the law or identity of the person. It is clear that a sacrifice is possible only if the person realizes the criminality of his act, i. e., he came to know the law or the identity. If then he forgets the information again, a new situation is created which is not a continuation of the previous one. This is a major topic of Tractate <i>Ševu`ot</i>.<br>It seems that הֶעֱלֵם, הֶעֱלֵימוֹת are Babylonisms in the text; G writes עֲלם, עָלִמות, יעלמות.</i>, but in two forgettings? Since even for one woman, if he had relations with her several times in one forgetting, he is liable for each one<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">It seems impossible to make sense of this sentence. The most probable emendation is to read “two forgettings”, see the preceding Note.</i>. Rebbi Simeon ben Rebbi Hillel ben Pazi asked before Rebbi Hillel ben Pazi: The Mishnah refers to one woman who is forbidden under many names<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">This Halakhah refers more to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Keritot 1:1" href="/Mishnah_Keritot.1.1">Mishnah <i>Keritut</i> 1:1</a> (for which no Yerushalmi exists) than to the present Mishnah which rather serves as a header for the following Mishnaiot (6–19) which take up all cases mentioned in the Mishnah. Since the rules of evidence essentially guarantee that nobody can be executed, it is asserted, and shown in detail in the following Halakhot, that a criminal who escapes the earthly court is condemned by the Heavenly court to extirpation. If a sin punishable by extirpation was committed inadvertently, it can be atoned for by a purification sacrifice. (No sin committed intentionally can be atoned for by a sacrifice.) <i>Keritut</i> 1:1 contains a list of 36 sins punishable by extirpation, including those mentioned in the Mishnah here. That the number 36 is mentioned in the Mishnah is interpreted to mean that for each category a separate sacrifice is needed. For example, a person who inadvertently sleeps with a woman who is his mother married to his father has to bring two sacrifices, one for sleeping with his mother and one for his father’s wife.</i>. But if there were many women, or many forgettings, is that in one forgetting<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">If in ignorance of the law, he slept with many menstruating women, or with several of his sisters, does this trigger the obligation of one or of several sacrifices? Similarly, if he repeatedly inadvertently slept with the same forbidden woman but in the intervals had realized the criminal character of his deed, does this trigger the obligation of one or of several sacrifices?</i>? He told him, it is necessary to state for one forgetting, since they disagreed: He acts in one forgetting but she in five forgettings. Rebbi Joḥanan said, he brings one sacrifice but she brings five sacrifices<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, <i>KeritutI</i> 15a, this is a tannaïtic statement. The dissenting opinion is not mentioned there.</i>. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, since he brings [only]<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">The word is missing in the Leiden ms., in G only the last א is clearly readable but the reconstruction of the word is quite certain.</i> one sacrifice, she brings only one sacrifice; lest you say that many women, or many forgettings, be treated as one forgetting. Therefore, it is necessary to say<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">In the missing Halakhah to <i>Keritut</i> 1:1, it is stated that the number of possible cases is stated to stress that each sin represents a different obligation, following R. Johanan. In both questions of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:5:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.5.2">Note 68</a> the answer is that several sacrifices are required.</i>, he is liable for each one.
<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph and the following almost to the end of the Halakhah have a slightly more complete parallel in <i>Šabbat</i> 7:2 (9c l.62–9d l.59).</i> Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya said<sup class="footnote-marker">73,</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Šabbat</i>, there is here a sentence connecting the text to the preceding discussion, not applicable here. This shows that the text here is not a mechanical copy of the text in <i>Šabbat</i>.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">One of R. Ismael’s hermeneutical principles is that “a detail which was singled out from a general class was singled out not for itself but as an example for the entire class.” In <i>Šabbat</i>, R. Abun bar Hiyya is reported here to have stated that according to R. Ismael this holds only for a single detail, not for two or more. (As a statement of R. Johanan see below, Notes 95 ff.).</i>: Rebbi Ismael stated so: <i>You shall not divine nor cast spells</i><sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 19:26" href="/Leviticus.19.26"><i>Lev</i>. 19:26</a>. Divination is an attempt to predict the future by magical means; spellbinding is practical witchcraft. Both are particular examples of the prohibition of witchcraft (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:17" href="/Exodus.22.17"><i>Ex</i>. 22:17</a>), but no penalty is indicated.</i>. Were not divination and spellbinding included in the general class but were mentioned separately to be treated differently from the general case? In general by extirpation, the separate cases for extirpation<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">To use witchcraft is a capital crime as indicated in the Mishnah; in the absence of witnesses there is an automatic Divine verdict of extirpation. But the special cases of divination and spellbinding only trigger a verdict of extirpation; they are not cases for the human court. This illustrates R. Ismael’s principle. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Kedoshim, Chapter 6 2" href="/Sifra,_Kedoshim,_Chapter_6.2"><i>Sifra Qedošim Pereq</i> 6(2</a>), R. Ismael and R. Aqiba identify divination and spellbinding as examples of make-believe witchcraft which according to Mishnah 19 is not punishable by the human court. Automatically, these are separate examples of sins which require a purification sacrifice if done without criminal intent. A person who unintentionally acts as sorcerer, divinator, and spellbinder has to bring three sacrifices.</i>. A statement of Rebbi Joḥanan says, it is a case of general case and detail<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">The wording might be slightly misleading. There is a hermeneutical principle (#5 on R. Ismael’s list) which states that a general expression followed by particulars only refers to the particulars. This presupposes that both general expression and details are in the same paragraph. For example, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 1:2" href="/Leviticus.1.2"><i>Lev</i>. 1:2</a> describes sacrificial animals as <i>animals, cattle, sheep, or goats</i>. In the context, “animals” means “cattle, sheep, and goats”. In the discussion here, the details are mentioned in paragraphs other than the one describing the general category. Then one has to find a reason why the details have to be mentioned separately.</i>, as Rebbi Abbahu said in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, <i>for anybody who would perform any of these abominations will be extirpated</i><sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:29" href="/Leviticus.18.29"><i>Lev</i>. 18:29</a>. This verse decrees a general verdict of extirpation on any violation of sexual taboos spelled out in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18" href="/Leviticus.18"><i>Lev</i>. 18</a>, whether or not they are criminally punishable.</i>, etc. Was not his sister included in the general class<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">The sister is forbidden in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:9" href="/Leviticus.18.9"><i>Lev</i>. 18:9</a> but in the chapter about penalties, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:17" href="/Leviticus.20.17"><i>Lev</i>. 20:17</a>, the punishment is reserved for Heaven.</i>? Rebbi Eleazar objected: Was it not written, <i>the nakedness of your mother’s sister and your father’s sister you shall not uncover</i><sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">A misquote from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:7" href="/Leviticus.18.7"><i>Lev</i>. 18:7</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:8" href="/Leviticus.18.8">8</a>. It seems that in G the verses were quoted correctly. It is incorrect also in <i>Šabbat</i>. It seems from the context that the text in G is a learned scribe’s correction of the original which, however, did not refer to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:7" href="/Leviticus.18.7"><i>Lev</i>. 18:7</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:8" href="/Leviticus.18.8">8</a> but to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:19" href="/Leviticus.20.19"><i>Lev</i>. 20:19</a>: <i>The nakedness of your mother’s sister and your father’s sister you shall not uncover, for his close relative he touched, their sin they have to carry</i>. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 54a" href="/Yevamot.54a">Babli <i>Yebamot</i> 54a</a>.</i>? He told him, it was stated separately for a reason, to judge it by touching<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:19" href="/Leviticus.20.19"><i>Lev</i>. 20:19</a> makes two statements: The punishment is reserved for Heaven and the sin is committed the moment the genitals of the parties touch, without any penetration. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 6:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.6.2.1">Mishnah <i>Yebamot</i> 6:2</a> extends the equivalence of touching and penetration to all sexual offenses.</i>. But is it not written<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:18" href="/Leviticus.20.18"><i>Lev</i>. 20:18</a>. The implications are the same as for v. 19.</i>: <i>A man who would lie with an unwell</i><i>woman, who uncovered her nakedness, he touched her source, and she uncovered the source of her blood</i>? He told him, it was stated separately for a reason, to judge it by touching. That you should not say, since one is guilty about her already by the impurity of touching, we should not treat the one who touched equal to the one who had full intercourse. Therefore, it was necessary to say it<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">In G and <i>Šabbat</i>: “Therefore, it was necessary to say that he is liable for each one,” cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:5:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.5.2">Note 71</a>. It is possible to justify the addition by noting that <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:29" href="/Leviticus.18.29"><i>Lev</i>. 18:29</a> decrees separate extirpation and, therefore, separate sacrifices for unintentional sin, for each separate category of incest.</i>. But is it not written<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:20" href="/Leviticus.20.20"><i>Lev</i>. 20:20</a>.</i>: <i>A man who would sleep with his aunt uncovered his uncle’s nakedness</i>? He told him, it was stated separately for a reason, to judge it by destruction<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Šabbat</i> there is a reference here to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:21" href="/Leviticus.20.21"><i>Lev</i>. 20:21</a>. This also is missing in G, showing that the text here is secondary to that in <i>Šabbat</i>, since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:20" href="/Leviticus.20.20"><i>Lev</i>. 20:20</a> says <i>they shall die destroyed</i> whereas v. 21 notes <i>they shall be destroyed</i>. The difference is explained in the following statement by R. Yudan. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 55a" href="/Yevamot.55a">Babli (<i>Yebamot</i> 55a</a>) applies both statements to both verses.</i>, as Rebbi Yudan said, at all places where <i>they will be destroyed</i> is mentioned, they will be childless; where <i>they shall die destroyed</i> is mentioned, they shall bury their children.
Rebbi Yose said, it was necessary that <i>his aunt</i> be mentioned separately, to exclude his mother’s brother’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">From punishment by loss of children (rejected in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 55a" href="/Yevamot.55a">Babli, <i>Yebamot</i> 55a</a>).</i>. What is the reason? It is said here <i>his aunt</i>, and it is said there<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 25:49" href="/Leviticus.25.49"><i>Lev</i>. 25:49</a>. Since the subject of the entire Chapter is inheritance, it is understood that only the male line is addressed.</i>, <i>either his uncle or his uncle’s son shall free</i><i>him</i>. Since by <i>his uncle</i> mentioned there, the verse understands his father’s paternal brother, also by <i>his aunt</i> mentioned here, the verse speaks of his father’s paternal brother’s wife. Also <i>his brother’s wife</i><sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">Who is forbidden in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:16" href="/Leviticus.18.16"><i>Lev</i>. 18:16</a>.</i> can be inferred<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">The reading of G and <i>Šabbat</i>, לְמֵידָה, seems preferable.</i> from <i>his aunt</i>. Since by <i>his aunt</i> mentioned there, the verse speaks of his father’s paternal brother’s wife, also by <i>his brother’s wife</i> mentioned here, the verse speaks of his paternal brother’s wife. So far following Rebbi Aqiba. Following Rebbi Ismael? Rebbi Ismael stated: It is said here <i>his brother’s wife</i> and it is said there<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:21" href="/Leviticus.20.21"><i>Lev</i>. 20:21</a>, the penalty clause referring to the prohibition formulated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:16" href="/Leviticus.18.16"><i>Lev</i>. 18:16</a>.</i>, <i>a man who would take his brother’s wife, she is niddah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">In biblical Hebrew, the meaning of the root נדד is the same as Arabic نحاد “to separate, to disperse”. This applies both to the menstruating woman (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:19" href="/Leviticus.18.19"><i>Lev</i>. 18:19</a>), who is forbidden relations with her husband, and to the person excommunicated (מְנֻדֶּה) who is separated from the community. In rabbinic Hebrew, the word נִדָּה is used exclusively for the menstruating woman; this is the reference made here, even though the argument is equally valid for the excommunicated person. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 54b" href="/Yevamot.54b">Babli <i>Yebamot</i>54b</a>.)</i>. Since a menstruating woman will be permitted after being forbidden, also his [paternal] brother’s wife may be permitted [after being forbidden.<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">The words in brackets are added from G and <i>Šabbat</i>. The menstruating woman <i>is</i> permitted after her purification; the brother’s wife <i>may be</i> permitted, <i>viz</i>., if the brother dies childless. In the latter case, “brother” means paternal brother (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:1:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.1.9"><i>Yebamot</i> 1:1, Note 45</a>).</i>] This excludes his maternal brother’s wife, who cannot be permitted after being forbidden<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">But for whom no punishment is spelled out.</i>.
But Rebbi Joḥanan himself had a problem: from where does one prove it<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the paragraph before the last, where R. Johanan explained that the sister had a special role in the list of incest prohibitions, to deduce that from the different levels of punishment the blanket decree of extirpation really represents separate decrees for each kind of infraction. In <i>Šabbat</i>, the name is Ismael; this may be the correct attribution, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:5:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.5.8">Note 124</a>.</i>? Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Eleazar in the name of Rebbi Hoshaia: Two prohibitions and one extirpation, the prohibitions split the extirpation<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">This answers R. Joḥanan’s question. It is rather frequent to find verses containing multiple prohibitions covered by one mention of extirpation where the context makes it clear that each single infraction triggers extirpation.</i>. For example<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 30:32" href="/Exodus.30.32"><i>Ex</i>. 30:32</a>,33 regarding the holy oil. Only v. 33 is discussed.</i>, <i>it should not be used to be rubbed on anybody’s skin and in its proportions you shall not imitate it</i>, and it is written, <i>a person who would compound similarly, or who would put it on a stranger, will be extirpated from his people</i>, that is two prohibitions and one extirpation. The prohibitions split the extirpation<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">A person who inadvertently compounds aromatic oil in the same composition as holy oil and uses it on people has to bring two sacrifices. The argument is repeated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 9:1:2-16" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.9.1.2-16">Halakhah 9:1</a> (end of fol. 26d) and accepted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Makkot 14b" href="/Makkot.14b">Babli, <i>Makkot</i> 14b</a>.</i>. Also from the following: Samuel bar Abba asked before Rebbi Ze`ura, should not well-being sacrifices, being treated separately, split all <i>sancta</i> regarding impurity<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Impurity of well-being sacrifices, the only ones available to lay people, is treated at length in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 7:11-27" href="/Leviticus.7.11-27"><i>Lev</i>. 7:11–27</a>. Impurity of sacrifices available to priests is treated in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:1-16" href="/Leviticus.22.1-16"><i>Lev</i>. 22:1–16</a>. One should assume that a priest who inadvertently eats a combination of impure well-being and other sacrifices has to bring separate purification sacrifices; but this is not the case.</i>? He told him, it was necessary that they be treated separately, to eliminate <i>sancta</i> destined for the upkeep of the Temple [regarding larceny]<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">The text in brackets is found in G and in <i>Šabbat</i>. While misuse of all kinds of sacrifices is also larceny, it is punishable only if the monetary value of the misuse is at least one <i>perutah</i>. Misuse of one half <i>perutah</i>’s worth of Temple donations and one half <i>perutah</i>’s worth of sacrifices is not punishable.</i>, lest one be liable for them because of mushiness<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Sacrificing with the intent of eating of the sacrificial meat out of its time and place.</i>, leftovers<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Eating of sacrificial meat after its allotted time.</i>, and impurity. But is that not a Mishnah? “All <i>sancta</i> destined for the altar combine with one another with respect to liability for mushiness, leftovers, and impurity<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">This shows that well-being and other sacrifices are equal in the hand of the Cohen.</i>,” in contrast to <i>sancta</i> destined for the upkeep of the Temple<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah <i>Me`ilah</i> 4:1. The categories of mushiness, leftovers, and impurity do not apply to monetary gifts to the Temple. Anything donated to the Temple which is not a sacrifice or a temple vessel is sold by the Temple treasurer and thereby reverts to fully profane status.</i>. Since they do not combine, they do (not)<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote">The word is not in G and <i>Šabbat</i>; it should be deleted.</i> split<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Somebody committing simultaneous larceny involving gifts to the Temple and sacrifices has to atone separately for the two offenses.</i>. Rebbi Ḥanina<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">G reads: Hinena, preferable for chronological reasons.</i> said, what he really questioned, should they not split but combine <sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">The question remains unanswered why the rules for well-being are no different from those for other sacrifices even for Cohanim. In <i>Šabbat</i>, R. Ḥanina’s statement is an assertion that the rules <i>are</i> different for well-being and other sacrifices. This would agree with the Babli, <i>Me`ilah</i> 15a, that in fact well-being and purification offerings do not combine; the contrary statement of the Mishnah is classified as a rabbinic stringency.</i>?
If He stated a general principle as a positive commandment but the detail as a prohibition<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">The vocalization and, consequently, the interpretation כלל of and פרט as verbs rather than nouns, is from G. Here ends the Genizah fragment.</i>, the word of Rebbi Eleazar is that this is a general principle followed by a detail<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">If a pentateuchal verse partially is an exhortation to action and partially a prohibition, it nevertheless forms a logical unit.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">From here to the end of the Halakhah there also is a parallel in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kilayim 8:1:6-11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kilayim.8.1.6-11"><i>Kilaim</i> 8:1, Notes 20–36</a> (Babli <i>Mo`ed qaṭan</i> 3a). The text in <i>Kilaim</i> practically is identical with that in <i>Šabbat</i>; the text here is slightly abbreviated. The punishment for violating a biblical prohibition for which no penalty is specified is by flogging. The problem is that ploughing is not specifically mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 25" href="/Leviticus.25"><i>Lev</i>. 25</a>.</i> Rebbi Eleazar said, one whips for ploughing in the Sabbatical year. Rebbi Joḥanan said, one does not whip for ploughing in the Sabbatical year. What is Rebbi Eleazar’s reason? <i>The Land shall keep a Sabbath for the Eternal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 25:3" href="/Leviticus.25.3"><i>Lev</i>. 25:3</a>.</i>, a general principle. <i>Your field you shall not sow, your vineyard you shall not prune</i><sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 25:4" href="/Leviticus.25.4"><i>Lev</i>. 25:4</a>.</i>, detail. The sower and the pruner were included in the general case; why were they mentioned separately? To include with them; since the sower and the pruner are particular in that they perform work on the ground or on a tree, I have only what is work on the ground or on a tree. How does Rebbi Joḥanan treat this? They are two different things, and two different details for one general principle do divide. In Rebbi Eleazar’s opinion they do not divide<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">To require separate atonement if performed inadvertently.</i>. But he holds that because they do not divide, they are for making inferences. In Rebbi Joḥanan’s opinion, they are not for making inferences. There is a difference here because He stated a general principle as a positive commandment but the detail as prohibitions. No positive commandment allows inferences for a prohibition and no prohibition allows inferences for a positive commandment. In Rebbi Eleazar’s opinion a positive commandment allows inferences for a prohibition but no prohibition allows inferences for a positive commandment. In Rebbi Joḥanan’s opinion it is obvious that one may dig cisterns, ditches, and caves during it. In Rebbi Eleazar’s opinion, may one dig cisterns, ditches, and caves during it? Just as one cannot make inferences for prohibitions, so one should not be able to make inferences for permissions<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">For R. Johanan, if ploughing is not sanctionable, digging for other than agricultural purposes certainly is permitted. But for R. Eleazar digging is work on the ground (in the language of his argument) but not in the field (as forbidden in the verse.)</i>. Rebbi Abba from Carthage said, Rebbi Joḥanan’s reason is <i>six years you shall sow your field</i>, not in the Sabbatical; <i>and six years you shall prune your vineyard</i><sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 25:3" href="/Leviticus.25.3"><i>Lev</i>. 25:3</a>.</i>, not in the Sabbatical. Any prohibition inferred from a positive commandment is a positive commandment; one violates a positive commandment<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">As such it is not sanctionable; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:3:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.3.4">Halakhah 5:3, Note 73</a>.</i>. Rebbi Jeremiah said, one violates a positive commandment. Rebbi Yose said, there is not even a positive commandment. But is it not written that <i>the Land shall rest as a repose for the Eternal</i>? That is for the prohibition implied by it<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">He takes R. Eleazar literally at his word. If <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 25:3-4" href="/Leviticus.25.3-4"><i>Lev</i>. 25:3–4</a> represents a general principle followed by a detail (even if the principle is a positive commandment and the detail a prohibition) then by R. Ismael’s hermeneutical rule כְּלָל וּפְרָט אֵין בִּכְלָל אֶלָּא מַה שֶׁבִּפְרָט “general principle followed by detail: the general principle only applies to the detail”, nothing not mentioned in the verse is prohibited.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is slightly shortened from <i>Kilaim</i> and <i>Šabbat</i>, explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kilayim 8:1:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kilayim.8.1.9"><i>Kilaim</i> 8:1, Notes 26–28</a>. As the other sources show, the first sentence is a rhetorical question from a <i>baraita</i> referring to rabbinic additions to Sabbatical prohibitions. The words in brackets represent the introductory formula יָכוֹל added from the parallel sources, “I could think that …” which has to be disproved. Since this formula is central to the understanding of the paragraph, one has an additional indication of the secondary character of the text here.</i>[I could think that] they should be giving lashes for the addition. Rebbi Joḥanan explains the <i>baraita</i>: I could think that one gives lashes for ploughing during the Sabbatical year, but Rebbi Eleazar explains the <i>baraita</i>: I could think that one gives lashes for the first two terms<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">The prohibition of agricultural work after the harvest of the preceding year, different for work on the ground or on trees.</i>. Some Tannaïm state: <i>Six years you shall sow your field, and six years you shall prune your vineyard</i>; but some Tannaïm state: <i>Your field you shall not sow</i>, etc. He who says <i>six years</i> supports Rebbi Joḥanan; he who says <i>your field you shall not sow</i> supports Rebbi Eleazar.
A <i>baraita</i> supports<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">In both parallels: <i>disagrees with</i>. The latter is the correct version as explained at length in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kilayim 8:1:10" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kilayim.8.1.10"><i>Kilaim</i> 8:1 Note 29</a> and refers to <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 70–71. The example refers to sacrificing outside the Temple district (or another holy place designated by God) and is missing in <i>Kilaim</i>. The statement itself is found in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Zevachim 106a" href="/Zevachim.106a">Babli, <i>Zebaḥim</i> 106a</a>.</i> Rebbi Eleazar: <i>Be on guard</i>, a prohibition. <i>Lest</i>, a prohibition. And it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 12:13-14" href="/Deuteronomy.12.13-14"><i>Deut</i>. 12:13–14</a>: Be on guard, <i>and do not offer your elevation sacrifices at any place which you see. Only at the place which the Eternal will choose</i> … there you shall offer <i>your elevation sacrifices</i> and there you shall do <i>everything which I am commanding you</i>. This is a general prohibition followed by two specific positive commandments.</i>: <i>There, you shall offer your elevation offerings and there you shall make. There, you shall offer</i>, that is the offering; <i>and there you shall make</i>, that is slaughtering and sprinkling. Just as offering is a positive commandment and a prohibition, so slaughtering and sprinkling which are positive commandments should be covered by a prohibition. Because it is written <i>there you shall offer, and there you shall make</i>. Therefore, if <i>there you shall offer, and there you shall make</i> were not written, no positive commandment would allow inferences for a prohibition and no prohibition would allow inferences for a positive commandment. How does Rebbi Joḥanan handle this? That you should not say as you say referring to the Sabbath: If one dug a hole, made a ditch, or dug to put in a pole, he is guilty only of one offense<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">Sabbath prohibitions are classified into 39 different categories (Mishnah <i>Šabbat</i>7:2). Different actions all of which are classified under the same category are considered one and the same violation of the Sabbath. The activities quoted here are all derivatives of ploughing (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 73b" href="/Shabbat.73b">Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 73b</a>).</i>. Similarly, if he slaughtered and offered, he should be guilty only of one offense; therefore, it was necessary to say, he is liable for every single action<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Zevachim 107b" href="/Zevachim.107b">Babli, <i>Zebaḥim</i> 107b</a>, according to one opinion this is R. Ismael’s position.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is from <i>Kilaim</i> (<b>ך</b>) 8:1, Notes 33–36.</i> Rebbi Zeˋira, Rav Ḥiyya bar Ashi in the name of Cahana: He who is planting on the Sabbath is guilty because of sowing. Rebbi Ze`ura said, he who prunes is like one who plants. If he planted and pruned on the Sabbath, according to Cahana he is guilty on two counts, according to Rebbi Ze`ura only on one count. Did not Rebbi Ze`ura say the pruner is like the planter, did perhaps he say the planter is like the pruner? All was included in the category of sowing; pruning was singled out for particular stringency. Because pruning was singled out for particular stringency you want to exempt it because of sowing? This means, there is no difference. If he planted and pruned on the Sabbath, according to both Cahana and Rebbi Ze`ura he is guilty on two counts

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A person having sexual relations with the mother is guilty because of mother and because of father’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">If he committed the incest in ignorance either of the person or the law, he owes two purification sacrifices.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah say, he is guilty only because of mother<sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote">He holds that <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:7" href="/Leviticus.18.7"><i>Lev</i>. 18:7</a> only forbids the mother; 18:8 only forbids the stepmother.</i>.<br>A person having sexual relations with the father’s wife is guilty because of father’s wife and because of married woman, whether during his father’s lifetime or after his father’s death<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">But if the widowed stepmother is not remarried, he is not guilty for sleeping with an otherwise married woman. Similarly, a man sleeping with his daughter-in-law (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:6:3-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.6.3-6">Halakhah 8</a>) is not guilty of adultery with a married woman if at the moment of the crime she was not married to anybody. Neither the prohibition of the stepmother nor that of the daughter-in-law are removed by divorce and remarriage to a third party.</i>, whether preliminarily married or definitively married.<br>A person having sexual relations with his daughter-in-law is guilty because of his daughter-in-law and because of a married woman, whether during his son’s lifetime or after his son’s death<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">But if the widowed stepmother is not remarried, he is not guilty for sleeping with an otherwise married woman. Similarly, a man sleeping with his daughter-in-law (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:6:3-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.6.3-6">Halakhah 8</a>) is not guilty of adultery with a married woman if at the moment of the crime she was not married to anybody. Neither the prohibition of the stepmother nor that of the daughter-in-law are removed by divorce and remarriage to a third party.</i>, whether preliminarily married or definitively married.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A person having sexual relations with the mother,” etc. Halakhah 7:“A person having sexual relations with the father’s wife,” etc. From where the warning<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">A prohibition the penalty for which is not spelled out carries a penalty of flogging (<i>Deut</i>. 25:21). For any more serious infraction the pentateuchal style requires that separate verses must spell out (1) the prohibition, (2) the penalty to be imposed by the court, (3) the penalty imposed by Heaven in case the crime was not observed by two blameless adult male witnesses and, therefore, no court case was possible. In case of sexual crimes this would mean that the witnesses have to see the sex act. For a civil case, such as a husband wishing to divorce his wife because of her adultery, without paying her <i>ketubah</i>, it is enough for witnesses to testify to her going to a room with another man, locking the door, and extinguishing the lights. But this is not enough for a criminal conviction.</i> for a person having sexual relations with the mother? <i>Your mother’s nakedness you shall not uncover</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:7" href="/Leviticus.18.7"><i>Lev</i>. 18:7</a>.</i> From where extirpation? <i>For anybody who would commit any of these abominations, the guilty persons will be extirpated from their people</i><sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:29" href="/Leviticus.18.29"><i>Lev</i>. 18:29</a>.</i>. From where the warning for a person having sexual relations with the father’s wife? <i>Your father’s wife’s nakedness you shall not uncover</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:8" href="/Leviticus.18.8"><i>Lev</i>. 18:8</a></i> From where extirpation? <i>For anybody who would commit</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:29" href="/Leviticus.18.29"><i>Lev</i>. 18:29</a>.</i> etc. Punishment from where? <i>A man who would sleep with his father’s wife, his father’s nakedness he uncovered; they shall be put to death</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:11" href="/Leviticus.20.11"><i>Lev</i>. 20:11</a>. Even R. Jehudah will agree that this verse also refers to the mother. The verse ends: <i>their blood be on them</i>. In the next Halakhah it will be determined that this expression implies stoning; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 54a" href="/Sanhedrin.54a">Babli 54a</a>.</i> etc.
From where the warning<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">A prohibition the penalty for which is not spelled out carries a penalty of flogging (<i>Deut</i>. 25:21). For any more serious infraction the pentateuchal style requires that separate verses must spell out (1) the prohibition, (2) the penalty to be imposed by the court, (3) the penalty imposed by Heaven in case the crime was not observed by two blameless adult male witnesses and, therefore, no court case was possible. In case of sexual crimes this would mean that the witnesses have to see the sex act. For a civil case, such as a husband wishing to divorce his wife because of her adultery, without paying her <i>ketubah</i>, it is enough for witnesses to testify to her going to a room with another man, locking the door, and extinguishing the lights. But this is not enough for a criminal conviction.</i> for a person having sexual relations with his daughter-in-law? <i>Your daughter-in-law’s nakedness you shall not uncover.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:15" href="/Leviticus.18.15"><i>Lev</i>. 18:15</a>.</i> From where extirpation? <i>For any man who would commit any of these abominations will be extirpated</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">131,</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:29" href="/Leviticus.18.29"><i>Lev</i>. 18:29</a>.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">The verse is slightly misquoted.</i> etc. Punishment from where? A <i>man who would sleep with his daughter-in-law</i><sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:12" href="/Leviticus.20.12"><i>Lev</i>. 20:12</a>.</i> etc.
We have it stated here, we have it stated in <i>Keritut</i><sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">The multiple transgressions committed by one act mentioned in the last three Mishnaiot are also implied by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Keritot 1:1" href="/Mishnah_Keritot.1.1">Mishnah <i>Keritut</i> 1:1</a>.</i>. One understands in <i>Keritut</i><sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">If the sin was committed inadvertently, one act may require multiple sacrifices for atonement.</i> that he brings one sacrifice and then has to bring a second. What can you say in <i>Sanhedrin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote">A person can be executed only once.</i>? That he is stoned and then stoned again? Rebbi Yudan, Rebbi Mattaniah’s father, said: explain it for warnings<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote">Since a person can only be convicted if he was warned in appropriate fashion (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:1:2-11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.1.2-11">Halakhah 5:1</a>), he will be convicted for the single transgression about which he had been warned.</i>. For if they warned him because of the father’s wife, he is hit,<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">As the commentaries point out, one cannot translate לוֹקֶה by “being flogged”, since one refers to capital crimes.</i> because of the mother, he is hit. Could they not also warn him because of a married woman? Rebbi Abun said, explain it if she was unmarried<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">But if the widowed stepmother is not remarried, he is not guilty for sleeping with an otherwise married woman. Similarly, a man sleeping with his daughter-in-law (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:6:3-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.6.3-6">Halakhah 8</a>) is not guilty of adultery with a married woman if at the moment of the crime she was not married to anybody. Neither the prohibition of the stepmother nor that of the daughter-in-law are removed by divorce and remarriage to a third party.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">These two paragraphs are partially corrupt. In a few places, the required corrections are obvious; other passages are not so simple. The text was treated at length by M. Assis לפירושה של סוגיא אחת בירושלמי סנהדרין Sinai 99(1986) pp. 110–127. The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 53a-54a" href="/Sanhedrin.53a-54a">Babli is 53a–54a</a>.</i> There, we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote">In the Yerushalmi תַּמָּן תַּנִּינָן always introduces a Mishnah quote. Already J. N. Epstein in מבוא לנוסח המשנה p. 150 has noted that one should read תַּמָּן תְּנַיִין “there (in Babylonia) one states.” The Babylonian <i>baraita</i> is quoted in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 53a" href="/Sanhedrin.53a">Babli, 53a</a>.</i>: Rebbi Jehudah says, if his mother was not fit for his father, he is liable only for one [sacrifice]. Therefore, if his mother was fit for his father, he is liable for two. Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: There is no difference. Whether his mother was fit for his father or unfit for his father, he is liable only once. The reason of Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that one has to read “R. Jehudah” since R. Johanan opposes the conclusion of the argument.</i>: <i>Your mother is she</i>, you find him guilty because of his mother; this directs the entire chapter towards his mother<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">This is only the end of an argument which can be reconstructed from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Kedoshim, Chapter 9 12" href="/Sifra,_Kedoshim,_Chapter_9.12"><i>Sifra Qedošim Pereq</i> 9(12</a>). <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:7" href="/Leviticus.18.7"><i>Lev</i>. 18:7</a> reads: <i>Your father’s nakedness and your mother’s nakedness you shall not uncover; she is your mother, do not uncover her nakedness</i>. The unusual wordiness of the verse has to be explained. Later in the paragraph there is disagreement whether <i>your father’s nakedness</i> refers to homosexual relations or describes a woman other than the mother who had sexual relations with the father. R. Jehudah opts for the first alternative. The mother then is singled out; she is equally forbidden whether she is or ever was his father’s wife or not, just as the father is forbidden whether he ever was married to his mother or not. This excludes any possibility to charge relations with her as father’s wife as a separate crime.</i>. Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya asked before Rebbi Zeˋira: What caused Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that one has to read “R. Jehudah” since R. Johanan opposes the conclusion of the argument.</i> to concentrate on the mother and to leave the father’s wife aside? He told him, for he argues with Rebbi Ismael, as Rebbi Ismael explained: <i>Your father’s wife’s nakedness</i><sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Obviously one has to read <i>your father’s nakedness</i> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:7" href="/Leviticus.18.7">v. 7</a>) instead of a quote from v.8.</i>; the verse refers to the male. Is not his father included in the category of the male<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote">Since homosexual intercourse also is a capital crime.</i>? Only to make him liable twice, as we have stated: A person having sexual relations with his father is doubly liable about him<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 54a" href="/Sanhedrin.54a">Babli 54a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Sanhedrin 54a:12:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Sanhedrin.54a.12.1">Tosaphot <i>s. v</i>. הבא</a>.</i>. Then should we not state “thirty-seven extirpations in the Torah”<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Keritot 1:1" href="/Mishnah_Keritot.1.1">Mishnah <i>Keritut</i> 1:1</a> lists 36 separate cases of extirpation; homosexual acts with the father are not listed.</i>? Rebbi Mana said, all denotations of males are one. <sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote">This text is repeated later as R. Aqiba’s opinion. Since R. Ismael was quoted as opposing this interpretation, it is not his opinion. The text is dittography from the following.</i><i>Your father’s wife’s nakedness</i>; the verse refers to the father’s wife. <i>Your mother’s nakedness</i>, that is his mother who is his father’s wife. From where his mother who is not his father’s wife? <i>Your mother is she; do not uncover her nakedness</i>. How does Rebbi Ismael treat this? He explains it to apply after [the father’s] death<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote">Why is the mother mentioned twice, once in parallel with the father and once separately?</i>. Does Rebbi Aqiba not explain <i>she is your father’s nakedness</i><sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:8" href="/Leviticus.18.8"><i>Lev</i>. 18:8</a>, referring to the stepmother.</i>? There is no difference whether during lifetime or after death. Rebbi Aqiba explains: <i>Your father’s wife’s nakedness</i><sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">Obviously one has to read <i>your father’s nakedness</i> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:7" href="/Leviticus.18.7">v. 7</a>) instead of a quote from v.8.</i>, the verse refers to the father’s wife. <i>Your mother’s nakedness</i>, that is his mother who is his father’s wife. From where his mother who is not his father’s wife? <i>Your mother is she; do not uncover her nakedness</i>. How does Rebbi Ismael treat this? He explains it to apply after [the father’s] death<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote">Dittography from above.</i>. Does not Rebbi Aqiba treat <i>your father’s nakedness, your mother’s nakedness</i><sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote">M. Assis here sees a lacuna referring to the earlier statement that the mother remains equally forbidden whether or not the father is alive. This is not a necessary inference.</i>? Since <i>your father</i> refers to your father in any capacity<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">Whether married, seducer, rapist or paying for sexual services.</i> both for punishment<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">Punishment is spelled out in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:11" href="/Leviticus.20.11"><i>Lev</i>. 20:11</a>, warning in 18:7.</i> and warning, so also <i>your mother</i> refers to one’s mother in any capacity both for punishment and warning. Is it not reasonable to explain that verse except following Rebbi Jehudah who because he does not accept “his mother who is his father’s wife”<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">He rejects the interpretation that the first mention of <i>your mother</i> in v. 7 refers to the father’s wife, the second mention to a mother not married to his father.</i> must explain that <i>your father’s nakedness, your mother’s nakedness</i> refers to your father in any capacity both for punishment and warning, so also <i>your mother</i> refers to your mother in any capacity both for punishment and warning. Rebbi Zeˋira said, this implies that one infers from parallel language<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">גְּזֵירָה שָׁוָה “equal cut” is the transfer of rules from one law to another if identical language was used. The majority opinion accepts inferences from “equal cut” only if (a) there exists a tradition that the words in question were written for this purpose and (b) no other inferences are drawn from the expressions in question (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 22b" href="/Niddah.22b">Babli <i>Niddah</i> 22b</a>). Property (b) is meant if an expression is called “free”. The equal cut here is the use of <i>your father’s nakedness</i> both in v.7 and v.8. As we have seen, in v.7 the expression clearly is not “free”.</i> even if it is free only from one side<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">M. Assis rightly points out that it is not free even in v.8 since the expression is used to forbid the stepmother after the father’s death.</i>. Rebbi Yudan said to him<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">As M. Assis points out, the statement also is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yoma 8:3:2-15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yoma.8.3.2-15"><i>Yoma</i> 8:3</a> (45a l. 48) where R. Yudan’s statement is an independent remark. Since R. Yudan lived a generation after R. Zeˋira, the <i>Yoma</i> version has to be accepted.</i>, this is obvious for Rebbi Aqiba since Rebbi Aqiba infers from parallel language even if it is not free<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">This statement is unknown to Babylonian sources; the statement of the Babylonian R. Zeˋira is found in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 64a" href="/Shabbat.64a">Babli, <i>Šabbat</i> 64a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Niddah 22b" href="/Niddah.22b"><i>Niddah</i> 22b</a>.</i>.
Rebbi Jeremiah asked: Is a person having sexual relations with his mother guilty [of adultery] with her as a married woman<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote">This is a question only for R. Jehudah; for the majority it already was answered positively, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:6:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.6.4">Note 128</a>.</i>? Come and see: if a third person had sexual relations with her, would he not be guilty [of adultery] with her as a married woman? Her son not so much more? Rebbi Yose objected: is not her stepson guilty [of adultery] with her as a married woman, but her son is not guilty [of adultery] with her as a married woman<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote">To make sense of this objection, one has to read אֵשֶׁת אָב “the father’s wife” instead of אֵשֶׁת אִישׁ “a married woman”. R. Jehudah in the Mishnah explicitly declares the prohibition of the father’s wife inapplicable to the mother.</i>? As we have stated:<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote">A similar text is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 10:1-2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.10.1-2">Tosephta 10:2</a>.</i> Also with all other cases of incest and adultery the situation is the same. His mother-in-law as a married woman, you catch him because of his mother-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote">The mother-in-law is forbidden as the wife’s mother (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17"><i>Lev</i>. 18:17</a>); the penalty for the willful crime is burning (20:14), more serious than strangling, the penalty for adultery (20:10).</i>. His daughter-in-law as a married woman, you catch him because of his daughter-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote">The penalty is stoning (20:10). Even though the question here is about the number of sacrifices due for an unintended crime, the more serious crime is the only one counted. But, naturally, if in case of intentional crime the warning was given only about adultery, not about any incestuous aspect, the perpetrator is tried for adultery. This <i>baraita</i> contradicts the Mishnah.</i>. His sister as a married woman, do you catch him because of his sister? You smuggle him away from the serious crime and strike him for the easier one<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Adultery is a capital crime; sleeping with one’s sister is punishable only by Heaven, not the human court.<br>The verb קנתר used here is Greek κεντρόω “to strike with a stick” (to goad an animal.)</i>; this you cannot do as we have stated: A person having sexual relations with his sister is liable because of her as his sister and as a daughter of his father’s wife<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote">The sister is always characterized as <i>your father’s daughter or your mother’s daughter</i> (18:9,20:17), describing the full sister or the maternal half-sister, or <i>your father’s wife’s daughter from your father</i>(18:11), describing the paternal half-sister. It seems that there is no biblical penalty attached to relations with the paternal extramarital half-sister. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 22b" href="/Yevamot.22b">Babli <i>Yebamot</i> 22b</a>.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Jehudah says, a person having sexual relations with his sister<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">The unmarried sister.</i> is only liable because of her as his sister; the same is true for his daughter-in-law. Rebbi Jeremiah, Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Jehudah follows the argument of his father Rebbi Jehudah. Just as Rebbi Jehudah accepts the description mentioned first, so Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Jehudah accepts the description mentioned first. Rebbi Jeremiah, Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan turned around: Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Jehudah does not follow the argument of his father Rebbi Jehudah. There he is liable because of his mother, who is not his father’s wife; he is liable because of his father’s wife who is not his mother. But here we find that he is permitted his father’s wife’s daughter, who is not his sister<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote">Children from previous marriages who are not related to one another are encouraged to marry. Rav was the son of R. Hiyya’s unrelated half-brother and half-sister from previous marriages of his parents.</i>.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A man who had sexual relations with a male or an animal, or a woman who brings an animal [upon herself]<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote">These are to be stoned, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.5.1">Mishnah 5</a>.</i>. If a human sinned, what did the animal sin<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:15" href="/Leviticus.20.15"><i>Lev</i>. 20:15</a> decrees that a male who had relations with an animal shall be killed together with the animal, while v. 16 decrees that a woman who had relations with an animal shall be stoned together with the animal. The two verses are considered a unit, so that <i>killing</i> in v. 15 is read as <i>stoning</i>.</i>? But because it caused a mishap to a human, therefore the verse decreed that it should be stoned. Another explanation: Lest the animal be seen in public and people say, this is the one because of which X was stoned.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A man who had sexual relations with a male.” From where the warning<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">A prohibition the penalty for which is not spelled out carries a penalty of flogging (<i>Deut</i>. 25:21). For any more serious infraction the pentateuchal style requires that separate verses must spell out (1) the prohibition, (2) the penalty to be imposed by the court, (3) the penalty imposed by Heaven in case the crime was not observed by two blameless adult male witnesses and, therefore, no court case was possible. In case of sexual crimes this would mean that the witnesses have to see the sex act. For a civil case, such as a husband wishing to divorce his wife because of her adultery, without paying her <i>ketubah</i>, it is enough for witnesses to testify to her going to a room with another man, locking the door, and extinguishing the lights. But this is not enough for a criminal conviction.</i> for a person having sexual relations with a male<sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">The form זְכוּר denotes, if not the penis, then the male as appendix to his sex organ.</i>? <i>With a male you shall not sleep in women’s ways</i><sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:22" href="/Leviticus.18.22"><i>Lev</i>. 18:22</a>. A general parallel to this paragraph is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 54b" href="/Sanhedrin.54b">Babli, 54b</a>.</i>. From where extirpation? <i>For anybody who would commit any of these abominations will be extirpated</i><sup class="footnote-marker">131,</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:29" href="/Leviticus.18.29"><i>Lev</i>. 18:29</a>.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">The verse is slightly misquoted.</i>, etc. Punishment from where? <i>A man who would sleep with a male in women’s ways, an abomination did both of them commit; they shall be put to death; their blood be on them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:13" href="/Leviticus.20.13"><i>Lev</i>. 20:13</a>.</i>. You learn <i>their blood be on them</i> from <i>their blood be on them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:12" href="/Leviticus.20.12"><i>Lev</i>. 20:12</a>. From <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:27" href="/Leviticus.20.27"><i>Lev</i>. 20:27</a>: <i>they shall be put to death, by a stone they shall be stoned, their blood be on them</i>, it is inferred that any expression “their blood be on them” means execution by stoning. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 54a" href="/Sanhedrin.54a">Babli 54a</a>.</i>. That is for the active one. For the passive one from where? <i>With a male you shall not sleep in women’s ways</i>, read: <i>to be slept with</i><sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote">The unvocalized text תשכב can be read either with the masoretes as active תִּשְׁכַּב “you shall sleep” or as passive תִּשָּׁכֵב “you shall be slept with”. The nonstandard vocalization in the text is from the ms. (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 54b" href="/Sanhedrin.54b">Babli 54b</a>).</i>. So far following Rebbi Aqiba. Following Rebbi Ismael? <i>There shall be no qadeš among the sons of Israel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:18" href="/Deuteronomy.23.18"><i>Deut</i>. 23:18</a>. The identification of the <i>qadeš</i> as the male prostitute follows later from the verse in <i>Kings</i>.</i>. From where extirpation for the passive homosexual following Rebbi Ismael? Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Abbahu. It says here <i>qadeš</i> and it says there, <i>also a qadeš was in the land</i><sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 14:24" href="/I_Kings.14.24"><i>1K</i>. 14:24</a>.</i>. You learn <i>qadeš</i> from <i>qadeš</i> and <i>qadeš</i> from <i>abomination</i><sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">It is assumed that <i>qadeš</i> means the same in both verses. Also, <i>qadeš</i> must refer to the male since the feminine form <i>qedešah</i> is explicitly mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:18" href="/Deuteronomy.23.18"><i>Deut</i>. 23:18</a>. <i>1K</i>. 14 continues: <i>They did all the</i> abominations <i>of the peoples whom the Eternal had uprooted from before the Children of Israel</i>. These <i>abominations</i> are referred to in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:29" href="/Leviticus.18.29"><i>Lev</i>. 18:29</a> and the only abominations unique to a male are homosexuality and active bestiality. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 54b" href="/Sanhedrin.54b">Babli, 54b</a>, both R. Ismael’s and R. Aqiba’s statements are quoted as <i>baraitot</i>; partially also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Kedoshim, Chapter 9 12" href="/Sifra,_Kedoshim,_Chapter_9.12"><i>Sifra Qedošim Pereq</i> 9(12</a>).</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Ada in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: <i>Abomination</i> from <i>abomination</i><sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Lev</i>.20, the expression <i>abomination</i> is only used for the homosexual. This implies that the <i>qadeš</i> in <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 14:24" href="/I_Kings.14.24"><i>1K</i>. 14:24</a>, and therefore in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:18" href="/Deuteronomy.23.18"><i>Deut</i>. 23:18</a> is engaged in homosexual acts.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, a <i>baraita</i><sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">Not recorded elsewhere.</i> states this: <i>Both committed an abomination</i><sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:22" href="/Leviticus.18.22"><i>Lev</i>. 18:22</a>. A general parallel to this paragraph is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 54b" href="/Sanhedrin.54b">Babli, 54b</a>.</i>. Both are stoned, both are subject to warning, both by extirpation.
From where the warning<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">A prohibition the penalty for which is not spelled out carries a penalty of flogging (<i>Deut</i>. 25:21). For any more serious infraction the pentateuchal style requires that separate verses must spell out (1) the prohibition, (2) the penalty to be imposed by the court, (3) the penalty imposed by Heaven in case the crime was not observed by two blameless adult male witnesses and, therefore, no court case was possible. In case of sexual crimes this would mean that the witnesses have to see the sex act. For a civil case, such as a husband wishing to divorce his wife because of her adultery, without paying her <i>ketubah</i>, it is enough for witnesses to testify to her going to a room with another man, locking the door, and extinguishing the lights. But this is not enough for a criminal conviction.</i> for a person having sexual relations with an animal? <i>Do not give your emission into an animal to defile yourself by it</i><sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:23" href="/Leviticus.18.23"><i>Lev</i>. 18:23</a>. The entire paragraph has a parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 54b" href="/Sanhedrin.54b">Babli, 54b</a>.</i>. From where extirpation? <i>For anybody who would commit any of these abominations will be extirpated</i><sup class="footnote-marker">131,</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:29" href="/Leviticus.18.29"><i>Lev</i>. 18:29</a>.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">The verse is slightly misquoted.</i>, etc. Punishment from where? <i>A man who would sleep with a animal shall be put to death</i><sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Lev</i>.20:15. The corresponding verse for a woman is 20:16.</i>. You infer <i>their blood be on them</i> from <i>their blood be on them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">15,</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:12" href="/Leviticus.20.12"><i>Lev</i>. 20:12</a>. From <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:27" href="/Leviticus.20.27"><i>Lev</i>. 20:27</a>: <i>they shall be put to death, by a stone they shall be stoned, their blood be on them</i>, it is inferred that any expression “their blood be on them” means execution by stoning. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 54a" href="/Sanhedrin.54a">Babli 54a</a>.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">184</sup><i class="footnote">The expression is used only in v. 16. It is implied that the punishment for male bestiality cannot be less than that of female bestiality.</i>. So far following Rebbi Aqiba. Following Rebbi Ismael? Rebbi Ismael from his source<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote">It is assumed that <i>qadeš</i> means the same in both verses. Also, <i>qadeš</i> must refer to the male since the feminine form <i>qedešah</i> is explicitly mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 23:18" href="/Deuteronomy.23.18"><i>Deut</i>. 23:18</a>. <i>1K</i>. 14 continues: <i>They did all the</i> abominations <i>of the peoples whom the Eternal had uprooted from before the Children of Israel</i>. These <i>abominations</i> are referred to in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:29" href="/Leviticus.18.29"><i>Lev</i>. 18:29</a> and the only abominations unique to a male are homosexuality and active bestiality. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 54b" href="/Sanhedrin.54b">Babli, 54b</a>, both R. Ismael’s and R. Aqiba’s statements are quoted as <i>baraitot</i>; partially also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Kedoshim, Chapter 9 12" href="/Sifra,_Kedoshim,_Chapter_9.12"><i>Sifra Qedošim Pereq</i> 9(12</a>).</i> and Rebbi Aqiba from his source<sup class="footnote-marker">185</sup><i class="footnote">R. Ismael includes bestiality in the actions of a <i>qadeš.</i> R. Aqiba always refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:29" href="/Leviticus.18.29"><i>Lev</i>. 18:29</a>.</i>. Extirpation for a male passive partner is not found for Rebbi Ismael<sup class="footnote-marker">186</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli disagrees and finds the passive participant in bestiality in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:18" href="/Exodus.22.18"><i>Ex</i>. 22:18</a>.</i>. Punishment for a male passive partner is not found for Rebbi Ismael or Rebbi Aqiba<sup class="footnote-marker">187</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20" href="/Leviticus.20"><i>Lev</i>. 20</a>.</i>, but it is written: <i>One who sacrifices to the forces of nature shall be banned</i>. Since this one is in for stoning and extirpation, also that one is in for stoning and extirpation<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote">The worshipper of the forces of nature is banned <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:19" href="/Exodus.22.19"><i>Ex</i>. 22:19</a>, but as adherent of foreign worship he is stoned. It is implied that the death penalty decreed in the preceding verse, <i>anybody lying with an animal shall be put to death</i>, for the passive participant in bestiality also must be executed by stoning.</i>. What is the difference between them? If one had active homosexual relations followed by passive ones, in Rebbi Ismael’s opinion he is liable only once; in Rebbi Aqiba’s opinion he is liable twice<sup class="footnote-marker">189</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 54b" href="/Sanhedrin.54b">Babli, 54b</a>, the attributions are switched. One has to follow the classical commentaries in correcting the Yerushalmi following the Babli since, as explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:7:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.7.2">Notes 175–178</a>, R. Aqiba finds the prohibition of active and passive homosexuality in the same verse whereas R. Ismael defines the passive homosexual as <i>qadeš</i>. Therefore, combined active and passive homosexual activity violates one verse for R. Aqiba, two for R. Ismael.</i>. If one had active relations with an animal followed by passive ones. Both in Rebbi Aqiba’s as in Rebbi Ismael’s opinions he is liable twice<sup class="footnote-marker">190</sup><i class="footnote">For both R. Aqiba and R. Ismael both <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:22" href="/Leviticus.18.22"><i>Lev</i>. 18:22</a> (or 23) and <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:18" href="/Exodus.22.18"><i>Ex</i>. 22:18</a> are violated. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 54b" href="/Sanhedrin.54b">Babli disagrees, 54b</a>.</i>. If he had active homosexual relations with both a male and an animal he is liable twice. If he had passive homosexual relations with both a male and an animal he is liable twice. If he had simultaneous active sexual relations with two males, since both of them became guilty because of him, he is liable twice. If he had simultaneous passive sexual relations with two males, since both of them became guilty because of him, he is liable twice. It was stated: For males, an underage boy does not have the status of an adult<sup class="footnote-marker">191</sup><i class="footnote">Sexual relations with males under the age of nine years and one day, and females under three years and one day, are not considered as sexual activities; cf. <i>Ketubot</i>1:3 Notes 147,152.</i>; a young animal has the status of a fully grown one. Rebbi Eleazar said, he cannot become liable because of it unless it be three years and one day of age<sup class="footnote-marker">192</sup><i class="footnote">This does not refer to bestiality but to homosexuality. Homosexual relations of a male with an underage boy are not punishable unless the boy is at least three  years and one day of age, i. e., that a valid sex act would have been performed if the child had been a girl. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 54b-55a" href="/Sanhedrin.54b-55a">Babli, 54b/55a</a>, Samuel derives this from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:22" href="/Leviticus.18.22"><i>Lev</i>. 18:22</a> where homosexual acts are called <i>lyings in woman’s way</i>.</i>.
Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya asked of Rebbi Zeˋira: For what reason did Rebbi Ismael and Rebbi Aqiba disagree about a male and an animal but did not disagree about any incest prohibition<sup class="footnote-marker">193</sup><i class="footnote">For all other sexual prohibitions they agree that the warnings and punishments equally apply to both partners.</i>? He told him, because for all incest prohibitions it is written <i>blood relative</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">194</sup><i class="footnote">The introductory clause <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:6" href="/Leviticus.18.6"><i>Lev</i>. 18:6</a>: <i>No human shall come near to his blood relative to uncover nakedness</i> refers to both sexes. The detailed prohibitions always are formulated for the male and mention the female’s nakedness, but here nakedness is mentioned without any pronoun, masculine or feminine.</i> and about these it is not written <i>blood relative</i>. They objected: About the menstruating woman it is not written <i>blood relative</i>; did they disagree about her<sup class="footnote-marker">195</sup><i class="footnote">Both agree that for both partners the warning is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:19" href="/Leviticus.18.19"><i>Lev</i>. 18:19</a> and the punishment, explicitly for both sexes, is 20:18.</i>? Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: For it is written <i>approach, approach</i>; it is as if all were here and there<sup class="footnote-marker">196</sup><i class="footnote">The singular in 18:19 is equivalent to the plural used in 18:6; it is as if “blood relative” were written there.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Aba in the name of Rebbi Ḥanina: <i>To the wife in the separation of her impurity you shall not come near to uncover her nakedness</i><sup class="footnote-marker">197</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:19" href="/Leviticus.18.19"><i>Lev</i>. 18:19</a>. The verse seems to refer exclusively to the male; it is quoted as an objection.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, “not to come near” is “not to uncover.<sup class="footnote-marker">198</sup><i class="footnote">Since “not to uncover” is used in 20:18 explicitly for both sexes, “not to come near” in 18:19 also must apply to both sexes.</i>”
From where the warning<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">A prohibition the penalty for which is not spelled out carries a penalty of flogging (<i>Deut</i>. 25:21). For any more serious infraction the pentateuchal style requires that separate verses must spell out (1) the prohibition, (2) the penalty to be imposed by the court, (3) the penalty imposed by Heaven in case the crime was not observed by two blameless adult male witnesses and, therefore, no court case was possible. In case of sexual crimes this would mean that the witnesses have to see the sex act. For a civil case, such as a husband wishing to divorce his wife because of her adultery, without paying her <i>ketubah</i>, it is enough for witnesses to testify to her going to a room with another man, locking the door, and extinguishing the lights. But this is not enough for a criminal conviction.</i> for a woman bringing an animal upon herself? <i>A woman should not stand before an animal to be impregnated; it is mixture</i><sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:19" href="/Leviticus.18.19"><i>Lev</i>. 18:19</a>.</i>. Extirpation from where? <i>For anybody who would commit any of these abominations will be extirpated</i><sup class="footnote-marker">131,</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:29" href="/Leviticus.18.29"><i>Lev</i>. 18:29</a>.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote">The verse is slightly misquoted.</i>. Punishment from where? <i>If a woman</i> stood before an animal <i>to be impregnated, you should slay the woman and the animal; dying they shall be put to death, their blood be on them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote">Misquoted from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:16" href="/Leviticus.20.16"><i>Lev</i>. 20:16</a>.</i>. One infers slaying from slaying, stoning from stoning, <i>their blood be on them</i> from <i>their blood be on them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Both for male and female bestiality it is said that the animal has to be <i>slain</i>; this shows that in both cases the animal has to be killed in the same way. Stoning is to be inferred from <i>their blood be on them</i> (Notes 15,184) referring to the female; this then is transferred also to apply to the male.</i>.
Rebbi Abba bar Mamal asked: Think of it, if he erroneously has sexual relations with it<sup class="footnote-marker">202</sup><i class="footnote">If a male thought that bestiality was not forbidden.</i>. Should it be stoned because of him while he is not liable<sup class="footnote-marker">203</sup><i class="footnote">Instead of simply stating that the verse requires that the animal be killed, the Mishnah states two different reasons for it. The first reason, that it led a human into sin, applies even if the human is not prosecutable because he was not duly warned of the criminality of the intended act. The second reason, that the animal was known as the one for which a human was stoned, does not apply. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 55b" href="/Sanhedrin.55b">Babli 55b</a> in the name of Babylonian Amoraïm.</i>? Rebbi Simeon asked: Think of it, if he used it to plough on the Sabbath. Is he not being stoned while it is not liable<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">The second reason stated in the Mishnah would apply here, but no animal can be stoned for a Sabbath violation.<br>Since R. Simeon is quoted after R. Abba bar Mamal, it seems that he is to be identified with R. Simeon ben Laqish.</i>? You have only, as Rebbi Samuel ben Rav Isaac explained: <sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Hosea 8:4" href="/Hosea.8.4"><i>Hos</i>. 8:4</a>.</i><i>With their silver and gold they made idols for themselves</i>; it is not written “that they be extirpated” but <i>that he be extirpated</i><sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">It is possible that of a group of criminals only one actually is prosecutable. There is nothing remarkable if human and animal are treated differently.</i>. As if a person say: the bones of X be ground up for he led his son to evil ways.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The blasphemer is not liable unless he explicitly use the Name<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">The Tetragrammaton in its original pronunciation, now lost.</i>. Rebbi Joshua ben Qorḥa said, during the trial one deals with the witnesses by substitute name, may Yose hit<sup class="footnote-marker">208</sup><i class="footnote">An expression of curse, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 28:22" href="/Deuteronomy.28.22"><i>Deut</i>. 28:22</a>.</i> Yose. At the end of the proceedings one does not sentence him to death by substitute name but one dismisses the public, retains the most prestigious among them<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">The witnesses.</i> and says to him, tell us explicitly what you heard. He says it while the judges are standing; they tear their garments<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">Since everybody who hears a blasphemy using the Name has to rend his garment, as if a close relative had died.</i> and never mend them<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">As for garments rent because of the death of a parent, the tear cannot be mended invisibly.</i>. The second one<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">The witnesses.</i> says, also I [heard] like him; the third<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">The witnesses.</i> one says, also I [heard] like him.
