<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The blasphemer is not liable,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 56a" href="/Sanhedrin.56a">Babli is 56a</a>.</i> From where a warning for the blasphemer? <i>You shall not curse God</i><sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:27" href="/Exodus.22.27"><i>Ex</i>. 22:27</a>. Since <i>El</i> means “power”, <i>Elohim</i> as a plural of majesty means “superior power”; in this case “supreme power” in contrast to <i>elohim aḥerim</i> which are not other gods” but “other powers”, such as the rain worshipped by Semites as Baal and by the Greeks as Zeus.</i>. Extirpation from where? <i>Anybody who curses his God shall bear his sin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 24:15" href="/Leviticus.24.15"><i>Lev</i>. 24:15</a>. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 9:13" href="/Numbers.9.13"><i>Num</i>. 9:13</a>, referring to the Second Passover, it is spelled out that “carrying one’s sin” is equivalent to “being subject to extirpation” [<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Chapter 19 6" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Chapter_19.6"><i>Sifra Emor Pereq</i>19(6</a>), in the name of R. Jehudah.]</i>. Punishment from where? <i>He who curses the Name of the Eternal shall be put to death</i><sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 24:16" href="/Leviticus.24.16"><i>Lev</i>. 24:16</a>.</i>. But according to Rebbi Ismael, since Rebbi Ismael said that the verse refers to judges<sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote">He reads <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:27" href="/Exodus.22.27"><i>Ex</i>. 22:27</a> as referring to judges, who are called <i>elohim</i> in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:7" href="/Exodus.22.7"><i>Ex</i>. 22:7</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 82:1" href="/Psalms.82.1"><i>Ps</i>. 82:1</a>. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 66a" href="/Sanhedrin.66a">Babli 66a</a>, <i>Mekhilta dR. IsmaelMišpatim</i> 19 (p. 317). The previous argument is R. Aqiba’s.</i>? If he is warned about judges, then so much more about [divine] substitute names<sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">Any reference to the Deity other than the Tetragrammaton, the Unique name. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 56a" href="/Sanhedrin.56a">Babli 56a</a>, <i>Mekhilta dR. Simeon ben Iohai</i> p. 213. The argument seems to contradict the principle that “one may not punish on the basis of a logical argument” (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:1:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.1.3">Halakhah 7:1 Note 9</a>). But since the argument refers only to warning and Heavenly retribution, not to penalties imposed by the court, there is no contradiction.</i>. If he is subject to extirpation for substitute names, so much more for the Unique Name. Some Tannaïm state: for substitute names warning and extirpation, for the Unique Name the death penalty. Some Tannaïm state: for substitute names warning, for the Unique Name the death penalty or extirpation<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Emor, Chapter 19 5" href="/Sifra,_Emor,_Chapter_19.5"><i>Sifra Emor Pereq</i> 19(5</a>), opinion of the rabbis opposing Rebbi Meïr who equates the Unique Name and its substitute names.</i>. He who says, for substitute names warning and extirpation, <i>you shall not curse God</i> and <i>anybody who curses his God shall bear his sin</i> by extirpation; for the Unique Name the death penalty, <i>he who curses the Name of the Eternal shall be put to death</i>. He who says, for substitute names warning, <i>you shall not curse God</i>, for the Unique Name the death penalty or extirpation, <i>he who curses the Name of the Eternal shall be put to death; anybody who curses his God shall bear his sin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote">The same group of verses can lead to two different conclusions without possibility of deciding between them.</i>, etc.
Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac: This<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah which states that the trial of the blasphemer proceeds before the court did hear the exact wording of the offensive statement.</i> implies that one proceeds on the basis of a doubt. How is this? “X killed a person.” One proceeds to try him until his witnesses come. Rebbi Yose said to him, does one arrest a person in the market and insult him<sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote">The court, acting as inquisitor, cannot arrest a person without a reasonable probability of conviction.</i>? But is it as follows: “X killed a person, and there are witnesses.” Let him be put under arrest until his witnesses come.
Does one tell him, blaspheme<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">This is a question about the Mishnah. How can the court require the witness to sin by repeating the entire blasphemy?</i>? But that Name which I am saying before you, that one he cursed or by that one he cursed<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">The witness is not asked to blaspheme. The text of the blasphemy except for the Name had been testified to earlier; now it is only necessary to confirm that the Name was used, which alone makes the blasphemy a capital crime.<br>The text makes it clear that blasphemy is not only cursing God by His Name but also cursing another person using the Name, including any magical practices using the Name.</i>. But the witnesses need not rend their garments since they already rent them when they heard it the first time.
Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, from here<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">From the Mishnah.</i> that in case the judges heard testimony while standing, their judgment is valid. You infer six statements from this<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">From the Mishnah.</i>. One infers the statement of Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac<sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote">The Mishnah which states that the trial of the blasphemer proceeds before the court did hear the exact wording of the offensive statement.</i>, and one infers the statement of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish. Also one infers that he who hears from one who heard has to rend<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Since the judges have to tear their garments, even though they are hearing the blasphemy only indirectly.</i>, and one infers that if one witness testified, the second one says, I testify to the same, and the third says, I testify to the same<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote">This statement seems to apply only to the case of the blasphemer. Witnesses have to be heard one at a time (5:3–4) to determine that they are not perjured. The speaking of the Name is the only case in which witnesses appear together, after having been interrogated separately about all other aspects of the case. However, the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 60a" href="/Sanhedrin.60a">Babli (60a</a>) reads the statement as implying that by biblical standards a witness may state that his testimony is identical with that of the first witness and that the rules of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:3:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.3.2-5">5:3–4</a> are rabbinic only.</i>. Also one infers that this is one of the tears which are not mended<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">As for garments rent because of the death of a parent, the tear cannot be mended invisibly.</i>, and one infers that even when they know from the start that it is the Unique Name, they have to rend.
Rebbi Ḥiyya said that Rebbi Yasa asked: We have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 6:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.6.2.1">Mishnah 6:2</a>.</i>: “The herald goes before him: ‘X ben Y is led to be stoned because he committed crime Z; U and V testified against him. Anybody who knows of his innocence shall come and argue.’ ” We inferred that he who hears from one who heard has to rend. Does he who hears from one who heard from one who heard have to rend<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">Does everybody who hears the herald have to rend his garment? Since this is not mentioned in the Mishnah, the implied answer to the question is negative.</i>?
Does one have to rend one’s garments for blasphemy?<sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote">Finally one asks why one has to rend his garment when he hears blasphemy since this obligation is not mentioned in the Torah.</i> Let us hear from the following: <i>When king Hezekias heard</i> the words of Rab Šake, <i>he rent his garment</i><sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 19:1" href="/II_Kings.19.1"><i>2K</i>. 19:1</a>. Since the king heard the blasphemy from his ministers, it proves that one has to rend his garment even if he hears it indirectly. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 69a" href="/Sanhedrin.69a">Babli 69a</a>.</i>. Does one have to rend for a Gentile’s blasphemy? According to him who said that Rab Šake was a Gentile, one rends. According to him who said that Rab Šake was an Israel, one does not rend<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">On the one hand, it is not likely that a high official of the king of Assyria was not an Assyrian. On the other hand, why should a high Assyrian official be able to speak Hebrew unless he was a Jewish apostate? <i>Mo`ed qaṭan</i> 3:6 (83b l. 32); <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 60a" href="/Sanhedrin.60a">Babli 60a</a>. M. Cogan and H. Tadmor, <i>II Kings</i>, The Anchor Bible vol. 11 (1988) p. 230.</i>. Rebbi Hoshaia stated: Both one who heard blasphemy from an Israel or one who heard from the mouth of a Gentile has to rend his garment. What is the reason? <i>Since I am the Eternal, God over all flesh, should anything be extraordinary for me</i><sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 32:26" href="/Jeremiah.32.26"><i>Jer</i>. 32:26</a>.</i>?
Does one rend his garment nowadays<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote">Since the pronunciation of the Name is unknown, an obligation to rend one’s garments would imply that it applies to substitutes of the Name. The paragraph has a parallel in <i>Mo`ed qatan</i> 3:6, 83b l. 38.</i>? Rebbi Yose, Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Abba, Rebbi Ḥisqiah, Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: When blasphemers proliferated, they stopped rending<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">The same statement in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 60a" href="/Sanhedrin.60a">Babli 60a</a> in the name of R. Hiyya (bar Abba). The implication is that the status of substitute names is the same as that of the Name.</i>. Does one rend for substitute names today? Let us hear from the following: Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish was travelling on the highway. He met a Samaritan who was repeatedly blaspheming, and he was rending. He dismounted from the donkey and gave him a blow on his heart saying to him: Samaritan! Does your mother have garments to supply me with? [His word] This implies<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">The scribe wrote הדא אמרה “this implies”. The corrector added מילתיה but then forgot to cross out הדא. One should read either “his word” or “this”.</i> that one rends for substitute names<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">Disagreeing with R. Joḥanan and the latter’s student R. Hiyya bar Abba.</i> and rends his garments at the present time.

Halakhah 9

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The worshipper of strange worship<sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote">Who is mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.5.1">Mishnah 5</a> as subject to stoning.</i> whether he worships<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">In a way customary for the worship of the idol even if it does not resemble any approved worship of Heaven.</i>, or sacrifices<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote">Any of the acts required in the Temple proffered to an idol is a capital crime even if ordinarily this is not the worship of this idol.</i>, or burns incense, or makes a libation, or prostrates himself; also one who accepts it as a god and says to it: you are my god<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote">Without any other action.</i>.<br>But one who embraces<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote">A statue.</i>, or kisses, or sweeps clean<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote">The floor on which the statue stands.</i>, or sprinkles water<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote">To settle the dust on the dirt floor on which the statue is standing.</i>; one who washes, rubs with oil, clothes, or puts shoes on it, violates a prohibition<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">The penalty would be flogging, not stoning.</i>. He who makes a vow in its name or keeps one in its name violates a prohibition. One who defecates in front of <i>Baal Pe`or</i> follows its worship<sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote">While in later biblical texts (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 5:14" href="/Isaiah.5.14"><i>Is</i>. 5:14</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 6:10" href="/Job.6.10"><i>Job</i> 6:10</a>) פער فعر means “to open one’s mouth wide”, in rabbinic Hebrew it always means “to defecate”. Therefore <i>Ba`al Pe`or</i> is interpreted as a deity worshipped by defecating in front of it. The defecation then becomes a capital crime.</i>. One who throws a stone at a statue of Mercury follows its worship<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote">While in general throwing a stone at an idol would be a commendable sign of disrespect, throwing a stone at a Hermes stele is a capital crime.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The worshipper of strange worship,” etc. From where warning about strange worship? <i>Do not worship them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 20:5" href="/Exodus.20.5"><i>Ex</i>. 20:5</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 5:9" href="/Deuteronomy.5.9"><i>Deut</i>. 5:9</a> the Second Commandment.</i>. Extirpation from where? <i>He blasphemed the Eternal and will be extirpated</i><sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:30" href="/Numbers.15.30"><i>Num</i>. 15:30</a>. The verse describes any person who sins intentionally as a blasphemer. The verse decrees extirpation as punishment for any willful deed for which a sacrifice would be required if done inadvertently, in case it cannot be prosecuted in court for lack of witnesses.<br>The traditional interpretation of the purification sacrifices prescribed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:22-29" href="/Numbers.15.22-29"><i>Num</i>. 15:22–29</a>, which differ from those prescribed under similar headings in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 4:1-5:14" href="/Leviticus.4.1-5.14"><i>Lev</i>. 4:1–5:14</a>, assigns the sacrifices prescribed in <i>Num</i>. exclusively to sins of idolatry; those of <i>Lev</i>. to the atonement of all other transgressions (<i>Sifry Num</i>. 111–112). Therefore, the following verse 15:30 can also be interpreted as specifically referring to idolatry.</i>. But is there not written “blasphemed”? As one would say to another, you scraped out the entire pot<sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">It seems that in Galilean dialect גדּף جدف  “to blaspheme” was pronounced like גדף جذف “to fly quickly” and this in turn sounded like גרף جرف “to scoop out with a shovel, to scratch out completely.” The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Keritot 7b" href="/Keritot.7b">Babli, <i>Keritut</i> 7b</a>, formulates גִּירַפְתָּ הַקְּעָרָה “you scratched out the pot” and Rashi comments: ד can be replaced by ר.</i> and did not leave anything; a parable which Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar formulated: Two people were sitting with a pot of porridge between them. One of them stretched out his hand, scraped out the entire pot, and did not leave anything in it. So both the blasphemer and the worshipper of strange worship do not leave any commandment as residue<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Obeying a Divine command after blaspheming or worshipping a strange deity is an empty gesture, devoid of all value.</i>. From where the punishment? <i>You shall lead out that man, or that woman, who did this deed to your gates</i>, etc., up to <i>and stone them with stones until they die</i><sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:5" href="/Deuteronomy.17.5"><i>Deut</i>. 17:5</a>.</i>.
<i>Do not worship them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 20:5" href="/Exodus.20.5"><i>Ex</i>. 20:5</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 5:9" href="/Deuteronomy.5.9"><i>Deut</i>. 5:9</a> the Second Commandment.</i>. Should I say, not unless he worshipped every single strange worship in the world? The verse says, <i>do not prostrate yourself before them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 20:5" href="/Exodus.20.5"><i>Ex</i>. 20:5</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 5:9" href="/Deuteronomy.5.9"><i>Deut</i>. 5:9</a> the Second Commandment.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">The argument is hinted at in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 60b" href="/Sanhedrin.60b">Babli, 60b</a>.</i> Prostration was included<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">Even though in the verse prostrating is mentioned before worshipping, it clearly is an act of worship and on purely logical grounds would not have to be mentioned separately.</i>; why is it mentioned separately? To tie to it: Prostration is special in that it is the act of a single person and is punishable separately, so I am adding any single act that one is liable for separately. Even though Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar said<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:10:2-11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.10.2-11">Halakhah 13</a>, 25c l. 18, the entire argument is attributed to R. Jehudah ben Tanhum.</i>, if one sacrificed, and burned incense, and poured a libation in one forgetting<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">If he was oblivious to the fact that worshipping other gods was forbidden, he only has to bring one purification sacrifice.</i> he is liable only for one; he agrees that if one worshipped it in its proper worship which is identical with the worship of Heaven like prostrating, he is liable for each single action<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">Applying any forms of worship of Heaven to any other purpose is sinful. Therefore, using it for pagan worship is not the same as accepting pagan rites of other forms.</i>. As Rebbi Samuel said in the name of Rebbi Zeˋira: <i>They should not continue to offer their sacrifices to spirits.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 17:7" href="/Leviticus.17.7"><i>Lev</i>. 17:7</a>.</i> They said to him, turn and refer it to sacrifices<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote">The paragraph forbids any sacrificial act outside the holy precinct. It is not applicable to the question at hand.</i>.
Rebbi Yasa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: If he sacrificed a defective lamb to it, he is guilty<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">It is forbidden to sacrifice defective animals to God (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:20" href="/Leviticus.22.20"><i>Lev</i>. 22:20</a>). Nevertheless, if regular pagan worship does not include animal sacrifices but a Jew chooses to sacrifice a defective animal to that idol, he is guilty of idolatry. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 51a" href="/Avodah_Zarah.51a">Babli, <i>Avodah zarah</i>51a</a>, quotes R. Abbahu in the name of R. Johanan in the opposite sense.</i>. From where this? As Rebbi Hila said, <i>do not do such to the Eternal, your God</i><sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 12:4" href="/Deuteronomy.12.4"><i>Deut</i>. 12:4</a>. The paragraph deals with the destruction of places of pagan worship. It is interpreted to mean that anything similar to Temple worship, even if executed in an unacceptable way, is forbidden as pagan worship. <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 81 follows the Yerushalmi: “Anything which cannot be sacrificed in the Temple but somebody sacrificed it as foreign worship, if its kind might be sacrificed to God he is guilty; otherwise he cannot be prosecuted.”</i>. Anything that you might do for the Eternal, your God, you may not do in this case.
Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya asked before Rebbi Zeˋira: <i>Do not worship them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 20:5" href="/Exodus.20.5"><i>Ex</i>. 20:5</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 5:9" href="/Deuteronomy.5.9"><i>Deut</i>. 5:9</a> the Second Commandment.</i>, a principle. <i>Do not prostrate yourself before them</i><sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 20:5" href="/Exodus.20.5"><i>Ex</i>. 20:5</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 5:9" href="/Deuteronomy.5.9"><i>Deut</i>. 5:9</a> the Second Commandment.</i>, a detail. <i>For you shall not prostrate yourself before another god</i><sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 34:14" href="/Exodus.34.14"><i>Ex</i>. 34:14</a>.</i>; He again stated the principle. Principle, detail, and principle: is nothing covered but the detail<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">Since in the Ten Commandments prostrating is mentioned before worshipping, the order really should be detail, principle, principle. Also, in our text of the <i>Introduction to Sifra</i>, “principle, detail, principle has to be judged in light of the detail,” adding anything similar to detail. The passage supports the thesis of Menahem Cahana [קוים לתולדות התפתחותה ספר זיכרון ,של מידת כלל ופרט בתקופת התנאים לתרצה ליפשיץ, Jerusalem 2005, pp. 173–216] that only the list of hermeneutical rules is original but the detailed interpretation of the rules is Babylonian (following R. Aqiba), never accepted in the Yerushalmi. The latter does not differentiate between כְּלָל וּפְרָט,פְּרָט וּכְלָל,כְּלָל וּפְרָט וּכְלָל, and in all cases reduces the validity of the principle to the case of the detail. The question naturally deserves no answer since it is not כְּלָל וּפְרָט וּכְלָל but פְּרָט וּכְלָל וּכְלָל, which is not the subject of any hermeneutical rule.</i>? Rebbi Abun bar Cahana asked before Rebbi Hila: <i>Do not do such</i><sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 12:4" href="/Deuteronomy.12.4"><i>Deut</i>. 12:4</a>. The paragraph deals with the destruction of places of pagan worship. It is interpreted to mean that anything similar to Temple worship, even if executed in an unacceptable way, is forbidden as pagan worship. <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 81 follows the Yerushalmi: “Anything which cannot be sacrificed in the Temple but somebody sacrificed it as foreign worship, if its kind might be sacrificed to God he is guilty; otherwise he cannot be prosecuted.”</i>, a principle. <i>One who sacrifices to gods shall be banned</i><sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:19" href="/Exodus.22.19"><i>Ex</i>. 22:19</a>.</i>, a detail. <i>Only for the Eternal alone</i><sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:19" href="/Exodus.22.19"><i>Ex</i>. 22:19</a>.</i>, He again stated the principle. Principle, detail, and principle; is not everything included<sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">This statement is not found elsewhere in talmudic texts. But in R. Aqiba’s system of additions (רֵבּוּי) and subtractions (מְעוּט), addition + subtraction + addition implies that almost everything corresponding to the broad description of the additions is included (Tosephta <i>Ševu`ot</i> 1:7, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Nazir 35b" href="/Nazir.35b">Babli <i>Nazir</i>35b</a>).</i>? Does it not add one who embraces and one who kisses<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 32:8" href="/Exodus.32.8"><i>Ex</i>. 32:8</a>, speaking of the Golden Calf.</i>? He told him, why is prostrating mentioned? Not to infer from it that it is an action? He who embraces and he who (prostrates himself)<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">It is clear that one has to read ומנשק “and kisses” instead of ומשתחוה “and prostrates himself”. Embracing and kissing are not acts of worship.</i> do not exemplify actions.
From where about him who says, “you are my god”<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">That it is a capital crime.</i>? Rav Abun in the name of the rabbis there<sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 32:8" href="/Exodus.32.8"><i>Ex</i>. 32:8</a>, speaking of the Golden Calf.</i>: <i>They prostrated themselves before it, and sacrificed to it, and said, these are your gods, Israel</i>. Then he should not be guilty unless he sacrifice, burn incense, and declare. Rebbi Yose said, the verse is written only for the disgrace of Israel. <i>They prostrated themselves before it</i>, not before Heaven. <i>And sacrificed to it</i>, not to Heaven. <i>And said</i>, not to Heaven. What about this<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">How does the verse imply that declaring one’s allegiance to another power constitutes a capital crime?</i>? <i>Saying</i> is mentioned here and <i>saying</i> is said about one who leads astray<sup class="footnote-marker">61,</sup><i class="footnote">The missionary for another faith who addresses individuals in private; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:11" href="/Deuteronomy.13.11"><i>Deut</i>. 13:11</a>, cf. Mishnah 16.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote">An example of הֶקֵּשׁ “trapping”, or בִּנְיַן אָב מִכָּתוּב אֶחָד, the third hermeneutical rule. Since in one case it is established that by talking alone one may commit a capital crime, in all other cases where talking is equated to actions constituting capital crimes, it is a capital crime in itself.</i>. Since for <i>saying</i> mentioned about one who leads astray, saying is equated with acting, also for the <i>saying</i> mentioned here, we have to equate saying with acting.
It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:3" href="/Deuteronomy.17.3"><i>Deut</i>. 17:3</a>. If not for R. Zeˋira’s interpretation, one would translate <i>or to the sun, or to the moon</i>.</i>: <i>He went and worshipped other powers and prostrated himself before them, and to the sun, and to the moon</i>. Rebbi Zeˋira said, it is not said <i>to the sun</i> but <i>and to the sun</i>. That is not principle and detail but addition<sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote">By the rule כְּלָל וּפְרָט וּכְלָל אֵין בִּכְלָל אֶלָּא מַה שֶׁבִּפְרָט “principle, detail, and principle: nothing is covered but the detail,” the verse seems to imply that only worship of sun or moon are capital crimes, not the worship of other gods (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:8:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.8.2">Note 213</a>). Since the detail is not standing alone but is connected to the general category by <i>and</i>, even R. Ismael will agree that the verse adds the worship of celestial bodies as bodies, rather than deities, to the definition of pagan worship.</i>. Rebbi Abba bar Zemina objected before Rebbi Ze`ura; is it not written <i>any which have fins and scales, and any which do not have fins and scales</i><sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 11:9" href="/Leviticus.11.9"><i>Lev</i>. 11:9</a>: <i>This you may eat from anything which is in the water: Any with fin and scale in the water</i>, in seas and rivers, <i>those you may eat</i>. On the face of it, the verse declares a principle of what may be eaten from the water, followed by a detail, from lakes (standing water) and rivers (flowing water).</i>? Then this is not principle and detail but additions since there is written <i>and</i><sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote">As explained later, the preceding argument would allow to eat seafood grown in barrels and aquariums, against the received rules, unless one accepts every <i>and</i>, even those needed by the rules of grammar, as additions. This may be R. Aqiba’s approach; it certainly is unacceptable for R. Ismael’s hermeneutical rules. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 66b" href="/Chullin.66b">Babli <i>Ḥulin</i>66b</a>.</i>? Rebbi Joḥanan bar Marius said, anywhere I am encountering <i>and</i>, I am deleting it<sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">This is essentially R. Ismael’s approach that “the Torah speaks human speech;” no word needed by the basic rules of grammar and syntax carries a hidden meaning.</i>. Rebbi Samuel ben Eudaimon said, I would have said that anything in the oceans is forbidden, what is in barrels and vivaria<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>vivarium</i> “game, fish preserve”.</i> should be permitted. The verse says, <i>and anything which lives in water</i>, an addition<sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote">Because of the introductory clause, the verse must be read as principle, principle, and detail; this does not fit the scheme of “principle and detail” but the wordiness must be interpreted as intended to cover all possible cases.<br>The verse as quoted does not exist; in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 11:9-10" href="/Leviticus.11.9-10"><i>Lev</i>. 11:9–10</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 14:9" href="/Deuteronomy.14.9"><i>Deut</i>. 14:9</a> one reads  מִכֹּ֖ל אֲשֶׁ֣ר בַּמָּ֑יִם, the partitive <i>mem</i> indicating that not everything living in the water can be eaten, but not referring to the varieties of water.</i>.
Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥmani in the name of Rebbi Hoshaia: If one says to it, you are my god, there is disagreement between Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote">This disagreement is not mentioned in any other source. It is possible that a name should be inserted here.</i> and the Sages. If he (prostrated himself)<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">It is clear that one has to read ומנשק “and kisses” instead of ומשתחוה “and prostrates himself”. Embracing and kissing are not acts of worship.</i>, what is the rule? Rebbi Joḥanan said, everybody agrees that if he lowered his body<sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote">This is prostrating which by the verse was defined as an idolatrous act.</i>, he is guilty. What is the difference between raising and lowering his body, and raising and lowering his lips<sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote">This is declaring the idol as one’s god, which also can be done by only moving body parts, the lips. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 65b" href="/Sanhedrin.65b">Babli, 65b</a>, R. Johanan extends his argument by criminalizing a person who prevents his ox from eating while threshing by shouting at it.</i>? Rebbi Joḥanan said, following disagreement<sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote">The nature of this disagreement cannot be determined. It is possible that R. Joḥanan by his argument implies that embracing and kissing idols are capital crimes.</i>. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, following the distinction<sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote">The distinction made in the Mishnah between idolatrous acts which are capital crimes and those which are simple transgressions.</i>. Rebbi Zeˋira said, a verse supports Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: <i>One rule should be for you, for the one</i> acting <i>in error</i><sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:29" href="/Numbers.15.29"><i>Num</i>. 15:29</a>; the reference to idolatrous acts is explained in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:9:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.9.2">Note 248</a>.</i>. This only refers to what represents an action. The one who embraces (and who prostrates himself)<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote">It is clear that one has to read ומנשק “and kisses” instead of ומשתחוה “and prostrates himself”. Embracing and kissing are not acts of worship.</i>, which are not action, from where<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore, embracing and kissing cannot be capital crimes since they do not fit the criterion for a purification sacrifice in case the act was unintentional.</i>?

Halakhah 10

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One who gives any of his descendants to the Moloch is only guilty if he delivers him to the Moloch and makes him pass through fire. If he delivered him to the Moloch but did not make him pass through fire, or made him pass though fire but did not deliver him to the Moloch, is only guilty if he delivers him to the Moloch and makes him pass through fire. The necromancer is the Πύθων<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">Πύθων, -ωνος, ὁ, “the serpent Python”, a spirit of divination. The plural πύθωνες “ventriloquists”.</i> and one who<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli and the independent Mishnah mss: the Πύθων who speaks from his armpit.</i> speaks from his armpit. The medium<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:27" href="/Leviticus.20.27"><i>Lev</i>. 20:27</a>. The necromancer is the person who raises the spirits of the dead; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 28" href="/I_Samuel.28"><i>1S</i>. 28</a>. The medium is one who incorporates a spirit which predicts the future, speaking from the medium’s body, not his mouth.</i> speaks through his mouth. These are stoned but one who consults them is forewarned.<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote">While turning to necromancers and fortune-tellers is repeatedly forbidden (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 19:31" href="/Leviticus.19.31"><i>Lev</i>. 19:31</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:10-11" href="/Deuteronomy.18.10-11"><i>Deut</i>. 18:10–11</a>), no punishment is spelled out in the biblical text.</i>
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “One who gives any of his descendants to the Moloch.” From where a warning not to give any of his descendants to the Moloch? <i>Do not give any of your descendants to the Moloch</i><sup class="footnote-marker">288</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:21" href="/Leviticus.18.21"><i>Lev</i>. 18:21</a>.</i>. Extirpation from where? <i>For he gave one of his descendants to the Moloch</i><sup class="footnote-marker">289</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:3" href="/Leviticus.20.3"><i>Lev</i>. 20:3</a></i><i>and shall be extirpated</i><sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote">A wrong quote from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:5" href="/Leviticus.20.5"><i>Lev</i>. 20:5</a>. It should read: <i>I shall extirpate him</i>.</i>. Punishment from where? <i>Each one of the Children of Israel, or of the sojourner in Israel, who would give any of his descendants to the Moloch shall be made to die; the people of the Land shall smash him with stones</i><sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:2" href="/Leviticus.20.2"><i>Lev</i>. 20:2</a>.</i>. <i>Do not give any of your descendants</i>, I could think that he was guilty if he handed over but did not make him pass<sup class="footnote-marker">292</sup><i class="footnote">In the interpretation of the Talmudim, the child was handed over to the Moloch priests and then made to pass or be carried between two fires. It is not assumed that the child was burned since that would be murder which in itself is a capital crime and would obviate the discussion of the exact conditions which make Moloch worship a capital crime. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 64b" href="/Sanhedrin.64b">Babli, 64b</a>, it is assumed that there is one fire in a ditch and the Moloch worship requires to jump, not to walk, over the fire. This interpretation also is possible for the Yerushalmi.<br>The paragraphs have a parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 64b" href="/Sanhedrin.64b">Babli, 64b</a>, partially with different attributions.</i>; the verse says: <i>Do not give any of your descendants to pass through</i>. I could think that he was guilty if he handed over and made him pass through but not for the Moloch; the verse says: <i>Do not give any of your descendants to pass through</i> for the Moloch<sup class="footnote-marker">293</sup><i class="footnote">Since passing through (or jumping over) fire is characteristic for Moloch worship and not part of worship of Heaven, doing this for any other deity is forbidden foreign worship, subject to divine extirpation, but not a prosecutable capital crime.</i>. I could think that he was guilty if he handed over and made him pass through for the Moloch but without fire; the verse says: <i>among you, nobody should be found to make his son or his daughter pass through fire</i><sup class="footnote-marker">294</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:10" href="/Deuteronomy.18.10"><i>Deut</i>. 18:10</a>. In the Moloch paragraphs in <i>Lev</i>., the nature of “passing through” is never spelled out; by the doctrine of invariability of lexemes it is only made definite in this quote. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Kedoshim" href="/Sifra,_Kedoshim"><i>Sifra Qedošim Parašah</i> 10(3</a>).</i>. Passing through, passing through as an equal cut<sup class="footnote-marker">295</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 3:9:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.3.9.5">3:10, Note 158</a>.</i>. Since “passing through” mentioned there is through fire, so “passing through” mentioned here also is through fire. You have to say that he is not guilty unless he handed over and made him pass through fire for the Moloch. Rebbi Nasa in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: He is guilty only if he hand him over to the priests, takes him, and makes him pass. What if he lets him walk normally? It was stated: one was drawing him and made him pass through. It was stated: if he made him walk through on his feet he is not prosecutable<sup class="footnote-marker">296</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 64b" href="/Sanhedrin.64b">Babli 64b</a>. In neither Talmud is it totally clear whether father or priests make the child pass through or over the fire.</i>. Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Simeon declares him guilty. Whether for the Moloch or for any other foreign worship; Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Simeon says, he is guilty only for the Moloch<sup class="footnote-marker">297</sup><i class="footnote">Babli 64a.</i>, he is guilty only for his descendants. Rebbi Joḥanan said, Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Simeon’s reason is from here: <i>It shall not be found in you</i><sup class="footnote-marker">298</sup><i class="footnote">The word בְּךָ in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:10" href="/Deuteronomy.18.10"><i>Deut</i>. 18:10</a> is read as <i>in you</i>; this is interpreted to describe one’s bodily issue, the children.</i>, from your body you should not be found making pass through. <i>I shall extirpate him … from among his people</i><sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote">A not quite correct quote from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:5" href="/Leviticus.20.5"><i>Lev</i>. 20:5</a>.</i>. To include all other foreign worship for extirpation<sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote">In the Moloch paragraph <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:1-5" href="/Leviticus.20.1-5"><i>Lev</i>. 20:1–5</a> extirpation is mentioned twice, in vv. 3 and 5. One refers to Moloch worship; the other then must refer to any other worship using fire. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Kedoshim" href="/Sifra,_Kedoshim"><i>Sifra Qedošim Parašah</i> 10(15</a>).</i>. From where punishment? <i>Of his descendants he gave to the Moloch</i><sup class="footnote-marker">289</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:3" href="/Leviticus.20.3"><i>Lev</i>. 20:3</a></i><i>, death he shall be made to die</i><sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:2" href="/Leviticus.20.2"><i>Lev</i>. 20:2</a>.</i>, if he made him pass through himself. Does he not pass through on his feet? Because he made him pass through himself, but if he was drawing him and made him pass through, he is guilty. What does Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Simeon mean, if he made him walk through on his feet he is not prosecutable? He has to make him pass through jumping.
Rebbi Abun bar Ḥiyya asked before Rebbi Zeˋira: If he handed over but did not make to pass through,<sup class="footnote-marker">301</sup><i class="footnote">At the start of the Halakhah it was noted that if somebody handed over his child to the Moloch priests but did not make him pass over the fire, he is not guilty under the Moloch paragraph. One has to read that to mean that the intent had been for a full Moloch ceremony but that for some reason it was not executed. Then the question here is, whether there is any guilt in handing over the child knowing that the ceremony cannot be performed.</i> is that the disagreement between Ḥizqiah and Rebbi Joḥanan? Fore they disagreed: If he slaughtered but did not sell, Ḥizqiah said he is liable, but Rebbi Joḥanan said, he is not liable<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">The thief of livestock who <i>slaughters</i> and <i>sells</i> stolen animals is liable to fourfold or fivefold restitution (Ex. 21 :37). The question arises whether stealing and slaughtering an animal which cannot be sold, e. g., one dedicated as a sacrifice but still in its owner's hand, triggers liability for quadruple or only double restitution. The problem is not mentioned elsewhere; a related one is in Ševuot 8:8. The comparison of civil and criminal law is unfounded; the question merits no answer.</i>.
Rebbi Abba bar Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan<sup class="footnote-marker">303</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 64a" href="/Sanhedrin.64a">Babli, 64a</a>, this is a tannaïtic statement attributed to R. Hanina ben Antigonos.</i>: Look at the expression which the Torah taught you, <i>Moloch</i>; anything that you make king over yourself, even a chip of wood, even a pebble<sup class="footnote-marker">304</sup><i class="footnote">Since the root <i>mlk</i> of “Moloch” means “to rule”.</i>. <i>I shall extirpate him from amidst his people</i>, to include all other foreign worship in extirpation<sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote">In the Moloch paragraph <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:1-5" href="/Leviticus.20.1-5"><i>Lev</i>. 20:1–5</a> extirpation is mentioned twice, in vv. 3 and 5. One refers to Moloch worship; the other then must refer to any other worship using fire. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Kedoshim" href="/Sifra,_Kedoshim"><i>Sifra Qedošim Parašah</i> 10(15</a>).</i>. Rebbi Nasa in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: to include all other foreign worship relating to sons and daughters, as it was stated: He is guilty whether for the Moloch or any other foreign worship, whether he worshipped them with sons and daughters, or worshipped them with fathers and mothers. Rebbi Zeˋira said: if its worship did not prescribe this; but if its worship did prescribe it, he is free from prosecution<sup class="footnote-marker">305</sup><i class="footnote">He holds that Moloch worship is defined by its rules, not by the name given to the deity being worshipped. Since R. Eleazar ben R. Simeon was quoted earlier that in Moloch worship one is guilty only for his descendants; if the rules of worship require descendants, the rules of Moloch worship apply. But if the Moloch rules are applied to the worship of a deity whose published rules do not include the Moloch rules, then it is an act of idolatry irrespective of the nature of the participants.</i>. Rebbi Hila said, even if its worship did prescribe it, he is twice guilty<sup class="footnote-marker">306</sup><i class="footnote">Once for idolatry and once for following the Moloch rules.</i>. A <i>baraita</i> supports Rebbi Hila: The Moloch was included in all other foreign worships; it is mentioned separately to be lenient in this regard that he be guilty only for his descendants<sup class="footnote-marker">307</sup><i class="footnote">The following paragraph shows that this <i>baraita</i> must be attributed to R. Simeon.</i>. Rebbi Tanḥum bar Jeremiah said, it follows that Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Simeon follows the argument of his father Rebbi Simeon. Just as Rebbi Simeon said, the Moloch was included in all other foreign worships; it is mentioned separately to be lenient in this regard that he be guilty only for his descendants, so Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Simeon said, the Moloch was included in all other foreign worships; it is mentioned separately to be lenient in this regard that he be guilty only for his descendants<sup class="footnote-marker">298</sup><i class="footnote">The word בְּךָ in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:10" href="/Deuteronomy.18.10"><i>Deut</i>. 18:10</a> is read as <i>in you</i>; this is interpreted to describe one’s bodily issue, the children.</i>.
Rebbi Tanḥum ben Yudan said, even though Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Simeon said<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:10:2-11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.10.2-11">Halakhah 13</a>, 25c l. 18, the entire argument is attributed to R. Jehudah ben Tanhum.</i>, if one sacrificed, and burned incense, and poured a libation in one forgetting<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">If he was oblivious to the fact that worshipping other gods was forbidden, he only has to bring one purification sacrifice.</i> he is liable only for one; he agrees that if one worshipped it in its proper worship which is identical to the worship of Heaven like prostrating, he is liable for each single action<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote">Applying any forms of worship of Heaven to any other purpose is sinful. Therefore, using it for pagan worship is not the same as accepting pagan rites of other forms.</i>. From where that if one sacrificed, and burned incense, and poured a libation in one forgetting he is liable only for one; he agrees that if one worshipped it in its proper worship which is identical with the worship of Heaven like prostrating, he is liable for each single action? As Rebbi Samuel said in the name of Rebbi Zeˋira: <i>They should not continue to offer their sacrifices to spirits</i><sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 17:7" href="/Leviticus.17.7"><i>Lev</i>. 17:7</a>.</i>. They said to him, turn and refer it to sacrifices.
Rebbi Yasa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: If he sacrificed a defective lamb to it, he is guilty<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">It is forbidden to sacrifice defective animals to God (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 22:20" href="/Leviticus.22.20"><i>Lev</i>. 22:20</a>). Nevertheless, if regular pagan worship does not include animal sacrifices but a Jew chooses to sacrifice a defective animal to that idol, he is guilty of idolatry. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Avodah Zarah 51a" href="/Avodah_Zarah.51a">Babli, <i>Avodah zarah</i>51a</a>, quotes R. Abbahu in the name of R. Johanan in the opposite sense.</i>. From where this? As Rebbi Hila said, <i>do not do such to the the Eternal, your God</i><sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 12:4" href="/Deuteronomy.12.4"><i>Deut</i>. 12:4</a>. The paragraph deals with the destruction of places of pagan worship. It is interpreted to mean that anything similar to Temple worship, even if executed in an unacceptable way, is forbidden as pagan worship. <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 81 follows the Yerushalmi: “Anything which cannot be sacrificed in the Temple but somebody sacrificed it as foreign worship, if its kind might be sacrificed to God he is guilty; otherwise he cannot be prosecuted.”</i>. Anything that be for the Eternal, your God, you may not do.
Rebbi Phineas said before Rebbi Yose in the name of Rav Ḥisda<sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote">The name tradition here is impossible. R. Phineas, student of the last generation Amora R. Yose who was R. Zeˋira’s student’s student, could not have been R. Zeˋira’s discussion partner and was an unlikely source for the statement of the second generation Rav Hisda.</i>: If its worship prescribed sons or daughters but he worshipped it with fathers or mothers, he is twice guilty. Rebbi Zeˋira enjoyed this; he thought that this was said following his teacher’s Rebbi Hila’s system and referred to Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Simeon. He told him, what do you have in your hand? It referred to the rabbis! He answered, did you need it for this<sup class="footnote-marker">309</sup><i class="footnote">Since the rabbis do not accept that the rules of the Moloch include any leniency, it is obvious that a person who worships any other deity by the Moloch ritual is guilty both of idolatry and of following the Moloch.</i>?
From where the warning about the necromancer? <i>Do not turn to the necromancers</i><sup class="footnote-marker">326</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 19:31" href="/Leviticus.19.31"><i>Lev</i>. 19:31</a>. Here starts the discussion of the second part of the Mishnah.</i>. From where extirpation? <i>A person who would turn to necromancers and mediums</i><sup class="footnote-marker">327</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:6" href="/Leviticus.20.6"><i>Lev</i>. 20:6</a>.</i>, etc. Punishment from where? <i>A man or woman, impersonating a necromancer or a medium, shall be put to death</i><sup class="footnote-marker">328</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:27" href="/Leviticus.20.27"><i>Lev</i>. 20:27</a>.</i>. Why is the medium not mentioned in <i>Keritut</i><sup class="footnote-marker">329</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Keritot 1:1" href="/Mishnah_Keritot.1.1">Mishnah <i>Keritut</i> 1:1</a> mentions only the necromancer, not the medium.</i>? Rebbi Ḥizqiah in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: Because they are taken together in one prohibition, <i>do not turn to the necromancers</i><sup class="footnote-marker">330</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>all</i> pentateuchal verses mentioning אוֹב it is paired with יִדְּעוֹנִי (the verses quoted plus <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:11" href="/Deuteronomy.18.11"><i>Deut</i>. 18:11</a>). <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 65b" href="/Sanhedrin.65b">Babli 65b</a>.</i>, etc. Rebbi Yasa in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: Because it is a prohibition implied by a positive commandment<sup class="footnote-marker">331</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 5:3:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.5.3.4">5:3, Note 73</a>. This formulation does not make any sense, as indicated by R. Zeˋira’s question. It should have been formulated: Because the medium is treated as an appendix to the necromancer. The medium never creates an obligation for a purification offering if one for necromancy already was established; he cannot be mentioned in <i>Keritut</i>_1:1 separately from the necromancer.</i>. Rebbi Zeˋira said before Rebbi Yasa: No person except you thought of stating the medium in this way in <i>Keritut</i>. He told him, because as the verse formulated it so the Mishnah formulates it, <i>a necromancer or a medium</i><sup class="footnote-marker">330</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>all</i> pentateuchal verses mentioning אוֹב it is paired with יִדְּעוֹנִי (the verses quoted plus <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:11" href="/Deuteronomy.18.11"><i>Deut</i>. 18:11</a>). <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 65b" href="/Sanhedrin.65b">Babli 65b</a>.</i>.
“The necromancer is the πύθων<sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote">Πύθων, -ωνος, ὁ, “the serpent Python”, a spirit of divination. The plural πύθωνες “ventriloquists”.</i> and one who<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli and the independent Mishnah mss: the Πύθων who speaks from his armpit.</i> speaks from his armpit. The medium<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:27" href="/Leviticus.20.27"><i>Lev</i>. 20:27</a>. The necromancer is the person who raises the spirits of the dead; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 28" href="/I_Samuel.28"><i>1S</i>. 28</a>. The medium is one who incorporates a spirit which predicts the future, speaking from the medium’s body, not his mouth.</i> speaks through his mouth. These are stoned but one who consults them is forewarned<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote">While turning to necromancers and fortune-tellers is repeatedly forbidden (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 19:31" href="/Leviticus.19.31"><i>Lev</i>. 19:31</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:10-11" href="/Deuteronomy.18.10-11"><i>Deut</i>. 18:10–11</a>), no punishment is spelled out in the biblical text.</i>. <i>And one who asks the dead</i><sup class="footnote-marker">332</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:11" href="/Deuteronomy.18.11"><i>Deut</i>. 18:11</a>. No criminal sanction is spelled out for this.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">333</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 10:3" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.10.3">Tosephta 10:7</a>, explaining the term “interrogating the dead”. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 65b" href="/Sanhedrin.65b">Babli, 65b</a>, the same <i>baraita</i> explains the term “necromancer”.</i> Some Tannaïm state: this is one who interrogates a skull. Some Tannaïm state: this is one who interrogates his<sup class="footnote-marker">334,</sup><i class="footnote">The dead.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">173</sup><i class="footnote">The form זְכוּר denotes, if not the penis, then the male as appendix to his sex organ.</i> masculinity. What is the difference between one interrogated by his skull or one raised by his masculinity? The one interrogated by his skull rises normally, rises on the Sabbath, and a commoner can raise a king. But one raised by his masculinity does not rise normally<sup class="footnote-marker">335</sup><i class="footnote">The dead appears feet up, head down.</i>, does not rise on the Sabbath, and a commoner cannot raise a king.
Rebbi Huna said, a verse supports him who said, the necromancer is the one who raises by his masculinity. What is the reason? <i>Please apply necromancer’s magic and raise for me whom I shall tell you</i><sup class="footnote-marker">336</sup><i class="footnote"><i>IS</i>.28:8.</i>. What do you understand from here? Rebbi Mana said, it implies that she was competent in many ways<sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote">Since Saul had to request a particular method, the woman must have been competent in all sorts of sorcery. She realized that her customer was Saul because she recognized Samuel whose status was that of a king.</i>. What about it? <i>Your voice will be from the earth like that of a necromancer</i><sup class="footnote-marker">338</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 29:4" href="/Isaiah.29.4"><i>Is</i>. 29:4</a>.</i>.
The words of the rabbis support Rebbi Yasa, as Rebbi Yasa said in the rabbis’ name: Because they burn incense to spirits<sup class="footnote-marker">339</sup><i class="footnote">This returns to the statement of R. Yasa in the first paragraph here. The user of necromancy is a potential candidate for a purification offering since it depends on an action, <i>viz</i>., burning incense to spirits. But a medium who is totally passive does not qualify.</i>. Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Yasa: Because they all were included by actions<sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote">A different formulation of the argument of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:10:11" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.10.11">Note 339</a>; all transgressions mentioned in <i>Keritut</i> 1:1 involve some action.</i>.

Halakhah 11

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One who desecrates the Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">59,</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:36" href="/Numbers.15.36"><i>Num</i>. 15:36</a>.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">341</sup><i class="footnote">If duly warned by two witnesses about the criminality of his intent, he can be prosecuted if in the absence of witnesses he would be subject to Divine extirpation. But if he violates any of the positive commandments for the Sabbath he cannot be prosecuted by biblical standards; for violating a simple prohibition he at most could be sentenced to 39 lashes.</i> by something which if performed intentionally makes him liable to extirpation, or to a purification sacrifice if in error. But he who curses father or mother<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:9" href="/Leviticus.20.9"><i>Lev</i>. 20:9</a>.</i> is guilty only of he cursed them by the Name<sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">The Tetragrammaton in its original pronunciation, now lost.</i>. If he cursed them by a substitute name, Rebbi Meïr declares him guilty but the Sages free him from prosecution.<br>One who has sexual relations with a preliminarily married adolescent<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">It is not mentioned anywhere in biblical literature as a recognized form of execution. The Babli’s discussion, 52b, is inconclusive.</i> is only liable if she was an adolescent, a virgin, and preliminarily married, in her father’s house. If two [men] had relations with her, the first one is stoned, the second is subject to strangling<sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote">As a common adulterer.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “One who desecrates the Sabbath,” etc. From where warning for the desecrator? <i>Do not perform any work</i><sup class="footnote-marker">343</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 20:10" href="/Exodus.20.10"><i>Ex</i>. 20:10</a>.</i>. From where extirpation? <i>For any who would perform work on it would be extirpated</i><sup class="footnote-marker">344</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 31:14" href="/Exodus.31.14"><i>Ex</i>. 31:14</a>.</i>. From where punishment? <i>Its desecrator shall be made to die the death</i>. Should we not state 37 kinds of extirpation in the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">345</sup><i class="footnote">This is a copy from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.9">Halakhah 9, Note 149</a>. The question should be that in <i>Keritut</i>1:1 74 kinds of extirpation should be mentioned since, as R. Yose ben Abun explains, each one of the 39 categories of work forbidden on the Sabbath defines its own obligation for a purification sacrifice if the person was aware that it was Sabbath and that he was performing this kind of work, and only had forgotten that it was forbidden. Then a single person could be obligated for up to 39 sacrifices for desecrating a single Sabbath. But if he simply had forgotten that it was Sabbath, a single sacrifice is due and this is what is counted in <i>Keritut</i>.</i>? Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, because if he performs all of them, intentionally on the Sabbath and intentionally for the work, he is liable for each one singly.
From where a warning for the one who curses father or mother? <i>Everybody has to fear his mother and father</i><sup class="footnote-marker">346</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 19:3" href="/Leviticus.19.3"><i>Lev</i>. 19:3</a>.</i>. From where punishment and extirpation? <i>And he who curses his father or mother shall be made to die the death</i><sup class="footnote-marker">347</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:17" href="/Exodus.21.17"><i>Ex</i>. 21:17</a>.</i>. And it says, <i>for anybody who would commit any of these abominations will be extirpated</i><sup class="footnote-marker">349,</sup><i class="footnote">This text is also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:9:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.9.2-4"><i>Ketubot</i> 3:9</a>, explained there with a list of readings in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:6:1-7:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.6.1-7.5">Notes 126–135</a>. The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 66b" href="/Sanhedrin.66b">Babli is 66b</a>.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:29" href="/Leviticus.18.29"><i>Lev</i>. 18:29</a>.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">349</sup><i class="footnote">This text is also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:9:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.9.2-4"><i>Ketubot</i> 3:9</a>, explained there with a list of readings in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:6:1-7:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.6.1-7.5">Notes 126–135</a>. The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 66b" href="/Sanhedrin.66b">Babli is 66b</a>.</i>“One who has sexual relations with a preliminarily married maiden.” Rebbi Yasa in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan, Rebbi Ḥiyya in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: This is Rebbi Meïr’s. But for the rabbis even if she is a minor. What is Rebbi Meïr’s reason? “<i>Lad</i>” is written defectively in the paragraph. How do the rabbis explain “<i>a lad</i>”? Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: Once in the paragraph it is written <i>a young woman</i>; this teaches that in the entire paragraph she is an adult. Rebbi Meïr objected to the rabbis: In the matter of the calumniator, <i>a lad</i> is written and she is an adult since a minor is not stoned? What do the rabbis do with this? Rebbi Abin said, explain it that he came to her as a male. Rebbi Jacob bar Abba asked before Rav: What is the law of him who comes to a minor? He said to him, by stoning. What is the law of him who comes to an adult? He said to him, I am reading <i>an adolescent</i>, not an adult. Read <i>an adolescent</i>, not a minor! Do you not agree with me that she has the right to a fine? He answered, <i>because he mistreated her</i>, that includes a minor for a fine. Read <i>because he mistreated her</i>, that includes an adult for a fine! Rav said, even though Rebbi Jacob bar Abba won the logical argument, practice is that he who comes to a minor is [punished] by stoning but she is free. Rebbi Abun in the name of (Rebbi)<sup class="footnote-marker">350</sup><i class="footnote">It is clear from <i>Ketubot</i> and the Babli that the speaker is Samuel, Rav’s contemporary, and not the later Galilean R. Samuel. <i>Sifry Deut</i> 243 disagrees with Samuels’ argument.</i> Samuel. Why? He understood it from the following: <i>The man who had lain with her alone shall die</i>. Do we not know that the girl has not committed a capital crime? Why does the verse say, <i>do not do anything to the girl; the girl has not committed a capital crime</i>? That includes him who has sexual relations with a [preliminarily married] underage girl; he is stoned and she is free.

Halakhah 12

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The one who leads astray<sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">The one who leads astray (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:9:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.9.6">Note 61</a>) presents a problem for law enforcement since a single listener cannot appear in court as a witness. In the Babli, the seducer (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.5.1">Note 62</a>) is one who openly propagates another faith, who is easily prosecuted. But in the Yerushalmi the difference between <i>him who leads astray</i> and the <i>seducer</i> is that the former speaks Hebrew while the latter speaks in the vernacular.</i> is a commoner who leads a commoner astray, by saying to him: There is something to worship at place X; it eats such and such, drinks such and such; it gives such and such benefits, can do such and such evil. For no capital crime in the Torah may one use entrapment<sup class="footnote-marker">352</sup><i class="footnote">By the prosecution, as spelled out in Mishnah 17.</i>, except for this one. If he said it to two persons, they become his witnesses, bring him to court, and stone him.<br>If he said this to a single person, he should tell him, I have friends who also want this<sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote">In order to have him speak before two witnesses.</i>. If he was sly<sup class="footnote-marker">354</sup><i class="footnote">He knows that if he only speaks to a single listener, he may with impunity try to convert a thousand people since no two of them can testify to the same occurrence and, therefore, cannot appear as witnesses in court.</i> and did not talk in their presence, one sets a trap behind a wall<sup class="footnote-marker">355</sup><i class="footnote">A rural wall of stones without mortar.</i>; he tells him, repeat what you told me alone; then he tells him, how can we abandon our God in Heaven and worship wood and stones<sup class="footnote-marker">356</sup><i class="footnote">This is the required warning, <i>viz</i>., that apostasy is a crime.</i>? If he repents, it is good<sup class="footnote-marker">357</sup><i class="footnote">Then he cannot be prosecuted since what he said was before he was duly warned, which is not prosecutable in court.</i>; if he says, it is our duty, or so it is good for us, those who stand behind the wall bring him to court and stone him.<br>He says, I shall worship, I shall go and worship, let us go and worship; I shall sacrifice, I shall go and sacrifice, let us go and sacrifice; I shall burn incense, I shall go and burn incense, let us go and burn incense; I shall pour libations, I shall go and pour libations, let us go and pour libations; I shall prostrate myself, I shall go and prostrate myself, let us go and prostrate ourselves. The seducer<sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">The one who leads astray (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:9:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.9.6">Note 61</a>) presents a problem for law enforcement since a single listener cannot appear in court as a witness. In the Babli, the seducer (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.5.1">Note 62</a>) is one who openly propagates another faith, who is easily prosecuted. But in the Yerushalmi the difference between <i>him who leads astray</i> and the <i>seducer</i> is that the former speaks Hebrew while the latter speaks in the vernacular.</i> is one who says, let us go and profess a strange worship.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The one who leads astray is a commoner,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">358</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel text is in <i>Yebamot</i> 16:6 (י) Notes 125–132. The text there is the original, since only there the question “and here, you say so?” and the answer to it make sense.</i> Therefore, not a Sage? Since he seduces, he is not a Sage. Since he is seduced, he is not a Sage. What does one do to outwit him? One hides two witnesses in an inner room and puts him into the outer room, lights a candle near him so they can see him and hear his voice. That is what they did to Ben Sateda in Lydda, where they hid two Sages, brought him to court, and stoned him. And here, you say so? It is different because he said, “I am”. Here also, “I am”? That he should not get wise to it. And what if he got wise to it? That he should not go away, and continue to seduce himself and others with him.
The one who leads astray says it aloud, the seducer speaks in a low voice. One who leads astray who spoke in a low voice becomes a seducer; a seducer who spoke in a low voice becomes one who leads astray. The one who leads astray speaks in Hebrew, the seducer speaks in a vernacular. One who leads astray who spoke in a vernacular becomes a seducer; a seducer who spoke in Hebrew becomes one who leads astray<sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">The one who leads astray (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:9:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.9.6">Note 61</a>) presents a problem for law enforcement since a single listener cannot appear in court as a witness. In the Babli, the seducer (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.5.1">Note 62</a>) is one who openly propagates another faith, who is easily prosecuted. But in the Yerushalmi the difference between <i>him who leads astray</i> and the <i>seducer</i> is that the former speaks Hebrew while the latter speaks in the vernacular.</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">359</sup><i class="footnote">Since one who leads astray and the seducer are two different biblical categories, a missionary for paganism cannot be condemned if the paragraph under which he is condemned is not determined.</i>.

Halakhah 13

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The sorcerer is one who does a deed<sup class="footnote-marker">360</sup><i class="footnote">To convict somebody of sorcery, to be punished by stoning (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.5.1">Mishnah 5</a>), the witnesses have to prove that he created something contradicting the laws of nature; at the end of the Halakhah this seems to be restricted to the creation of a parentless living creature.</i> but not one who creates an illusion<sup class="footnote-marker">361</sup><i class="footnote">In this matter, visual impressions do not count.</i>. Rebbi Aqiba says in the name of Rebbi Joshua: Two are collecting green melons<sup class="footnote-marker">362</sup><i class="footnote">In modern Hebrew “zucchini”; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kilayim 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kilayim.1.2.1"><i>Kilaim</i> Chapter 1, Note 38</a>.</i>; one who collected cannot be prosecuted, the other one is guilty. The who does a deed is guilty; he who creates an illusion cannot be prosecuted.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The sorcerer is one who does a deed,” etc. <i>A sorceress you shall not let live</i><sup class="footnote-marker">363</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:17" href="/Exodus.22.17"><i>Ex</i>. 22:17</a>.</i>, whether man or woman, but the Torah taught you the way of the world that most women have a tendency to sorcery<sup class="footnote-marker">364</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 67a" href="/Sanhedrin.67a">Babli 67a</a> and <i>Mekhilta dR. Simeon ben Iohai, ad loc</i>., the first part only in <i>Mekhilta dR. Ismael, ad loc</i>.</i>. Rebbi Eliezer said, a sorcerer is [executed] by stoning. What is Rebbi Eliezer’s reason? It says here, <i>a sorceress you shall not let live</i>, and it says there, <i>whether human or animal they shall not live</i><sup class="footnote-marker">365</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 19:13" href="/Exodus.19.13"><i>Ex</i>. 19:13</a>. The verse requires <i>stoning or shooting</i> the transgressor.<br>In the Babylonian sources (Babli and the two <i>Mekhiltot</i>), this argument is attributed to R. Aqiba, who in the Yerushalmi rejects it.</i>. Since <i>shall not live</i> there means by stoning, also here by stoning. What is the rabbis’<sup class="footnote-marker">366</sup><i class="footnote">There “rabbis” oppose the Mishnah and decree beheading for the sorcerer; in Babli and <i>Mekhilta dR. Simeon ben Iohai</i> the author is R. Yose the Galilean, in <i>Mekhilta dR. Ismael</i> it is R. Ismael.</i> reason? It says here, <i>a sorceress you shall not let live</i>, and it says there, <i>you shall not let live anybody</i><sup class="footnote-marker">367</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 20:16" href="/Deuteronomy.20.16"><i>Deut</i>. 20:16</a>.</i>. Since <i>you shall not let live</i> there means death by the sword, also <i>you shall not let live</i> here means death by the sword. Rebbi Aqiba said, from this argument I am deciding. It is preferable to learn <i>you shall not let live</i> from <i>you shall not let live</i> rather than from <i>shall not live</i>. What is Rebbi Jehudah’s reason<sup class="footnote-marker">368</sup><i class="footnote">The student of R. Eliezer’s student gives the final argument for the Mishnah. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 21b" href="/Berakhot.21b">Babli (here and <i>Berakhot</i> 21b</a>) and <i>Mekhilta dR. Simeon ben Iohai</i> his argument is attributed to Ben Azzai, in <i>Mekhilta dR. Ismael</i> to R. Yose the Galilean.</i>? It says here, <i>a sorceress you shall not let live</i>, and it says there, <i>anybody lying with an animal shall die the death</i><sup class="footnote-marker">369</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:18" href="/Exodus.22.18"><i>Ex</i>. 22:18</a>, the verse following the one about the sorceress. Since in v. 17 the method of execution is not indicated, the instruction of v. 18 is interpreted in the light of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:15-16" href="/Leviticus.20.15-16"><i>Lev</i>. 20:15–16</a> and applied to both verses.</i>. Since the execution of the animal is by stoning, so here also by stoning<sup class="footnote-marker">370</sup><i class="footnote">Since for animals the only explicitly mentioned example of execution is the stoning of the notorious bull.</i>.
Example. Rebbi Eliezer, Rebbi Joshua, and Rebbi Aqiba went to bathe at the public baths<sup class="footnote-marker">371</sup><i class="footnote">δημόσια (<i>scil</i>., βαλανεῖα).</i> of Tiberias. A Minean<sup class="footnote-marker">372</sup><i class="footnote">A Jewish heretic; a name frequently but not exclusively applied to Jewish Christians.</i> saw them, said what he said, and the cupola caught them<sup class="footnote-marker">373</sup><i class="footnote">They were put under a spell so they could not leave the space under the cupola of the main room of the thermal baths.</i>. Rebbi Eliezer said to Rebbi Joshua:<sup class="footnote-marker">374</sup><i class="footnote">In the rules of witchcraft all Sages of his generation were students of R. Eliezer, as told at the end of the Halakhah.</i> Joshua ben Ḥanania, look what you can do. When this Minean was leaving, Rebbi Joshua said what he said and the door trapped him. Anybody who entered hit him with his fist, anybody leaving hit him when forcing the door open. He told them, undo what you did; they told him, you undo, then we shall undo. They mutually undid. When they left, Rebbi Joshua said to this Minean, is that all you are wise to? He answered, let us go down to the sea. When they had descended to the sea, this Minean said what he said and the sea was split. He told them, is that not what your teacher Moses did to the sea? They answered, do you not agree that our teacher Moses walked through it? He said to them, yes. They told him, enter it. He entered it. Rebbi Joshua commanded the prince of the sea<sup class="footnote-marker">375</sup><i class="footnote">The angel running the Sea of Genezareth. The idea of angels running natural phenomena is a Jewish adaptation of the Greek myth of gods of the sea and nymphs of sources.</i> who swallowed him.
Example. Rebbi Eliezer, and Rebbi Joshua, and Rabban Gamliel travelled to Rome. They came to a place where they found children making stone heaps and saying as follows: What they do in the Land of Israel is to say, this is heave, this is tithe. They said, it is clear that Jews live here. They entered a place and were received at a house. They sat down to eat. It happened that no dish was brought to them unless it was brought [first] to a certain bedroom<sup class="footnote-marker">377</sup><i class="footnote">Greek κοιτών.</i>. They became afraid that perhaps they were eating offerings to the dead<sup class="footnote-marker">378</sup><i class="footnote">Since it is not usual to eat in a bedroom, they were afraid that the food was first offered to a corpse in a pagan ceremony which would make the food forbidden to them.</i>. They asked him, why is it that you bring no dish before us unless you brought it first to that bedroom? He told them, I have an old father who vowed not to leave that bedroom until he might see the Sages of Israel. They told him, go and tell him to come out because they are here. He came out; they asked him, what is your problem? He told them, pray for my son because he is sterile. Rebbi Eliezer said to Rebbi Joshua:<sup class="footnote-marker">374</sup><i class="footnote">In the rules of witchcraft all Sages of his generation were students of R. Eliezer, as told at the end of the Halakhah.</i> Joshua ben Ḥanania, look what you can do. He told them, bring me linseed; they brought him linseed. It appeared to them as if he was sowing it on a table<sup class="footnote-marker">379</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>tabula</i>.</i>. It appeared as if he was watering it; it appeared to grow; it appeared that he was plucking out of it, until there appeared a woman with braided hair. He told her, undo what you did. She answered, I shall not undo. He told her, then I shall make you known. She said, I cannot, because they<sup class="footnote-marker">380</sup><i class="footnote">The charms used for the spell put on the son to make him sterile.</i> were thrown into the sea. Rebbi Joshua commanded the prince of the sea<sup class="footnote-marker">375</sup><i class="footnote">The angel running the Sea of Genezareth.
