The idea of angels running natural phenomena is a Jewish adaptation of the Greek myth of gods of the sea and nymphs of sources.</i> who disgorged them. Then they prayed for him and he had the merit of raising Rebbi Jehudah ben Bathyra<sup class="footnote-marker">381</sup><i class="footnote">The family Ben Bathyra is placed in both Talmudim (cf. <i>Berakhot</i> 3:4 Note 391) at Nisibis in Kurdistan, not on the road from Palestine to Rome. The source of the stories, characterized as non-legal texts by their Aramaic language, is a problem because it mixes Palestinian חמי “to see” with the Babylonian meaning “to decree” of the root גזר instead of Galilean “to decide”.</i>. They said, if we came here only to bring the just person to the world, it would have been enough.
Rebbi Joshua ben Hanania said: I am able to take gourds and watermelons and turn them into rams and deer who would produce rams and deer. Rebbi Yannai said, I was walking on a road in Sepphoris when I saw a Minean<sup class="footnote-marker">372</sup><i class="footnote">A Jewish heretic; a name frequently but not exclusively applied to Jewish Christians.</i> taking a pebble, throwing it into the air, after which it came down transforming itself into a calf. But did not Rebbi Eleazar say in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Zimra: If all people of the world came together, they could not create one mosquito and bring it to life<sup class="footnote-marker">382</sup><i class="footnote">Since the objection is not raised against R. Joshua, plants are recognized as living things parallel to animals. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 67b" href="/Sanhedrin.67b">Babli 67b</a>.</i>. Let us say that this Minean did not take a pebble, threw it into the air, after which it came down transforming itself into a calf, but he called on his genie<sup class="footnote-marker">383</sup><i class="footnote">Both vocalization and translation are tentative.</i> who stole a calf for him from a cattle barn and brought it to him.
Rebbi Ḥinena ben Ḥanania said: I was promenading at Gufta<sup class="footnote-marker">384</sup><i class="footnote">An unidentified suburb of Sepphoris; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kilayim 9:3:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kilayim.9.3.5"><i>Kilaim</i> 9:4 Note 85</a>.</i> of Sepphoris when I saw a Minean taking a skull, throwing it into the air, after which it came down transforming itself into a calf. I went and told it to my father. He said, if you ate from it, it was an action; otherwise it was an illusion.
Rebbi Joshua ben Ḥanania said: Rebbi Eliezer used to explain 300 chapters in the matter of the sorceress, but from all of them I understood only two things: “Two are collecting green melons<sup class="footnote-marker">362</sup><i class="footnote">In modern Hebrew “zucchini”; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kilayim 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kilayim.1.2.1"><i>Kilaim</i> Chapter 1, Note 38</a>.</i>; one who collected cannot be prosecuted, the other one is guilty. He who does a deed is guilty; he who creates an illusion cannot be prosecuted.” Rebbi Darosa said, there were 900 chapters. 300 where one is guilty, 300 where one is free<sup class="footnote-marker">385</sup><i class="footnote">Creating the illusion of witchcraft is not forbidden.</i>, and 300 where one is guilty but cannot be prosecuted.<sup class="footnote-marker">386</sup><i class="footnote">Forbidden action which nevertheless cannot lead to prosecution. A similar situation exists for Sabbath prohibitions where only a small part of Sabbath violations are of the kind that could be prosecuted in court. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 68a" href="/Sanhedrin.68a">Babli 68a</a>.</i>

Chapter 8



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The deviant and rebellious son<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Who has to be stoned according to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.5.1">Mishnah 7:5</a>.</i>. When can one become a deviant and rebellious son? From the moment he grows two [pubic] hairs to when he sports a beard, the lower, not the upper<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote">If the pubic area is fully covered by hair.</i>, because the Sages used clean language<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">To avoid mentioning genitals.</i>. For it is written: <i>If a man have a [deviant and rebellious] son</i><sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:18" href="/Deuteronomy.21.18"><i>Deut.</i>21:18</a>.</i>. A son but not a daughter, a son but not a father<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">From the moment that a son is sexually mature, he can no longer be tried as deviant and rebellious son.</i>. The underage [son] is not liable since he does not have any obligation<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">An underage child never has any obligation; his parents have the duty to educate him.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The deviant and rebellious son,” etc. Rebbi Zeˋira, Rebbi Abbahu, Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish. It is written: <i>If a man would concoct against his neighbor to kill him slyly</i><sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:14" href="/Exodus.21.14"><i>Ex</i>. 21:14</a>. The argument is an almost untranslatable pun, identifying the two meanings of the root זוד “to plot, to be mischievous” and “to cook” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 69a" href="/Sanhedrin.69a">Babli 69a</a>). (Gesenius-Buhl also notes the two meanings for the root; modern Jewish lexicographers following Ben Jehudah prefer to derive the <i>hapax</i> “to cook” from a root נזד.)</i>. When does he become a man? When he concocts. When is he done cooking? When his <i>palm</i><sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Palm</i> as anatomic detail denotes the <i>mons veneris</i> of a woman (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 1:2:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.1.2.7"><i>Yebamot</i> 1:2, Note 143</a>); it is used here for the corresponding pubic area of the man.</i> expands. A simile: If the seed is fully cooked inside, the pot becomes black on the outside. Rebbi Zeˋira said that Rebbi Shila bar Bina stated: <i>If a man have a son</i>, not that the son be a father. From the moment that he may come to a woman and make her pregnant, he is a potential father, not a son<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">While it is accepted that from the age of 9 years a male may be able to have full intercourse with a woman (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 3:10:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.3.10.2"><i>Yebamot</i> 3:10 Note 143</a>), he cannot be held responsible for his actions before he reaches age 13. Therefore, he can be a responsible father only at age 13. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 68b" href="/Sanhedrin.68b">Babli (68b</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 69b" href="/Sanhedrin.69b">69b</a>) and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 10:7:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.10.7.8">Yerushalmi (<i>Yebamot</i> 10:14, Notes 209–211</a>; copied <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:2:2-33" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.2.2-33"><i>Qiddušin</i> 1:2</a> 59c l. 26, p. 73) recognize the fact that an underage male may become a father. The son born to an underage father can never become <i>deviant and rebellious</i> since he is not the son of a <i>man</i> as required by the verse.</i>. But the Torah said, a son, not a father. It parallels what Rebbi Yasa said in the name of Rebbi Sabbatai: The entire period of a “deviant and rebellious son” is only six months<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Since everywhere in talmudic literature the period between onset of female puberty and full feminine development is taken to be six months, the same is asserted here for the male. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 69a" href="/Sanhedrin.69a">Babli, 69a</a>, R. Sabbatai determines this period as three months.</i>.
Rebbi Yasa said, all these rules would be reasonable if they were the opposite. It was stated: You should know that this is the case. Who according to reason should be guilty, son or daughter? One would say, a daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">Who in her youth has to be obedient to her parents and later in life to her husband.</i>. But the Torah freed the daughter and declared the son guilty<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">As stated in the Mishnah.</i>. Who according to reason should be guilty, the younger or the older? One would say, the older. But the Torah freed the older and declared the younger guilty<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">As stated in the Mishnah.</i>. Who according to reason should be guilty, one who steals from others or one who steals from father or mother? One would say, one who steals from others. But the Torah freed the one who steals from others and declared the one who steals from father or mother guilty<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 8:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.8.5.1">Mishnah 5</a>.</i>. To teach that all of these [rules] are only the King’s decisions<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Even though this seems to contradict <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 8:7:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.8.7.2-3">Halakhah 7</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> When is he guilty? From the moment he eats a fourfold<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Greek τετραμοιρία “fourfold portion”, cf. H. and E. Guggenheimer, תרטימר בשר Sinai 83(1978) p. 191. A <i>baraita</i> in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 86b" href="/Pesachim.86b">Babli (<i>Pesahim</i> 86b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Beitzah 25b" href="/Beitzah.25b"><i>Besah</i>25b</a>) states that a civilized person drinks a cup of wine (a quarter <i>log</i>, about 130 cm<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup>) in two sips. One becomes deviant in drinking half a <i>log</i> in one gulp; this is the fourfold amount of a civilized person. The “fourfold amount” of meat is defined in the Halakhah (and the Babli) as half a Roman pound. Therefore, a civilized person will eat meat in portions no larger than 1½ Roman oz. per bite. The amount mentioned in the Mishnah refers to a single bite or sip, not the total amounts consumed during a meal (Maimonides <i>Mamrim</i> 7:2).<br>The form טרטימר instead of טטרמור is not unusual since Greek words copied into Aramaic or Hebrew often exhibit metathesis if one of the consonants λμνρ is involved [H. and E. Guggenheimer, למילון התלמודי יב <i>Lešonenu</i> 39(1975) 59–60.]</i> portion of meat and drinks half a <i>log</i> of wine. Rebbi Yose says, a <i>mina</i> of meat<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">A Greek <i>mina</i> of 100 drachmas, not a Semitic <i>maneh</i> of 60 šeqels (between 120 and 240 drachmas), cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 8:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.8.2.2">Note 20</a>.</i> and a <i>log</i> of wine. If he ate in a company of obligation<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">In modern Hebrew this is called סְעוּדַת מִצְוָה “a meal of obligation”, the festive meal at religious occasions such as weddings, circumcisions, redemption of firstborns, etc.</i>, or at the lengthening of a month<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Before the publication of the calendar computations the Synhedrion, and its successor, the Academy of Tiberias, had to determine for every month whether it should have 29 or 30 days. This meeting always was the occasion of a festive meal.</i>, or ate Second Tithe in Jerusalem, or ate torn or carcass meat, abominations and crawling things, i. e., if he ate anything which either is an obligation or anything forbidden, or ate any food but not meat, or drank any drink but not wine, he does not turn into a deviant and rebellious son unless he ate meat and drank wine, since it is said: <i>gorging and drinking to excess</i><sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:18" href="/Deuteronomy.21.18"><i>Deut.</i>21:18</a>.</i>. Even if it is not proof, there is a hint in what is said: <i>Do not be among those who drink wine excessively, nor with those who are gorging themselves on meat</i><sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 23:20" href="/Proverbs.23.20"><i>Prov</i>. 23:20</a>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “When is he guilty,” etc. Rebbi Yose said<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote">The Amora R. Yose determines the amount required by the Sages as half that indicated by the Tanna R. Yose, a statement ascribed in the Babli to his teacher’s teacher R. Zeˋira. His statement implies that, as a weight, a mina (100 drachmas) was identified with the pound of 12 ounces, i. e. 96 denars. Since other talmudic data indicate that as a coin, <i>drachma</i> in the Eastern Roman Empire was the name of the silver denar, one has to assume that <i>mina</i> as a weight simply was a name for the Roman pound. [D. Sperber (<i>Roman Palestine 200–400</i>, <i>Money and Prices</i>, Ramat Gan 1974) consistently writes <i>mina</i> for the weight and <i>maneh</i> for the coin. But since a talmudic מנה always denotes 100 denars, there is no reason not to read the word as Μνᾶ, מְנָה.]</i>, the fourfold portion is half a Roman pound.
He is guilty only it he ate it rare<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Superficially grilled. Eating grilled meat rare is not human. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 70a" href="/Sanhedrin.70a">Babli (70a</a>) this is called “cooked and uncooked”.</i>. If he ate it raw, he is a dog. If he ate it cooked, he is a human. If he ate cartilage<sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote">The word הסוקים is a <i>hapax</i> and probably corrupt. It is translated as if it were written חסוכים.</i>, what is the rule? What is the rule about soft sinews? <sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">This text to the end of the paragraph is a shortened form of a discussion in <i>Pesahim</i>7:11 (35a l. 62); the final result there and here is that the discussion is irrelevant for the rules regarding the deviant and rebellious son, which implies that for the <i>fourfold portion</i> nothing can be included that is not regularly counted as food.<br>The paschal lamb may be eaten only by persons who had subscribed to it, i. e., who were part of the group for whom the lamb was slaughtered during the afternoon of the 14<sup class="footnote-marker">th</sup> of Nisan. The lamb should be eaten in small quantities at the end of the meal; the minimum quantity per person is the volume of an average olive (כְּזַיִת). The question now arises whether barely edible parts, such as cartilage and soft sinews, can be used to fulfill the duty of eating from the paschal lamb and the number of subscribers increased accordingly.</i> Rebbi Joḥanan said, one subscribes to them; Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, one does not subscribe to them. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Zeˋira: Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish disagreed about what is stated there<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Chullin 9:2" href="/Mishnah_Chullin.9.2">Mishnah <i>Ḥulin</i> 9:2</a>. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 9:5:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.9.5.3">Mishnah 9:1</a> states that in general the hide of an animal is subject to the rules of impurity of food, but not to those of impurity of carcasses. Then <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 8:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.8.2.1">Mishnah 2</a> lists some animals whose hides follow the rules of flesh in all respects (general consensus exists only for humans and domesticated pigs.) R. Johanan holds that for eating pigskin one never can be prosecuted, while R. Simeon ben Laqish holds that eating pigskin, not yet transformed into leather, is as punishable as eating pork.</i>: “The following have their hides treated like their flesh.” Rebbi Joḥanan said, this was only said as prohibition and regarding impurity, but not for flogging. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, Rebbi stated a complete Mishnah, not only for prohibition and regarding impurity<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Pesaḥim</i> it is stated explicitly that the differences among the rabbis are about whipping offenders.</i>. The reasoning of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish seems inverted. There, he treats it as flesh, but here, he does not treat it as meat<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">“There” is <i>Ḥulin, “here” is Pesaḥim</i>.</i>. Rebbi Judah bar Pazi said, there is a difference, since there one refers to skin which in the end will become hard. This emphasizes that the reasoning of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish seems inverted! Since there, where in the end it will harden, he treats it as flesh, here where in the end it will not harden<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">Animal hide will become inedible; soft sinews and cartilage will remain edible after cooking.</i>, not so much more? Rebbi Abbahu<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Pesaḥim</i>” R. Abun”.</i> said, the reason of Rebbi Judah bar Pazi is: <i>they shall eat the meat in that night</i><sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:8" href="/Exodus.12.8"><i>Ex</i>. 12:8</a>, a verse about the paschal lamb, irrelevant for the rules about the deviant and rebellious son.</i>, not sinews.
“If he ate in a company of obligation<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">In modern Hebrew this is called סְעוּדַת מִצְוָה “a meal of obligation”, the festive meal at religious occasions such as weddings, circumcisions, redemption of firstborns, etc.</i>, or at the lengthening of a month<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">Before the publication of the calendar computations the Synhedrion, and its successor, the Academy of Tiberias, had to determine for every month whether it should have 29 or 30 days. This meeting always was the occasion of a festive meal.</i>, or ate Second Tithe in Jerusalem.” <i>They would discipline him</i>, but he does not listen to their voice<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">A slight misquote from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:18" href="/Deuteronomy.21.18"><i>Deut</i>. 21:18</a>, for: <i>but he does not listen to the voice of his father or his mother</i>.</i>. This excludes one who listens to the voice of his Father in Heaven<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:7:19" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.7.19"><i>Qiddušin</i> 1:2, Note 630</a>.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph does not belong here. It is a slight reformulation of a paragraph in <i>Mo`ed qatan</i> 2:3 (81b l. 33). There it was stated that one is permitted to earn money on the intermediate days of a holiday in order to have more money to spend on festive meals. The connection to this Chapter is that the deviant and rebellious son is absolved if he partakes of festive meals.</i> Rebbi Joḥanan said, if you were nominated for the city council, may the Jordan be the master of your border<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Since the Roman government never allowed local taxes, it appointed rich people to the council (βουλή); these had to provide public services at their own expense. To avoid such an onerous <i>leiturgia</i>, one is permitted to leave the Land of Israel.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, one complains to the government to be freed from the city council<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">While in general one should avoid contact with Roman imperial officials, it is permitted to file complaints to make oneself undesirable, so as not to be considered for a council appointment.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, one borrows against interest for a company of obligation and the sanctification of the month. Rebbi Joḥanan used to go to the assembly hall in the morning<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Before he became a member of the body fixing the calendar.</i>, collect the crumbs, and eat them, saying: May my part be with those who in the evening were sanctifying the month.
“Or ate torn or carcass meat, abominations and crawling things.” <i>They would discipline him</i>, but he would not listen to their voice<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">A slight misquote from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:18" href="/Deuteronomy.21.18"><i>Deut</i>. 21:18</a>, for: <i>but he does not listen to the voice of his father or his mother</i>.</i>. This excludes one who even to the voice of his Father in Heaven<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kiddushin 1:7:19" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kiddushin.1.7.19"><i>Qiddušin</i> 1:2, Note 630</a>.</i> does not listen<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 70b" href="/Sanhedrin.70b">Babli 70b</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If he stole from his father and ate at his father’s property, or from others and ate at others’ property, or from others and ate at his father’s property, he is not treated as deviant and rebellious son unless he stole from his father and ate at others’ property<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">That he stole money from his father to which he has easy access and ate at other’s premises where does not have to fear to be easily discovered. The facility of the crime will turn him into a habitual criminal (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 71a" href="/Sanhedrin.71a">Babli 71a</a>).</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Jehudah says, unless he stole both from his father and his mother<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Since in the relevant paragraph the Torah insists to mention the mother on equal footing with the father. If the mother has no separate property of her own, there is a question whether according to this opinion the son can never become deviant and rebellious (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 8:4:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.8.4.2">Note 50</a>).</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If he stole from his father,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">This Halakhah also is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 11:2:2-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.11.2.2-5">Halakhah 11:2</a> (<b>א</b>); only the second paragraph is relevant here.</i> From where a first warning about stealing: <i>you shall not steal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">As in 11:2 one should read <i>do not steal</i>לֹא תִגְנוב, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 20:16" href="/Exodus.20.16"><i>Ex</i>. 20:16</a>. The Ten Commandments only refer to the worst of crimes; <i>stealing</i> referred to there is kidnapping of humans, a capital crime (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 86a" href="/Sanhedrin.86a">Babli 86a</a>, <i>Bava meṣia`</i> 61b).</i>. From where a second warning about stealing: <i>you shall not steal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">Stealing as a civil offense is prohibited in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 19:11" href="/Leviticus.19.11"><i>Lev</i>. 19:11</a>. The remainder of the paragraph is a <i>baraita</i> also in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Kedoshim, Section 2 2" href="/Sifra,_Kedoshim,_Section_2.2"><i>Sifra Qedošim Parašah</i> 2(2</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Bava Kamma (Lieberman) 10" href="/Tosefta_Bava_Kamma_(Lieberman).10">Tosephta <i>Bava qamma</i>10</a>;37–38, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 27b" href="/Bava_Kamma.27b">Babli <i>Bava qamma</i> 27b</a> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 6:9-11:32" href="/Genesis.6.9-11.32"><i>Tanhuma Noah</i> 4</a>). Stealing is forbidden even if one intends to return the stolen goods after teaching the owner a lesson, or to have a pretext to give a poor person money in the shape of a fine.</i>. <i>You shall not steal</i>, in order to aggravate; <i>you shall not steal</i>, in order to pay double restitution, in order to pay quadruple or quintuple restitution. Ben Bagbag says, do not steal your own property from the thief, lest you be seen stealing.
Rebbi Abba, Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">With 11:2 read “Rebbi”.</i> Hoshaia: he is guilty only if he steals money. Rebbi Zeˋira in the name of Rebbi Hoshaia: he is guilty only if he shows contempt for money. What means showing contempt for money? Where do we hold? If about him who says, here you have five and give me for three, he is an idiot. Here you have three and give me for five, he is a regular person. But we deal with one who says, here you have five and give me for five<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">Since he has money, he has the urge to spend all of it even if it means that he buys more than he actually needs.</i>.
What is a thief and what is a robber<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">With 11:2 read: “R. Zeˋira said.”</i>? Rebbi Hila said, if he stole in the presence of witnesses, he is a thief, in the presence of the owners he is a robber. Rebbi Ze`ura asked<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">While the thief pays double to quintuple restitution, the robber only has to return the robbed goods. The distinction between thief and robber has far-reaching consequences. The thief takes by stealth, the robber in public. The question is, what is the definition of “in public”?</i>: but if he intended to rob in front of its owners, he is not a robber. What is a robber according to Rebbi Ze`ura? Rebbi Samuel ben Sosarta in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: only if he rob in the presence of ten people. The prototype for all these: <i>He robbed the spear from the hand of the Egyptian and killed him with his own spear</i><sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 23:21" href="/II_Samuel.23.21"><i>2S</i>. 23:21</a>. R. Zeˋira insists that the characteristic of the robber is not that he takes by force, even in the presence of the owners, but that he does it in public. As always, “in public” is defined as in the presence of ten adult males. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 79b" href="/Bava_Kamma.79b">Babli <i>Bava qamma</i> 79b</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If his father was willing but not his mother, or his father unwilling but his mother willing, he cannot be treated as deviant and rebellious son unless both be willing<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote">The son can be brought before the court only by unanimous consent of his parents. This usually is derived from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:20" href="/Deuteronomy.21.20"><i>Deut</i>. 21:20</a> where the parents have to complain that the son does not listen to their voice. The singular used, voice, implies common voice. (The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 71a" href="/Sanhedrin.71a">Babli 71a</a> infers that the parents actually have to speak with one voice; their voices have to sound the same. This is not mentioned in Yerushalmi or <i>Sifry</i>.)</i>. Rebbi Jehudah says if his mother was inappropriate for his father<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">Usually this means that his mother is (biblically or rabbinically) forbidden to his father. Here one could not exclude the disqualification of a mismatch.</i>, he cannot be treated as deviant and rebellious son.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If his father was willing,” etc. Rebbi Joḥanan said, even if his mother was not suitable for his father<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">Practice should not follow R. Jehudah.</i>. But is not all of his mother’s property also his father’s<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">Only if his mother be married to his father; an illegitimate son is not excluded either from inheritance or filial obligations. The question is relevant only for R. Jehudah in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 8:3:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.8.3.1">Mishnah 3</a>, who requires that the son had stolen from his mother’s property which was not his father’s.</i>? Rebbi Yose ben Abun said, explain it about one who took in lodgers, made repasts, and he stole from there.<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">This explanation really is unnecessary; in Tractate <i>Ketubot</i> many exceptions are noted to the rule that the husband has the usufruct of the wife’s property or the right to her earnings.</i>

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If one of them<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">Of the parents.</i> was one-armed, or lame, or mute, or deaf, he cannot be tried as deviant and rebellious son, as it is said:<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:19" href="/Deuteronomy.21.19"><i>Deut</i>. 21:19</a>.</i> <i>His father and mother shall grab him</i>, not one-armed ones, <i>bring him out</i>, not lame ones, <i>and say</i>, not mute ones, <i>this son of ours</i>, and not blind ones<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">Blind persons cannot point their fingers at the accused, they cannot know where in the room he is.</i>, <i>he does not listen to our voice</i>, not deaf ones. One warns him before three [judges] and whips him. If he becomes a repeat offender, he is tried by 23 but cannot be stoned unless the original three were present, since it is said <i>this son of ours</i>, this is the one who was whipped before you<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">The original judges become the witnesses who can testify to a proper warning given to the deviant son.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If one of them was one-armed.” etc. Just as one explains for his father and mother, so one explains for the Elders of the Court,<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">The Supreme Court.</i> as it is said <sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:2" href="/Deuteronomy.21.2"><i>Deut</i>. 21:2</a>.</i>: <i>They shall go out</i>, to exclude lame ones; <i>and say</i> <sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:7" href="/Deuteronomy.21.7"><i>Deut</i>. 21:7</a>.</i>, to exclude mute ones; <i>our hands did not spill</i>, to exclude one-armed ones; <i>and our eyes did not see</i>, to exclude blind ones. The verse tells you that just as the Elders of the Court must be unblemished morally, so they must be unblemished physically<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">Rejected by the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 36b" href="/Sanhedrin.36b">Babli, 36b</a>. Moses, the president of the first Supreme Court, had a speech defect.</i>.
Rebbi Joḥanan said, if one of the first [judges] died, he cannot be stoned. Is that not the Mishnah: “he cannot be stoned unless the original three were present”? Rebbi Hoshaia said, you should not say that the second trial should become the first<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">If a member of the original court had died, the second court cannot warn and whip the deviant son and set him up to be executed by a third court.</i>; therefore, one had to state this.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If he escaped before sentence was passed and then grew the lower beard, he is not liable<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">If he is recaptured, he needs a new trial. But since by then he already is an adult able to have children, he cannot be tried as a deviant and rebellious son. If sentence already was passed, no new trial is needed; the prior sentence can be carried out.</i>; but if he escaped after sentence was passed and then grew the lower beard, he is liable.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If he escaped before sentence was passed,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 4:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.4.2.2"><i>Sotah</i> 4:3, Notes 39–41</a>. This is one of the few cases where the Leiden ms. does not copy the text but simply refers to it by “etc.” The parallel quotes in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 25a" href="/Sotah.25a">Babli are <i>Sotah</i> 25a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 88a" href="/Sanhedrin.88a"><i>Sanhedrin</i>88a</a>.</i> Rebbi Joshia said, Zeˋira told me in the name of the people of Jerusalem: In three cases, if they want to forgive, they may forgive. These are: The suspect wife, the deviant son, and the Elder rebelling against the [Supreme] Court.
The suspect wife, is that not a Mishnah, “one whose husband refuses to let her drink”? They wanted to say, before the scroll was written. He comes to tell, even after the scroll was written. But it does not apply to the case where the scroll had been erased<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">In the ordeal of the suspected adulteress, if the text of the curses involving the Divine Name has been erased, the procedure is irreversible, just as a judicial procedure is after judgment was passed.</i>.
The deviant son, is that not a Mishnah, “if his father was willing but not his mother, or his mother willing but his father unwilling”? They wanted to say, before he was tried. He comes to tell, even after he was tried. But it does not apply to the case where judgment had been passed.
The rebellious Elder<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">Who refuses to follow the ruling of the Supreme Court sitting on the Temple Mount, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:8-13" href="/Deuteronomy.17.8-13"><i>Deut</i>. 17:8–13</a>. Even if he is not executed, he has to be stripped of his judicial functions.</i>; that means not to kill him. But they cannot let him return to his place.
<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">This continues the statement of Rebbi Joshia which was interrupted by the discussion of the three cases. In the Babli, the dissenters are “my colleagues in the South.”</i> But when I came to Rebbi Jehudah ben Bathyra at Nisibis, he agreed with me in two cases and disagreed in one. He disagreed about the rebellious Elder, lest quarrels increase in Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">The suspected adulteress and the deviant and rebellious son can be prosecuted only on request of the injured party; refusal to obey the instructions of the Supreme Court must be prosecuted automatically.</i>.
What is the reason of the House of Shammai? “Bring me my husband and I shall drink.” What is the reason of the House of Hillel? Since there is no husband to let her drink, the Torah returns her to a state of doubt, which induces another doubt, which remains a doubt<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph has nothing to do with the current subject but belongs to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 4:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.4.2.2"><i>Sotah</i> 4:3</a>. It was omitted there together with the preceding four paragraphs.<br>If a husband suspects his wife of adultery and warns her in the presence of two adult witnesses not to be with her suspected paramour, then if there is circumstantial evidence of adultery but no proof which would hold up in court, the wife is forbidden to her husband until she undergoes the ordeal by drinking the magic water in the Temple court (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 11:5-31" href="/Numbers.11.5-31"><i>Num</i>. 11:5–31</a>). If the ordeal confirms her adultery, she is divorced as adulteress without any money.The ordeal must take place in the presence of the husband. If the husband dies before the ordeal can take place, the woman cannot drink. The House of Shammai rules that she is a widow, entitled to all benefits due to a widow, since the death of her husband barred her from clearing her name without her fault. The House of Hillel hold that as suspected adulteress she cannot go to court to collect money from the heirs to the estate since only valid claims can be enforced in court; it is not the heirs’ doing that she cannot prove her case (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 4:1:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.4.1.3"><i>Soṭah</i> 4:1 Notes 13–16</a>).</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">The text from here to the end of the Halakhah is mainly from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:7:3-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.7.3-6"><i>Ketubot</i> 9:7, Notes 167–185</a>. It has no connection with the theme in <i>Sanhedrin</i>, only a tenuous one with the previously quoted text from <i>Sotah</i>. The text here is secondary as shown by a few omissions.</i> There, we stated: “If she had compromised her <i>ketubah</i>, she shall not be able to collect without an oath.” It was stated “compromised”, not that she reduced [her <i>ketubah</i>]. How? If her <i>ketubah</i> was 200 but she claims a mina, she is paid without an oath. What is the difference between one who did compromise and one who claims less? Rebbi Ḥanina said, if she compromises there was a transaction between them; if she claims less there was no transaction between them.
Rebbi Jeremiah asked: Since we stated there: “If one witness testified that [the <i>ketubah</i>] was paid, she shall not be able to collect without an oath”; should it be similar that if one witness testifies that [the <i>ketubah</i>] was reduced, she shall not be able to collect the reduced amount without an oath? Rebbi Yose said, at the moment when one witness testified that it was paid, he does not contradict two [witnesses]; but when he testifies that it was reduced he would contradict two [witnesses.]
<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 9:8:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.9.8.3"><i>Ketubot</i> 9:9, Notes 200–204</a>.</i> It was stated: “If she collects in his absence, she shall not be able to collect without an oath.” Can one collect from a person in his absence? Rebbi Jeremiah said, explain it about a contract for which interest is due. Would the court collect interest? Explain that it was guaranteed for a Gentile.
It was stated: If an heir’s father held a partially paid promissory note, the son collects without swearing. In this the son’s power is greater than the father’s since the father can collect only by swearing. Rebbi Eleazar said, nevertheless he has to execute an heir’s oath, “that our father did not charge us, that our father did not tell us, that we did not find a document among our father’s documents stating that this note was paid.” Therefore, if there was a document, the note was paid. Rebbi Hoshaia asked, does the <i>baraita</i> follow the House of Shammai? For the House of Shammai say, “she collects her <i>ketubah</i> and does not drink.” Rebbi Yose said, there the reason of the House of Shammai is: bring my husband and I shall drink! But here, it would be in order that even his father would not have to swear. They instituted a rule that he has to swear. They instituted this for him, but not for his son. When he died, you put his son on the biblical rule.
If a father became obligated to swear in court and died, his son cannot collect. If it were otherwise, what could we say? Can a man let his son inherit an obligation to swear? Rebbi <sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">In <i>Ketubot</i>: Abun.</i> Ba said, it was said as follows: if a man compromised his document in court, his son cannot collect. <sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">This is also quoted in <i>Ševuot</i> 7:6 (38a l. 25).</i> Rav Ḥisda asked: Because he walked two steps, does he lose? If he compromised it outside the court, he collects. Because he compromised it in court, he cannot collect?

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The deviant and rebellious son is judged because of his end; the Torah said, it is better that he should die innocent rather than guilty, for death of the evildoers is an enjoyment for them and enjoyment for the world, but concerning the just it is bad for them and bad for the world. Wine and sleep of the evildoers is an enjoyment for them and enjoyment for the world, but concerning the just it is bad for them and bad for the world. Scattering of the evildoers is an enjoyment for them and enjoyment for the world, but concerning the just it is bad for them and bad for the world. Coming together of the evildoers is bad for them and bad for the world, but concerning the just it is an enjoyment for them and enjoyment for the world. Quiet of the evildoers is bad for them and bad for the world, but concerning the just it is an enjoyment for them and enjoyment for the world.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The deviant and rebellious son,” etc. The Holy One, praise to Him, saw that this one in the end will waste his father’s and his mother’s properties, will sit at road crossings, rob people, and kill them, and in the end will forget all he has learned<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">And therefore descend to the level of animals. While the opinion voiced in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 71a" href="/Sanhedrin.71a">Babli (71a</a>) that “the case of the deviant and rebellious son never happened and never will happen” is not found in the Yerushalmi, the detailed rabbinic rules certainly are intended to make sure it never can happen in rabbinic Judaism. But apart from offering ample material for sermons, the rules clearly are intended to show that in biblical law the father has no power over the life of his children; any action against a child needs not only the consent of the mother but a court proceeding, in stark contrast to ancient Roman law (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 72a" href="/Sanhedrin.72a">Babli 72a</a>).</i>. Therefore, the Torah said, he should die innocent rather than die guilty, for death of the evildoers is an enjoyment for them and enjoyment for the world, but concerning the just it is bad for them and bad for the world.
“Wine and sleep of the evildoers is an enjoyment for them and enjoyment for the world, but concerning the just it is bad for them and bad for the world.” Rebbi Abbahu said, only wine with an excess of sleep<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Even the just have to sleep and to drink some wine, as long as one does not drink so much that he has to sleep off his alcohol.</i>. Rebbi Jonathan said, they sleep a little so they can concentrate better.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The intruder by stealth is judged because of his end<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:1" href="/Exodus.22.1"><i>Ex</i>. 22:1</a> permits the residents of a house to kill the stealth intruder since it is assumed that he would kill anybody offering resistance to his burglary.</i>. If in the course of a burglary he broke an amphora, if he has blood-guilt attached to him<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><i>If the sun shone on him, Ex</i>. 22:2.</i>, he is liable<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:2" href="/Exodus.22.2"><i>Ex</i>. 22:2</a>.</i>; if he has no blood-guilt attached to him, he is not liable<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Since he can be killed, his burglary is the equivalent of a capital crime cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 8:9:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.8.9.3">Note 102</a>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The intruder by stealth,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Parallel texts are in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 72a" href="/Sanhedrin.72a">Babli 72a</a>, <i>Mekhilta dR.. Ismael Mišpaṭim</i> 13, <i>dR. Simeon ben Iohai</i> p. 192, <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 217; partially <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:4:7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.4.7"><i>Yerushalmi Ketubot</i> 4:4 (Notes 88–93</a>).</i> Rebbi Ismael stated: This is one of three verses<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">To the verses <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:19" href="/Exodus.21.19"><i>Ex</i>. 21:19</a> and 22:2 mentioned here one has to add <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:17" href="/Deuteronomy.22.17"><i>Deut</i>. 22:17</a>.</i> which in the Torah have been formulated as a simile: <i>If he gets up and walks outside on his support</i><sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:19" href="/Exodus.21.19"><i>Ex</i>. 21:19</a>.</i>. <i>If the thief is found in the digging, if the sun shone on him, he has blood</i><sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:2" href="/Exodus.22.2"><i>Ex</i>. 22:2</a>.</i>. Does the sun shine only on him? Does the sun not shine on all beings in the world? But just as sunshine is special in that it brings peace to the entire world, so in any case in which you know that you are at peace with him, whether it be day or night his killer will be killed<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 79b" href="/Sanhedrin.79b">Babli, 79b</a>, states that if a father intrudes in the son’s home, the son does not have the right to kill him. The Yerushalmi does not have this good opinion of family relationships, cf. the next paragraph.</i>. If sometimes he comes to steal, sometimes he comes to kill, you say that if certainly he comes to steal, his killer will be killed<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 11:5" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.11.5">Tosephta 11:9</a>, this is a declarative sentence; the next sentence is missing there.</i>? Since sometimes he comes to kill, he may be killed. From here you argue about danger to life, to say that just as (foreign worship)<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Obviously, <i>foreign worship</i> has to be deleted since <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 8:9:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.8.9.1">Mishnah 9</a> states clearly that a person intent on idolatry cannot be killed before he acts. One must read שְׁפִיכוּת דָּמִים “bloodshed” which defiles the Land (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:33" href="/Numbers.35.33"><i>Num</i>. 35:33</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 33a" href="/Shabbat.33a">Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 33a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 85a" href="/Yoma.85a"><i>Yoma</i> 85a</a>); by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 8:9:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.8.9.1">Mishnah 9</a> a person intent on committing murder may be killed by any bystander before he commits the murder. If a person with a drawn sword runs after another, it is only a surmise but one which allows the bystander to kill the attacker; maybe the pursuer would not kill his victim. This is the “action in doubt“ referred to in this sentence.</i> is special in that it defiles the Land, desecrates the Name, removes the Divine Presence, and doubts are disregarded, so much more that doubts have to be disregarded in cases of danger to life<sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote">The Sabbath must be desecrated for the possibility of saving a life. For example, if there was a landslide on the Sabbath and it is only surmised that somebody was buried in it, one starts digging without delay.</i>.
It is written: <i>If the thief was found in a tunnel, was smitten, and died, there is no blood-guilt</i><sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 22:1" href="/Exodus.22.1"><i>Ex</i>. 22:1</a> permits the residents of a house to kill the stealth intruder since it is assumed that he would kill anybody offering resistance to his burglary.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya stated: In the tunnel<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">From חתר “to undermine”. The thief digs under the wall to enter the house.</i> there is no blood-guilt, outside the tunnel there is blood guilt. Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai stated: Even outside the tunnel there is no blood-guilt, for a person’s property is beloved by him like his own soul. He<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">The property owner.</i> sees him<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">The thief.</i>, that he<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">The thief.</i> comes to take his<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote">The property owner.</i> money away from him, stands up against him<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">The thief.</i> and kills him<sup class="footnote-marker">88,</sup><i class="footnote">The thief.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote">A similar statement is anonymous in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 85b" href="/Yoma.85b">Babli, <i>Yoma</i> 85b</a>.</i>. Rav Huna said, if he took a wallet, turned to leave and went, if then one stood up against him and killed him<sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">The thief.</i> the killer will not be killed. What is Rav Huna’s reason? <i>For his temper is hot</i><sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:6" href="/Deuteronomy.19.6"><i>Deut</i>. 19:6</a>, another case of non-prosecutable homicide.</i>. Rav said, I would kill anybody who would come against me, except Ḥanania ben Shila<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">A cousin of Rav, lover of roast pigeon (Babli <i>Pesaḥim</i> 10:8).</i>, of whom I know that he would come only to take his meal from me. Rebbi Isaac said, if he has the temerity to do something like that, he cannot be Ḥanania ben Shila<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">Therefore, any their caught in a house may be killed by the owner.</i>.

Halakhah 9

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The following ones one saves at the cost of their own persons<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote">Preferably by injuring him; if this is not possible by killing him (Babli).</i>: He who purses another to kill him, the male<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote">In order to commit homosexual rape.</i>, or the preliminarily married virgin girl<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">Whose rape is equated with murder, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:26" href="/Deuteronomy.22.26"><i>Deut</i>. 22:26</a>.</i>. But he who pursues an animal<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">To commit bestiality. It is not permitted to kill a person intending to commit a capital crime; only a person bent on committing murder or a crime against a human comparable to murder has to be killed if caught in <i>flagranti</i>.</i>, or who desecrates the Sabbath, or who worships strange worship, one may not save at the cost of their own persons.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The following ones one saves at the cost of their own persons” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">Similar texts are in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 73a" href="/Sanhedrin.73a">Babli 73a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 11:5" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.11.5">Tosephta 11:10–11</a>.</i>“He who pursues another to kill him, whether in a house or on the field one saves at the cost of his own person, both him who pursues another to kill him or him who pursues any of the transgressions<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">The parallel texts and the continuation of the <i>baraita</i> make it likely that one should not read עֲבֵירוֹת “transgressions” but עֲרָיוֹת“nakednesses; acts of incest and adultery which constitute either capital crimes or deadly sins.”</i> in the Torah one saves at the cost of his own person. But if it was a widow for a High Priest, a divorcee or one who had received <i>ḥalîṣah</i> for a common priest, a bastard or a Gibeonite for an Israel, an Israel woman for a bastard or a Gibeonite, one does not save him at the cost of his own person<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">Sexual offenses which are simple misdemeanors cannot be prevented by killing the offender.</i>. If the deed had been done, one does not save him at the cost of his own person<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">This is a case for the police and regular administration of justice.</i>. If there are people to save her, one does not save him at the cost of his own person<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">This is a case for the police and regular administration of justice.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah says, if she<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">The victim of sexual agression who is afraid she might be killed.</i> said, let him do it, one does not save at the cost of his own person. For if they would injure him, they through him would come to spill blood.”
The following is obvious: A murderer who broke vessels or otherwise caused damage is liable to pay<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">Since no crime can be punished more than once (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Terumot 7:1:2-15" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Terumot.7.1.2-15"><i>Terumot</i> 7:1 Notes 3–73</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 3:1:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.3.1.6"><i>Ketubot</i>3:1 Note 29</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ketubot 32b" href="/Ketubot.32b">Babli <i>Ketubot</i> 32b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Kamma 36a" href="/Bava_Kamma.36a"><i>Bava qamma</i> 36a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Makkot 7b" href="/Makkot.7b"><i>Makkot</i> 7b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Makkot 13b" href="/Makkot.13b">13b</a>), any damage done during the commission of a crime cannot be recovered from the criminal. Any damage caused before and after the crime has been committed can be recovered. The only question, the subject of the next two sentences, is whether the pursuit of the victim is part of the crime and protects the murderer from damage claims or not.</i>. If he continued to break until he came to the town, Rebbi Zeˋira and Rebbi Hoshaia: One said, he pays, the other said, he does not pay. If the pursuer becomes the pursued, may one save the pursuer through the person of the pursued<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">If the intended victim gets hold of a weapon and turns against the agressor, is there any cause for the uninvolved to act? The question is not answered.</i>? An adult (who became)<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">From the following text it seems clear that one has to read: If an adult was pursued by a minor, may one save the adult through the minor’s life? In a parallel text, <i>Šabbat</i> 14 (14d l. 67), the question is attributed to Rav Hisda, mentioned later here also.</i> a minor, may one save the adult through the person of the minor? Rebbi Jeremiah objected, did we not state<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Oholot 7:6" href="/Mishnah_Oholot.7.6">Mishnah <i>Ahilut</i> 7:6</a>. If the life of the mother is endangered during childbirth, the attendants must kill the fetus by cutting it into pieces and removing it. But if head and torso are already outside, so that the baby is breathing on his own, he cannot be killed even if he is endangering his mother’s life. This is a case of a minor pursuing an adult.</i>: “If his head and most of his body were born, one does not touch him, for one does not push aside one life for another.” Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said in the name of Rav Ḥisda: It is different there since you do not know who is killing whom<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Since the life of the baby is equally endangered, one cannot conclude that a minor intent on murder may not be killed by bystanders.</i>.
It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">Tosephta 11:12 in the name of R. Eleazar ben R. Ṣadoq.</i>: “Rebbi Eleazar ben Rebbi Simeon says, one who goes to worship a strange worship is saved at the cost of his own person.“ If one saves at the cost of his own person to protect the honor of flesh and blood<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">To save a woman from being raped.</i>, so much more because of the Life of the World<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Daniel 12:7" href="/Daniel.12.7"><i>Daniel</i> 12:7</a>. The vocalization חַי is standard Sephardic; traditional Ashkenazic is חֵי (cf. M. Hershler, <i>Siddur of R. Solomon ben Samson of Garmaise including the Siddur of the Haside Ashkenas</i>, Jerusalem 1971, pp. 21–22.)</i>.

Chapter 9



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The following are to be burned: one who copulates with a woman and her daughter,<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:14" href="/Leviticus.20.14"><i>Lev</i>. 20:14</a>.</i> and the daughter of a Cohen who committed adultery<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:9" href="/Leviticus.21.9"><i>Lev</i>. 21:9</a>.</i>. In the category of <i>a woman and her daughter</i> are included his daughter, his daughter’s daughter, his son’s daughter, his wife’s daughter, her daughter’s daughter, and her son’s daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:17" href="/Leviticus.18.17"><i>Lev</i>. 18:17</a> includes relations with a woman and her granddaughter with the prohibition of a woman and her daughter. The Mishnaiot in the Babli and most independent Mishnah mss. include mention of the mother and the grandmother-in-law. This is logically redundant.</i>. The following are to be beheaded: the murderer,<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:1:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.1.2">Chapter 7, Note 4</a>.</i> and the inhabitants of a seduced town<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:16" href="/Deuteronomy.13.16"><i>Deut</i>. 13:16</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:1:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.1.2-7">Halakhot 7:1</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:6:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.6.2-3">10:7</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:6:3-6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.6.3-6">8</a>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The following are to be burned,” etc. There, we have stated<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">The entire following Halakhah is a copy of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 11:1:2-13" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.11.1.2-13"><i>Yebamot</i> 11:1</a>, explained there in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 9:1:1-6:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.9.1.1-6.4">Notes 4–65</a>. The text here does not always follow the same order as given there. The Notes here are restricted to indicate where the text of <i>Yebamot</i> (Y) was preferred for translation. The corruptions in the <i>Sanhedrin</i> text make it clear that the Y text is original.</i>:
“One may marry [relatives of] a rape victim or a seduced woman.” So is the Mishnah: One may marry after<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">The reading of Y אחר clearly is the correct one, not אחד “one,” as written here.</i> a rape or after a seduction. If he raped a woman, her mother is permitted. If he seduced a woman, he daughter is permitted.
“He who rapes or seduces [a relative of] a married woman is [criminally] liable.” Rebbi Joḥanan said, one stated this for marriage. If he married a woman and then raped her mother, he is [criminally] liable. If he married a woman and then seduced her daughter, he is [criminally] liable.
Rebbi Eleazar said, Symmachos and Rebbi Joḥanan ben Nuri said the same thing, since we stated there: “If he slaughtered her, her daughter’s daughter, and afterwards her daughter, he absorbs forty [lashes]. Symmachos said in Rebbi Meïr’s name, he absorbs eighty.” There, we have stated: “Rebbi Joḥanan ben Nuri said, he who copulates with his mother-in-law may be liable because of his mother-in-law, his mother-in-law’s mother, and his father-in-law’s mother. They said to him, all three fall under the same law.” Rebbi Jehudah bar Pazi in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: Symmachos agrees with Rebbi Joḥanan. It was found stated: it still is in dispute. What is Rebbi Joḥanan ben Nuri’s reason? Since a woman and her daughter and a woman and her daughter’s daughter fall under two separate prohibitions, also a woman and (her daughter) [her son’s daughter]<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Text of Y. The text of <i>Sanhedrin</i> (in parentheses) simply is a copy of the preceding sentence.</i> and her daughter’s daughter fall under two separate prohibitions. What is the reason of the rabbis? Since a woman and her daughter and a woman and her daughter’s daughter fall under one and the same prohibition, also a woman and her son’s daughter and her daughter’s daughter fall the under same prohibition.
It is written, <i>the genitals of a woman and her daughter you shall not uncover</i>, and it is written, <i>if a man take a woman and her mother, it is taboo</i>. Everywhere is written <i>lying with</i>, but here is written <i>taking</i>, to teach you that he cannot be [criminally] liable for the second woman unless she be taken by him. Or maybe he is [criminally] liable only by marriage? We already said that there is no valid incestuous marriage. But is it not written: <i>Nobody may marry his father’s wife, and he should not uncover his father’s garment’s corner</i>? This comes to tell that she was permitted to him before his father married her. But is it not written: <i>If a man take his brother’s wife</i>? This comes to tell you that she was permitted to him before his brother married her. This is understood by levirate. But is it not written: <i>You should not take a woman in addition to her sister</i>? This comes to tell you that she was permitted to him before he married her sister. This is understood after her sister’s death. But is it not written: <i>A man who would take his sister, his father’s daughter or his mother’s daughter, it is ḥesed</i>? That you should not say that Cain married his sister, Abel married his sister, <i>it is charitable</i>, I was charitable with the first generations so the world could be inhabited; <i>I said, the world was built on ḥesed</i>. But is it not written: <i>Widow, divorcee, and desecrated, these he shall not take</i>? This comes to tell you that if he became betrothed to her, the betrothal is valid.
(Rav Huna said:)<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Missing in Y, probably spurious.</i> so far his daughter’s daughter from marriage. His daughter’s daughter from a rape? It is written, <i>the genitals of your son’s daughter or your daughter’s daughter you shall not uncover</i>. Where do we hold? If from marriage, it already had been said. So it cannot refer to marriage but must refer to rape. So far about his daughter’s daughter; from where his daughter? Rav said, if he is forewarned about his daughter’s daughter, so much more for his daughter! If for his daughter’s daughter he is subject to punishment (by extirpation)<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Missing in Y, probably spurious.</i>, so much more for his daughter!
<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">Missing in Y. Rav’s argument is rejected in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 76a" href="/Sanhedrin.76a">Babli 76a</a> since it violates a fundamental principle of criminal law that no act is punishable which is not listed as punishable in the written law. Therefore one needs a verse which punishes sexual relations with an illegitimate daughter.</i> From where does he have this? If was found stated by Ḥizqiah: <i>And if the daughter of a Cohen man start to whore</i><sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:9" href="/Leviticus.21.9"><i>Lev</i>. 21:9</a>.</i>. Why does the verse say <i>man</i>? To include one who copulates with his daughter from a rape among the burned<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote">The verse states clearly that the priesthood is inherited from the male line. A daughter of a Cohen who is not the daughter of the Cohen’s wife still is a Cohen’s daughter and subject to the rules of the priesthood. But the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 76a" href="/Sanhedrin.76a">Babli 76a</a> rejects the argument given here since the verse states that the Cohen’s daughter has to be burned because <i>she desecrates her father</i>; this excludes an incestuous relationship, in which the father desecrates his daughter.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">The changes from or additions to the text in Y are underlined. It is clear that the <i>Yebamot</i> text is the correct one, where in the references to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:14" href="/Leviticus.20.14"><i>Lev</i>. 20:14</a> “upwards” and “downwards” have to be interchanged and in the last sentence “mother” replaces “daughter”.</i> Rav Huna understood all of these [rules] from this verse: <i>The genitals of a woman and her daughter you should nor uncover</i>. And it is written, <i>if a man take a woman and her daughter, it is taboo</i>. Taboo-taboo for an equal cut. Since there are three generations downwards, so there are three generations upwards. Since there is a prohibition downwards, there is a prohibition upwards. Since downwards one requires marriage, so upwards one requires marriage. Since downwards they are burned, so upwards they are burned. Since downwards He gave the male’s daughter the same status as the female’s daughter, so upwards we give the male’s daughter the same status as the female’s daughter.
And following Rebbi Meïr? Since Rebbi Meïr said, a <i>gezerah šawah</i> is at the place it comes from, from where is the third generation downwards forbidden? (And following the rabbis, who say, a <i>gezerah šawah</i> is at the place it comes from, from where is the third generation downwards forbidden?)<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Missing in Y, probably spurious.</i> And following the rabbis, who say, a <i>gezerah šawah</i> is said about them, from where is the third generation upwards punished by burning? Both for Rebbi Meïr and the rabbis, from where that the third generation downwards is forbidden? (Rebbi Yose said,)<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Missing in Y, probably spurious.</i> since it is written <i>taboo-taboo</i>, it is as if all were there.
<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence is quite out of place here; in <i>Yebamot</i> it follows the paragraph after the next. All sexual offenses against a daughter are covered by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 19:29" href="/Leviticus.19.29"><i>Lev</i>. 19:29</a>; punishment only has to be specified in different cases. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 76a" href="/Sanhedrin.76a">Babli 76a</a>.</i> Rebbi Yose ben Rebbi Abun said, one may even understand this from the warning: <i>Do not desecrate your daughter to force her into prostitution</i>.
Rebbi Ḥaggai asked before Rebbi Yose: Why do we not say, “your daughter you should not uncover, your daughter’s daughter you should not uncover”? He said, if it were written “the genitals of a woman and her daughter’s daughter you shall not uncover,” we would have said “your daughter you should not uncover, your daughter’s daughter you should not uncover”.
If there are two prohibitions and one liability to extirpation, the prohibitions split the extirpation. What is the reason? <i>On human flesh it may not be rubbed and in its proportions you should not make [a compound] like it</i>, etc.. And it is written: <i>A man who would compound like it, etc</i>. This implies that for two prohibitions and one liability to extirpation, the prohibitions split the extirpation.
They asked before Rebbi Abbahu: If [a man] copulated with a woman, she had a daughter, and after that he came and copulated with the latter. Is he [criminally] liable about her because of a woman and her daughter, her daughter’s daughter, and her son’s daughter? He said to them, <i>they are relatives, it is taboo</i>, all because of taboo.
What is the reason of Rebbi Jehudah? <i>A man may not take his father’s wife, and he should not uncover his father’s wing;</i> that is his rape victim. How do the rabbis explain “his father’s wing”? There, they say and they do not know the origin of the tradition, that refers to a wing which is in need of his father. Would he not anyhow be [criminally] liable for her because of “his father’s wife”? Rebbi Hila said, because of forewarning; if he was warned because of his father’s wife he will be whipped, and because of his father’s wing he will be whipped. Rebbi Jehudah agrees about whipping. Rebbi Jehudah agrees about sacrifice. Rebbi Jehudah agrees about all other men<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Probably for האנשים one should read האנסים “the rapists.” A man can have relations with a woman raped or seduced by any close relative except his father, and even marry her. In Y the reading is הספיקות “the doubts” (see there, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 9:6:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.9.6.3">Note 61</a>.)</i> that he is free. Rebbi Jehudah agrees that if he marries her preliminarily that the preliminary marriage is legally valid.
<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">In this paragraph, the indications of who is the speaker of each sentence are given in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 11:1:13" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.11.1.13"><i>Yebamot</i> 11:1, Notes 62–65</a>.</i> Rebbi Ḥaggai asked before Rebbi Yose: Is the child a bastard following Rebbi Jehudah? He said to him, <i>No one with a damaged testicle or with cut-off penis may marry into the Eternal’s congregation</i> interrupts the argument. It interrupted the argument in the matter of the father’s wife. The father’s wife was part of the set of all incest prohibitions; it was selected from this set to teach about bastardy for all incest prohibitions. Similarly, let the rape victim be selected to teach a prohibition concerning all rape victims. The father’s wife was part of the set of all incest prohibitions; it was selected from this set to teach about bastardy for all incest prohibitions. Can you say here that the rape victim was in the set, that it could teach a prohibition concerning all rape victims? Why cannot the father’s wife be selected to teach about the rape victim in her case? He said to him, if she is his father’s wife, she is not his rape victim; if she is the father’s rape victim, she is not his wife.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> A murderer who attacked someone with a stone or an iron<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">These are the cases described in the Torah, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:16" href="/Numbers.35.16"><i>Num.</i> 35:16</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:17" href="/Numbers.35.17">17</a>.</i>, or forced him under water or into fire so he could not escape from there and died, is [criminally] liable. If he pushed him into water or fire and he could have escaped from there by himself but died, he is not [criminally] liable<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">This is a case of indirect causation, not covered by biblical law.</i>. If he provoked a dog or a snake against him, he is not [criminally] liable<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">This is a case of indirect causation, not covered by biblical law.</i>. If he let a snake bite him<sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote">The murderer held the poisonous snake until it started to bite the victim. For R. Jehudah it is a case of murder, for the Sages one of indirect causation.</i>, Rebbi Jehudah declares him [criminally] liable but for the Sages he is not [criminally] liable.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “A murderer who attacked someone,” etc. It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:17" href="/Numbers.35.17"><i>Num</i>. 35:17</a>.</i>: <i>If he hit him with a lethal stone in his hand so that he died, (the hitter shall die, he is a murderer,)</i><sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:21" href="/Numbers.35.21"><i>Num</i>. 35:21</a>; the quote is not appropriate</i><i>the murderer shall be put to death. Or he hit him with a lethal wooden implement in his hand so that he died, the murderer shall be put to death</i><sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:18" href="/Numbers.35.18"><i>Num</i>. 35:18</a>.</i>. When He comes to iron<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:16" href="/Numbers.35.16"><i>Num</i>. 35:16</a>. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 76b" href="/Sanhedrin.76b">Babli 76b</a>.</i>, He does not speak of lethal or not lethal, but even a small hook when applied to the esophagus could kill him; but a stone must be lethal, wood must be lethal<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">Prosecution of murder with a stone or wood is possible only if the stone or wood can be classified as lethal; otherwise the murderer can claim that the slain person was the victim of an accident.</i>. If he put him in front of a horse<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">In the following cases, it is presumed that the murderer somehow immobilized his victim. In these cases, the murderer is guilty if the horse already was galloping, or the arrow or spear already flying, etc. Then the action of the murderer is murder. But according to the Mishnah, tying a person as a target for other people’s future shots is indirect causation. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 77a" href="/Sanhedrin.77a">Babli 77a</a>.</i>, in front of an arrow, in front of a spear, put him out in the cold, gave him bad water to drink, removed the ceiling over him and the rains came down and killed him, or he opened a water canal whose waters swept over him<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">It is murder if the first wave of water is lethal.</i>.
What is Rebbi Jehudah’s reason? Because of the poison in the hollow teeth<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">For R. Jehudah, the moment when the snake starts biting, the poison starts to flow. Therefore holding a snake is no different from holding a dagger. The rabbis hold that the snake has to push out the poison by the action of some of its muscles; this makes the action of the murderer indirect causation; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 78a" href="/Sanhedrin.78a">Babli 78a</a>.</i>. What is the reason of the rabbis? There is no poison in the hollow teeth until it excretes it.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If somebody injures another person by a stone or with his fist<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The language is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:18" href="/Exodus.21.18"><i>Ex</i>. 21:18</a>.</i> and they expected him to die, but he got better and only afterwards deteriorated and died; he is [criminally] liable. Rebbi Neḥemiah declares him not liable since it is not unsubstantiated<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">For R. Nehemiah it is probable that the death was not caused by the injury; for the rabbis the opposite is true.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If somebody injures another person,” etc. So is the Mishnah: <sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The entire Halakhah is also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nazir 9:5:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nazir.9.5.2-3"><i>Nazir</i> 9:5</a>, explained there in Notes 163–186 with due attention given to the differences in reading in <i>Sanhedrin</i>.</i>“Rebbi Neḥemiah declares him not [criminally] liable but the Sages declare him [criminally] liable since it is not unsubstantiated.” The Sages say, two estimations have precedence over one estimation; Rebbi Neḥemiah says, the intermediate estimation has precedence over the two. What is Rebbi Neḥemiah’s reason? <i>If he gets up and walks outside on his cane, the attacker is exonerated</i>. Could you think that this one walks in the market and the other one is executed because of him? But even if he dies according to the first estimation, he cannot be prosecuted. What is the rabbi’s reason? <i>If he does not die but is bedridden</i>. Would we not know that even if he does not die that he will be bedridden? But if they did not estimate that he would die. If they did not estimate that he would die, that is what is written: <i>If he gets up and walks outside on his cane, the attacker is exonerated</i>. Therefore, if he does not get up, [the attacker] is [criminally] liable. But if they estimated that he would die? If they estimated that he would die, that is what is written: <i>But he has to pay for his disability and the medical costs</i>. Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: It is an extraordinary decree of Scripture that he has to pay. Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina: It was an erroneous estimation. What is the difference between them? “But he got better and only afterwards deteriorated and died; he is [criminally] liable. Rebbi Neḥemiah declares him not liable since it is not unsubstantiated.” For him who said, it is an extraordinary decree of Scripture that he has to pay; if he paid, he paid. If he did not pay, does he have to pay? For him who said, it was an erroneous estimation; if he did not pay, one does not order him to pay. If he paid, can he take it back? A <i>baraita</i> supports one and a <i>baraita</i> supports the other. A <i>baraita</i> supports Rebbi Yose bar Ḥanina: If they estimated that he would live but he died, from when does one count for him?
