From the moment he turns worse<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">A Genizah reading: “improves” (<i>Nazir</i> Note 179).</i>. This implies that the estimate was wrong. If you would say, it is an extraordinary decree of Scripture that he has to pay, he should pay from the first moment. A <i>baraita</i> supports Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: If they estimated that he would die but he lived, from when does one count for him? From the moment he turns worse. Rebbi Yose said, it does not say here “from the moment he turns worse” but “from the moment he turns better.” That means, it is an extraordinary decree of Scripture that he has to pay. But if you say, it was an erroneous estimation, he has to pay until [the victim] dies.
<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">The entire Halakhah is also <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nazir 9:5:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nazir.9.5.2-3"><i>Nazir</i> 9:5</a>, explained there in Notes 163–186 with due attention given to the differences in reading in <i>Sanhedrin</i>.</i> If he hit him on his hand and it withered. The physicians said, if his hand is amputated he will live. Does he have to pay for the hand? Let us hear from the following: <i>If people quarrel, if people brawl</i>. Is not brawl quarrel? Why does the verse say, <i>if people quarrel, if people brawl</i>? To apply the rules of the intended to the unintended and of the unintended to the intended. One understands from the intended to the unintended. Of the unintended to the intended? It must be the following: If he hit him on his hand and it withered. The physicians said, if his hand is amputated he will live. Does he have to pay for the hand? Since you say there, it is an extraordinary decree of Scripture that he pay for the hand, so here it is an extraordinary decree of Scripture that he pay for the hand.
“If one intended to kill an animal,” etc. Rebbi Isaac asked: If they estimated that he would survive but he died; is it not common for the living to die? Since it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:19" href="/Exodus.21.19"><i>Ex</i>. 21:19</a>.</i> <i>but he has to pay for his disability and the medical costs</i>, he is liable to pay for disability and medical costs<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">This still belongs to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 9:3:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.9.3.2-3">Halakhah 3</a>. Since we have a principle that nobody subject to criminal punishment pays damages, why was it stated earlier that if medical opinion was that the victim would survive, the attacker has to pay the victim’s expenses and loss of earnings even though in the end he faces prosecution for murder? His monetary obligation starts immediately with the act of agression; he faces trial only after the victim’s death.</i>. Rebbi Isaac asked: If they estimated that he would die but he survived; is it not common for the dying to live. Since it is written <i>but he has to pay for his disability and the medical costs</i>, he is liable to pay for disability and medical costs<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">The moment it becomes clear that the agressor does not face criminal charges, the monetary obligations are activated.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If one intended to kill an animal but he killed a human, a Non-Jew but he killed a Jew, a stillborn<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">A newborn who is not expected to live for 30 days is considered stillborn.</i> but he killed a viable baby, he is not criminally liable<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">Biblical law provides sanctions for murder and unintentional homicide, but not for intentional homicide that fails to qualify as murder. Similarly, biblical law is not applicable to Gentiles (<i>Tanḥuma Mišpatim</i> 3, based on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:1" href="/Exodus.21.1"><i>Ex</i>. 21:1</a>). These cases cannot be tried in rabbinic court; they are cases for the king’s police powers or extrajudicial powers of the communal court (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 9:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.9.6.1">Mishnah 10</a>).</i>.<br>If one intended to hit someone on his hips where it would not have been enough to kill but it went on his heart where it was enough to kill and he died, he cannot be prosecuted. If one intended to hit someone on his heart where it would have been enough to kill but it went on his hips where it was not enough to kill but he died, he cannot be prosecuted. If one intended to hit someone big whom it would not have been enough to kill but it went on somebody small whom it was enough to kill and he died, he cannot be prosecuted. If one intended to hit someone small whom it would have been enough to kill but it went on somebody big whom it was not enough to kill but he died, he cannot be prosecuted.<br>If one intended to hit someone on his hips where it was enough to kill but it went on his heart and he died; [or] if one intended to hit someone big and it was enough to kill but it went on somebody small and he died; he is [criminally] liable<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">These cases all fit the definition of premeditated murder.</i>. Rebbi Simeon says, even if he intended to kill one person but killed another, he is not criminally liable<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Mishnah 4 and Note 33. In his opinion, not only is it homicide if a human is killed instead of an animal, but even if a different human is killed than the intended victim. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 12:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.12.2">Tosephta 12:4</a> he is opposed by R. Jehudah.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If one intended to hit someone on his hips,” etc. Ḥizqiah asked: If one threw a deadly stone which killed one person and broke another’s vessels, did the verse give the law for one but not for the other<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:22-23" href="/Exodus.21.22-23"><i>Ex.</i> 21:22–23</a> it is spelled out that in case of injuries, payment is due only if there is no criminal case. But this refers only to one person. If the stone had killed one person and broke the same person’s vessels, no payment for the vessels would be due. But this says nothing about the obligations of the thrower towards a third person, not involved in the personal injury case.</i>? Ḥizqiah asked: If one threw a stone which was not deadly but which killed one person<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">Assuming that in the previous case the law was that the thrower could not be sued by the owner of the vessels, the question remains open whether he can be sued if the thrower cannot be sued for murder (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 35:17" href="/Numbers.35.17"><i>Num</i>. 35:17</a>) but only sued for money by the heirs of the slain person. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 79b" href="/Sanhedrin.79b">Babli 79b</a> both questions are answered in the negative.</i> and broke another’s vessels, did the verse give the law for one but not for the other?
Rebbi Simeon<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote">This R. Simeon must be the Amora R. Simeon ben Laqish; he cannot be the Tanna R. Simeon ben Iohai mentioned in the Mishnah, who lived a full generation before Rebbi.</i> says, those of the House of Rebbi state: even if he intended to kill one person but killed another, he is not criminally liable<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">He cannot be prosecuted for premeditated murder unless he stated before witnesses the name of the person whom he intended to kill. All other cases are cases of willful homicide, not covered by biblical law (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 9:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.9.4.1">Note 33</a>).</i>. The House of Rebbi follows Rebbi Nathan, as it was stated in the name of Rebbi Nathan: If one was standing next to a group of people and said, I am intending to kill one of you<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote">But he did not specify whom he intended to kill.</i>. Even if he intended to kill one person but killed another, he is not criminally liable.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> If a murderer was mixed up with others, none of them are criminally liable<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">Since nobody can be convicted if he was not identified by witnesses.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah says, one keeps them in jail<sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote">Until each person be identified by witnesses.</i>. Any condemned to death who were mixed up with others<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Also condemned to death.</i> shall be executed by the easier way. Those to be stoned with those to be burned, Rebbi Simeon says they shall be stoned because burning is more painful, but the Sages say they shall be burned since stoning is more painful.<br>Rebbi Simeon told them, if burning were not more painful it would not have been prescribed for a Cohen’s daughter who committed adultery. They answered him, if stoning were not more painful, it would not have been prescribed for the blasphemer and those who worship strange cults. Those to be slain with those to be strangled, Rebbi Simeon says by the sword, but the Sages say by strangulation<sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.1.1">Mishnah 7:1</a>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “If a murderer was mixed up with others,” etc. Rebbi Joḥanan said, the Mishnah deals with a murderer mixed up with innocent people<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">In this interpretation, R. Jehudah allows the police to arrest innocent people and keep them in prison until they have proven their innocence.</i>. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, the Mishnah deals with a murderer being tried mixed up with a murderer who already was convicted. Samuel said, the Mishnah deals with a bull mixed up with other bulls. If the Mishnah referred to a bull<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">A bull which has killed a human and must be stoned by the verdict of a court of 23. Humans can be identified by witnesses; cattle all look alike.</i> mixed up with other bulls, would we state about them that “one keeps them in jail”?
Rebbi Simeon says, burning is worse than stoning, but the rabbis teach that stoning is worse than burning. Rebbi Simeon says, strangulation is worse than decapitation; but the rabbis teach that decapitation is worse than strangulation<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:1:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.1.2-7">Halakhah 7:1</a>, first sentences.</i>.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Somebody who was found guilty of two death penalties shall be convicted to the more painful one. One who committed one crime punishable by two death penalties shall be convicted to the more painful one. Rebbi Yose says, he shall be convicted for the first connection.<br>If somebody was repeatedly whipped, the court sends him to jail<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">For the third conviction of the same kind. These rules have no biblical justification.</i> where he is fed barley until his belly bursts. One sends the murderer without witnesses to jail and feeds him scanty bread and sparing water<sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 30:20" href="/Isaiah.30.20"><i>Is</i>. 30:20</a></i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Somebody who was found guilty of two death penalties,” etc. There<sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 81a" href="/Sanhedrin.81a">Babli 81a</a>.</i> it was stated that one states: “Rebbi Yose says, he shall be convicted for the first connection.” How is this? His mother-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote">Who was a widow or a single parent at the moment of his marriage.</i> who then became a married woman<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote">If he sleeps with her after her remarriage.</i> is [executed] by burning. As a married woman<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote">If she was forbidden to him as a married woman before his marriage.</i> who later became his mother-in-law it is by strangulation, if he copulated with his mother-in-law. How with his mother-in-law and daughter-in-law? How can this be? A man married a woman, and her brother’s daughter, and the woman’s daughter. If he copulated with the old woman<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">The first wife’s mother who is his other two wives’ grandmother.</i> he is liable for her because of his mother-in-law, the mother of his mother-in-law, and the mother of his father-in-law. If his mother-in-law is simultaneously his daughter-in-law<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">He married a woman whose mother was married to his son.</i>, how does Rebbi Yose treat this? The more severe and the lesser, how does Rebbi Yose treat this<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli indicates that R. Yose might accept that a more general and more stringent prohibition supersedes the more narrow one. The Yerushalmi strongly disagrees, as explained in the next paragraph.</i>? Two simultaneous prohibitions, how does Rebbi Yose treat this<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">In the example of the man with three wives his mother-in-law who is the mother of his father-in-law is doubly forbidden in the same degree. For which crime does he have to be prosecuted first and, since a person can be executed only once, the only time?</i>?
They said, what was asked of Rebbi Yose also can be asked of Rebbi Ismael since it was stated in the name of Rebbi Ismael: If she became widowed, divorced, desecrated, and a whore in this order<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 21:14" href="/Leviticus.21.14"><i>Lev</i>. 21:14</a>, speaking of the High Priest: <i>A widow, divorcee, desecrated woman, whore, these he may not take</i>.<br>A desecrated woman is one who had forbidden sexual contact with a Cohen, e. g., a divorcee who is forbidden to a common priest. A whore is a woman who slept with a man whom she could not marry, e. g., a close relative or a Gentile.<br>Since the verse treats the four prohibitions as one, a High Priest who inadvertently sleeps with a woman who became forbidden to him on all four counts in the order enumerated in the verse has to bring a single purification offering.<br>In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 77a" href="/Kiddushin.77a">Babli, <i>Qiddušin</i> 77a</a>, the argument is the opposite one. A widow is forbidden only to the high priest. A divorcee is also forbidden to a common priest. A desecrated woman of priestly descent in addition of being barred from marrying a priest is barred from eating heave. A whore may also be forbidden to an Israel; in case she was a married woman who committed adultery she becomes forbidden to her husband. Since the prohibitions cover an ever wider circle, they are cumulative. Therefore, for the Babli, a High Priest who sleeps with a divorcee who afterwards became a widow is liable only for one purification offering, whereas the next sentence shows that for the Yerushalmi he is liable for two.</i>: when afterwards he copulated with her, he is liable only once. If she whored, was desecrated<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote">A whore is forbidden to a priest. If he sleeps with her the first time, he desecrates her. If then she again sleeps with a priest, this one sleeps with a woman who first whored and then became desecrated.</i>, and after that he copulated with her, he is liable for every single [transgression]. If she became widowed and divorced simultaneously<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">If a first man had contracted with her a legally defective preliminary marriage and then a second man contracted a clearly legal preliminary marriage, the first man has to divorce her and the second may marry her (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Gittin 89b" href="/Gittin.89b">Babli <i>Gittin</i> 89b</a>). If then the second man dies exactly at the moment when she receives the first man’s bill of divorce, she becomes simultaneously a widow and a divorcee.</i>, how does Rebbi Ismael treat this? The more severe and the lesser, how does Rebbi Ismael treat this<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">The Babli indicates that R. Yose might accept that a more general and more stringent prohibition supersedes the more narrow one. The Yerushalmi strongly disagrees, as explained in the next paragraph.</i>? Two simultaneous prohibitions, how does Rebbi Ismael treat this<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">In the example of the man with three wives his mother-in-law who is the mother of his father-in-law is doubly forbidden in the same degree. For which crime does he have to be prosecuted first and, since a person can be executed only once, the only time?</i>?
Rav said, the Mishnah [deals with the case that the crime was committed] inside from the witnesses. Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, when he could not receive warning<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 9:6:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.9.6.1">Mishnah 10</a>. While for all other death penalty cases one can be satisfied with letting Heaven mete out the penalty (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 23:7" href="/Exodus.23.7"><i>Ex</i>. 23:7</a>), no commonwealth can exist which lets 99.99% of all murders go unpunished. It is agreed that the death penalty cannot be imposed if not all conditions for such a judgment are satisfied. A rabbinic court cannot be oblivious of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:15" href="/Deuteronomy.19.15"><i>Deut</i>. 19:15</a> which clearly requires two eye witnesses for criminal conviction and excludes circumstantial evidence and testimony of a single witness. It is explained that a sentence of life in jail can be imposed on the testimony of two witnesses whose testimony would be inadmissible in a death penalty case. According to Rav, one possible scenario is that of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 4:9:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.4.9.2">Halakhah 4:11</a>, where two witnesses testify that the accused entered a room where the victim was alive, left with a bloody sword, and the victim was found inside stabbed to death. R. Yose ben Hanina points to another scenario, where there were eye witnesses to the murder but it had not been possible to deliver the statutory warning before the murder was committed.</i>.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> He who steals the chalice<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">A Temple vessel.</i>, or who curses by charms, or who copulates with a Gentile woman, one<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">In all other sources of the Mishnah, and an indirect quote in the Hahakhah: Zealots hit him, referring to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 25:11" href="/Numbers.25.11"><i>Num.</i> 25:11</a> where Phineas is praised for being a zealot by killing the chieftain who copulated with the Midianite princess. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 82a" href="/Sanhedrin.82a">Babli 82a</a> makes clear that the offender may be killed with impunity only during the act. If the parties are still together naked but not engaged in actual intercourse, killing them is prosecutable murder.</i> strikes him. If a priest officiated while impure, his brother priests do not bring him to court but the young priests take him outside the courtyard and smash his brain with bats<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">These are straight pieces of lumber which are impervious to impurity. The offending priest is killed without his executioners becoming impure.</i>. A non-priest who officiated in the Temple: Rebbi Aqiba said, by strangulation, but the Sages say, by the hands of Heaven.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “He who steals the chalice,” etc. קסווה <i>cista</i><sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">Also cf. Greek κίστη “basket, hamper; writing case; voting urn”.</i>. Rav Jehudah said, it was a Temple vessel, as one says <i>and the libation chalices</i><sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 4:7" href="/Numbers.4.7"><i>Num</i>. 4:7</a>. The same explanation in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 81b" href="/Sanhedrin.81b">Babli, 81b</a>.</i>.
“He who curses by a charm.” Like those Nabateans who curse “your creator, your smith, your acquisition<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">Explanation of J. Levy in his Dictionary, based on Arabic קני “to acquire, to create”, קינ “smith; any craftsman”; a similar but Hebrew formulation in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 81a" href="/Sanhedrin.81a">Babli 81a</a>. He also notes that the words might be substitutes for others, similar to קונם, קונח, קונס used for קָרְבָּן in vows (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nedarim 1:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nedarim.1.2.1">Mishnah <i>Nedarim</i> 1:2</a>).</i>.
“One who copulates with a Gentile woman,” etc. Rebbi Ismael stated: This is one who marries a Gentile woman, sires children, and from her raises enemies of the Omnipresent<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 4:10:2-7" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.4.10.2-7"><i>Megillah</i> 4:10</a> (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 25a" href="/Sanhedrin.25a">Babli 25a</a>) this is R. Ismael’s explanation of <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 18:21" href="/Leviticus.18.21"><i>Lev</i>. 18:21</a>, giving one’s descendants to the Moloch.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 82a" href="/Sanhedrin.82a">Babli 82a</a>, <i>Num</i>. <i>rabba</i> 20(26), <i>Tanhuma Balaq</i> 21, <i>Tanhuma Buber Balaq</i> 30. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 25:7" href="/Numbers.25.7"><i>Num</i>. 25:7</a>.</i> It is written: <i>Phineas ben Eleazar ben Aharon the priest saw</i>. What did he see<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote">Since Zimri did his deed in public, everybody saw.</i>? He understood what happened and remembered practice: “One who copulates with a Gentile woman, zealots strike him.” It was stated: not with the agreement of the Sages<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Since in most cases the zealot’s intervention would be first degree murder.</i>. Would Phineas act against the Sages? Rebbi Jehudah bar Pazi said, they wanted to excommunicate him had not the Holy Spirit jumped on him and declared that <i>an eternal covenant of priesthood shall be for him and his descendants after him</i><sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 25:12" href="/Numbers.25.12"><i>Num</i>. 25:12</a>.</i>, etc.
What is Rebbi Aqiba’s reason? It says here, <i>dying he shall be put to death</i><sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">E. g. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 20:10" href="/Leviticus.20.10"><i>Lev.</i> 20:10</a>. An unspecified death penalty is by strangling;</i>, and it says there, <i>anybody acceding to the Eternal’s abode will die, etc</i>.<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 17:28" href="/Numbers.17.28"><i>Num.</i> 17:28</a>. While the verse speaks of the access of non-priests to the Sanctuary, it supports only the rabbis’ argument since it clearly refers to Heaven’s actions. The parallel in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 84a" href="/Sanhedrin.84a">Babli 84a</a> (<i>Sifry Deut</i>. 116, end) makes more sense.</i> What is the rabbis’ reason? It says here, <i>dying he shall be put to death</i>, but it says there, <i>any outsider coming close shall be put to death</i><sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 18:7" href="/Numbers.18.7"><i>Num</i>. 18:7</a>. This verse supports R. Aqiba.</i>. It is better to compare <i>shall be put to death</i> with <i>shall be put to death</i> and <i>not shall be put to death with shall die</i><sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote">To transfer the interpretation of one word to another verse, the word has to be in the same grammatical form. It is clear that the positions of יומת and ימות have to be switched.</i>.

Chapter 10



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> All of Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Even those executed for a capital crime. In contrast to Christian (Pauline) teaching that everybody is damned unless he be saved by his particular faith, it is asserted that everybody is saved except when he denies himself salvation.</i> have a part in the World to Come. But the following have no part in the World to Come: One who says that the resurrection of the dead is not biblical<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">Since he denies the existence of the World to Come, it cannot exist for him.</i>, or that the Torah is not from Heaven, or the Epicurean<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">Who holds that the world is an assembly of atoms subject to random effects.</i>. Rebbi Aqiba says, also one who reads outside books<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote">Sectarian religious literature.</i>, or who whispers over a wound<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote">Or any sick person. It is blasphemous to use biblical verses to heal through miracles.</i> and says, <i>any sickness that I put on Egypt I shall not put on you, for I am the Eternal, your Healer</i>. Abba Shaul said, also one who pronounces the Name<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">YHWH, whose vocalization does not follow grammatical rules. In cabbalistic invocations of the Name, therefore, one never mentions the letters of the Name in straight sequence but says: YH <i>in</i> WH.</i> by its letters.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The following have no part in the World to Come,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">This and the following paragraphs are from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Peah 1:1:53-57" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Peah.1.1.53-57"><i>Peah</i> 1:1 (Notes 199–213</a>,P) and partially also from <i>Qiddušin</i> 1:10 (Notes 657–680,Q), where the differences in readings are noted.<br>For this paragraph, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 99a" href="/Sanhedrin.99a">Babli 99a</a>, <i>Sifry Num</i>. 112, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pirkei Avot 3:15" href="/Pirkei_Avot.3.15">Mishnah <i>Avot</i> 3:15</a>.</i> They added one who tears away the yoke, one who breaks the Covenant, and one who finds aspects in the Torah, to those who have no part in the World to Come. He who tears away the yoke is one who says the Torah is obligatory but I cannot stand it. He who breaks the Covenant is one who pulls himself a prepuce. He who finds aspects in the Torah is one who says that the Torah was not given from Heaven. But did we not state separately: “He who says that the Torah is not from Heaven?” Rebbi Ḥanina Entanaya stated before Rebbi Mana: This is one who publicly transgresses the words of the Torah in the manner of Joiakim ben Josia, king of Judah, and his circle.
Idolatry and incest and adultery. Rebbi Jonah and Rebbi Yose, one said, like the easy ones<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">As explained in <i>Peah</i> and qualified in the next paragraph, easy sins are those for which a person is punished in this world so that they will not diminish his bliss in the World to Come. Hard ones are those for which a person will suffer in Hell.</i>, and one says, like the hard ones. What are we talking about? If he repented, there is nothing that stands in the way of those who repent. But what we are talking about is one who did not repent and died through extirpation.
A majority of merits and a minority of transgressions: they<sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote">The Heavenly Court.</i> let him pay for the minority of transgressions in this world in order to give him his complete recompense in the Future World. A majority of transgressions and a minority of merits: they give him the reward for his merits in this world in order to make him pay completely in the Future World.
He who has a preponderance of merit inherits paradise. He who has a preponderance of sins inherits hell. What if he is in equilibrium? Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, it does not say “He lifts sins” but rather <i>He lifts sin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 34:7" href="/Exodus.34.7"><i>Ex</i>. 34:7</a>, Michal 7:18.</i>. The Holy One, praise to Him, removes one document from the sins and the merits tilt. Rebbi Eleazar said, <i>kindness is Yours, o Master, because You repay everyone according to his deeds</i><sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 62:13" href="/Psalms.62.13"><i>Ps</i>. 62:13</a>.</i>, and if he has none, You give him from Yours. This is the opinion of Rebbi Eleazar, because Rebbi Eleazar said, <i>and much kindness</i><sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 34:7" href="/Exodus.34.7"><i>Ex</i>. 34:7</a>.</i>, He turns towards kindness.
Rebbi Jeremiah said that Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac asked: <i>Justice protects the one on the straight path but sin destroys the sinner</i><sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 13:6" href="/Proverbs.13.6"><i>Prov</i>. 13:6</a>.</i><i>. Evil deeds will pursue the sinner but He will reward the just</i><sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 13:21" href="/Proverbs.13.21"><i>Prov</i>. 13:21</a>.</i>. <i>While He makes scoffers targets of scoffing, He will bestow grace on the meek</i><sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 3:34" href="/Proverbs.3.34"><i>Prov</i>. 3:34</a>.</i><i>. He will watch over the feet of his pious ones, but evildoers will be silent in the darkness</i><sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote"><i>1 Sam</i>.. 2:9.</i><i>. The wise will inherit honor, but shame will mark the stupid ones</i><sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 3:35" href="/Proverbs.3.35"><i>Prov</i>. 3:35</a>.</i>. Fences are made fences and doors doors. Is it so that fences make fences and doors doors? But so it is: Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Samuel ben Rav Isaac: If a person is careful the first, second, and third times not to commit a sin, then in the future the Holy One, praise to Him, will watch over him. What is the reason? <i>All this God will do twice, three times with a man</i><sup class="footnote-marker">19</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 33:29" href="/Job.33.29"><i>Job</i> 33:29</a>.</i>. Rebbi Zeˋira said, but only if the person does not revert [to sin]. What is the reason? It does not say <i>the triple thread</i> “will never snap” but rather <i>will not quickly snap</i><sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 4:12" href="/Ecclesiastes.4.12"><i>Eccl</i>. 4:12</a>.</i>. If you work on it, it will split.
Rebbi Huna said in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: There is no forgetting before the Holy One, but for Israel He becomes forgetful. What is the reason? <i>He forgives sin</i><sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 34:7" href="/Exodus.34.7"><i>Ex</i>. 34:7</a>, Michal 7:18.</i>; “He forgets<sup class="footnote-marker">21</sup><i class="footnote">Identifying the Hebrew root נשׂא “to carry” with the Aramaci נשׂי “to forget.”</i>” is written. And so David said, <i>You forgot Your people, You covered up all their misdeeds, Selah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">22</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 85:3" href="/Psalms.85.3"><i>Ps</i>. 85:3</a>.</i>”.
<sup class="footnote-marker">23</sup><i class="footnote">The same text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yoma 8:7:4-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yoma.8.7.4-5"><i>Yoma</i> 8:8</a> (45b l.70, <b>ו</b>),<i>Ševuot</i> 1:9 (33b l.60, <b>ש</b>); similar texts in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yoma 86a" href="/Yoma.86a">Babli <i>Yoma</i> 86a</a>, Tosephta <i>Yom Hakippurim</i> 5:6, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 18:1-20:23" href="/Exodus.18.1-20.23"><i>Mekhilta dR. Ismael Yitro</i>7</a>, <i>Avot dR. Nathan A</i> 29, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 10:6" href="/Proverbs.10.6"><i>Midrash Mishle</i> 10(6</a>) [<i>Yalqut Šim`ony Jeremiah</i> 269, <i>Wehizhir</i> part 1 p. 54].</i> Rebbi Matthew ben Ḥarash asked Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah in the Academy<sup class="footnote-marker">24</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonian sources he either asked R. Eleazar ben Azariah in Rome or R. Eleazar the Caper grower in Laodicea.</i>. He told him, did you hear the four types of Atonement which Rebbi Ismael explained? He answered him, there are three in addition to repentance. One verse says<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 3:22" href="/Jeremiah.3.22"><i>Jer</i>. 3:22</a>.</i>, <i>return, naughty children, I shall heal your waywardness</i>. But another verse says<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 16:30" href="/Leviticus.16.30"><i>Lev</i>. 16:30</a>.</i>, <i>for on that day, He shall pardon you, to cleanse you</i>. And another verse says<sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 89:33" href="/Psalms.89.33"><i>Ps</i>. 89:33</a>.</i>, <i>I shall visit their crime with the rod, and their iniquity with plagues</i>. And another verse says<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 22:14" href="/Isaiah.22.14"><i>Is</i>. 22:14</a>.</i>, <i>the iniquity of this people shall not be atoned for until you die</i>. How is this? If somebody violates a positive commandment and repents, immediately before he moves from there the Holy One, praise to Him, would forgive him. About this one it says, <i>return, naughty children, I shall heal your waywardness</i>. If one transgresses a prohibition, repentance suspends judgment, and the Day of Atonement pardons. About this one it says, <i>for on that day, He shall pardon you</i>, etc. If one intentionally transgressed [sins punishable by] extirpations or death penalties, repentance and the Day of Atonement pardon half, and sufferings pardon half. About this one it says, <i>I shall visit their crime with the rod</i>, etc. But by whom the Name of Heaven was desecrated, there is no power in repentance to suspend judgment, nor in the Day of Atonement to pardon, nor in sufferings to scour; but repentance and the Day of Atonement pardon a third, and suffering a third, and death scours<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">The root מרק is used in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 6:21" href="/Leviticus.6.21"><i>Lev</i>. 6:21</a> to describe the thorough cleansing of a metal vessel by scouring.<br>In the <i>Ševuot</i> text, punishment for behavior that amounts to Desecration of the Name, i. e., unethical behavior by reputedly religious persons, can be suspended by repentance and the Day of Atonement, but only death in suffering scours.</i> a third. About this one it says, <i>the iniquity of this people shall not be atoned for until you die</i>. From this we learn that death scours.
<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yoma 8:7:4-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yoma.8.7.4-5"><i>Yoma</i> 8:8</a> (45c l.12, <b>ו</b>), <i>Ševuot</i> 1:9 (33b l.75, <b>ש</b>).</i> Rebbi Joḥanan said, these are the words of Rebbi Eleazar ben Azariah, Rebbi Ismael, and Rebbi Aqiba. But the words of the Sages are that the sent-away ram<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">The scapegoat which carries the sins to the desert. The other two sources have a statement that in the absence of a scapegoat the day of Atonement alone pardons. This is necessary for an understanding of the text.</i> pardons. How does it pardon? Rebbi Zeˋira said, by and by. Rebbi Ḥanina said, at the end<sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">The moment when the scapegoat falls down the cliff (אֶרֶץ גְּזֵרָה the cut-off land”), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 16:22" href="/Leviticus.16.22"><i>Lev</i>. 16:22</a>.</i>. What is the difference between them? If somebody died in-between<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote">In the time interval between the High Priest’s confession which puts the sins on the ram and its arrival at the cliff.</i>. In the opinion of Rebbi Zeˋira, he already was pardoned. In the opinion of Rebbi Ḥanina, he was not pardoned. Rebbi Ḥanina said, a <i>baraita</i> supports Rebbi Zeˋira<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Yoma (Lieberman) 4:16" href="/Tosefta_Yoma_(Lieberman).4.16">Tosephta <i>Kippurim</i> 4:16</a>. Rashi deleted the parallel quote from the Babli <i>Ševuo</i> t 13b, <i>s. v</i>. דתניא חומר בשעיר.</i>: There is strength in the ram which is not in the Day of Atonement, and in the Day of Atonement which is not in the ram, for the Day of Atonement pardons without a ram, but the ram does not atone except on the Day of Atonement. There is strength in the ram, for it pardons immediately but the Day of Atonement only at nightfall. Rebbi Huna said, the question was raised before Rebbi Jeremiah<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote">Is not the ram atoning when there is a Temple, the Day of Atonement when there is none?</i> and he said, explain it if they intended to bring another ram but they did not bring it<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">In case the original ram developed a bodily defect before it was sent away, a substitute has to be chosen. If none was found, the Day must pardon even if there is a Temple.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Yose said, but does the Holy One, praise to Him, not see into the future? Then He should pardon immediately<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">The questioner (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:1:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.1.9">Note 35</a>) is correct.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 99a" href="/Sanhedrin.99a">Babli 99a</a>, <i>Sifry Num</i>. 112.</i> It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:31" href="/Numbers.15.31"><i>Num</i>. 15:31</a>.</i>: <i>For he showed contempt for the Eternal’s Word</i>. Not only if he was contemptuous of the teachings of the Torah, from where if he denied one verse, one Aramaic expression, one argument <i>de minore ad majus</i>? The verse says, <i>His command he violated</i>. One verse, <i>Lotan’s sister was Timna`</i><sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 36:22" href="/Genesis.36.22"><i>Gen</i>. 36:22</a>; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 82:15" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.82.15"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 82(15</a>).</i>. One Aramaic expression, <i>Laban called it Yegar Sahadu̅ta̅</i><sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 31:47" href="/Genesis.31.47"><i>Gen</i>. 31:47</a>. In <i>Gen. rabba</i> 72(12) the expression is characterized as Syriac.</i>. One argument <i>de minore ad majus</i>: <i>For Cain would be avenged sevenfold</i>, etc.<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 4:24" href="/Genesis.4.24"><i>Gen</i>. 4:24</a>. While Lemekh’s song violates the formal rules of an argument <i>de minore ad majus</i>, the verse is Divine approval of poetry.</i>.
Another interpretation: That is one who mentions teachings of the Torah at a filthy place. <sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 3:5:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.3.5.9"><i>Berakhot</i> 3:5 (Notes 222–223</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 24b" href="/Berakhot.24b">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 24b</a>.</i> As the following: Rebbi Hila and the colleagues were sitting in front of a hostelry in the evening. They asked, may one say words of the Torah? They said, since if it were daytime we would see what is before us, therefore now it is forbidden.
<sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote">A complete parallel to this paragraph is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Vayikra Rabbah 36:3" href="/Vayikra_Rabbah.36.3"><i>Lev. rabba</i> 36(3</a>); a short reference is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 104a" href="/Sanhedrin.104a">Babli, 104a</a>.</i> Bar Qappara said, Ahaz and all evil kings of Israel have no part in the World to Come. What is the reason? <i>All their kings fell, not one of them calls to Me</i><sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Hosea 7:7" href="/Hosea.7.7"><i>Hos</i>. 7:7</a>. This seems to contradict Misnhah 2, where only two kings of Israel are denied part in the World to Come.</i>. They objected to him: Is he not mentioned in the era<sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ὑπατεία, ἡ, “consulate”, for which years are counted.</i> of kings, <i>in the days of Uzziahu, Yotham, Ahaz, Yeḥizqiahu the kings of Jehudah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 1:1" href="/Isaiah.1.1"><i>Is</i>. 1:1</a>.</i>? He answered them, because he showed shame. How did he show shame? Rebbi Aḥa in the name of Rebbi Eleazar, Rebbi Yose in the name of Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: You find that when the prophet came to accuse him<sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">In the Midrash, “to needle him”. The change from קנטר to קטרג may be a scribal error.</i>, he fled to an impure place and buried his face in an impure place, implying that the Divine Presence does not dwell at an impure place. That is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 7:3" href="/Isaiah.7.3"><i>Is</i>. 7:3</a>.</i>: <i>The Eternal said to Isaiah, please go out towards Aḥaz, you and your son Še’ar Yašuv, to the end of the canal of the upper pond, to the path of the fuller’s field</i>. Do not read <i>fuller’s</i> but <i>suppressing</i><sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">The argument suggests that under the influence of the Greek, שׁ,שׂ,ס all sounded the same.</i>. He hid his face and fled before him. (How is that? When the prophet came to accuse him, he fled to an impure place and buried his face in an impure place.)<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">The repetition of the sentence looks like dittography, but it also appears in the Midrash text.</i> Rebbi Jehudah<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">He is Rebbi. R. Jehudah ben Rabban Simeon, as spelled out in the Midrash and required for chronological reasons.</i> says, because he was made to suffer about his firstborn son. What is the reason? <i>Zimri, the strongman of Ephraim, killed</i><sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 28:7" href="/II_Chronicles.28.7"><i>2Chr</i>. 28:7</a>. The name should be זִכְרִי not זִמְרִי.</i> etc. Rebbi Hoshaia the Elder said, because his father was just. <sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">From here on exists a Genizah fragment (G): L. Ginzberg, <i>Yerushalmi Fragments</i>, New York 1909, pp. 260–264.</i> But was Manasse’s father not just<sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.2.1">Mishnah 2</a> declares that Manasse has no part in the World to Come. It implies that Ahaz has part in the World to Come.</i>? Manasse’s father was just but his son was evil. Hezekias’s father was evil and his son was evil. That is what Hezekias says<sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 38:17" href="/Isaiah.38.17"><i>Is</i>. 38:17</a>.</i>: <i>Behold about peace, bitter is bitter for me</i>. Bitter before me, from Aḥaz. Bitter after me, from Manasse. Aḥaz’s father was just and his son just, that is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">57</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 11:21" href="/Proverbs.11.21"><i>Prov</i>. 11:21</a>. The first part of the verse has differing interpretations below and in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 11:21" href="/Proverbs.11.21"><i>Midrash Prov</i>. 11:21</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 61a" href="/Berakhot.61a">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 61a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Eruvin 18b" href="/Eruvin.18b"><i>Eruvin</i> 18b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 4b" href="/Sotah.4b"><i>Sotah</i> 4b</a>.</i>: <i>hand to hand will not cleanse evil, but the seed of the just will escape</i>. [Rebbi Phineas said.]<sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote">Addition from G. In the Midrash: R. Simon.</i> it is not written “the seed of a just will escape” but <i>the seed of the just will escape</i>. The seed lying<sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote">In G: “planted between” מושתת.</i> between two just men will escape<sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 104a" href="/Sanhedrin.104a">Babli 104a</a> states categorically that the good deeds of the son save the father from judgment but the merits of the father cannot save the son. This is the basis of the <i>Qaddish</i> ritual of modern Judaism.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Vayikra Rabbah 36:3" href="/Vayikra_Rabbah.36.3"><i>Lev. rabba</i> 36(3</a>).</i> Another explanation: <i>Hand to hand will not cleanse evil</i>. Rebbi Phineas said, that is one who gives alms and expects an immediate reward. Rebbi Simon said, like a man who says, here is a sack, here is a tetradrachma, and here is a <i>se`ah</i>, go and fill it. You should know that this is so, for if the patriarchs had demanded to receive the reward in this world for the good deeds which they did, from where would their merit remain for their descendants after them? That is what Moses told Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 26:42" href="/Leviticus.26.42"><i>Lev</i>. 26:42</a>.</i>: <i>I shall remember My covenant with Jacob</i>, etc.
<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Vayikra Rabbah 36:5" href="/Vayikra_Rabbah.36.5"><i>Lev. rabba</i> 36(5</a>).</i> How far did the merit of the forefathers extend? Rebbi Tanḥuma said in the name of the Elder Rebbi Ḥiyya, (Bar) [Rebbi]<sup class="footnote-marker">G</sup> Naḥman said it in the name of Rebbi Berekhiah, Rebbi Ḥelbo in the name of Rebbi Abba bar Zavda, up to Joaḥaz. <i>The Eternal was compassionate about them and had mercy for them</i> etc., <i>up to now</i><sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 13:23" href="/II_Kings.13.23"><i>2K</i>. 13:23</a>.</i>. Up to that moment, the merit of the forefathers existed. Samuel said, up to Hosea’s [time]. <i>But now, I shall uncover her scandalous behavior before the eyes of her lovers, and no man may save her from My hand</i><sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Hosea 2:12" href="/Hosea.2.12"><i>Hos</i>. 2:12</a>.</i>. <i>Man</i> can only mean Abraham, as you say, <i>but now return the</i><i>man’s wife, for he is a prophet</i><sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 20:7" href="/Genesis.20.7"><i>Gen</i>. 20:7</a>.</i>. <i>Man</i> can only mean Isaac, as you say, <i>who is this man coming in the field towards us</i><sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 24:65" href="/Genesis.24.65"><i>Gen</i>. 24:65</a>.</i>? <i>Man</i> can only mean Jacob, as you say, <i>but Jacob was a simple man</i><sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 25:27" href="/Genesis.25.27"><i>Gen</i>. 25:27</a>.</i>. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, up to Elijah: <i>It was when the time of the afternoon service came that Elijah the prophet approached and said, O Eternal, God of Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, today it shall be proclaimed that You are God in Israel and I am Your servant</i><sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 18:36" href="/I_Kings.18.36"><i>1K</i>. 18:36</a>. Since Elijah’s prayer was granted, this gives a <i>terminus post quem</i>.</i> etc. Rebbi Yudan said, up to Hezekias, <i>to increase dominion and peace without end</i><sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 9:6" href="/Isaiah.9.6"><i>Is</i>. 9:6</a>.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sifra Behuqqotai Pereq</i> 7(11), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shemot Rabbah 44:3" href="/Shemot_Rabbah.44.3"><i>Ex. rabba</i> 44(3</a>). The argument really is not about the patriarchs’ merits but about the validity of the Covenant.</i> Rebbi Aḥa said, the merit of the forefathers extends forever: <i>For the Eternal is a Merciful Power</i>, etc., up to <i>and He shall not forget your forefather’s covenant</i><sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 4:31" href="/Deuteronomy.4.31"><i>Deut</i>. 4:31</a>.</i>. This teaches that the covenant was sealed with the tribes. Rebbi Yudan bar Ḥanan in the name of Rebbi Berekhiah: The Holy One, praise to Him, said to Israel: If you see that the merit of the fathers reels, and the merit of the mothers trembles, go and cling to grace.<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 54:10" href="/Isaiah.54.10"><i>Is</i>. 54:10</a>.</i><i>For mountains may reel, and hills tremble; for mountains may reel</i>, this is the fathers’ merit, <i>and hills tremble</i>, this is the mothers’ merit. After that, <i>but My Grace will not leave you and My Covenant of Peace will not reel, says the One Who has mercy on you, the Eternal</i>.
“The Epicurean.” Rebbi Joḥanan and Rebbi Eleazar, one said, like him who said “this book<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">Speaking of the Torah.</i>”, and one said, like him who said “these rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote">In a contemptuous way. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 100a" href="/Sanhedrin.100a">Babli 100a</a>, a person is defined as Epicurean who is not sufficiently respectful towards his teacher.</i>”. Rebbi Eleazar and Rebbi Samuel ben Rebbi Naḥman, one said, [it<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">The influence of an Epicurean.</i> is comparable] to a stone cupola. If one stone is weakened, all are weakened. The other said, [it is comparable] to a house full of chaff. Even if one removes it from there one finds that it weakened the walls.
Rav said, Koraḥ was very rich; the treasury<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">Greek θησαυρός. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 110a" href="/Sanhedrin.110a">Babli 110a</a> Korah found Joseph’s treasures. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 110a" href="/Sanhedrin.110a">Babli 110a</a> he found the treasures of Joseph.</i> of Pharao was discovered by him between Migdol and the Sea.
<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">Similar texts are in <i>Tanhuma Qorah</i> 2 (Buber 4), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bamidbar Rabbah 18:2" href="/Bamidbar_Rabbah.18.2"><i>Num. rabba</i> 18(2</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 11:27" href="/Proverbs.11.27"><i>Midrash Prov</i>. 11(27</a>).</i> Rav said, Koraḥ was an Epicurean. What did he do? He went and made togas completely of blue wool. He came before Moses and asked him, does a toga made completely out of blue wool need <i>ṣiṣit</i>? He answered, it is an obligation since it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:12" href="/Deuteronomy.22.12"><i>Deut</i>. 22:12</a>. While from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 15:37-41" href="/Numbers.15.37-41"><i>Num</i>. 15:37–41</a> one might free a blue toga from exhibiting a blue thread, this verse makes it clear that a knotted appendage is needed.</i>: <i>braids you shall make for yourselves</i>. Does a house full of Torah scrolls need a <i>mezuzah</i>? He answered, it needs a <i>mezuzah</i> since it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:9" href="/Deuteronomy.6.9"><i>Deut</i>. 6:9</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 11:20" href="/Deuteronomy.11.20">11:20</a>.</i>, <i>you shall write them on the door-posts of your house</i>, etc. He asked him, what is the rule for a white spot the size of a bean<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 13:18-23" href="/Leviticus.13.18-23"><i>Lev</i>. 13:18–23</a>. By rabbinic interpretation, a white spot indicates skin disease only if it is at least the size of a Cilician bean.</i>? He answered him, it is impure. If it spread over his entire body? He answered him, it is pure<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 13:13" href="/Leviticus.13.13"><i>Lev</i>. 13:13</a>.</i>. At that moment, Koraḥ said that the Torah is not from Heaven, nor is Moses a [true]<sup class="footnote-marker">G</sup> prophet, nor Aaron a High Priest. <sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bamidbar Rabbah 18:15" href="/Bamidbar_Rabbah.18.15"><i>Num. rabba</i> 18(15</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 11:27" href="/Proverbs.11.27"><i>Midrash Prov</i>. 11(27</a>).</i> Then Moses said, Master of all worlds! If a mouth of the earth had been created during the Six Days of Creation, it is fine. Otherwise it should be created now: <i>If the Eternal would create a Creation</i><sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 16:30" href="/Numbers.16.30"><i>Num</i>. 16:30</a>.</i>.
Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, three [persons] were untrue to their prophetic insights because of <i>ponaria</i><sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>poenariae (scil., actiones)</i> “criminal” (actions), a post-Augustean word (E.G.). The criticism levelled at Moses, Elijah, and Micha (i. e., Michaihu ben Nimla) is that they formulated as a possibility what they prophetically knew was a certainty.</i>, viz., the following: Moses, Elijah, and Micha. Moses said, <i>if an everyman’s death these should die</i><sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 16:29" href="/Numbers.16.29"><i>Num</i>. 16:29</a>.</i>, etc. Elijah said, <i>hear me, o Eternal, hear me, so this people will know</i>, otherwise <i>You would have turned their hearts backwards</i><sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 18:37" href="/I_Kings.18.37"><i>1K</i>. 18:37</a>.</i>. Micha said, <i>if you would return in peace, the Eternal did not speak through me</i><sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 22:28" href="/I_Kings.22.28"><i>1K</i>. 22:28</a>.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 16:33" href="/Numbers.16.33"><i>Num</i>. 16:33</a>.</i><i>They and everything that belonged to them descended alive into the pit</i>. Rebbi Berekhiah in the name of Rebbi Ḥelbo, even their names flew away from their papyrus rolls<sup class="footnote-marker">90a</sup><i class="footnote">Greek τόμος, “piece, roll of papyrus, volume”.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, even one of their needles that was in the hand of an Israel as a loan was swallowed up with them, for it is written: <i>They and everything that belonged to them descended alive into the pit</i>. Who prayed for them? Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman said, Moses prayed for them, <i>Reuben shall live and not die</i><sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 33:6" href="/Deuteronomy.33.6"><i>Deut</i>. 33:6</a>, this refers to Datan and Abiram from the tribe of Reuben.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Midrash Shemuel</i> ed. Buber 5(12).</i> Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, Hannah prayed for them. This is Rebbi Joshua ben Levi’s opinion, as Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said in the name of Rebbi Yose: Koraḥ’s (opinion) [band]<sup class="footnote-marker">G</sup> was continuously sinking until Hannah stood up and said, <i>the Eternal kills and brings to life, He sends down into the pit and lifts</i><sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 2:6" href="/I_Samuel.2.6"><i>1S</i>. 2:6</a>. She was married to a descendant of Korah’s (<i>2 Chr</i>. 6:18–23).</i>.
“Rebbi Aqiba says, also he who reads outside books.” <sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 100b" href="/Sanhedrin.100b">Babli 100b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kohelet Rabbah 12:13" href="/Kohelet_Rabbah.12.13"><i>Eccl. rabba</i> 12(13</a>).</i> For example, the books of Ben Sirach and Ben Laana<sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote">The name of the second, otherwise unknown, author is בן לענא in G and בן תגלא in the Midrash. Rav Saadya Gaon in his <i>Egron</i> (Note 152) seems to read בן עיראי. In the Babli: books of heretics (מינין). The only books forbidden to study are non-canonical books claiming biblical status.</i>. But the books of Homer and all books written from now on, one who reads them is like one who reads a letter. What is the reason? <i>More than these, my son, be careful</i><sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 12:12" href="/Ecclesiastes.12.12"><i>Eccl</i>. 12:12</a>. The reference is to the end of the verse, not quoted here: לַהַג הַרְבֶּה. The quote leads to a digression about <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 12:11" href="/Ecclesiastes.12.11"><i>Eccl</i>. 12:11</a>.</i> etc. They are given to be read, not given for exertion.
<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">The following is a series of homilies on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 12:11" href="/Ecclesiastes.12.11"><i>Eccl</i>. 12:11</a>, without direct connection with the theme of the Chapter; cf Note 96. Parallels are found in <i>Pesiqta rabbati</i> 3 (ed. Ish-Shalom 7b–8a); <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 12:11-12" href="/Ecclesiastes.12.11-12"><i>Midrash Qohelet</i> 12:11–12</a>; <i>Lev. rabba</i> 129(6), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bamidbar Rabbah 13:11-13" href="/Bamidbar_Rabbah.13.11-13"><i>Num. rabba</i> 13:11–13</a>).</i><i>The words of the Sages are like goads;</i> Rebbi Huna said, like a pearl. There, they call a pearl <i>dirah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">In Babylonia one uses the Arabic דּוּרָּה. Read דורה with G.</i>. Another explanation, <i>like goads</i>, like a girl’s ball. Just as this ball is caught from hand to hand but in the end will come to rest in one hand, so “Moses received the Torah from Sinai and transmitted it to Joshua, Joshua to the Elders, the Elders to the Prophets, and the Prophets transmitted it to the Men of the Great Assembly<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Pirkei Avot 1:1" href="/Pirkei_Avot.1.1">Mishnah <i>Avot</i> 1:1</a>.</i>.” Another explanation, <i>like goads</i>. It has three names, <i>mardea`</i>, <i>da̅r</i><sup class="footnote-marker">e</sup><i>va̅n, malmad. Mardea`</i>, because it teaches knowledge to the cow<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">It already is noted in the <i>Pesiqta</i> that מרדע is a Mishnaic, not a biblical word.</i>. <i>Da̅r</i><sup>e</sup><i>va̅n</i>, because it plants understanding in the cow. <i>Malmad</i>, because it teaches the cow to plough, to keep its owners alive. Rebbi Ḥama bar Ḥanina said, if a person makes a goad for his cow, certainly [he has to make one] for his bad inclinations which will remove him from this world and the World to Come.
<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">The following is a series of homilies on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 12:11" href="/Ecclesiastes.12.11"><i>Eccl</i>. 12:11</a>, without direct connection with the theme of the Chapter; cf Note 96. Parallels are found in <i>Pesiqta rabbati</i> 3 (ed. Ish-Shalom 7b–8a); <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 12:11-12" href="/Ecclesiastes.12.11-12"><i>Midrash Qohelet</i> 12:11–12</a>; <i>Lev. rabba</i> 129(6), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bamidbar Rabbah 13:11-13" href="/Bamidbar_Rabbah.13.11-13"><i>Num. rabba</i> 13:11–13</a>).</i><i>And like planted nails</i>. Why does he not say, “like fixed nails and planted trees”? They chose and selected the iron and improved the planting of iron rods. Another explanation, <i>and like planted nails</i>. Just as this nail, once it has been fixed, if you then remove it from its place, its place remains visible; so everybody against whom the rabbis<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">Plural of רִבִּי as recognized by E. S. Rosenthal (M. Cahana in <i>Mehqere Talmud</i> I, ed. Y. Sussman, D. Rosenthal, Jerusalem 1990, p. 6 <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:1:6" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.1.6">Note 17</a>).</i> stretched out their hand<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote">They put him in ban.</i>, even if afterwards they took him back, in the end he will take what is coming to him from their hands. Another explanation, <i>and like planted nails</i>; it is written <i>watches</i><sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. also E. Porath, <i>Mishnaic Hebrew</i>, Jerusalem 1938, p. 130 <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.1.1">Note 4</a>.<br>The <i>watches</i> are the 24 clans of priests (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 24" href="/I_Chronicles.24"><i>1Chr</i>. 24</a>), each of which was serving in the Temple for one week.</i>. Since there are 24 watches, there should be 24 nails<sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">The following has a parallel in <i>Šabbat</i> 6:1 (8a l. 21 ff.), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 60b" href="/Shabbat.60b">Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 60b</a>. It is forbidden to wear nail-studded work-boots on the Sabbath. But it is permitted to wear shoes decorated with nails. There are different traditions about the number of nails which will constitute a decoration.</i>. How many nails should it have? Rebbi Joḥanan said five, corresponding to the five books of the Torah. Rebbi Ḥinena said seven, <i>corresponding to your days are your steps</i><sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 33:24" href="/Deuteronomy.33.24"><i>Deut</i>. 33:24</a>.</i>. Rebbi Aḥa explained following Rebbi Ḥanina: nine. Rebbi put eleven on one [shoe] and thirteen on the other, for the number of watches. Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, a crooked nail is not counted with the nails<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli, the equivalent of כלבת is כלבוס.</i>. Rebbi Abba bar Zavda asked before Rebbi Zeˋira<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote">For reasons of chronology, one has to switch the position of the names, as in <i>Šabbat</i>: The third generation R. Zeˋira asked the second generation R. Abba bar Zavda. Here ends the Genizah fragment.</i>: may one put all of them on one boot? He told him, it is permitted. May one put all of them on one sandal? He told him, it is permitted. It was stated: One does not scrape<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">Again this belongs to the rules of the Sabbath (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 141b" href="/Shabbat.141b">Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 141b</a>); it is forbidden to scrape off dirt from one’s shoes on the Sabbath.</i> old boots or sandals but one may anoint them or dip them in water. Rebbi Crispus in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The students of the Elder Rebbi Ḥiyya say that those of first rank said, one may scrape, those of second rank said, one may not scrape. They asked Rebbi, who told them, one does not scrape. Rebbi Zeˋira said, here goes one of the students of the Elder Rebbi Ḥiyya<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Rebbi certainly is of the authorities of first rank.</i>. Rebbi Ḥiyya bar Ashi said, we used to sit before Rav and were anointing and rinsing, but not scraping. It was stated: A person should wear new boots and sandals only if he walked in them during daytime<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">On Friday.</i>. How far should he walk? The people from the house of Bar Qappara said, from the House of Study of Bar Qappara to the House of Study of Rebbi Hoshaia<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">In the village of Dabbara (Golan) where the lintel of Bar Qappara’s House of Study was excavated.</i>. The Sepphoreans say, from the Babylonian synagogue to Rebbi Ḥama bar Ḥanina’s house. The Tiberians say, from the Academy to Rebbi Hoshaia’s store. It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">The following is from <i>Ševi`it</i> 8:8, Notes 119–124. Olive oil produced in the Sabbatical year has to be used for the personal needs of man or animal; it is permitted to use it to daub one’s body but not to prepare leather or leather products.</i>: Nobody should anoint his foot in a shoe or sandal but he may anoint his foot and step into his shoe or his sandal. One may anoint himself and roll on a tarpaulin without worry. One should not put it on a marble slab to roll himself in it, but Rabban Gamliel permits it. Another explanation, <i>and like planted nails</i>. If words about Torah are spelled out clearly by their authors, they are sweet to their listeners like well-ordered saplings. But if they come out confused, they are as bitter for their listeners as nails.
<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">The following is a series of homilies on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 12:11" href="/Ecclesiastes.12.11"><i>Eccl</i>. 12:11</a>, without direct connection with the theme of the Chapter; cf Note 96. Parallels are found in <i>Pesiqta rabbati</i> 3 (ed. Ish-Shalom 7b–8a); <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 12:11-12" href="/Ecclesiastes.12.11-12"><i>Midrash Qohelet</i> 12:11–12</a>; <i>Lev. rabba</i> 129(6), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bamidbar Rabbah 13:11-13" href="/Bamidbar_Rabbah.13.11-13"><i>Num. rabba</i> 13:11–13</a>).</i><i>Masters of assembly</i><sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote">The translation chosen follows the explanation given here as second possibility. Rashi (following Dunash), Ibn Janah, and Qimhi: “collectors.” Levy/Torczyner: “set in frames.”</i>. “Assembly” only means the Synhedrion, as you say: <i>Assemble for Me seventy men from the Elders of Israel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 11:16" href="/Numbers.11.16"><i>Num</i>. 11:16</a>.</i>. Another explanation, <i>masters of assembly</i>, it was said in an assembly. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, if somebody told me that Chronicles<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">Not the book of Chronicles but a coherent interpretation of its genealogical part, known as ‘book of genealogies” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 62b" href="/Pesachim.62b">Babli <i>Pesahim</i> 62b</a>).</i> was to be found in Babylonia, I would go and fetch it from there. But now, if all our rabbis came together, they could not bring it from there.
<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote">The following is a series of homilies on <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 12:11" href="/Ecclesiastes.12.11"><i>Eccl</i>. 12:11</a>, without direct connection with the theme of the Chapter; cf Note 96. Parallels are found in <i>Pesiqta rabbati</i> 3 (ed. Ish-Shalom 7b–8a); <a class="refLink" data-ref="Ecclesiastes 12:11-12" href="/Ecclesiastes.12.11-12"><i>Midrash Qohelet</i> 12:11–12</a>; <i>Lev. rabba</i> 129(6), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bamidbar Rabbah 13:11-13" href="/Bamidbar_Rabbah.13.11-13"><i>Num. rabba</i> 13:11–13</a>).</i><i>They were given from one shepherd</i>. The Holy One<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote">One has to add, “praise to him.”</i> said, if you heard something<sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote">An explanation of a topic in the Torah.</i> from the most insignificant one of Israel and it gave you satisfaction, it should not be in your eyes as if you heard it from an insignificant one but from an important one; and not as if you heard it from an important one but from a Sage; and not as if you heard it from a Sage but from a prophet; and not as if you heard it from a prophet but from a shepherd (and shepherd only means Moses, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 63:11" href="/Isaiah.63.11"><i>Is</i>. 63:11</a>.</i>: <i>He remembered the days of old, Moses with his people; where is He Who brought them up from the Sea with his people’s shepherd; where is He Who gave His Holy Spirit in its midst</i>); not as if you heard it from a shepherd but from Divinity. <i>They were given from one shepherd</i>, but “One” is only the Holy One, praise to Him, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:4" href="/Deuteronomy.6.4"><i>Deut</i>. 6:4</a>.</i>: <i>Hear, o Israel, the Eternal is our God, the Eternal is One</i>.
“One who whispers over a wound and says, <i>any sickness that I put on Egypt I shall not put on you, for I am the Eternal, your Healer</i>.” Rav said, only one who spits. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, even if he only said, <i>damage by skin disease if it be on a human</i><sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 15:26" href="/Leviticus.15.26"><i>Lev</i>. 15:26</a>.</i> and spits, he has no part in the Future World<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Using verses as part of magical rites is an unpardonable sin (in the absence of genuine repentance.)</i>.
Abba Shaul said, also one who pronounces the Name<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote">YHWH, whose vocalization does not follow grammatical rules. In cabbalistic invocations of the Name, therefore, one never mentions the letters of the Name in straight sequence but says: YH <i>in</i> WH.</i> by its letters. Rebbi Mana said, for example, those swearing Samaritans<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">It is not known what Samaritans did in those days. Modern Samaritans use the equivalent of <i>the Name</i> for all mentions of the Name.</i>. Rebbi Jacob bar Aḥa said, it is written as <i>yod he</i> but read as <i>alef dalet</i><sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">The Name has to be pronounced as if written אדני. It seems that he prohibits <i>any</i> pronunciation of YHWH even if demonstrably unhistorical (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:1:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.1.4"><i>Berakhot</i> 1:1, Note 14</a>.)</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> Three kings and four private persons have no part in the Future World<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">The Name has to be pronounced as if written אדני. It seems that he prohibits <i>any</i> pronunciation of YHWH even if demonstrably unhistorical (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:1:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.1.4"><i>Berakhot</i> 1:1, Note 14</a>.)</i>. Three kings: Ahab, Jeroboam, Manasse. Rebbi Jehudah says, Manasse has part in the Future World, as it is said:<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 33:13" href="/II_Chronicles.33.13"><i>2Chr</i>. 33:13</a>.</i> <i>he prayed to Him. He let Himself be petitioned, and heard his supplications, and returned him to Jerusalem, to his kingdom</i>. They told him, He returned him to his kingdom; He did not return him to life in the Future World<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">R. Jehudah’s position is that of the author of Chronicles, the rabbis’ that of the author of <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 21" href="/II_Kings.21">Kings (<i>2K</i>. 21</a>).</i>. Four private persons: Bileam and Doëg<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">While in the Talmudim <i>Doëg the Edomite</i> is treated as a Jew, his being grouped in the Yerushalmi Mishnah with the Midianite Bileam, separate from the two Israelites, may indicate that for the Yerushalmi Mishnah Gentiles (at least those who are descendants of Abraham) have part in the Future World unless they act to lose it.</i>, Aḥitophel<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">The sin is not new; for the Yerushalmi Jeroboam has part in the World to Come.</i> and Gehazi<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Not a single golden calf but 13.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “Three kings and four private persons,” etc. All of these invented new kinds of sins.
So what did Jeroboam do<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">To commit a new kind of sin.</i>? Because he made two golden calves. But did Israel not make many calves<sup class="footnote-marker">130</sup><i class="footnote">The sin is not new; for the Yerushalmi Jeroboam has part in the World to Come.</i>? Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai stated: Thirteen calves did Israel make<sup class="footnote-marker">131</sup><i class="footnote">Not a single golden calf but 13.</i>; of these one was common property<sup class="footnote-marker">132</sup><i class="footnote">Greek δημόσιος, -α, -ον, adj. “belonging to the people”. Also used as noun.</i> to all of them. What is the reason? <i>They said, these are your gods, Israel</i><sup class="footnote-marker">133</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 32:4" href="/Exodus.32.4"><i>Ex</i>. 32:4</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 32:8" href="/Exodus.32.8">8</a>.</i>; this refers to the twelve tribes. <i>This is your god</i><sup class="footnote-marker">134</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Nehemiah 9:18" href="/Nehemiah.9.18"><i>Neh</i>. 9:18</a>.</i>, i. e., one common property for all of them.
So what did Aḥab do<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">To commit a new kind of sin.</i>? It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">135</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 16:31" href="/I_Kings.16.31"><i>1K</i>. 16:31</a>.</i>: <i>If it would have been too easy to follow the sins of Jeroboam ben Nevat</i>. Are not the light sins of Aḥab the serious sins of Jeroboam? Why was Jeroboam counted first<sup class="footnote-marker">136</sup><i class="footnote">This shows that the Mishnah underlying the Halakhah was not the Mishnah as quoted in the ms. but followed the order of the Yerushalmi: Jeroboam, Ahab, Manasse.</i>? Because he started the misconduct. What did Aḥab do? He adorned himself every day and stood before his army commander<sup class="footnote-marker">137</sup><i class="footnote">The word probably represents Greek στρατηλάτης “army commander”.</i> Ḥiel, asking him, for how much am I good today? He answered him, so and so much; then he donated its value<sup class="footnote-marker">138</sup><i class="footnote">Greek τίμησις “estimation, valuation”.</i> to foreign worship. That is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">139</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 21:20" href="/I_Kings.21.20"><i>1K</i>. 21:20</a>.</i> <i>Because you sold yourself to do evil in the Eternal’s eyes</i>. Rebbi Levi continued for six months to explain the following verse to shame<sup class="footnote-marker">140</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 21:25" href="/I_Kings.21.25"><i>1K</i>. 21:25</a>.</i> <i>There never was anyone like Aḥab who sold himself to do evil in the Eternal’s eyes</i>. He came to him at night<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">This shows that Ahab has part in the World to come, against the Mishnah.</i> and asked him, how did I sin against you, what did I do before you? You have the first part of the verse, but you do not have the end of the verse: <i>whom his wife Jezebel had misguided</i>. He<sup class="footnote-marker">142</sup><i class="footnote">R. Levi.</i> continued for six months to explain it as praise, <i>only one should not be like Aḥab … whom his wife Jezebel had misguided</i>.
It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 16:34" href="/I_Kings.16.34"><i>1K.</i> 16:34</a>; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 113a" href="/Sanhedrin.113a">Babli 113a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 14:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.14.2">Tosephta 14:6–9</a>.</i>: <i>In his days did Ḥiel from Bet-El build Jericho; with his first-born Aviram he set the foundation and with his youngest son Seguv he put in the doors</i>. Ḥiel is from the descendants of Josaphat<sup class="footnote-marker">144</sup><i class="footnote">Identifying this Hiel with Yehiel, <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 21:2" href="/II_Kings.21.2"><i>2K.</i>21:2</a>.</i>, Jericho is in the territory of Benjamin. Only that good deeds are put in the hands of the worthy and bad deeds in the hands of the unworthy; therefore, it is said, <i>with his first-born Aviram he set the foundation and with his youngest son Seguv he put in the doors</i>.
