If it was not appropriate for him to learn from his firstborn Aviram, should he not have learned from the wicked Seguv<sup class="footnote-marker">145</sup><i class="footnote">The death of the firstborn could have been an accident; the death of the youngest certainly must be ascribed to Joshua’s curse. (It is presumed here that the children died a natural death, not that they were killed by their father as building sacrifice.)</i>? Because they wanted to make more money<sup class="footnote-marker">146</sup><i class="footnote">The rebuilding of Jericho was a real estate investment.</i>, the curse ruled over them and they were continuously weakened to confirm what was said<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 16:34" href="/I_Kings.16.34"><i>1K.</i> 16:34</a>; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 113a" href="/Sanhedrin.113a">Babli 113a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 14:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.14.2">Tosephta 14:6–9</a>.</i>, <i>following the word of the Eternal, the God of Israel, which He had spoken through Joshua ben Nun</i>. It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">147</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 17:1" href="/I_Kings.17.1"><i>1K.</i> 17:1</a>, the verse immediately following 16:34; the medieval division into chapters is misleading.</i>: <i>Elijah the Tisbite, from the inhabitants of Gilead, said to Aḥab: By the Living Eternal, the God of Israel, before Whom I stood, there will not be dew or rain in the coming years except by my word</i>. What is the connection between these<sup class="footnote-marker">148</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 17:1" href="/I_Kings.17.1"><i>1K.</i> 17:1</a>, and <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 16:34" href="/I_Kings.16.34"><i>1K.</i> 16:34</a>.</i>? The Holy One, praise to Him, had said to Elijah: this Ḥiel is an important personality, go and pay a visit of condolence. He answered, I do not want to go. He asked, why? He said, for if I go and they say things that enrage You, I shall not be able to bear it. He told him, If they say anything that would enrage Me, anything that you decide I shall fulfill. He went and found them discussing the verse<sup class="footnote-marker">149</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 6:26" href="/Joshua.6.26"><i>Jos.</i>6:26</a>.</i>: <i>At that time, Joshua imprecated as follows: Cursed be the man before the Eternal who would build this town, Jericho; with his first-born he shall put in the foundation and with his youngest set the doors</i>. He said, praised be the God of the just, Who fulfills the words of the just. Aḥab also was there. Aḥab said to them, who is greater, Moses or Joshua? They told him, Moses. He said to them, in Moses’s Torah it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">150</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 11:16-17" href="/Deuteronomy.11.16-17"><i>Deut.</i> 11:16–17</a>.</i>: <i>Watch yourselves, lest your hearts be seduced, you deviate, and worship other powers and bow down before them</i>. What is written next? <i>The rage of the Eternal will burn against you, He will lock up the sky and there will be no rain</i>. But I did not leave any strange worship that I would not have worshipped, and all good and comforting things came in my generation. He did not uphold the words of Moses; would He uphold Joshua’s words? Elijah told him, it is as you say, <i>by the Living Eternal, the God of Israel, before Whom I stood, there will not be dew or rain in the coming years except by my word</i>. When he heard this, he started crying. That is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">151</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 21:27" href="/I_Kings.21.27"><i>1K.</i> 21:27</a>. This belongs to the Nabot affair, not the drought.</i>: <i>When Aḥab heard these words, he tore his garments, put sackcloth on his flesh, fasted, slept in sackcloth and went at</i>. How long did he fast? He fasted for three hours. If he was used to eat at 6 o’clock, he ate at noontime. If he was used to eat at noontime, he ate at three p.m. <i>He went at</i>. What is <i>at</i>? Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, he went barefoot<sup class="footnote-marker">152</sup><i class="footnote">The early Medieval translator Daud ben Abraham Alfasi in his <i>Jamuˋ</i> (S. L. Skoss, <i>Kitab Jamuˋ Al Alfāz</i>, New Haven 1935) accepts the Jerushalmi’s explanation. Rav Saadya Gaon (נחמיה אלוני, האגרון לדב סעדיה גאון, י־ם תשכט) translates אט as رفق “to be sweet. Compare Arabic اطّ “to creak, to groan”.</i>. It is written:<sup class="footnote-marker">153</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 21:28-29" href="/I_Kings.21.28-29"><i>1K.</i>21:28–29</a>.</i> <i>The word of the Eternal went to Elijah the Tisbite as follows: Did you see that Aḥab surrendered before me</i>? The Holy One, praise to Him, said to Elijah: See the good part which I put in My world. A person may sin greatly before Me, but if he repents I am accepting him<sup class="footnote-marker">141</sup><i class="footnote">This shows that Ahab has part in the World to come, against the Mishnah.</i>. That is what is written, <i>did you see that Aḥab surrendered before Me?</i> You saw that Aḥab repented. <i>Because Aḥab surrendered before me, I shall not bring the evil in his days; in his son’s days I shall bring the evil over his dynasty.</i>
<sup class="footnote-marker">154</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 42:4" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.42.4"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 42(4</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Vayikra Rabbah 11" href="/Vayikra_Rabbah.11"><i>Esther rabba Introduction, Lev. rabba</i> 11</a>, <i>Ruth rabba</i>1(7).</i> But what did Aḥaz do? He built a throne in the Temple Court. That is what is written: “The throne-hall which they built in the Temple,<sup class="footnote-marker">155</sup><i class="footnote">This exists no such verse. Probably, as indicated by <i>Qorban ha ˋEdah,</i> the reference is to <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 16:18" href="/II_Kings.16.18"><i>2K.</i> 16:18</a>: The Sabbath shelter which they had built in the temple …”</i>” etc. Rebbi Onias in the name of Rebbi Eleazar. Why is he called “the grabber<sup class="footnote-marker">156</sup><i class="footnote">אחז “to grab”.</i>”? For he grabbed synagogues and houses of study<sup class="footnote-marker">157</sup><i class="footnote">To close them down.</i>. To what may Aḥaz be compared? To a king who had a son whom he entrusted to his pedagogue<sup class="footnote-marker">158</sup><i class="footnote">Greek παιδαγωγός, the slave accompanying the child.</i>. The latter wanted to kill him. He said, if I kill him, I will be put to death. But I shall draw his wet-nurse away from him and he will die of himself. So Aḥaz said, if there are no kid goats there are no he-goats. If there are no he-goats there are no goats. If there are no goats there is no shepherd<sup class="footnote-marker">159</sup><i class="footnote">God.</i>. If there is no shepherd there is no world; if it were thinkable that there be no world. So Aḥaz was thinking, if there are no children<sup class="footnote-marker">160</sup><i class="footnote">Going to school.</i> there are no adults. If there are no adults, there are no Sages. If there are no Sages, there are no prophets. If there are no prophets, there is no Holy Spirit. If there is no Holy Spirit, there are no synagogues and no houses of study. If it were thinkable, the Holy One, praise to Him, will not let His Presence rest over Israel. Rebbi Jacob bar Abbai in the name of Rebbi Aḥa brings it from the following<sup class="footnote-marker">161</sup><i class="footnote">That Ahaz had eliminated all religious instruction, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 8:17" href="/Isaiah.8.17"><i>Is.</i> 8:17</a>.</i> <i>I shall wait for the Eternal, Who hid His Face from the House of Jacob, and put my hope in Him.</i> There was no worse moment in the world than when the Holy One, praise to Him, said to Moses<sup class="footnote-marker">162</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 31:18" href="/Deuteronomy.31.18"><i>Deut.</i> 31:18</a>.</i>: <i>I shall certainly hide My Face at that time.</i> From that moment on, <i>I put my hope in Him,</i> Who said at Sinai,<sup class="footnote-marker">163</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 31:21" href="/Deuteronomy.31.21"><i>Deut.</i> 31:21</a>. This was not said at Sinai but in the steppes of Moab; it is a promise that the study of Torah will never cease.</i> <i>for it shall not be forgotten by his descendants.</i> What would its use be<sup class="footnote-marker">164</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 8:18" href="/Isaiah.8.18"><i>Is.</i> 8:18</a>. A different interpretation in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 19b" href="/Sanhedrin.19b">Babli 19b</a>.</i>? <i>Behold, I and the children which the Eternal has given me.</i> Were they his children? Were they not his students? But this teaches he loved them as if they were his sons and called them “my sons”.
What did Manasse do? It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">165</sup><i class="footnote"><i>2K.</i> 20:1, <i>Is.</i> 38:1.</i>: <i>In these days, Hezekias became critically ill,</i> etc., <i>for you will die, you will not live. For you will die,</i> in this world, <i>you will not live,</i> in the Future World. He asked him, why? He answered him, because you did not want to have children<sup class="footnote-marker">166</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 10a" href="/Berakhot.10a">Babli <i>Berakhot</i> 10a</a>.</i>. He asked him, why do you not want to have children? He answered him, I saw that I will have an evil son; therefore, I do not want to have children. He told him, marry my daughter<sup class="footnote-marker">167</sup><i class="footnote">Manasse was born after Hezekias’s illness; his mother’s name is given without patronymic.</i>, maybe descending from me and you he will become a good person. Nevertheless the result was only a bad person. That is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">168</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 32:7" href="/Isaiah.32.7"><i>Is.</i> 32:7</a>.</i>, <i>but my vessels, his vessels are bad.</i> He told him, I am not listening to you, I only am jumping on what my ancestor said, who told me<sup class="footnote-marker">169</sup><i class="footnote">A slightly different version is in <i>Taˋaniot</i> 2:1 (65b l.3), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kohelet Rabbah 7:29" href="/Kohelet_Rabbah.7.29"><i>Eccl. rabba</i> 7(29</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 6:9-11:32" href="/Genesis.6.9-11.32"><i>Tanhuma Noah</i> 8</a>. The Yerushalmi version is the basis of a central piece of the Ashkenazic service of New Year’s day (in the Eastern European version also of the Day of Atonement). The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Rosh Hashanah 16b" href="/Rosh_Hashanah.16b">Babli version (<i>Roš Haššanah</i> 16b</a>) is quite different.</i>, if you see bad dreams or bad visions do jump onto three things and you will be saved. These are: prayer, giving alms, and repentance. All three from one verse<sup class="footnote-marker">170</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 7:14" href="/II_Chronicles.7.14"><i>2Chr.</i> 7:14</a>.</i>: <i>If My people, over whom My Name is called, are subdued and they will pray,</i> that refers to prayer, <i>and they will ask before me,</i> that refers to giving alms, as you say<sup class="footnote-marker">171</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 17:15" href="/Psalms.17.15"><i>Ps.</i> 17:15</a>.</i>, <i>I, by giving alms, shall see Your Face, I shall be satiated in waking by Your image. They shall repent their evil ways,</i> that is repentance. If they did this, what is written there? <i>I shall listen from Heaven, forgive their sins, and heal their land.</i> Immediately, he turned, as is written.
<sup class="footnote-marker">172</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 38:2" href="/Isaiah.38.2"><i>Is.</i> 38:2</a>.</i><i>Hezekiah turned his face to the wall.</i> Which wall did he lift his eyes to? Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, he lifted his eyes to Raḥab’s wall, <i>for her house was on the wall of the fortification; she lived on the wall.</i> He said before Him: Master of all worlds, Raḥab saved two souls for You, and see how many souls You saved for her. That is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">174</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Jos</i>.6:25.</i>: <i>The youths, the spies, came and led out Raḥab, and her father’s house, and her mother, and her brothers, and all of hers, and all her families they brought out and left them outside of Israel’s camp.</i> Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai stated, even if her family was 200 persons strong and they furthermore were related to other families, all of whom were saved by her merit. My forefathers who brought to You all these proselytes so much more that You should spare my life.
Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman said, he lifted his eyes to the wall of the woman from Sunem, as it was said<sup class="footnote-marker">175</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 4:10" href="/II_Kings.4.10"><i>2K</i>. 4:10</a>.</i>: <i>Let us make a small upper storey on the wall and put there a bed, a table, a chair, and a lamp.</i> He said before Him: Master of all worlds, the woman from Sunem made one wall for Elisha and You revived her son. My forefathers who built for You all this glory, so much more that You should spare my life.
Rebbi Ḥinena bar Pappus said, he lifted his eyes to the wall of the Temple. <sup class="footnote-marker">176</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 43:8" href="/Ezekiel.43.8"><i>Ez</i>. 43:8</a>.</i><i>When they put their lintel next to My lintel, their doorposts next to My doorpost, with the wall between Me and them.</i> They were important people; they could not go and pray in the Temple every time, so they prayed in their house and the Holy One, praise to Him, considers it as if they had prayed in the Temple. My forefathers who built for You all this glory, so much more that You should spare my life.
But the rabbis say, he lifted his eyes to the walls of his heart. <sup class="footnote-marker">177</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 4:19" href="/Jeremiah.4.19"><i>Jer.</i> 4:19</a>.</i><i>My innards, my innards I make tremble, the walls of my heart are in uproar; my heart is beating inside me, I cannot be silent.</i> He said before Him: Master of the world, I checked all my 248 limbs<sup class="footnote-marker">178</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Oholot 1:8" href="/Mishnah_Oholot.1.8">Mishnah <i>Ahilut</i> 1:8</a>.</i> that You gave me and I did not find one of them I offended you with; so much more that You should spare my life.
It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">179</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 20:4-5" href="/II_Kings.20.4-5"><i>2K.</i> 20:4–5</a>.</i>: <i>The Word of the Eternal was to the prophet Isaiah as follows: Go and tell Hezekias, My people’s leader</i>…<i>so says the Eternal, your ancestor David’s God, I heard your prayer, I saw your tear; now I am adding fifteen years to your days.</i> He told Him, first I told him one way, now I have to tell him this? He told Him, he is a great personality and will not believe me. He answered him, he is a very meek person and will believe you. Not only that, but the rumor has not yet spread in the city: <i>Isaiah had not yet left the middle courtyard;</i> “city” is written<sup class="footnote-marker">180</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Courtyard</i> is <i>Qere, city</i> is <i>Ketib.</i> The rumor is that Isaiah told the king that he would die. The prophet does not have to fear that his credibility was impaired.</i>.
When Manasse became king, he was wild<sup class="footnote-marker">181</sup><i class="footnote">This word may be read either as Aramaized פֶּרֶא “wild” or as Latin <i>ferus</i>“wild” (E. G.).</i> after Isaiah; he wanted to kill him, but he fled before him. He fled to a cedar tree, the cedar swallowed him, except to a <i>ṣiṣit</i> of his coat. They came and reported it before him. He said, go and cut down the cedar. They cut down the cedar and blood was seen flowing<sup class="footnote-marker">182</sup><i class="footnote">The story is hinted at in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 103b" href="/Sanhedrin.103b">Babli 103b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 49b" href="/Yevamot.49b"><i>Yebamot</i> 49b</a>.</i>. <i>But the Eternal did not want to pardon</i><sup class="footnote-marker">183</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 24:4" href="/II_Kings.24.4"><i>2K</i>. 24:4</a>.</i>: from here that he has no part in the Future World. How is it possible for flesh and blood to fill Jerusalem with innocent blood from mouth to mouth? But he slew Isaiah who was equal to Moses, about whom is written<sup class="footnote-marker">188</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 12:8" href="/Numbers.12.8"><i>Num.</i> 12:8</a>.</i>: <i>Mouth to mouth I would speak to him.</i>

<sup class="footnote-marker">199</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Sifry Num.</i> 131–132 (<i>Yalqut Hosea</i>526). That is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">200</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 25:15" href="/Numbers.25.15"><i>Num.</i> 25:15</a>.</i>: <i>he is the head of related tribes in Midian.</i> What did they do? They built dining rooms<sup class="footnote-marker">201</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>coenaculum</i> “upper storey room; dining room; garret”. They put an old woman outside and a young girl inside. Israel were eating and drinking. If one of them went to stroll around, to buy himself something from the grocer, the old woman would offer to sell to him for the going price, but the girl told him, come and take it for less. This happened that first day, the second day, the third day. After that, she told him, from now on you are like a member of the family; enter and select for yourself. When he entered, there was a pitcher full of wine, of the strong Ammonite wine which seduces the body to whoring. Its smell was seething and (Gentile wine) [libation wine] was not yet forbidden for Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">204</sup><i class="footnote">The text in parenthesis is the scribe’s original text, the one in brackets his correction. Formally, the original text is the only correct one. Wine used in idolatrous libations is forbidden for all usufruct as חֶרֶם, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:18" href="/Deuteronomy.13.18"><i>Deut.</i> 13:18</a>. The prohibition of the consumption of other Gentile wine is attributed to Daniel (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Daniel 1:8" href="/Daniel.1.8"><i>Dan.</i> 1:8</a>); it is not Mosaic. The corrected text and its parallel sequel adopt popular language which calls יַיִן נֶסֶךְ what correctly should be called סְתָם יֵינָם “their unspecified wine”.</i>. She told him, maybe you want to drink a cup of wine? He answered her, yes. She gave to him and he drank. When he drank, the wine was burning in him like a viper’s poison<sup class="footnote-marker">205</sup><i class="footnote">Read כריסה.</i>; he told her, consent to me. She told him, do you want me to consent to you? He answered, yes. Immediately she took out a shape of Peˋor from her bosom and told him, bow down before this one and I shall consent to you. But he answered her, should I bow down before foreign worship? She told him, you do not bow down, you only strip for it. This is what the Sages said<sup class="footnote-marker">206</sup><i class="footnote">Mishnah 7:12 (Notes 238,239).</i>, “one who defecates in front of <i>Baal Peˋor</i> follows its worship. One who throws a stone at a statue of Mercury follows its worship.” <sup class="footnote-marker">207</sup><i class="footnote">Duplication of previous text.</i> There was a pitcher full of wine, of the strong Ammonite wine which seduces the body to whoring. Rebbi Eleazar said, just as a nail cannot be taken out of a door without [loss of] wood, so it is impossible to get rid of <i>Peˋor</i> without [loss of] life. It happened that Sabbatai from Ulam leased his donkey to a Gentile woman to bow down before <i>Peˋor.</i> When they arrived at <i>Peˋor’s</i> temple, she told him, wait here for me while I am entering and bowing down before <i>Peˋor.</i> After she came out, he told her, wait here for me while I am entering and do what you did. What did he do? He entered, relieved himself, and cleansed himself on <i>Peˋor</i>’s nose. All were praising him and said, nobody yet had done what this man did<sup class="footnote-marker">209</sup><i class="footnote">He committed a deadly sin of idol worship while intending to debase the idol.</i>. It happened that Menaḥem from Guvta-Ariaḥ was occupied with amphoras when the spirit of <i>Peˋor</i> came to him in the night. What did he do? He took a spit, stood up against him; he fled. He came to him in the second night and asked him, Menaḥem, why do you curse me? He was afraid of him and promised him, I shall not curse you in the future<sup class="footnote-marker">210</sup><i class="footnote">The story is fragmentary. It may be influenced by Christian beliefs that the old gods were turned into demons.</i>. It happened that a ruler came from overseas to bow down before <i>Peˋor.</i> He told them, bring one bull, one ram, and one sheep, to bow down before <i>Peˋor.</i> They told him, you have no need for all of these; you only have to strip yourself for him. What did he do? He provoked סניגורים<sup class="footnote-marker">211</sup><i class="footnote">Elsewhere, סניגור is συνήγορος “advocate, intercessor”. In <i>Sifry</i> סנגדודים, in <i>Yalqut</i> סנגלרים. According to the context, pretorians must be intended.</i> against them; they were hitting them and smashing their brains with bats, saying to them: woe to you and your error.
It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">212</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 25:3-4" href="/Numbers.25.3-4"><i>Num.</i> 25:3–4</a>.</i> <i>The rage of the Eternal was kindled against Israel. The Eternal said to Moses: Take all the heads of the people and hang them for the Eternal before the sun.</i> What he told him was, install their heads as judges over them and let them execute the sinners<sup class="footnote-marker">213</sup><i class="footnote">Not the heads; cf. the Targumim.</i> at daytime. That is what is written: <i>Moses told the judges of Israel: each one should kill his men who cling to the Baˋal Peˋor</i><sup class="footnote-marker">214</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 25:5" href="/Numbers.25.5"><i>Num</i>. 25:5</a>.</i>. How many were the judges of Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">215</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 1:4:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.1.4.5">Halakhah 1:7, Note 356</a>.</i>? 78’600. Heads of thousands, 600. Heads of hundreds, 6'000. Heads of fifties, 12’000. heads of tens, 60’000. It turns out that the judges of Israel were 78’600. He told them, each of you should execute two. It turns out that the number of the killed was 157’200. <i>Behold, a man from the Children of Israel came and introduced to his brothers the Midianite woman, to the eyes of Moses</i><sup class="footnote-marker">216</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 25:6" href="/Numbers.25.6"><i>Num.</i> 25:6</a>.</i>. What means <i>to the eyes of Moses</i><sup class="footnote-marker">217</sup><i class="footnote">The text does not say <i>before his eyes</i> but <i>in his eyes.</i></i>? Like a man who says, that is in your eyes, Moses. He told him, is not Ẓippora a Midianite, and are not her hooves split<sup class="footnote-marker">218</sup><i class="footnote">The sign of a kosher animal.</i>? This one is pure, that one is impure? There, Phineas was present. He said, is there nobody who would kill him or be killed? Where are the lions? <i>A lion whelp is Jehudah</i><sup class="footnote-marker">219</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 49:9" href="/Genesis.49.9"><i>Gen.</i> 49:9</a>.</i><i>; Dan is a lion whelp</i><sup class="footnote-marker">220</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 33:22" href="/Deuteronomy.33.22"><i>Deut.</i> 33:22</a>.</i><i>; Benjamin a rapacious wolf</i><sup class="footnote-marker">221</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 49:27" href="/Genesis.49.27"><i>Gen.</i> 49:27</a>.</i>. When Phineas saw that nobody of Israel did anything, he immediately rose from his court, took the spear in his hand, and put its iron under his belt<sup class="footnote-marker">222</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>fascia</i> “band, girdle”.</i>. He was leaning on its wood until he arrived at his door. When he arrived at his<sup class="footnote-marker">223</sup><i class="footnote">Zimri ben Salu’s.</i> door, they<sup class="footnote-marker">224</sup><i class="footnote">The tribe of Simon, protecting their head.</i> asked him, where to, Phineas? He said to them, do you not agree that everywhere the tribe of Levi is with the tribe of Simeon? They said, let him, maybe the Pharisees permitted the matter<sup class="footnote-marker">225</sup><i class="footnote">Echoing a popular opinion that the “oral law” can be made to adapt to all circumstances, moral or immoral.</i>. When he entered, the Holy One, praise to Him, performed six wonders for him<sup class="footnote-marker">226</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 82b" href="/Sanhedrin.82b">Babli 82b</a>, in the name of R. Johanan.</i>. The first miracle: usually they would separate, but the angel glued the one to the other<sup class="footnote-marker">227</sup><i class="footnote">If they were not killed in the act, the killing would have been murder.</i>. The second miracle: He directed the spear into her belly to that his penis should be seen inside her belly because of the fault-finders, lest they say that he muscled himself in with them and satisfied himself<sup class="footnote-marker">228</sup><i class="footnote">In the Babli: Thus Phineas had direct proof in court that the killing was justified. Phineas’s act established a rule of law which could never be used again.</i>. The third miracle: the angel closed their mouths, so they could not cry. The fourth miracle: they did not slip from the weapon but stayed in place. The fifth miracle: The angel lifted the lintel so that both of them were carried out between his shoulders. The sixth miracle: When the plague started to destroy the people, what did he do? He threw them on the ground and prayed. That is what is written: <i>Phineas stood and prayed; the plague was arrested</i><sup class="footnote-marker">229</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 106:30" href="/Psalms.106.30"><i>Ps.</i> 106:30</a>.</i>.
When Israel came to exact vengeance from Midian, they found there Bileam ben Beor. What did he do there? He came to collect his wages for the 24’000 of Israel who died at Shittim. Phineas told him, you followed neither your Creator nor Balaq. You did not follow your Creator, Who told you, do not go with Balaq’s emissaries, but you went. You did not follow Balaq who told you to come and curse Israel, but you blessed them. I also will not hold back your wages. That is what is written: <i>The Children of Israel slew Bileam ben Beor the sorcerer on top of their slain</i><sup class="footnote-marker">230</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Joshua 13:22" href="/Joshua.13.22"><i>Jos.</i> 13:22</a>. The masoretic text, as represented by the Aleppo and Leningrad codices, reads אל־חלליהן, not על־. One finds על־חלליהן in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 31:8" href="/Numbers.31.8"><i>Num.</i> 31:8</a>, not referring to Bileam but to the five tribal heads of Midian which in <i>Num.</i> are titled “kings” but in <i>Jos.</i>“princes of Sihon”. <i>Jos.</i> describes the situation before the arrival of the Children of Israel, <i>Num.</i> the actual situation after the fall of Sihon. One may read the following explanations as a polemic against opinions like that of M. Noth (<i>Das Buch Josua, Tübingen</i> 1938, p. 50) that אל־חלליהן is a gloss, taken from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 31:8" href="/Numbers.31.8"><i>Num.</i> 31:8</a> and inserted in the wrong place.</i>. What means <i>on their slain</i>? That he was as important as all their slain. Another explanation, <i>on their slain.</i> Just as their slain were irrelevant, so he was irrelevant. Another explanation, <i>on their slain.</i> He was flying over their corpses, but Phineas showed him the [High Priest’s] diadem and he fell down. Another explanation, <i>on their slain.</i> This teaches that Israel paid him his wages in full and did not hold back.
Doëg was a man great in Torah. Israel came and asked David, does the showbread supersede the Sabbath<sup class="footnote-marker">231</sup><i class="footnote">The only place where Doëg is mentioned is <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 21-22" href="/I_Samuel.21-22"><i>1S.</i> 21–22</a>. Since it is stated in 21:7 that David was given showbread still hot when removed from the Tent of Meeting, it must have been on the Sabbath (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 24:8" href="/Leviticus.24.8"><i>Lev.</i> 24:8</a>). Since the High Priest earlier had indicated misgivings about giving him holy bread, he must have convinced the High Priest by learned arguments that what he asked for was permitted.</i>? He told them, its arrangement supersedes the Sabbath, but neither its kneading nor its forming supersedes the Sabbath. Doëg was there and said, who is the one who comes to instruct in my presence<sup class="footnote-marker">232</sup><i class="footnote">It is implied that Doëg claimed status as the generations’s teacher. That would make asking anybody else for religious instruction in his presence a deadly sin [<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Gittin 1:2:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Gittin.1.2.5"><i>Gittin</i> 1:2 (Note 94</a>), <i>Ševiˋit</i> 6:1 (Notes 23–30).]</i>? They told him, it is David ben Jesse. He went immediately and counseled Saul, the king of Israel, to kill the priests of Nob, the city of priests. This is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 22:17" href="/I_Samuel.22.17"><i>1S</i>. 22:17</a>.</i>: <i>The king said to the runners who stood by him, surround and kill the priests of the Eternal for they also are involved with David,</i> etc., up to <i>they did not inform me.</i> Who were they? Rebbi Samuel bat Rav Isaac said, they were Abner and Amasa. They told him, you have us indebted to you only for this belt<sup class="footnote-marker">234</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ζωνάριον, τό, “belt”.</i> and this כלינירין<sup class="footnote-marker">235</sup><i class="footnote">According to <i>Arukh,</i> one should read כַלִינָרִין χαλινάριον “bridle”. Levy prefers to read כְלָנִידִין χλανίδιον “upper garment, blanket.” This fits better into the context. They tell the king that they do not need his salary.</i>. Here they are torn for you. <sup class="footnote-marker">233</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 22:17" href="/I_Samuel.22.17"><i>1S</i>. 22:17</a>.</i><i>The king’s servants did not want to kill the priests of the Eternal. The king said to Doyeg.</i> Rebbi Jehudah bar Pazi said, it is written <i>to Doyeg.</i> They told him, you are caught like a fish; you committed a great sin<sup class="footnote-marker">236</sup><i class="footnote">In Chapter 21, he is called דואג, in Chapter 22 mostly דויג. This must be explained; the second form of the name is derived from דָּג “fish”. The episode is an illustration of the maxim that calumny (לָשׁוֹן הָרַע) is a deadly sin.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">237</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 22:18" href="/I_Samuel.22.18"><i>1S.</i> 22:18</a>. It is stated that Doeg slew 85 men wearing the <i>ephod,</i> a vestment by pentateuchal rules appropriate only for the High Priest.</i><i>Turn you and smite the priests of the Eternal. Doëg the Edomite turned and smote the priests,</i> etc. But did not Rebbi Ḥiyya state, “one does not appoint two High Priests together”? But this teaches that all of them were qualified for the High Priesthood. How was he removed<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">What visible sign was given that he had no part in the Future World.</i>? Rebbi Ḥanina and Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: One said, fire came from the Holiest of Holies<sup class="footnote-marker">239</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 21" href="/I_Samuel.21"><i>1S</i>. 21</a> makes it clear that there was a Holy Tent at Nob, even though the Ark was still at Qiryat Yearim.</i> and burned around him. But the other said, competent students came to him, they were learning but he was forgetting<sup class="footnote-marker">240</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 106b" href="/Sanhedrin.106b">Babli 106b</a>.</i>, to confirm what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">241</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Job.</i> 20:15.</i>: <i>The property swallowed by him he throws up; God removes it from his belly.</i>
Aḥitophel was a man great in Torah. It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">242</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 6:1" href="/II_Samuel.6.1"><i>2S.</i> 6:1</a>. The verse is written in military language but does not appear in a military context.</i>: <i>David again assembled all young men in Israel, 30’000.</i> Rebbi Berekhiah in the name of Rebbi Abba bar Cahana<sup class="footnote-marker">243</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Num. rabba</i> 4(21),12(25); <i>Midrash Samuel</i> 24(5).</i>: Ninety thousand Elders did David ordain on one day, but he did not ordain Aḥitophel with them<sup class="footnote-marker">244</sup><i class="footnote">Justifying Ahitophel’s hatred of David. He had enough reason as Batseba’s grandfather.</i>. That is what is written: <i>David again assembled all young men in Israel, 30’000.</i> He added, 30’000. Again, 30’000, and the simple sense of the verse, 30’000; together 90’000. You find that at the moment when David came to carry the Ark of the Eternal’s Covenant, he did not carry it following the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 7:9" href="/Numbers.7.9"><i>Num.</i> 7:9</a>.</i>. <i>They moved the Ark of God’s Covenant on a new car</i><sup class="footnote-marker">245</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 6:3" href="/II_Samuel.6.3"><i>2S</i>. 6:3</a>.</i>, etc. The Ark lifted the Cohanim up and tore them down to the ground; lifted the Cohanim up and tore them down to the ground. David sent and brought Aḥitophel. He told him, can you not tell me why the Ark lifted the Cohanim up and tore them down to the ground, lifted the Cohanim up and tore them down to the ground? He answered, send and ask all the wise men whom you ordained. David said, any man who knows how to put this in order but does not put it in order should end up strangled. He said something in front of it and it was steadied. That is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">246</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 6:13" href="/II_Samuel.6.13"><i>2S</i>. 6:13</a>; <i>2 Chr.</i> 15:20. The two verses contradict one another.</i>: <i>It was when the carriers of the Eternal’s Ark took six steps that he sacrificed a bull and a fattened calf</i>. Rebbi Ḥanina and Rebbi Mana, one said, for every step a bull and a fattened calf and at the end seven oxen and seven rams; but the other said, for every step seven oxen and seven rams and at the end a bull and a fattened calf<sup class="footnote-marker">247</sup><i class="footnote">To explain both verses (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:2:20" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.2.20">Note 246</a>). <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sotah 35b" href="/Sotah.35b">Babli <i>Sotah</i> 35b</a>.</i>. The Holy One, praise to Him, said to Aḥitophel: Something which the schoolchildren say every day in assembly you did not say to him: <i>to the Bene Qehat he did not give; for the service of the holy [vessels] is on them, they should carry on the shoulder</i><sup class="footnote-marker">248</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 7:9" href="/Numbers.7.9"><i>Num.</i> 7:9</a>.</i>. But so you told him. <sup class="footnote-marker">249</sup><i class="footnote">Differently <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sukkah 53a" href="/Sukkah.53a">Babli <i>Sukkah</i> 53a</a>; hinted at <a class="refLink" data-ref="Makkot 11a" href="/Makkot.11a"><i>Makkot</i> 11a</a>.</i> Similarly you find that when David started to excavate the foundations<sup class="footnote-marker">250</sup><i class="footnote">Greek θεμελίωσις; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sotah 6:1:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sotah.6.1.4"><i>Sotah</i> 6:2 Note 17</a>.</i> of the Temple, he dug down fifteen hundred cubits and did not find the abyss. At the end he found a clay pot and wanted to lift it. It told him, you cannot lift me. We asked, why? It answered, because I am here suppressing the abyss. He asked it, since when are you here? It answered, from the Moment that the Merciful spoke on Sinai: <i>I am the Eternal, your God</i><sup class="footnote-marker">251</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 20:2" href="/Exodus.20.2"><i>Ex</i>. 20:2</a>.</i>, the earth trembled and sank down, and I was put here to suppress the abyss<sup class="footnote-marker">252</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. Babli ˋ<i>Avodah zarah</i> 3a, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 74" href="/Psalms.74"><i>Midrash Tehillim</i> 74 #4</a>. The reference is to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 76:9" href="/Psalms.76.9"><i>Ps.</i>76:9</a>: <i>The earth was fearful and quiet.</i> The earth was fearful because it was created on condition that Israel accept the Torah; when Israel accepted the Ten Commandments the earth became quiet since its continued existence was assured. The cover on the abyss sits on the waters of the Deluge (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 7:11" href="/Genesis.7.11"><i>Gen.</i>7:11</a>).</i>. Nevertheless, he did not listen to it; when he lifted it the abyss rose and threatened to flood the world. Aḥitophel was standing there. He said, now David will be strangled and I shall rule. David said, any Sage who knows how to put this in order but does not put it in order should end up strangled. He said what he said<sup class="footnote-marker">253</sup><i class="footnote">A magical spell.</i> and it was steady. David started to sing <i>a song of ascent,</i> a song for a rise of 100 [cubits]. For each hundred cubits he composed a song. Nevertheless, he ended up strangled. Rebbi Yose said, that is what the proverb says, a person has to worry about the curse of a rabbi, even if it is for nothing<sup class="footnote-marker">254</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Berakhot 56a" href="/Berakhot.56a"><i>Babli</i> Berakhot 56a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Makkot 11a" href="/Makkot.11a"><i>Makkot</i> 11a</a>.</i>. Rebbi Jeremiah in the name of Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac: The scroll which Samuel handed over to David, Aḥitophel composed it by the Holy Spirit<sup class="footnote-marker">255</sup><i class="footnote">The blueprint for building the Temple (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Chronicles 28:11" href="/I_Chronicles.28.11"><i>1Chr.</i> 28:11</a>).</i>. What did Aḥitophel do? If anybody asked for his counsel in anything and he gave his advice, he said go and do such and such, and if you do not believe me ask the Urim and Tummim. He went, asked, and found it correct<sup class="footnote-marker">256</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 3:4" href="/Psalms.3.4"><i>Midrash Tehillim</i> 3(4</a>). (We do not find that the oracle could be used for anything but affairs of state.)</i>. That is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">257</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 16:23" href="/II_Samuel.16.23"><i>2S</i>. 16:23</a>.</i>: <i>The counsel of Aḥitophel which he gave in those days,</i> etc. <i>Man</i> is read but not written<sup class="footnote-marker">258</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Nedarim 37b" href="/Nedarim.37b">Babli <i>Nedarim</i> 37b</a>.</i>; the verses could not call him “a man.<sup class="footnote-marker">259</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 3:4" href="/Psalms.3.4"><i>Midrash Tehillim</i> 3(4</a>): “but an angel.”</i>”
How was he removed<sup class="footnote-marker">238</sup><i class="footnote">What visible sign was given that he had no part in the Future World.</i>? <i>When Aḥitophel saw that his counsel was not taken, he saddled his donkey</i><sup class="footnote-marker">260</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Samuel 17:23" href="/II_Samuel.17.23"><i>2S.</i> 17:23</a>. He committed suicide; therefore his death could not scour off his sins, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:1:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.1.8">Note 29</a>. A parallel to this paragraph is in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 147a" href="/Bava_Batra.147a">Babli, <i>Bava batra</i> 147a</a>.</i>, etc. Three things did Aḥitophel command his sons: Do not rebel against the dynasty of David, since we find that the Holy One, praise to Him, shows them favor even when they acted brazenly<sup class="footnote-marker">261</sup><i class="footnote">Greek παρρησία, as in the case of Batseba.</i>. Do not have dealings with anybody who has a lucky streak<sup class="footnote-marker">262</sup><i class="footnote">Since the other party would win in court or in contract negotiations.</i>. And if Pentecost was clear, sow wheat of the best quality<sup class="footnote-marker">263</sup><i class="footnote">The next fall planting season.</i>. But we do not know whether clear from dew or clear from <i>šarav</i><sup class="footnote-marker">264</sup><i class="footnote">The dry wind from the East, Arabic <i>hamsin</i>.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">266</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 107b" href="/Sanhedrin.107b">Babli 107b</a>.</i> Geḥazi was great in Torah, but three things were the matter with him: He was grudging, dissolute in sexual matters, and denied the Resurrection of the Dead. Grudging. When Elisha sat and formulated his teachings, Geḥazi sat outside the door. The students saw him and said, Geḥazi did not find room inside, could we find room inside? His<sup class="footnote-marker">267</sup><i class="footnote">Elisha’s who had no listeners.</i> statements were said without anybody profiting from them. Once he was removed, what is written there? <i>The prophecy students said to Elisha</i> (etc.,) <i>the place where we are sitting is too narrow for us</i><sup class="footnote-marker">268</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 6:1" href="/II_Kings.6.1"><i>2K</i>. 6:1</a>, the verse immediately following Gehazi’s dismissal.</i>. It does not contain the general population<sup class="footnote-marker">269</sup><i class="footnote">Greek ὄχλος, “multitude”.</i> and the students who were there.
<sup class="footnote-marker">270</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Yevamot 2:4:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Yevamot.2.4.3"><i>Yebamot</i> 2:4 (Notes 81–85</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Vayikra Rabbah 24:6" href="/Vayikra_Rabbah.24.6"><i>Lev. rabba</i>24(6</a>). The text here seems to be original since only here (and <i>Lev. rabba</i>) the observation of R. Samuel bar Rav Isaac’s maid is given justification.</i> Dissolute in sexual matters. For the woman of Shunem said to her husband: <i>Lo, I know that he is a holy man of God</i><sup class="footnote-marker">271</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 4:9" href="/II_Kings.4.9"><i>2K.</i>4:9</a>.</i>. Rebbi Jonah said, he is holy, but his student is not holy. Rebbi Abun said, because he never looked at her. But the rabbis of Caesarea say, he never had an involuntary emission. The slave girl of Rebbi Samuel ben Rav Isaac said, I was washing my master’s garments. I never saw a bad thing on my master’s garments. It is written: <i>Geḥazi drew near to push her away</i><sup class="footnote-marker">272</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 4:27" href="/II_Kings.4.27"><i>2K.</i>4:27</a>.</i>. What is לְהָדְפָהּ? Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, he put his hand on her beauty spot, between her breasts.
And denied the Resurrection of the Dead. You find that at the time when Elisha came to resurrect the Shunamite’s son, he told him<sup class="footnote-marker">273</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 4:29" href="/II_Kings.4.29"><i>2K.</i> 4:29</a>.</i>: <i>Take my support staff in your hand and go, and if you meet a man do not greet him, or if a person greets you do not answer him.</i> But he did not do that, but when a person met him and asked, from where and to where, Geḥazi? He told him, I am going to resurrect the dead. This one would tell him, only the Holy One, praise to Him, can resurrect the dead, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">274</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 2:6" href="/I_Samuel.2.6"><i>1S.</i>2:6</a>.</i>: <i>The Eternal kills and gives life, brings down to the pit and lifts up.</i> He went there and did not do anything. He returned to him and said to him, I know that if he really were dead, he would not wake up through you.
You find [written] when Naˋaman, the army commander of the king of Aram, came to him with his horses and his chariot. Rebbi Joḥanan said, it is written <i>with his horse</i><sup class="footnote-marker">275</sup><i class="footnote">The actual <i>Ketib</i> in all sources of <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 5:9" href="/II_Kings.5.9"><i>2K.</i>5:9</a>.</i>. He wanted to give him gold and silver, stolas and garments, precious stones and pearls, but he did not accept. That is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">276</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 5:16" href="/II_Kings.5.16"><i>2K.</i> 5:16</a>.</i>: <i>He insisted that he take, but he refused.</i> Geḥazi came and said, <i>by the living Eternal, if I would run after him and take anything from him</i><sup class="footnote-marker">277</sup><i class="footnote"><i>2K</i>.5:20; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bamidbar Rabbah 7:6" href="/Bamidbar_Rabbah.7.6"><i>Num. rabba</i> 7(6</a>). The invocation of the Name in a dishonest enterprise is blasphemy.</i>. “A defect” is written<sup class="footnote-marker">278</sup><i class="footnote">A <i>Ketib</i> מומה “its defect” for <i>Qere</i>מְאוּמָה “anything” is not in Eastern (Aleppo and Peterburg) codices but it is an old Ashkenazic (Rashi <i>ad loc.</i>) and Provençal [<a class="refLink" data-ref="Bamidbar Rabbah 7:6" href="/Bamidbar_Rabbah.7.6"><i>Num. rabba</i> 7(6</a>)] tradition; cf. Y.S.R. Norzi, מנחת שי <i>ad loc.</i></i>. He went, met him, took what he took, and hid it in his upper storey. He came to Elisha, who asked him, <i>from where</i> to where, <i>Geḥazi</i>? You refused the reward of the just<sup class="footnote-marker">279</sup><i class="footnote">He lost his reward in the Future World.</i>! He answered<sup class="footnote-marker">280</sup><i class="footnote"><i>2K</i>.5:23–24. In v. 24, Gehazi’s skin disease is declared hereditary.</i>, <i>your servant did not go here or there. But he said, did not my thoughts go when a man turned from his carriage towards you; is it time</i> to take silver and gold; is it time to take precious stones and pearls? Therefore, <i>Naˋaman’s skin disease shall cling to you.</i> It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">281</sup><i class="footnote"><i>2K</i>.7:3.</i>: <i>Four men afflicted with skin disease were at the door of the gate.</i> Who were they? Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">282</sup><i class="footnote">Read: <i>Rav</i> Jehudah. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 107b" href="/Sanhedrin.107b">Babli (107b</a>): R. Johanan.</i> Jehudah in the name of Rav: They were Geḥazi and his three sons.
It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">283</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 8:7" href="/II_Kings.8.7"><i>2K.</i> 8:7</a>.</i>: <i>Elisha came to Damascus when Ben-Hadad the king of Aram was sick.</i> What did he come to do there? He went to bring back Geḥazi but found him absolutely impure<sup class="footnote-marker">284</sup><i class="footnote">Most rules of skin-disease (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 13:1-46" href="/Leviticus.13.1-46"><i>Lev.</i>13:1–46</a>) define two stages of the diagnosis. In the first one, the sufferer is quarantined (מֻסְגָּר). If he be found pure, a simple immersion in water will make him ritually pure. But if he was found impure after quarantine, he is <i>absolutely impure</i> and can regain purity only by the elaborate ceremony described in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 14" href="/Leviticus.14"><i>Lev.</i> 14</a>. For an inhabitant of the Northern kingdom, this would present almost insurmountable difficulties. (Naˋaman as a Gentile did not need any ceremony.) Elisha is faulted for not helping Gehazi to repent and regain his purity.</i>. From here that one should push away with one’s left hand but bring back close with one’s right. Rebbi Joḥanan said, <i>the stranger should not stay outside overnight; my doors I opened for the guest</i><sup class="footnote-marker">285</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 31:32" href="/Job.31.32"><i>Job</i> 31:32</a>.</i>. From here that one should push away with one’s left hand but bring back close with one’s right. Not as Elisha did who pushed Geḥazi away with both hands. Elisha was sick with two sicknesses<sup class="footnote-marker">286</sup><i class="footnote">In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 107b" href="/Sanhedrin.107b">Babli 107b</a>: three sicknesses; the two mentioned here and an additional one for sending the bears against the children. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 13:14" href="/II_Kings.13.14"><i>2K.</i> 13:14</a> it is mentioned that Elisha fell ill “with the sickness which would cause his death”. This implies that it was not his only sickness; he must have been sick at least twice.</i>. One in the ways of the world, and one because he pushed Geḥazi away.
<sup class="footnote-marker">287</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Bamidbar Rabbah 14:1" href="/Bamidbar_Rabbah.14.1"><i>Num. rabba</i> 14(1</a>).</i> Rebbi Ḥanania and Rebbi Joshua ben Levi: at the time when they voted and said that three kings and four private persons had no part in the Future World, there came a disembodied voice and said<sup class="footnote-marker">288</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 34:33" href="/Job.34.33"><i>Job</i> 34:33</a>.</i>, <i>does it pay for you that you oppose, that you choose, not I, and what can you say</i><sup class="footnote-marker">289</sup><i class="footnote">It is presumptuous for a human theologian to pretend to know God’s judgment.</i>? They wanted to include Solomon with them<sup class="footnote-marker">290</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 104b" href="/Sanhedrin.104b">Babli 104b</a>.</i>. David came and bowed down before them, but some say that fire came out of the Holiest of Holies and flared around them. Hadar IIla was used to be answered when he prayed. From the time he voted with them he prayed but was not answered. The interpreters of hints say, all of them have part in the Future World. What is the reason? <i>Mine is Gilead, mine is Manasse, Ephraim my main fortress, Jehudah is my scepter, Moab my washing trough, at Edom I shall throw my shoe</i><sup class="footnote-marker">291</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 60:9-10" href="/Psalms.60.9-10"><i>Ps.</i> 60:9–10</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 108:9-10" href="/Psalms.108.9-10">108:9–10</a>.</i><i>. Mine is Gilead,</i> that is Ahab, king of Israel, who fell at Ramot Gilead. <i>Mine is Manasse,</i> its plain meaning. <i>Ephraim my main fortress,</i> that is Jeroboam ben Nevat the Ephraimite. <i>Jehudah is my scepter,</i> that is Aḥitophel. <i>Moab my washing trough,</i> that is Geḥazi<sup class="footnote-marker">292</sup><i class="footnote">Whose sin was connected with Naˋaman’s washing.</i>. <i>At Edom I shall throw my shoe,</i> that is Doëg the Edomite. Israel said before the Holy One, praise to Him: Master of all Worlds, what can we do if David, King of Israel, cursed them? <i>Men of blood and deceit shall not live to half of their days</i><sup class="footnote-marker">293</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 55:24" href="/Psalms.55.24"><i>Ps.</i> 55:24</a>. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 69b" href="/Sanhedrin.69b">Babli, 69b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 106b" href="/Sanhedrin.106b">106b</a>, the verse is read as meaning that Doëg and Ahitophel did not live to age 35.</i>! He told them, it is up to Me to make them friends one to the other. <i>For me Peleshet is friendly; to me Peleshet makes friends</i><sup class="footnote-marker">294</sup><i class="footnote">The root פלש in addition to “invade” can mean “to clear a path”.</i>; it is up to Me to lead them to good deeds and to make them friends one to the other.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The generation of the Deluge has no part in the World to Come and they do not stand in judgment, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">296</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 6:3" href="/Genesis.6.3"><i>Gen.</i> 6:3</a>.</i>: <i>My Spirit shall not judge man forever.</i> The people of Sodom have no part in the World to Come but they stand in judgment. Rebbi Neḥemiah says, neither of them stands in judgment, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">297</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 1:5" href="/Psalms.1.5"><i>Ps.</i> 1:5</a>.</i>: <i>Therefore, evildoers shall not rise in judgment, nor sinners in the company of the just. Therefore, evildoers shall not rise in judgment,</i> that is the generation of the Deluge, <i>nor sinners in the company of the just,</i> these are the people of Sodom. They said to him, in the company of the just they will not rise; they will stand in the company of evildoers.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The generation of the Deluge has no part in the World to Come,” and will not see the future<sup class="footnote-marker">298</sup><i class="footnote">In contrast to most other sinners whose souls will take part in Eternal Life after having been punished for their sins, these souls will be completely destroyed. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 108a" href="/Sanhedrin.108a">Babli 108a</a>.</i>. What is the reason? <sup class="footnote-marker">299</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 7:23" href="/Genesis.7.23"><i>Gen</i>. 7:23</a>.</i><i>He wiped off all that was standing</i> in this world; <i>they were wiped off from the Land</i><sup class="footnote-marker">300</sup><i class="footnote">The double mention of “wiping off” in one verse implies that each of them must have another object. In Psalms, “the Land” usually refers to the Future Life; the Land of the Living to Paradise, the Land without attribute to the Netherworld.</i>, in the future.
<sup class="footnote-marker">301</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 108a" href="/Sanhedrin.108a">Babli 108a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 13:1" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.13.1">Tosephta 13:6</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 26:6" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.26.6"><i>Gen. rabba</i>26(6</a>),<a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 28:3" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.28.3">28(3</a>).</i> It was stated: Rebbi Neḥemiah says, one understands it from what was said<sup class="footnote-marker">296</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 6:3" href="/Genesis.6.3"><i>Gen.</i> 6:3</a>.</i> <i>My Spirit shall not judge man forever.</i> Rebbi Jehudah says, <i>My Spirit shall not judge him,</i> for I shall not give My Spirit into them when I shall give My Spirit into people<sup class="footnote-marker">302</sup><i class="footnote">At the resurrection. The interpretations differ in formulation, not in meaning.</i>. Rebbi Simeon says, <i>My Spirit shall not judge him,</i> for I shall not give My Spirit into them when I shall distribute the rewards of the just. Others say, <i>My Spirit shall not judge him</i>, I shall not bring it back into its sheath<sup class="footnote-marker">303</sup><i class="footnote">In the container where souls are kept to be born or resurrected.</i>. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, mainly their<sup class="footnote-marker">304</sup><i class="footnote">The generation of the flood.</i> scalding was parboiling. What is the reason? <i>At the time when they were scalded they shrank; in its heat they disappear from their place</i><sup class="footnote-marker">305</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Job 6:17" href="/Job.6.17"><i>Job</i>6:17</a>.</i>. What is <i>in its heat</i>? In their boiling. Rebbi Joḥanan said, every single drop which the Holy One, praise to Him, rained on them, He brought to a boil in Hell and rained it on them<sup class="footnote-marker">306</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 28:9" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.28.9"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 28(9</a>) [M. Sokoloff, <i>The Geniza Fragments of Bereshit Rabba</i>(Jerusalem 1982) p. 120].</i>. That is what is written, <i>in its heat they disappear from their place.</i> Jehudah ben Rebbi Ḥizqiah and Rebbi<sup class="footnote-marker">307</sup><i class="footnote">Probably one should read “Jehudah and Hizqiah, the sons of R. Hiyya”, or a name in missing here. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Eduyot 2:10" href="/Mishnah_Eduyot.2.10">Mishnah <i>Idiut</i>2:10</a>, the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 33b" href="/Shabbat.33b">Babli, <i>Šabbat</i> 33b</a>, and <i>Thr. rabba</i>1(42), the statement is anonymous. In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 28:7" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.28.7"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 28(7</a>) it is attributed to R. Johanan, a student of Hizqiah.<br>The statement is the basis of the rule that prayers for deceased parents may be said only for 11 months, so as not to declare one’s parents as evildoers.</i> said, the Holy One, praise to Him, judges the evildoers in Hell for twelve months. First He brings the itch on them; then He brings them into fire and they say woe, woe; after that He brings them into snow and they say wai, wai. What is the reason? <i>He brought me up from the noisy pit, from miry mud</i><sup class="footnote-marker">308</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 40:3" href="/Psalms.40.3"><i>Ps.</i> 40:3</a>.</i>. What is <i>from</i> יָוֶן <i>mud</i>? From a place where one says woe. Why could they not receive their punishment<sup class="footnote-marker">309</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the statement of the Mishnah that the people of the Deluge have no part in the World to Come, i. e., that their souls were destroyed.</i> and then take part in the World to Come? Because <i>the scoffer will not hear rebuke</i><sup class="footnote-marker">310</sup><i class="footnote">Since the goal of punishment is reform, punishment of scoffers is useless. Their souls, instead of being punished, must be destroyed.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">311</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 109a" href="/Sanhedrin.109a">Babli 109a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 13:1" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.13.1">Tosephta 13:8</a>. The paragraph also is part of the Mishnah in the Babli and the independent Mishnah mss. not from the Maimonides tradition.</i>“The people of Sodom have no part in the World to Come,” and they will not see the future. What is the reason? <i>The people of Sodom were very evil and sinful against the Eternal</i><sup class="footnote-marker">312</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 13:13" href="/Genesis.13.13"><i>Gen.</i> 13:13</a>.</i><i>. Evil and sinful</i> in this world, <i>against the Eternal very much</i> in the future. <sup class="footnote-marker">313</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 41:10" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.41.10"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 41(10</a>).</i> Another explanation. <i>Evil</i> against one another, <i>and sinful</i> in incest and adultery, <i>against the Eternal</i> in foreign worship, <i>very much</i> in spilling blood.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The generation of the desert has no part in the World to Come, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">314</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 14:35" href="/Numbers.14.35"><i>Num.</i> 14:35</a>. The argument in the longer text of the Mishnah in the Babli is reproduced here at the start of the Halakhah. In all these cases, the double emphasis in the verse is interpreted that the first expression refers to this world, the second to the World to Come.</i>: <i>in this desert they shall be terminated and there they will die,</i> the words of Rebbi Aqiba. Rebbi Eliezer says, about them it says<sup class="footnote-marker">315</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 50:5" href="/Psalms.50.5"><i>Ps.</i> 50:5</a>.</i>, <i>assemble for Me My lovely ones, who sealed My Covenant by a sacrifice</i><sup class="footnote-marker">316</sup><i class="footnote">The ceremony described in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 24:1-9" href="/Exodus.24.1-9"><i>Ex.</i> 24:1–9</a> guaranteed their eternal life. Since R. Aqiba war R. Eliezer’s student, the inversion of the chronological order clearly indicates that the latter’s opinion is accepted as practice.</i>.<br>The band of Korah will not be resurrected in the future, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">317</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 16:33" href="/Numbers.16.33"><i>Num.</i> 16:33</a>.</i> <i>the earth covered them; they were lost from among the congregation,</i> the words of Rebbi Aqiba. Rebbi Eliezer says, about them it says<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 2:6" href="/I_Samuel.2.6"><i>1S</i>. 2:6</a>. She was married to a descendant of Korah’s (<i>2 Chr</i>. 6:18–23).</i>, <i>the Eternal kills and brings to life, He sends down into the pit and raises up.</i>
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">318</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 110b" href="/Sanhedrin.110b">Babli 110b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 13:1" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.13.1">Tosephta 13:9–12</a>.</i>“The generation of the desert has no part in the World to Come,” and will not see the future, as it is said: <i>in this desert they shall be terminated and there they will die. In this desert they shall be terminated,</i> in this world, <i>and there they will die, in the future;</i> and so He says<sup class="footnote-marker">319</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 95:11" href="/Psalms.95.11"><i>Ps.</i> 95:11</a>.</i>, <i>what I swore in My rage, lest they come to My rest,</i> the words of Rebbi Aqiba. Rebbi Eliezer says, about them it says, <i>assemble for Me My lovely ones, who sealed My Covenant by a sacrifice.</i> Rebbi Joshua said, <i>I swore and I shall keep it</i><sup class="footnote-marker">320</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 119:106" href="/Psalms.119.106"><i>Ps.</i> 119:106</a>; cf. <i>Eccl. rabba</i> 10(23) <i>ad</i>10:20. In a more adequate context the verse is quoted in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Chagigah 1:8:2-14" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Chagigah.1.8.2-14"><i>Hagigah</i> 1:8</a>.</i>; sometimes I do not keep it. Ḥanania the son of Rebbi Joshua’s brother says, it is written: <i>what I swore in My rage;</i> I swore in My rage, I am changing My mind. It was stated: Rebbi Simeon ben Menassia says, about them it says <i>assemble Me My lovely ones,</i> who performed acts of love for Me<sup class="footnote-marker">321</sup><i class="footnote">In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 2:1" href="/Jeremiah.2.1"><i>Jer.</i> 2:1</a>, the Exodus is described as an act of love of God.</i>. <i>The executors of My Covenant,</i> who were extirpated by Me. <i>By sacrifice,</i> they elevated me and were sacrificed for My name. It was stated: Rebbi Joshua ben Qorḥa says, about these generations He says<sup class="footnote-marker">322</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 35:10" href="/Isaiah.35.10"><i>Is.</i> 35:10</a>.</i>, <i>those freed by the Eternal shall return.</i> Rebbi says, these and those<sup class="footnote-marker">323</sup><i class="footnote">The generation of the desert and the Ten Tribes (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:5:1-5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.5.1-5">Mishnah 6</a>).</i> have part in the World to Come. What is the reason? <sup class="footnote-marker">324</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 27:13" href="/Isaiah.27.13"><i>Is.</i> 27:13</a>; cf. <i>Eccl. rabba</i> 1(20).</i><i>It</i> <i>shall be on that day, a great ram’s horn will be blown, and those lost in the land of Assyria will come,</i> these are the Ten Tribes, <i>and those displaced in the land of Egypt,</i> that is the generation of the desert. These and those <i>will bow down before the Eternal on the Holy Mountain [and] in Jerusalem.</i>
<sup class="footnote-marker">325</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 109b" href="/Sanhedrin.109b"><i>Babli</i> 109b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 13:1" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.13.1"><i>Tosephta</i> 13:9</a>.</i> The band of Korah will not have part in the Future World and not be resurrected in the future. What is the reason? <sup class="footnote-marker">317</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 16:33" href="/Numbers.16.33"><i>Num.</i> 16:33</a>.</i><i>The desert covered them,</i> in this world; <i>they were lost from among the congregation,</i> in the future. It was stated: Rebbi Jehudah ben Bathyra says, one understands from what is said, <i>I erred like a lost sheep; look after Your servant</i><sup class="footnote-marker">326</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 119:176" href="/Psalms.119.176"><i>Ps</i>. 119:176</a>.</i>, that just as the lost object mentioned there at the end will be searched for, so also the lost object mentioned here at the end will be searched for<sup class="footnote-marker">327</sup><i class="footnote">By the doctrine of invariability of lexemes.</i>.
Who prayed for them? Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman said, Moses prayed for them, <i>Reuben shall live and not die</i><sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 33:6" href="/Deuteronomy.33.6"><i>Deut</i>. 33:6</a>, this refers to Datan and Abiram from the tribe of Reuben.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Midrash Shemuel</i> ed. Buber 5(12).</i> Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, Hannah prayed for them. This follows Rebbi Joshua ben Levi, as Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said: Korah’s band was continuously sinking until Hannah stood up and said<sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Samuel 2:6" href="/I_Samuel.2.6"><i>1S</i>. 2:6</a>. She was married to a descendant of Korah’s (<i>2 Chr</i>. 6:18–23).</i>, <i>the Eternal kills and brings to life, He sends down into the pit and lifts up.</i>

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The Ten Tribes will not return in the future, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">328</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 29:27" href="/Deuteronomy.29.27"><i>Deut.</i> 29:27</a>.</i>, <i>He threw them into another country like this day.</i> As this day passes and does never return, so they go, never to return, the words of Rebbi Aqiba. Rebbi Eliezer says, <i>like this day,</i> as the day gets dark and then light, so also they for whom there was darkness there will be light in the future.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The Ten Tribes,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">330</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 110b" href="/Sanhedrin.110b">Babli 110b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 13:1" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.13.1">Tosephta 13:12</a>.</i> The Ten Tribes have no part in the World to Come, and will not see the future. What is the reason? <i>He threw them into another country like this day.</i> As the day passes and does never return, so they go, never to return, the words of Rebbi Aqiba. Rebbi Simeon ben Jehudah from Kefar-Ikos said in the name of Rebbi Simeon: If their behavior remains as on this day, they will not return; otherwise, they will return.
<sup class="footnote-marker">331</sup><i class="footnote">It is difficult to understand why this digression about a crypto-Jewish Roman emperor was inserted here. It is futile to try to determine to whom one refers; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Kilayim 9:3:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Kilayim.9.3.3"><i>Kilaim</i>9:4, Note 79</a>. It was implied already in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:1:2-26" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.1.2-26">Halakhah 1</a> that Gentiles may have part in the World to Come.<br>A parallel, in slightly different order, is in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 1:11:2-8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.1.11.2-8"><i>Megillah</i> 1:13</a>. For the first sentence, cf. <i>Lev. rabba</i> 3(20), <i>Midrash Ps.</i> 22(29).</i> Rebbi Ḥizqiah, Rebbi Abbahu in the name of Rebbi Eleazar: When in the Future World the proselytes come, Antoninus comes at the head of all of them. How do you understand this? Since they saw him walking with a slight shoe on the Day of Atonement<sup class="footnote-marker">332</sup><i class="footnote">The wearing of leather shoes is forbidden on the Day of Atonement (except where it is necessary, as when walking on muddy streets.) That Antoninus did not wear leather shoes on the Day of Atonement is no proof that he became a proselyte since many “God-fearing people”, Gentiles known as “Friends of the Synagogue”, do the same.</i>, what do you infer since even God-fearing people go outside thus. There is information that Antoninus did not become a proselyte, and there is information that Antoninus did become a proselyte. Antoninus came to Rebbi and asked him, can you see me eating from the Leviathan<sup class="footnote-marker">333</sup><i class="footnote">The just feasting on Leviathan meat in the World to Come are also mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Vayikra Rabbah 22:7" href="/Vayikra_Rabbah.22.7"><i>Lev. rabba</i> 22(7</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bava Batra 74b-75a" href="/Bava_Batra.74b-75a">Babli <i>Bava batra</i>74b–75a</a>.</i> in the World to Come? He said, yes. He told him, from the Passover lamb you would not let me eat, but from Leviathan you make me eat in the World to Come? He answered, what can we do for you since about the Passover lamb it is written that <i>no uncircumcised man may eat from it</i><sup class="footnote-marker">334</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 12:48" href="/Exodus.12.48"><i>Ex.</i> 12:48</a>.</i>. This implies that Antoninus did not become a proselyte. When he heard this, he went and became a proselyte. He came to Rebbi and said to him, look at my circumcision. He answered him, at mine I never looked<sup class="footnote-marker">335</sup><i class="footnote">It is indecent to look at sexual organs. References to this insert are <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Megillah 1:11:2-8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Megillah.1.11.2-8"><i>Megillah</i> 1:13</a> (72b l.57, 3:3 74a l.39); <i>Avodah zarah</i> 3:1 (42c l.5); <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 118b" href="/Shabbat.118b">Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 118b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Pesachim 104a" href="/Pesachim.104a"><i>Pesahim</i> 104a</a>; the text here is copied by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosafot on Ketubot 30a:4:1" href="/Tosafot_on_Ketubot.30a.4.1">Tosaphot <i>Ketubot</i>30a <i>s.v</i>. הכל</a>.</i>, and at yours I should look? This implies that Antoninus became a proselyte. Why is he called our holy teacher? Because he never in his life looked at his circumcision. And why is his name Naḥum the holiest of holies<sup class="footnote-marker">336</sup><i class="footnote">An otherwise unknown personality.</i>? Because he never in his life looked at the figure on a coin. Antoninus came to Rebbi; he said to him, pray for me. He said to him, may He save you from the cold, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">337</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 147:17" href="/Psalms.147.17"><i>Ps.</i> 147:17</a>.</i>, <i>who can withstand His cold</i>? He said, is that not a superfluous prayer? You cover yourself with an outer garment and the cold will go away. He said to him, may He save you from the hot wind that comes into the world. He said, that is a prayer; may your prayer be heard, as it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">338</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Psalms 19:7" href="/Psalms.19.7"><i>Ps.</i> 19:7</a>.</i>, <i>nothing is hidden from His heat.</i>
Rebbi Joḥanan said, the group of Joḥanan ben Qareaḥ<sup class="footnote-marker">339</sup><i class="footnote">Who flouted Jeremiah’s advice and fled to Egypt, <i>2K.</i> 42.</i> has no part in the World to Come. What is the reason? <i>They were traitors to the Eternal for they produced foreign children. Now a new Moon shall eat their parts</i><sup class="footnote-marker">340</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Hosea 5:7" href="/Hosea.5.7"><i>Hos.</i> 5:7</a>.</i>.
Rebbi Eleazar and Rebbi Jehudah. One said, they were exiles only when they were uncircumcised<sup class="footnote-marker">341</sup><i class="footnote">After a digression, one returns to the Ten Tribes.</i>. The other said, they were exiled only when they were bastards. He who says uncircumcised, for circumcision and commandments<sup class="footnote-marker">342</sup><i class="footnote">The question is whether people suspected of being descendants of the Ten Tribes, who did not join in the return of Judeans and who clearly will not follow rabbinic rules for marriage and divorce, can be allowed to marry rabbinic Jewish partners. The first opinion states that while they cannot be expected to follow biblical commandments, they are eligible as marriage partners once their Israelite identity is ascertained or they undergo regular conversion (even if this is intrinsically futile for descendants of Jews in the female line.)</i>. But he who says bastards, from their fathers<sup class="footnote-marker">343</sup><i class="footnote">In this opinion, all descendants of the Ten Tribes are barred from marrying Jewish partners other than bastards or proselytes.</i>. Rebbi Joḥanan said, Israel was exiled only after they formed 24 heretical sects. What is the reason? <i>Son of man, I am sending you to the Children of Israel, to rebellious peoples who rebelled against Me</i><sup class="footnote-marker">344</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 2:3" href="/Ezekiel.2.3"><i>Ez.</i> 2:3</a>.</i>. It is not written “to a rebellious people” but <i>to rebellious peoples who rebelled against Me; they and their fathers have acted criminally against Me up to this day.</i> Rebbi Berekhia and Rebbi Ḥelbo in the name of Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman. Israel was exiled to three diasporas<sup class="footnote-marker">345</sup><i class="footnote">Since each tribe is called גּוֹי “a people” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 35:11" href="/Genesis.35.11"><i>Gen.</i> 35:11</a>), the plural implies that it counts for at least two, for a total of at least 24. Possibly this is a take-off on the multiplicity of Christian sects.</i>: one inside the river Sanbation<sup class="footnote-marker">346</sup><i class="footnote">A river which stops flowing on the Sabbath. <i>Plinius, Hist. nat.</i> XXXI,2; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 65b" href="/Sanhedrin.65b"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 65b</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 11:6" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.11.6"><i>Gen. rabba</i> 11(6</a>),<a class="refLink" data-ref="Bereishit Rabbah 73:5" href="/Bereishit_Rabbah.73.5">73(5</a>); <i>Pesiqta rabbati</i> 23 [ed. Ish-Shalom Note 79].</i>, one to Daphne of Antiochia<sup class="footnote-marker">347</sup><i class="footnote">Site of an Aphrodite shrine of famously ill repute. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:5:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.5.5">Note 343</a>.</i>, and one on whom the Cloud<sup class="footnote-marker">348</sup><i class="footnote">The Divine Cloud of Exodus (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 14:19" href="/Exodus.14.19"><i>Ex.</i>14:19</a>) and Temple (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 8:10-11" href="/I_Kings.8.10-11"><i>1K.</i> 8:10–11</a>).</i> descended and covered them. Just as they were exiled to three diasporas, so the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and half the tribe of Manasse were exiled into three diasporas. What is the reason? <i>You went in the way of your sister and I gave her cup into your hand</i><sup class="footnote-marker">349</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 23:31" href="/Ezekiel.23.31"><i>Ez</i>. 23:31</a>.</i>. So when they return, they will return from three diasporas. What is the reason? <sup class="footnote-marker">350</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Isaiah 49:9" href="/Isaiah.49.9"><i>Is.</i> 49:9</a>.</i><i>To tell the prisoners, leave,</i> those who were exiled inside the river Sanbation; <i>those in darkness, become visible,</i> those upon whom the Cloud descended and covered them; <i>on the roads they are grazing and on all plains is their pasturage,</i> those who were exiled to Daphne of Antiochia.

Halakhah 6
