<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The people of a seduced town<sup class="footnote-marker">351</sup><i class="footnote">Who according to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 9:5:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.9.5.3">Mishnah 9:1</a> are executed by the sword.</i> have no part in the World to Come, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">352</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:14" href="/Deuteronomy.13.14"><i>Deut.</i> 13:14</a>.</i>: <i>Useless men</i><sup class="footnote-marker">353</sup><i class="footnote">They left their faith, therefore they cannot receive the reward of the faithful.</i><i>left your midst</i><sup class="footnote-marker">354</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., from their tribe.</i><i>and seduced the inhabitants of their town as follows.</i> Therefore they cannot be executed unless the seducers be from that town and from that tribe, unless the majority was seduced, unless the seducers were men. If women or minors seduced them, or if a minority were seduced, they are single individuals<sup class="footnote-marker">355</sup><i class="footnote">They must be prosecuted for idolatry on an individual basis.</i> and need two witnesses and warning for each single one. This is more stringent for individuals than for the multitude since individuals are stoned, therefore their money escapes<sup class="footnote-marker">356</sup><i class="footnote">It is inherited by the heirs.</i> while the multitude is executed by the sword, therefore their money is lost<sup class="footnote-marker">357</sup><i class="footnote">It must be destroyed by fire and is forbidden for all usufruct, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:17-18" href="/Deuteronomy.13.17-18"><i>Deut.</i> 13:17–18</a>.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The people of a seduced town,” etc. A town but not a village, a town but not a fortified place<sup class="footnote-marker">358</sup><i class="footnote">As noted in the dictionaries, both the etymology and the exact meaning of עִיר are unknown. For R. Meïr, עִיר is a village and כְּפָר a hamlet; this is the usual meaning of the words in the Babli. For R. Jehudah, עִיר is any larger settlement. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 15b" href="/Sanhedrin.15b">Babli, 15b</a>, this is a dispute between authorities of the generation between Tannaïm and Amoraïm. The opinion of R. Jehudah here is adopted there by R. Jonathan while R. Yoshia defines עִיר as a settlement of between 10 and 100 households.</i>. This means, from five to ten<sup class="footnote-marker">359</sup><i class="footnote">Households.</i>, the words of Rebbi Meïr; Rebbi Jehudah says, from one hundred up to a majority of the tribe. If two seduced two, is it possible to try the two who had seduced two both as seducers and as seduced<sup class="footnote-marker">360</sup><i class="footnote">Since <i>men</i> are mentioned in the verse, the seducers, to be stoned, cannot be less than two. On the other hand, if they did seduce only a few people and the majority was seduced by others, they are not seducers of the עִיר and may be tried as inhabitants, to be decapitated.</i>? If there were proselytes and residents<sup class="footnote-marker">361</sup><i class="footnote">Resident Gentiles.</i>, are they counted for the majority? If there were menageries<sup class="footnote-marker">362</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>vivarium, -ii, n.</i></i> for wild animals, birds, or fish<sup class="footnote-marker">363</sup><i class="footnote">These are not domesticated animals; the question is whether they have to be destroyed as property.</i>; birds flying higher than ten [handbreadths]<sup class="footnote-marker">364</sup><i class="footnote">The airspace above ten handbreadths is a separate domain. This is important mainly for the rules of the Sabbath but is noted also in property cases.</i>, what are the rules<sup class="footnote-marker">365</sup><i class="footnote">Since (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 14:1" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.14.1">Tosephta 14:1</a>) the case of the seduced city never arose and never will arise, no answers are required.</i>?
Rebbi Simeon says, burning is worse than stoning, but the rabbis teach that stoning is worse than burning. Rebbi Simeon says, strangulation is worse than decapitation; but the rabbis teach that decapitation is worse than strangulation<sup class="footnote-marker">366</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:1:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.1.3">Chapter 7:1, Note 1</a> (24b l. 15)</i>.

Halakhah 7

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> <i>Slaying you shall slay the inhabitants of that town by the sword</i><sup class="footnote-marker">367</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:16" href="/Deuteronomy.13.16"><i>Deut.</i> 13:16</a>.</i>. A caravan of donkeys or of camels which passes from place to place saves them<sup class="footnote-marker">368</sup><i class="footnote">The Yerushalmi gives no indication as to what this means. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 112a" href="/Sanhedrin.112a">Babli (112a</a>) holds that temporary residents after 30 days become voting citizens of the town; if they do not follow the permanent inhabitants into apostasy, they will deprive the apostates of a majority and the rules of the seduced town cannot be applied. But it might be that the Yerushalmi follows <i>Sifry Deut.</i> 94 that if at the moment of judgment there are people in town to whom the judgment does not apply, it cannot be executed since the verse requires that only the inhabitants of <i>that</i> town be killed.</i>. <i>Destroy it and all which is in it, including its domestic animals</i><sup class="footnote-marker">369</sup><i class="footnote">As property, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:6:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.6.2">Note 363</a>.</i>,<i>by the sword.</i> From here they said, the properties of just people in its midst are lost, what is outside escapes; that of evildoers both inside and outside is lost.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> <i>Slaying you shall slay the inhabitants of that town by the sword,</i> etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">370</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 14:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.14.2">Tosephta 14:5</a>.</i> Rebbi Simeon says, <i>its domesticated animal,</i> not first born or tithes found there; <i>its booty,</i> not Temple money or Second Tithe found there<sup class="footnote-marker">371</sup><i class="footnote">All the items enumerated are Heaven’s property. While the second part of the verse insists that the <i>town’s property</i> must be destroyed, Heaven’s property cannot be destroyed. The disposal of Heaven’s property is discussed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.8.1">Mishnah 9</a>. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 112b" href="/Sanhedrin.112b">Babli 112b</a>.</i>. Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina asked: What is the status of hair of its just women<sup class="footnote-marker">372</sup><i class="footnote">Since a woman could cut off her hair and sell it to a wig-maker, it represents value. Should the woman be forced to cut off her hair before she is forced to leave town following the conviction of the town for organized idolatry? Since Temple money must be taken out undamaged, so the just woman must be taken out unhurt. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 112a" href="/Sanhedrin.112a">Babli, 112a</a>, somewhat disagrees.</i>? Let us hear from the following: Rebbi Simeon says, <i>its domesticated animal,</i> not first born or tithes found there; <i>its booty,</i> not Temple money or Second Tithe found there. The <i>sancta</i> of a seduced town<sup class="footnote-marker">373</sup><i class="footnote">Once an animal has been dedicated as sacrifice, all private use of it is larceny (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 5:14-16" href="/Leviticus.5.14-16"><i>Lev.</i>5:14–16</a>).</i>, Rebbi Joḥanan said, one cannot commit larceny with them; Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, one can commit larceny with them. Rebbi Joḥanan objected to Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: According to your opinion that one can commit larceny with them, should one not state that “six purification offerings are left to die”<sup class="footnote-marker">374</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Temurah 4:1" href="/Mishnah_Temurah.4.1">Mishnah <i>Temurah</i> 4:1</a> enumerates 5 kinds of purification offerings which can neither be redeemed nor sacrificed. An animal dedicated by an idolator of a seduced town should be added as sixth kind. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 112a" href="/Sanhedrin.112a">Babli 112a</a>.</i>? He answered, because in this case even an elevation offering dies<sup class="footnote-marker">375</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Temurah 4:1" href="/Mishnah_Temurah.4.1">Mishnah <i>Temurah</i> 4:1</a> only treats cases particular to purification offerings.</i>. Rebbi Hila in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: One can commit larceny with them because of <i>sancta</i> of an apostate. Should they not be sacrificed? Because of <i>the sacrifice of an evildoer is an abomination</i><sup class="footnote-marker">376</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 21:27" href="/Proverbs.21.27"><i>Prov.</i> 21:27</a>. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Chullin 5a" href="/Chullin.5a">Babli, <i>Hulin</i> 5a</a>, finds the same result in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 1:2" href="/Leviticus.1.2"><i>Lev.</i> 1:2</a>.</i>. Rebbi Uqba said, also in the following they disagree: <sup class="footnote-marker">377</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 4:8:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.4.8.2"><i>Bava qamma</i> 4:9, Notes 122–125</a></i> If a bull was led out to be stoned when its witnesses were found to be perjured, Rebbi Joḥanan said, the first to come acquires it; Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, it was false despair. Similarly, if a slave was led out to be executed when its witnesses were found to be perjured, Rebbi Joḥanan said, he acquired himself; Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, it was false despair.

Halakhah 8

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> <i>All its spoils you shall collect in its public square</i><sup class="footnote-marker">378</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:17-18" href="/Deuteronomy.13.17-18"><i>Deut.</i> 13:17–18</a>.</i>. If it has no public square, one creates a public square in it. If its public square was outside, one collects it<sup class="footnote-marker">379</sup><i class="footnote">One extends the territory of the town to include the public square.</i> inside, for it is said: <i>In its public square you shall burn the town and all its spoils in fire;</i> its spoils but not Heaven’s spoils. From here they said that dedicated objects in it shall be redeemed, heaves shall be left to rot, Second Tithes and Holy Scriptures shall be put away<sup class="footnote-marker">371</sup><i class="footnote">All the items enumerated are Heaven’s property. While the second part of the verse insists that the <i>town’s property</i> must be destroyed, Heaven’s property cannot be destroyed. The disposal of Heaven’s property is discussed in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:8:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.8.1">Mishnah 9</a>. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 112b" href="/Sanhedrin.112b">Babli 112b</a>.</i>.<br><i>Totally for the Eternal, your God.</i> Rebbi Simeon said, if you judge the seduced town, I will credit it for you as if you brought an entire elevation offering before Me. <i>It shall be an eternal mound, it shall not be</i><i>rebuilt.</i> It should not even be made into gardens and orchards, the words of Rebbi Yose the Galilean. Rebbi Aqiba says, it shall not be rebuilt as it was but it may be made into gardens and orchards<sup class="footnote-marker">380</sup><i class="footnote">R. Yose the Galilean reads תֵּל with the Accadic as <i>ruin,</i> R. Aqiba with the Arabic as <i>mound, butte.</i></i>.<br><i>Nothing of what should be destroyed shall stick to your hands, so the Eternal may change from His anger to grant you mercy, have mercy on you and increase you,</i> etc. Any time evildoers are in the world, anger is in the world; when the evildoers are lost from the world, anger passes away from the world.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> <i>All its spoils you shall collect,</i> etc. Rebbi Simeon said, is there not an argument <i>de minore ad majus</i> about this? Since properties, which have no knowledge of good or bad, but because they caused the just to dwell with the evildoers the Torah said, should be burned, if somebody has the intention of influencing his neighbor and influences him from good ways to bad ones, not so much more? Rebbi Eleazar said, the matter is demonstrated by Lot who dwelt in Sodom only because of his money but left there with his hands on his head. This is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">381</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Genesis 19:22" href="/Genesis.19.22"><i>Gen.</i> 19:22</a>.</i>: <i>Quickly escape to there</i>; it is enough for you that you escape with your life.
<sup class="footnote-marker">382</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.2">Halakhah 2, Notes 143–146</a>.</i> It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 16:34" href="/I_Kings.16.34"><i>1K.</i> 16:34</a>; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 113a" href="/Sanhedrin.113a">Babli 113a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 14:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.14.2">Tosephta 14:6–9</a>.</i>: <i>In his days did Ḥiel from Bet-El build Jericho.</i> Ḥiel is from the descendants of Josaphat, Jericho is in the territory of Benjamin. Only that bad deeds are put in the hands of the unworthy; therefore, it is said, <i>with his first-born Aviram he set the foundation and with his youngest son Seguv he put in the doors.</i> [If it was not appropriate for him to learn from his firstborn Aviram, should he not have learned from]<sup class="footnote-marker">383</sup><i class="footnote">The addition in brackets is only in a Genizah fragment.</i> the wicked Seguv? Because they wanted to make more money, the curse ruled over them and they were continuously weakened to confirm what was said<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 16:34" href="/I_Kings.16.34"><i>1K.</i> 16:34</a>; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 113a" href="/Sanhedrin.113a">Babli 113a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 14:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.14.2">Tosephta 14:6–9</a>.</i>, <i>following</i> <i>the word of the Eternal, the God of Israel, which He had spoken though Joshua ben Nun.</i>
<i>Totally, for the Eternal. your God. Nothing of what should be destroyed shall stick to your hands.</i> It was stated<sup class="footnote-marker">384</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 14:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.14.2">Tosephta 14:10</a>.</i>: Rebbi Simeon ben Eleazar says, they did not rebuild it but built another town. After it was built, you are permitted to dwell there<sup class="footnote-marker">385</sup><i class="footnote">As the Tosephta points out, the students of prophecy lived at Jericho, <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 2:5" href="/II_Kings.2.5"><i>2K.</i>2:5</a>.</i>. Rebbi Yose<sup class="footnote-marker">386</sup><i class="footnote">The Tanna.</i> and Rebbi Joshua ben Qorḥa say, why does the verse say<sup class="footnote-marker">143</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 16:34" href="/I_Kings.16.34"><i>1K.</i> 16:34</a>; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 113a" href="/Sanhedrin.113a">Babli 113a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 14:2" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.14.2">Tosephta 14:6–9</a>.</i>, <i>who would build this town, Jericho</i>? That one may not build another town and call it Jericho, or Jericho and call it another town. And so He says<sup class="footnote-marker">387</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:16" href="/Deuteronomy.17.16"><i>Deut.</i> 17:16</a>.</i>, <i>you shall not continue to return on this way,</i> you may not return for dwelling; you may return for peddling, business<sup class="footnote-marker">388</sup><i class="footnote">Greek πραγματεία.</i>, or to conquer the land<sup class="footnote-marker">389</sup><i class="footnote">The verse prohibits return to Egypt to procure war materiel. It seems that the inference is based on a derivation of the word לָשׁ֛וּב not from the root שוב but from ישב.</i>.

Chapter 11



Halakhah 1

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> But the following are strangled<sup class="footnote-marker">1</sup><i class="footnote">Since no particular form of execution is prescribed for them.</i>: One who hits his father or his mother<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:15" href="/Exodus.21.15"><i>Ex</i>. 21:15</a>.</i>, and one who kidnaps a person from Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">3</sup><i class="footnote">In order to sell him or her as a slave, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 21:16" href="/Exodus.21.16"><i>Ex.</i> 21:16</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:7" href="/Deuteronomy.24.7"><i>Deut.</i> 24:7</a>.</i>, and the Elder who rebels against the Court<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The Supreme Court sitting in the Temple court. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:12" href="/Deuteronomy.17.12"><i>Deut.</i> 17:12</a>.</i>, and the false prophet<sup class="footnote-marker">5</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:20-22" href="/Deuteronomy.18.20-22"><i>Deut.</i> 18:20–22</a>.</i>, and one who prophesies in the name of foreign worship<sup class="footnote-marker">6</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:6" href="/Deuteronomy.13.6"><i>Deut.</i> 13:6</a>.</i>, and one who copulates with a married woman<sup class="footnote-marker">7</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:22" href="/Deuteronomy.22.22"><i>Deut.</i> 22:22</a>. This also applies to the woman.</i>, and the perjured witness of a Cohen’s daughter and her paramour<sup class="footnote-marker">8</sup><i class="footnote">Even though the adulterous daughter of a Cohen is burned, there is no verse to apply the same punishment to the adulterer. Since witnesses to adultery are witnesses simultaneously to both parties, they cannot be punished more than the adulterer would be.</i>.<br>One who hits his father or his mother is not punishable unless he inflict a wound on them. The following is more aggravating about one who curses<sup class="footnote-marker">15</sup><i class="footnote">Father or Mother; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:11:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.11.1">Mishnah 7:14</a>.</i> than one who hits, in that one who curses is punishable even after death, but one who hits after death cannot be prosecuted.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> But the following are strangled,” etc. From where warning<sup class="footnote-marker">9</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:7:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.7.5">Chapter 7, Note 129</a>.</i> for one who hits his father or his mother? <i>Forty times he shall hit him, he may not add</i><sup class="footnote-marker">10</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 25:3" href="/Deuteronomy.25.3"><i>Deut</i>. 25:3</a>, speaking of punishment decreed by the court.</i>. Since one who is commanded to hit is commanded not to hit, one who is commanded not to hit <i>a fortiori</i> is commanded not to hit<sup class="footnote-marker">11</sup><i class="footnote">It is sinful to hit anybody one is not commanded to hit. But only hitting a parent may be a captial crime. <i>Mekhilta dR. Ismael</i> <i>Mišpatim</i> 5 (ed. Horovitz-Rabin p. 266). The argument establishes a guide for ethical behavior; it is not one in criminal law for which only explicit verses may form the basis.</i>.
“He is not punishable unless he inflict a wound on them<sup class="footnote-marker">12</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 11:5:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.11.5.5">Mishnah 2</a>.</i>.” What kind of wound? A wound for the laws of the Sabbath, a wound for the law of torts? If you say, as a wound for the laws of the Sabbath, even if he did not cause them to miss anything<sup class="footnote-marker">13</sup><i class="footnote">It is a desecration of the Sabbath to cause a contusion. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Shabbat 14:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Shabbat.14.1.1">Mishnah <i>Šabbat</i> 14:1</a>.</i>; if you say, as a wound for the laws of torts, only if he caused them to miss something<sup class="footnote-marker">14</sup><i class="footnote">Some particle of skin or blood. Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bava Kamma 8:1:5" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bava_Kamma.8.1.5"><i>Bava qamma</i> 8:1, Notes 15–17</a>.</i>.

Halakhah 2

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> And one who kidnaps a person from Israel is not punishable unless he bring him into his property<sup class="footnote-marker">16</sup><i class="footnote">Or sells him as a slave.</i>. Rebbi Jehudah says, unless he bring him into his property and use him, as it is said, <i>and enslaved him or sold him.</i> One who kidnaps his own son, Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa<sup class="footnote-marker">17</sup><i class="footnote">The Babylonian attributions in the last two cases are different. The Halakhah shows that in the last sentence also here one has to read <i>R. Jehudah,</i> not R. Joḥanan ben Beroqa.</i> declares punishable but the Sages make him not prosecutable. One who kidnapped a person half slave and half free Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa declares punishable but the Sages make him not prosecutable.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> <sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">The entire paragraph is from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 8:3:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.8.3.2-4">Halakhah 8:3, Notes 38-43</a>.</i> From where a first warning about stealing: <i>you shall not steal.</i> From where a second warning about stealing: <i>you shall not steal. You shall not steal,</i> in order to aggravate; <i>you shall not steal,</i> in order to pay double restitution, in order to pay quadruple or quintuple restitution. Ben Bagbag says, do not steal your own property back from the thief, lest you be seen stealing.
Rebbi Abba, Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rebbi Hoshaia: he is punishable only if he steals money. Rebbi Zeˋira in the name of Rebbi Hoshaia: he is punishable only if he shows contempt for money. What means showing contempt for money? Where do we hold? If about him who says, here you have five and give me for three, he is an idiot. Here you have three and give me for five, he is a regular person. But we deal with one who says, here you have five and give me for five.
What is a thief and what is a robber? Rebbi Hila said, if he stole in the presence of witnesses, he is a thief, in the presence of the owners he is a robber. Rebbi Zeˋira asked: but if he intended to rob (for copulation)<sup class="footnote-marker">18</sup><i class="footnote">A copyist’s error who wrote לבעילה “for sexual intercourse” instead of לבעליה “in front of its owners” as in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 8:3:2-4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.8.3.2-4">Halakhah 8:3</a>.</i>, he is not a robber. What is a robber according to Rebbi Zeˋira? Rebbi Samuel ben Sosarta in the name of Rebbi Abbahu: only if he rob in the presence of ten people. The prototype for all these: <i>He robbed the spear from the hand of the Egyptian,</i> etc.
What is the reason of Rebbi Joḥanan ben Beroqa? <i>Of the Children of Israel.</i> What is the reason of the rabbis? <i>Of his brothers,</i> not his sons<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:7" href="/Deuteronomy.24.7"><i>Deut.</i> 24:7</a> reads: <i>If a man be found kidnapping one of his brothers, of the Children of Israel, and enslaves him or sells him, the kidnapper shall die; you shall eliminate evil from Israel.</i> This paragraph speaks of the son, the next (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 11:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.11.2.1">Note 17</a>) of the half-emancipated slave. <i>Sifry Deut.</i> 273 parallels the first paragraph but in the case of the semi-emancipated slave treats the rabbis’ as unanimous opinion. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 86a" href="/Sanhedrin.86a">Babli 86a</a> finds a reason to exclude the semi-emancipated slave from the partitive <i>mem</i> in the verse <i><u>of</u> the Children of Israel,</i> which implies “not all of the Children of Israel.”</i>. What is the reason of Rebbi Jehudah? <i>Of his brothers,</i> even partially his brother. What is the reason of the rabbis? <i>Of his brothers,</i> unless he be totally his brother.

Halakhah 3

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> The Elder who rebels against the Court, as it is said: <i>If a law case is too difficult for you, whether blood and blood, or case and case</i>, etc. Three courts were there, one at the entrance of the Temple Mount, one at the entrance of the Temple courtyard, and one in the ashlar hall. They come to the one at the entrance to the Temple Mount and he says, so I argued and so my colleagues argued, so I taught and so my colleague taught. If they had heard it, they tell them; otherwise they come to the one at the entrance of the Temple courtyard and he says, so I argued and so my colleagues argued, so I taught and so my colleagues taught. If they had heard it, they tell them; otherwise these and those come to the Supreme Court in the ashlar hall, for from there instruction goes out to all of Israel as it is said, <i>from that place which the Eternal will choose.</i><br>If he returned to his town<sup class="footnote-marker">25</sup><i class="footnote">The representative of the lower court who had been told by the Supreme Court that his opinion was wrong.</i>, repeated and taught as was his custom, he cannot be prosecuted. If he instructed to act, he is punishable, as it is said<sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The Supreme Court sitting in the Temple court. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:12" href="/Deuteronomy.17.12"><i>Deut.</i> 17:12</a>.</i>, <i>but the man who would act criminally</i> etc. He is not punishable unless he instruct to act. A student who instructed to act cannot be prosecuted; it turns out that his severity is his leniency<sup class="footnote-marker">26</sup><i class="footnote">A person unqualified to judge who nevertheless judges commits a grievous sin, worse than the qualified judge who does not obey the rulings of the Supreme Court. But his punishment is reserved for Heaven, not the human court.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “The Elder who rebels,” etc. <b>Halakhah 4:</b> “If he returned to his town, repeated and taught as was his custom,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">27</sup><i class="footnote">This <i>baraita</i> exists in two other versions, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 87a" href="/Sanhedrin.87a">Babli 87a</a> and <i>Sifry Deut.</i> 152. It is the subject of a study by E. A. Finkelstein, HUCA XXXII (1961) <b>א-כה</b>.</i> It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">20</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 24:7" href="/Deuteronomy.24.7"><i>Deut.</i> 24:7</a> reads: <i>If a man be found kidnapping one of his brothers, of the Children of Israel, and enslaves him or sells him, the kidnapper shall die; you shall eliminate evil from Israel.</i> This paragraph speaks of the son, the next (cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 11:2:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.11.2.1">Note 17</a>) of the half-emancipated slave. <i>Sifry Deut.</i> 273 parallels the first paragraph but in the case of the semi-emancipated slave treats the rabbis’ as unanimous opinion. The <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 86a" href="/Sanhedrin.86a">Babli 86a</a> finds a reason to exclude the semi-emancipated slave from the partitive <i>mem</i> in the verse <i>of the Children of Israel,</i> which implies “not all of the Children of Israel.”</i>: <i>If something is being distinguished for you in law,</i> this shows that the verse speaks about the distinguished member of the court<sup class="footnote-marker">28</sup><i class="footnote">The person representing the lower court before the Supreme Court has to be its most distinguished member.</i>. <i>For you,</i> this is counsel. <i>Something</i> is sermonizing<sup class="footnote-marker">29</sup><i class="footnote">In the parallel sources: This is practice. Since the verse defines the areas of competence of the Supreme Court, it is difficult to see what the legal relevance of <i>aggadah</i> could be unless one subscribes to Maimonides’s opinion that all interpretations of biblical verses by the hermeneutical rules are rabbinic in character, <i>i. e.,</i> aggadic.</i>. <i>Whether blood and blood,</i> whether menstrual blood or blood of virginity; whether menstrual blood, blood of flux, or blood of skin disease<sup class="footnote-marker">30</sup><i class="footnote">As Finkelstein points out, the plain text of the verse seems to restrict the objects of appeal to purely legal cases; the interpretation given here extends it to all areas of life.</i>. <i>Whether case or case,</i> between those who are stoned, or burned, or decapitated, or strangled<sup class="footnote-marker">31</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence is missing in the parallel sources; it already is contained in the other explanations of the same clause.</i>. <i>Whether defect or defect,</i> between a quarantined sufferer from skin disease or an absolute one<sup class="footnote-marker">31,</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence is missing in the parallel sources; it already is contained in the other explanations of the same clause.</i><sup class="footnote-marker">32</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 10:2:26" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.10.2.26">Chapter 10, Note 284</a>.</i>; <i>whether defect or defect,</i> between defects of humans or of garments or of houses<sup class="footnote-marker">33</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 13" href="/Leviticus.13"><i>Lev.</i> 13</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 14" href="/Leviticus.14">14</a>.</i>. <i>Words,</i> that is the drinking of the suspected adulteress, breaking the neck of the calf, and the purification of the sufferer from skin disease<sup class="footnote-marker">34</sup><i class="footnote">While the suspected adulteress drinks water with which written words were obliterated (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Numbers 5:23" href="/Numbers.5.23"><i>Num.</i> 5:23</a>) and the expiation of an unsolved murder case requires the priests to recite words (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 21:7-8" href="/Deuteronomy.21.7-8"><i>Deut.</i> 21:7–8</a>), the purification of the the sufferer from skin disease is a wordless ceremony. Rashi in the Babli explains that skin disease is punishment for calumniating. One could explain that the first step in the purification is a declaration by a priest that the skin disease was healed and his command to assemble the items necessary for purification (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 14:3-4" href="/Leviticus.14.3-4"><i>Lev.</i> 14:3–4</a>).</i>. <i>Quarrels,</i> these are estimations, bans, and dedications<sup class="footnote-marker">35</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 27" href="/Leviticus.27"><i>Lev.</i> 27</a>; all of these need dedications by explicit declaration.</i>. <i>You shall get up,</i> from the court, <i>and rise,</i> this is the ascent<sup class="footnote-marker">36</sup><i class="footnote">Climbing up all the way to Jerusalem.</i>.
Another explanation: <i>You shall get up,</i> from here that the Temple should be built only on the height of the world<sup class="footnote-marker">37</sup><i class="footnote">When in fact the Temple Mount is conspicuously lower than the surrounding hills, to indicate that it is not a Canaanite High Place.</i>. What is the reason? <i>For on</i> My Holy Mountain, on <i>the mountain of the height of Israel shall I plant it, that it may sprout branch and carry fruit</i><sup class="footnote-marker">38</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Ezekiel 17:23" href="/Ezekiel.17.23"><i>Ez.</i> 17:23</a>. For different approaches to the same statement, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 11:3:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.11.3.2">Note 27</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Kiddushin 69a" href="/Kiddushin.69a">Babli <i>Qiddušin</i> 69a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Zevachim 54b" href="/Zevachim.54b"><i>Zevahim</i> 54b</a>, <i>Sifry Deut.</i> 37, end.</i><i>. And you shall come</i><sup class="footnote-marker">39</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:9" href="/Deuteronomy.17.9"><i>Deut</i>. 17:9</a>.</i>, <i>to</i> include the court at Jabneh. Rebbi Zeˋira says, to ask<sup class="footnote-marker">40</sup><i class="footnote">As <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 11:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.11.4.1">Mishnah 6</a> shows, disobedience to a court not sitting in the ashlar hall is not a crime punishable by a human court; but nevertheless the obligation to ask the opinion of the Supreme Court in cases of doubt remains as long as such a court exists.<br>Since Rabban Johanan ben Zakkai asked for “Jabneh and its Sages” from Vespasian, it follows that even during the times of the Temple an important academy existed at Jabneh (and since Miriam the Hasmonean in her will had given Jabneh to Empress Livia, this was the only place in all of Judea which Vespasian could not give away without declaring himself as emperor.)</i>.
A rebellious Elder who instructed to act and acted is punishable. If he instructed but did not act, he is not prosecutable. If he instructed not for application, he is not prosecutable. If he instructed for application, even if he himself did not act, he is punishable<sup class="footnote-marker">41</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 88b" href="/Sanhedrin.88b">Babli 88b</a>. <i>Sifry Deut</i>. 155 infers from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:12" href="/Deuteronomy.17.12"><i>Deut</i>. 17:12</a> which decrees the death penalty for the person who acts against the judgement which <i>he</i> heard from the Supreme Court that any person acting on instructions from a person who <i>heard</i> from the Supreme Court cannot be prosecuted. Therefore, the actions of persons acting on the instructions of a judge are considered actions of the judge, not those of his officers.</i>. Rebbi Hila said, Rebbi Ismael stated thus: <i>Who would act</i><sup class="footnote-marker">4</sup><i class="footnote">The Supreme Court sitting in the Temple court. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:12" href="/Deuteronomy.17.12"><i>Deut.</i> 17:12</a>.</i>, even in he did not act himself. Rav Huna said, if he was instructing for practice and later a case came up, one acts on his instruction. If he taught it on the occasion of a case, one acts on it for others but not for himself<sup class="footnote-marker">42</sup><i class="footnote">This is a general legal principle, applicable to civil as well as to criminal law. A legal doctrine formulated before a case arose can be applied to any case. But a doctrine formulated in the discussion of a case cannot be applied if the party formulating it is party to the case; that would be a conflict of interest (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Yevamot 77a" href="/Yevamot.77a">Babli <i>Yebamot</i>77a</a> in the name of Rav, Rav Huna’s teacher.)</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">43</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Pirkei Avot 6:8" href="/Pirkei_Avot.6.8">Mishnah <i>Avot</i> 6:8</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 11:4" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.11.4">Tosephta <i>Sanhedrin</i>11:8</a>. In these sources, the original author is R. Simeon ben Iohai.</i> Rebbi Simeon ben Menasia says: Beauty, and vigor, and riches, and wisdom, and white hair, and honor, and children, are an adornment for the just. What is the reason? <i>A crown of glory is white hair; on the way of piety it is found</i><sup class="footnote-marker">44</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 16:31" href="/Proverbs.16.31"><i>Prov.</i> 16:31</a>.</i><i>. A crown of the elderly are grandchildren; the glory of children are their parents</i><sup class="footnote-marker">45</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 17:6" href="/Proverbs.17.6"><i>Prov</i>. 17:6</a>.</i><i>. The glory of the young is their force; the splendor of the elderly is white hair</i><sup class="footnote-marker">46</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Proverbs 20:29" href="/Proverbs.20.29"><i>Prov.</i> 20.29</a>.</i><i>.</i> And it says, <i>before his Elders in honor</i><sup class="footnote-marker">47</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Is</i> 24:23.</i>. <sup class="footnote-marker">48</sup><i class="footnote">This sentence has to be deleted since Rebbi’s father cannot speak about his son and grandsons. Since Rebbi was the last of the Tannaïm, only amoraic statements about him are legitimate.</i> It was stated: Rabban Simeon ben Gamliel says, these seven qualities which the Sages enumerated for the just were all realized by Rebbi and his sons. Rebbi Joḥanan said, all seven qualities which the Sages enunciated about the just were in Rebbi. Who was Rebbi? Rebbi is Rebbi Jehudah the Prince. Rebbi Abbahu said, Rebbi is Rebbi Yudan the Prince, is Our Teacher<sup class="footnote-marker">49</sup><i class="footnote">It is not clear whether he refers to R. Jehudah I ben Simeon, mentioned by R. Johanan, or to R. Jehudah II ben Gamliel.</i>.

Halakhah 4

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> [Denial] about words of the Sopherim is more serious than about words of the Torah. He who says that there are no phylacteries, to transgress the words of the Torah, is not prosecutable. Five compartments to add to the words of the Sopherim is punishable<sup class="footnote-marker">50</sup><i class="footnote">The person who denies a verse in the Torah (in this case <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:8" href="/Deuteronomy.6.8"><i>Deut.</i> 6:8</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 11:18" href="/Deuteronomy.11.18">11:18</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 13:16" href="/Exodus.13.16"><i>Ex.</i>13:16</a>) is harmless since every schoolchild knows better. But the details of the construction of phylacteries are purely traditional , <i>viz.,</i> that the phylacteries on the arm have to be put into one box but those of the head into four compartments. As Y. Yadin has noted in his publication on the phylacteries from the Judean desert, they are made in the way of rabbinic phylacteries (at least as they used to be made until 200 years ago, with boxes of 1 cm edge length) but the text contains many more than the authorized verses. These <i>tefillin</i> therefore have to be classified as non-rabbinical.</i>.<br>One executes him not at the court in his town, nor at the court at Jabneh<sup class="footnote-marker">51</sup><i class="footnote">The nearby court of appeals.</i> but one transports him to the Supreme Court in Jerusalem, keeps him until a holiday of pilgrimage, and executes him on the holiday<sup class="footnote-marker">52</sup><i class="footnote">On holiday eve when everybody had arrived.</i> as it is said, <i>the entire people shall see and fear</i><sup class="footnote-marker">53</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:13" href="/Deuteronomy.17.13"><i>Deut.</i> 17:13</a>.</i>, the words of Rebbi Aqiba. Rebbi Jehudah says, one does not procrastinate in his case but executes him immediately, writes, and sends messengers to all places: Mr. A son of Mr. B was found guilty to be executed by the court.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “[Denial] about words of the Sopherim is more serious,” etc. <b>Halakhah 6:</b>“One executes him not,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">54</sup><i class="footnote">This and the next paragraphs are from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:4:2-3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.4.2-3"><i>Berakhot</i> 1:7 (Notes 182–191</a>) (<b>ת</b>). It is copied again in <i>Avodah zarah</i> 2:8 41c l. 46 (<b>ע</b>).</i> The colleagues in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The words of the Sopherim are related to the words of Scripture and are pleasant like the words of Scripture; <i>your throat is like good wine</i><sup class="footnote-marker">55</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Song of Songs 7:10" href="/Song_of_Songs.7.10"><i>Cant.</i>7:10</a></i>. Simeon bar Abba in the name of Rebbi Joḥanan: The words of the Sopherim are related to the words of Scripture and are more pleasant than the words of Scripture, <i>for your friendship is better than wine</i><sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Song of Songs 1:2" href="/Song_of_Songs.1.2"><i>Cant.</i>1:2</a>.</i>. Rebbi Abba bar Cohen in the name of Rebbi Judah bar Pazi: You may know that he words of the Sopherim are more pleasant than the words of Scripture, because if Rebbi Tarphon did not recite at all he would only have transgressed a positive commandment. But because he transgressed the words of the House of Hillel he should have suffered death since it says, <i>if one breaches a wall he will be bitten by a snake</i><sup class="footnote-marker">56</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Song of Songs 1:2" href="/Song_of_Songs.1.2"><i>Cant.</i>1:2</a>.</i>.
Rebbi Ismael stated: In the Torah there are forbidden matters and permitted matters. There are easy parts and severe parts. But in the words of the Sopherim all are severe. You can realize that this is so since we have stated: “He who says that there are no phylacteries, to transgress the words of the Torah, is not prosecutable. Five compartments to add to the words of the Sopherim is punishable.” Rebbi Ḥinena, the son of Rebbi Ada, in the name of Rebbi Tanḥum bar Ḥiyya: The words of the Sages carry more weight than those of the prophets since it is written, <i>do not preach, they preach</i><sup class="footnote-marker">58</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Micah 2:6" href="/Micah.2.6"><i>Micha</i> 2:6</a>.</i>. And it is written, <i>I shall preach to you for wine and liquor</i><sup class="footnote-marker">59</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Micah 2:11" href="/Micah.2.11"><i>Micha</i> 2:11</a>.</i>. The relation of prophet and scholar can be compared to the case of a king who sent two <i>diplomatarii</i><sup class="footnote-marker">60</sup><i class="footnote">A person authorized to use the imperial mail; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:4:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.4.3"><i>Berakhot</i> 1:7 Note 189</a>.</i> to a province. About one of them it was written, if he does not show you my seal and σημαντήριον<sup class="footnote-marker">61</sup><i class="footnote">“Seal” in Greek; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 1:4:3" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.1.4.3"><i>Berakhot</i> 1:7 Note 190</a>.</i>, do not believe him. About the other it was written, even if he does not show you my seal and σημαντήριον, believe him. So about a prophet is written, <i>he gives you a sign or miracle</i><sup class="footnote-marker">62</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:2" href="/Deuteronomy.13.2"><i>Deut</i>. 13:2</a>.</i>. But here it is written, <i>according to the teachings that they will teach you</i><sup class="footnote-marker">63</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 17:11" href="/Deuteronomy.17.11"><i>Deut</i>. 17:11</a>.</i>.
The Torah said, four compartments for four paragraphs<sup class="footnote-marker">64</sup><i class="footnote">The word טטפת (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 13:16" href="/Exodus.13.16"><i>Ex</i>. 13:16</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:8" href="/Deuteronomy.6.8"><i>Deut.</i>6:8</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 11:18" href="/Deuteronomy.11.18">11:18</a>) “head <i>tefillin</i>” is confirmed by the Babli’s use, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 57a" href="/Shabbat.57a"><i>Šabbat</i> 57a</a>, as “woman’s headband”. A fancy etymology, which reads the number 4 into the word, to support the statement that head phylacteries must bemade with four compartments (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 4b" href="/Sanhedrin.4b"><i>Sanhedrin</i> 4b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Zevachim 37b" href="/Zevachim.37b"><i>Zevahim</i>37b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 34b" href="/Menachot.34b"><i>Menahot</i> 34b</a>) is rabbinic.</i>. If he made five compartments for four paragraphs, he is punishable. Rebbi Abba, Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rebbi Hoshaia: He is punishable only if he instructs in a matter whose root is from the Torah but whose explanation is from the words of the Sopherim; for example, the carcass; for example, the crawling animal, whose root is from the words of the Torah<sup class="footnote-marker">65</sup><i class="footnote">The different kinds of impurity of dead animals are described in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 11" href="/Leviticus.11"><i>Lev</i>. 11</a> but the details, in particular the minimal quantities which induce impurity, are rabbinic.</i> but whose explanation is from the words of the Sopherim. Rebbi Zeˋira said, he never is punishable unless he deny and instruct in a matter whose root is from the Torah but whose explanation is from the words of the Sopherim; for example, the carcass; for example, the crawling animal, whose root is from the words of the Torah but whose explanation is from the words of the Sopherim, on condition that he simultaneously deduct in a matter which permits subtraction and addition<sup class="footnote-marker">66</sup><i class="footnote">R. Zeˋira restricts the original saying of R. Hoshaia, which was extended by R. Johanan to include impurity of dead animals. In the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 88b" href="/Sanhedrin.88b">Babli 88b</a> it is asserted that in the interpretation here ascribed to R. Zeˋira the only crime a rebellious Elder could be charged with was to instruct to make head phylacteries not with four but with five compartments. Then he obviously adds to the number of compartments but at the same time, since one of the four texts now has to occupy two compartments, he eliminates the rule which determines the order in which the texts have to be placed into compartments. This is simultaneously adding and subtracting; from the following discussion (Notes 63–71) it follows that this also is the interpretation required for the Yerushalmi. It is clear that <i>tefillin</i> of the kind found in the Judean desert (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 11:4:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.11.4.1">Note 50</a>) are not considered.</i>. The face of Rav<sup class="footnote-marker">67</sup><i class="footnote">This should read “Rebbi”.</i> Hoshaia lit up<sup class="footnote-marker">68</sup><i class="footnote">He was happy that R. Johanan quoted him even though the extension to include carcasses and dead crawling animals was not his formulation.</i>. He<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">R. Johanan.</i> told him, do I need you that you enjoy it? I do not need you, I am adding to your statement. Thirteen years he<sup class="footnote-marker">69</sup><i class="footnote">R. Johanan.</i> went and came before his teacher even though he did not need him. Rebbi Samuel in the name of Rebbi Zeˋura: Was it not enough for him to have paid his respects to his teacher since anybody who pays his respects to his teacher is as if he paid his respects to the Divine Presence. Rebbi Berekhiah objected, did we not state<sup class="footnote-marker">70</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Negaim 6:1" href="/Mishnah_Negaim.6.1">Mishnah <i>Negaˋim</i> 6:1</a>; cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Nedarim 3:2:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Nedarim.3.2.4"><i>Nedarim</i> 3:2 Note 49</a>, <i>Maˋserot</i> 5:7 Notes 122–125.<br><i>Baheret</i> is a skin disease in which white spots appear on the skin (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 13" href="/Leviticus.13"><i>Lev</i>. 13</a>). The minimum size of such a spot which makes its bearer impure is that of a “square split cilician bean” which is defined as 36 (hairwidths)<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup>. All questions are directed to R. Zeˋira; one tries to find a law other than that of phylacteries where a ruling by a rebellious Elder could simultaneously add and subtract from the received norm.<br>It was shown in <i>Mas</i>ˋ<i>erot</i>, by a question of R. Berekhiah, that <i>square</i> cannot mean that the white spot be an exact square, since nothing in biology exhibits geometrically straight lines and right angles. Therefore, the question can only be whether the spot must contain a square of minimal size or only have surface area of 36 (hairwidths)<sup class="footnote-marker">2</sup>.</i>, “the body of <i>baheret</i> is the square area of a split cilician bean”? Rebbi Abba Mari said, one who said it is pure<sup class="footnote-marker">71</sup><i class="footnote">For ms. דכן “pure” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Eduyot 8:4" href="/Mishnah_Eduyot.8.4">Mishnah <i>Idiut</i> 8:4</a>) <i>editio princeps</i> has הכן “so”, which made the clause incomprehensible. In <i>Ma</i>ˋ<i>serot</i> and <i>Nedarim</i>, it was determined that the Mishnah has to be read as referring to surface area. An elder who would read the Mishnah as requiring a white spot containing a square of minimal size would actually declare most impure spots as pure. This is diminution; nothing is added.</i>. Rebbi Abba bar Mamal objected, did we not state<sup class="footnote-marker">72</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Menachot 3:7" href="/Mishnah_Menachot.3.7">Mishnah <i>Menahot</i> 3:7</a>. Again the obligation to write words of the Torah on one’s doorposts is biblical (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 6:9" href="/Deuteronomy.6.9"><i>Deut</i>. 6:9</a>,<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 11:19" href="/Deuteronomy.11.19">11:19</a>) while the selection of the texts and the details are rabbinic. If one put the two texts into two cases instead of writing them on one sheet of parchment, it would be simultaneously adding and subtracting.</i>, “two paragraphs in the <i>mezuzzah</i>”? He told him, phylacteries and <i>mezuzah</i> are the same<sup class="footnote-marker">73</sup><i class="footnote">It is agreed that instead of “only <i>tefillin</i>” one should accept “only <i>tefillin</i> and <i>mezuzzot</i>” as possible objects of the Elder’s misdeeds since both are mentioned together in the biblical texts.</i>. Rav Hamnuna objected, was it not stated<sup class="footnote-marker">74</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 41b" href="/Menachot.41b"><i>Menaḥot</i> 41b</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Bekhorot 39b" href="/Bekhorot.39b"><i>Bekhorot</i> 39b</a>, determining the minimal length of the unknotted part of the <i>ṣisit</i>, the threads to be attached to the corners of one’s rectangular garment.</i>: The <i>ṣiṣit</i> must be four finger lengths for four threads? He told him, in that he diminished but did not add<sup class="footnote-marker">75</sup><i class="footnote">This is pure diminution; nothing is added.</i>. Rebbi Ḥaggai objected before Rebbi Yose, was it not stated<sup class="footnote-marker">76</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Mishnah Menachot 7:1" href="/Mishnah_Menachot.7.1">Mishnah <i>Menahot</i> 7:1</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Menachot 89a" href="/Menachot.89a"><i>Menaḥot</i> 89a</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sifra, Tzav, Chapter 11 6" href="/Sifra,_Tzav,_Chapter_11.6"><i>Sifra Saw Pereq</i> 11(6</a>). The rules of a thanksgiving sacrifice (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Leviticus 7:12-14" href="/Leviticus.7.12-14"><i>Lev</i>. 7:12–14</a>) require three kinds of unleavened oiled breads in addition to a set of leavened bread. The rabbinic interpretation requires that the flour be divided into three equal parts but that half of the oil be used on the unleavened bread scalded in hot water like a bagel, the rest being used for the other two kinds. If instead somebody instructed also to distribute the oil evenly, would he not subtract from one kind and add to the others?</i>, one third for the scalded<sup class="footnote-marker">77</sup><i class="footnote">Explanation of Rashi in <i>Menaḥot</i>.</i>, one third for round cakes, one third for flat cakes. If he used it in thirds, one third for the scalded, one third for round cakes, one third for flat cakes? He told him, he subtracts from the scalded and adds for round cakes and flat cakes<sup class="footnote-marker">78</sup><i class="footnote">The questioner considered all three kinds of <i>mazzah</i> as one commandment when in fact they are three different obligations; there is no simultaneity for one obligation.</i>.

Halakhah 5

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> And the false prophet and one who prophesies what he did not hear and what was not said to him<sup class="footnote-marker">79</sup><i class="footnote">These are cases for the human court.</i>. But as to one who suppresses his vision, and one who disregards the prophet’s words, and a prophet who transgressed his own word, their death is by the Hand of Heaven as it is said, <i>I shall ask it from him</i><sup class="footnote-marker">80</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:19" href="/Deuteronomy.18.19"><i>Deut</i>. 18:19</a>, cf. <i>Sifry</i> <i>Deut</i>. 177.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “And the false prophet,” etc. “And one who prophesies what he did not hear,” like Ṣedekias ben Kenaana<sup class="footnote-marker">81</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 22:11" href="/I_Kings.22.11"><i>1K</i>. 22:11</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 89a" href="/Sanhedrin.89a">Babli 89a</a>.</i>. “And what was not said to him,” like Ḥanania ben Azzur. Rebbi Joshua ben Levi said, Ḥanania ben Azzur was a true prophet;<sup class="footnote-marker">82</sup><i class="footnote">Since Jeremiah called him a prophet.</i> only he took instruction<sup class="footnote-marker">83</sup><i class="footnote">Deriving the unexplained word קיבוסת from Arabic قنس which among other meanings also signifies “to take instructions from somebody.” The background is explained in the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 89a" href="/Sanhedrin.89a">Babli, 89a</a>: Since Hanania had heard Jeremiah predict the downfall of Elam, which the talmudic authors take as an ally, not an adversary, of Babylonia, and concluded that if the ally fell, the principal would fall with him.</i> and heard what Jeremiah prophesied in the upper market; he went and prophesied in the lower market. Ḥanania ben Azzur told him, is not the essence<sup class="footnote-marker">84</sup><i class="footnote">Explaining סמא either from Arabic سما “to be high” or from Latin <i>summa</i>.</i> of the matter <i>only once seventy years will be fullfilled for Babylon, I shall remember you</i><sup class="footnote-marker">85</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 29:10" href="/Jeremiah.29.10"><i>Jer</i>. 29:10</a>.</i>. In all, the days of Manasse were 55 years. Deduct from them 20 years for which the Heavenly Court does not punish or extirpate, add the two of Amon and 31 of Josia<sup class="footnote-marker">86</sup><i class="footnote">This follows the author of Kings who puts all blame for the Babylonian exile on Manasse. While the numbers add up to 68, they make no sense. Manasse became king at age 12, therefore he was responsible during 47 years of kingship. (For the doctrine that people become responsible adults in the eyes of Heaven at age 20, cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Bikkurim 2:1:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Bikkurim.2.1.4"><i>Bikkurim</i> 2:1, Note 13</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shabbat 89b" href="/Shabbat.89b">Babli <i>Šabbat</i> 89b</a>.) Josia became king at age 8; his 31 years therefore should be reduced to 23 but, since he was the only good king following Manasse, he should not be counted at all. Adding then 2 for Amon, 11 for Joyakim, and 5 for Sedekias, one only obtains 65 years (or 66 if a full year is counted for Joyachin.)</i>. That is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">87</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Jer</i>.28:1–3.</i>: <i>At the beginning of the reign of Ṣedekias the king of Jehudah, in the fifth</i><sup class="footnote-marker">88</sup><i class="footnote">In the verse: fourth.</i> <i>year, in the fifth month, Ḥanania ben Azzur, the prophet from Gibeon, said to me in the House of the Eternal, before the priests and all the people, as follows: So said the Eternal of Hosts, the God of Israel, as follows. I broke the yoke of the king of Babylon; in another two years I shall return to this place all the Temple vessels which Nebuchadnezzar, the king of Babylon, took from this city and brought to Babylon.</i> Jeremiah told him, you are saying that<i>in another two years I shall return</i>, etc. But I say that Nebuchadnezzar will come and take the remainder. <i>To Babylon they will be brought and stay there</i><sup class="footnote-marker">89</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 27:22" href="/Jeremiah.27.22"><i>Jer</i>. 27:22</a>.</i>, etc. He<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Hananiah.</i> said to him, give a sign. He<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah.</i> answered, I am prophesying bad things and cannot give a sign for my words since the Holy One, praise to Him, said to bring evil and might refrain from it<sup class="footnote-marker">92</sup><i class="footnote">This is generally accepted; repentance always may avert evil.</i>. But you prophesy good things; you are obligated to give a sign. He<sup class="footnote-marker">90</sup><i class="footnote">Hananiah.</i> said to him, no, it is you who has to give a sign for your words. He<sup class="footnote-marker">91</sup><i class="footnote">Jeremiah.</i> answered, if it is so, I shall give a sign and miracle in the person of that man; this year he dies, for he spoke obstinately about the Eternal. This happened to him; <i>Ḥanania the prophet died in this year, in the Seventh month</i><sup class="footnote-marker">93</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jeremiah 28:17" href="/Jeremiah.28.17"><i>Jer</i>. 28:17</a>. While the Talmud assumes that the “Day of Remembrance,” the first of the seventh month, always was New Year’s Day, it is clear that <i>Jer</i>. follows the Judean calendar which starts the year in Spring.</i>. This was another year and you are saying so? But it teaches that he died on the Eve of New Year’s Day and ordered his sons and wife to hide the matter, that they should bury him after the new Year in order to falsify Jeremiah’s prophecy.
“And one who suppresses his prophecy,” like Jonah ben Amitai<sup class="footnote-marker">94</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 89a" href="/Sanhedrin.89a">Babli 89a</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 14:4" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.14.4">Tosephta 14:15</a>.</i>. Rebbi Jonah said, Jonah ben Amitai was a true prophet. You find that when the Holy One, praise to Him, told him, <i>get up and go to the great city of Nineveh and call out over it that their evil came before Me</i><sup class="footnote-marker">95</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jonah 1:2" href="/Jonah.1.2"><i>Jonah</i> 1:2</a>.</i>, Jonah said, I know that Gentiles are close to repentance; if I would go and prophesy for them and they repented, the Holy One, praise to Him, would make himself paid from the haters of Israel<sup class="footnote-marker">96</sup><i class="footnote">I. e., punish Israel for not repenting.</i>. What can I do? I must flee! <i>Jonah got up to flee to Tarshish from before the Eternal; he descended to Jaffa, found a ship destined for Tarshish, paid his fare and entered it</i>,<sup class="footnote-marker">97</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Jonah 1:3" href="/Jonah.1.3"><i>Jonah</i> 1:3</a>.</i>” etc.
“And one who disregards the prophet’s words.” Like the seer Ido<sup class="footnote-marker">98</sup><i class="footnote">The text is lacunary. One must read with the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 14:4" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.14.4">Tosephta (14:15</a>) and the <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 89b" href="/Sanhedrin.89b">Babli (89b</a>): One who disregards the prophet’s words, like the companion of Micha (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 20:35" href="/I_Kings.20.35"><i>1K.</i>20:35</a>) and the prophet who disregards his own words like the seer Ido (mentioned in <a class="refLink" data-ref="II Chronicles 12:15" href="/II_Chronicles.12.15"><i>2Chr.</i> 12:15</a> who in all talmudic sources is identified as the anonymous “prophet from Jehudah” in <a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 13" href="/I_Kings.13"><i>1K.</i> 13</a>). R. Samuel bar Rav Isaac said, the old prophet living in Bethel (<a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 13:11" href="/I_Kings.13.11"><i>1K.</i> 13:11</a>) is Amasiah the priest of Bethel <a class="refLink" data-ref="Amos 7:12" href="/Amos.7.12"><i>(Am.</i> 7:12</a>).</i>. Rebbi Samuel bar Rav Isaac said, this is Amaṣiah the priest of Bethel. Rebbi Yose said, this is breaking of eggs<sup class="footnote-marker">99</sup><i class="footnote">R. Samuel bar Rav Isaac spoke in error; the old prophet at the time of Jeroboam I cannot be the priest at the time of Jeroboam II.</i>; who is it? He is Jonathan ben Gershom ben Manasse<sup class="footnote-marker">100</sup><i class="footnote">Jonathan ben Gershom ben Moses, as asserted in an anonymous note (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 9:2:12" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.9.2.12"><i>Berakhot</i> 9:3, Note 135</a>). To support this assertion, the next paragraph is a rearrangement of a text in <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 9:2:12" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.9.2.12"><i>Berakhot</i> 9:3 (Notes 128–135</a>); it lacks the punch line that Jonathan was the old prophet.</i>.
You find that when David came and found him serving foreign worship, he asked him: You are the grandson of that righteous man and you worship idols? <i>He</i><sup class="footnote-marker">100a</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Italics</i> show that Jonathan is the speaker.</i> said to him, <i>I</i> have a tradition from my grandfather, sell yourself to foreign worship rather than need other people. He said to <i>him</i>; Heaven forbid! He did not say so, but rather sell yourself to work that is strange to you rather than need other people. When David saw that <i>he</i> loved money, he made <i>him</i> Count<sup class="footnote-marker">100b</sup><i class="footnote">Latin <i>comes</i>“associate, partner”, a Byzantine title for a high-level bureaucrat. The combination תֵּיסַווְרִין עַל־הָאוֹצָרוֹת is a Greek-Hebrew double expression.</i> of the Temple treasuries. That is what is written, <i>Shabuel ben Gershom ben Moshe, overseer of the treasuries</i>. “Shabuel” because he returned to God with all his might; “overseer of the treasuries” that he made him Count of the treasuries.
The colleagues asked before Rebbi Samuel ben Naḥman: <i>He</i> was a priest of idol worship and lived so long? He said to them, because <i>he</i> was grudging to his idol. How was <i>he</i> grudging to his idol? If a man came to sacrifice an ox, a sheep, or a goat to the idol and told him: Make it favorably inclined towards me, <i>he</i> would say, what use does it have for you? It never eats, nor drinks, nor does good or evil. He said to <i>him</i>, what should we do? <i>He</i> said to him, go, make, and bring me a wooden vessel full of fine flour and put on it ten eggs, then <i>I</i> shall make it favorably inclined towards you. After <i>he</i> left, he would eat it. One day, a son of pashas came and <i>he</i> said that to him. He said to <i>him</i>, if it is of no use, what are <i>you</i> doing here? <i>He</i> answered him, because of my livelihood.
They objected to Rebbi Samuel bar Naḥman: <i>Until the day the Land went into exile</i>. He said to them, when David died, Solomon rose and exchanged all his counselors<sup class="footnote-marker">100c</sup><i class="footnote">A description of Byzantine practices.</i>. <i>He</i> returned to his former bad ways.
“And a prophet who transgressed his own word,” like the companion of Micha<sup class="footnote-marker">101</sup><i class="footnote">This should read: “the prophet Ido” (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 11:5:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.11.5.2">Note 91</a>).</i>. That is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">102</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 13:11-20" href="/I_Kings.13.11-20"><i>1K</i>. 13:11–20</a>. The verses obviously are quoted from memory.</i>: <i>An old prophet was dwelling at Bethel; his son came and told him all the actions which the man of God had wrought,</i> etc. <i>Their father asked them, which way did he go</i>, etc. <i>He told his sons, saddle the donkey for me,</i> etc. <i>He followed the man of God and found him sitting under the terebinth,</i> etc. <i>He said to him, come with me to my house and eat. He told him, I cannot return</i>, etc., up to <i>he said to him, I also am a prophet like you and an angel spoke to me the words of the Eternal as follows</i>, etc., up to <i>he should eat food and drink water; he tricked him</i>. What means “tricked him”? He lied to him. <i>While they were sitting at table, the word of the Eternal came to the prophet who had turned him back</i>. It is not written “who had returned,” but “who had turned him back.” Is that not an argument <i>de minore ad majus</i>? Since one who fed his neighbor food in falsehood was worthy of the Word to be addressed to him, one who feeds his neighbor food in truth, so much more.
It is written<sup class="footnote-marker">103</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 20:35-42" href="/I_Kings.20.35-42"><i>1K</i>. 20:35–42</a>.</i>: <i>One of the young prophets said to his neighbor by the Word of the Eternal</i>, etc. <i>He told him, since you did not listen to the Word of the Eternal, when you depart from me the lion will hit you; he departed from him, the lion found him and hit him. He found another man, said to him, hit me, and he hit him</i><sup class="footnote-marker">104</sup><i class="footnote">The quote stops short of <i>he injured him</i> which later (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 11:5:8" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.11.5.8">Note 101</a>) will be shown to be essential.</i> etc. <i>The prophet went, stood in the king’s way, and had disguised himself by a band over his eyes. When the king passed by, he cried to the king</i>, etc. <i>Your servant went to and fro</i>, etc. <i>He told him, so says the Eternal: Because you sent away from your hand the man whom I had banned, your life will be for his life, and your people for his people</i>. And it is written<sup class="footnote-marker">105</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Threni rabbati</i> 1(43). The full verse reads: <i>The man of God approached and <u>said</u></i> <i>to the king of Israel and <u>said</u></i>, …</i>: <i>The man of God approached and said, so says the Eternal</i>. Why two times “and said”? But in the first address he told him, if Ben Hadad falls into you hand, do not have mercy on him and do not spare him. In the second address he told him, <i>because you sent away from your hand the man whom I had banned</i>, how many traps and hunting nets<sup class="footnote-marker">106</sup><i class="footnote">Identifying חרם حرم “ban” with חרם خرم “netting”.</i> I made for him until I delivered him into your hand, and you sent him away and he went in peace. Therefore, <i>your life will be for his life, and your people for his people</i>. You find that when Israel went to war, nobody of them died but Ahab, the king of Israel. That is what is written<sup class="footnote-marker">107</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="I Kings 22:34" href="/I_Kings.22.34"><i>1K</i>. 22:34</a>.</i>: <i>A man shot from his bow without aiming and hit the king of Israel between the joints of his armor; he told the driver, take me out of the camp because I became sick</i>. How can I confirm <i>your people for his people</i>? Rebbi Joḥanan in the name of Rebbi Simeon ben Ioḥai: That drop of blood which was drawn from the just man<sup class="footnote-marker">108</sup><i class="footnote">The prophet who was injured (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 11:5:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.11.5.9">Note 103</a>). The suffering of the Just as atonement for the entire people is an idea found in apocryphal literature such as IV Maccabees; in rabbinic texts otherwise only in Midrash literature [<i>Tanhuma Wayyaqhel</i> 9 = <a class="refLink" data-ref="Shemot Rabbah 35:4" href="/Shemot_Rabbah.35.4"><i>Ex. rabba</i> 35(4</a>), <a class="refLink" data-ref="Vayikra Rabbah 2:1" href="/Vayikra_Rabbah.2.1"><i>Lev. rabba</i> 2(1</a>).]</i> did atone for all of Israel.

Halakhah 6

<strong>MISHNAH:</strong> One who prophesies in the name of foreign worship<sup class="footnote-marker">109</sup><i class="footnote">Who is strangled, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 11:1:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.11.1.1">Mishnah 11:1</a>.</i> and says, so speaks the foreign worship, even if he stated practice correctly to declare the impure impure and the pure pure. One who copulates with a married woman, from the moment she is in the husband’s domain for definitive marriage even if she did not have intercourse<sup class="footnote-marker">110</sup><i class="footnote">The preliminarily married virgin and her paramour are stoned. But once she entered the place where the definitive marriage is scheduled to take place, even though she still is a virgin, her adultery is punished by strangulation. This presupposes that the definitive marriage is celebrated on the husband’s property.</i>, one who copulates with her is strangled. And the false witnesses of a Cohen’s daughter and her paramour. Therefore all false witnesses are executed by that death except for the false witnesses of a Cohen’s daughter and her paramour<sup class="footnote-marker">111</sup><i class="footnote">The whoring daughter of a Cohen is burned only if she committed adultery while married (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:5:1" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.5.1">Chapter 7, Notes 8–12</a>). But the adulterer with a married woman is strangled. The perjured witnesses have to be executed in the way the adulterer would have been executed had their testimony stood up in court since (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 19:19" href="/Deuteronomy.19.19"><i>Deut</i>. 19:19</a>) <i>you shall do to him what he intended to do to his brother</i>. Therefore, it is impossible to punish the perjured witnesses of a Cohen’s daughter by exactly the death they intended to bring her to. This is the introduction to the next Chapter (<i>Makkot</i> 1 - <i>Sanhedrin</i>12) which starts by exploring the punishment of perjured witnesses accusing a Cohen of breaking priestly rules.</i>.
<strong>HALAKHAH:</strong> “One who prophesies in the name of foreign worship,” etc. <sup class="footnote-marker">112</sup><i class="footnote">This paragraph is thoroughly corrupt; the meaning can be understood approximately by reference to <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 14:4" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.14.4">Tosephta 14:13</a>: “He who prophesies to uproot one of the words of the Torah is punishable. Rebbi Simeon says, if he prophesies to uproot one of the words of the Torah but affirms others he cannot be prosecuted; but about foreign worship, even if he endorses it today but reneges tomorrow he is punishable.”<br>With <i>Qorban</i> <i>Haˋedah</i> it seems that the quote from the Ten Commandments (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Exodus 20:16" href="/Exodus.20.16"><i>Ex</i>. 20:16</a>) was induced by the parallel text at the beginning of the next Halakhah and should be replaced by <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:22" href="/Deuteronomy.18.22"><i>Deut</i>. 18:22</a>. The argument would go as follows: In <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:20-22" href="/Deuteronomy.18.20-22"><i>Deut</i>. 18:20–22</a>, the court is commanded to punish the false prophet by a death sentence. The manner of execution is not specified; this implies that it must be by strangling. But in 13:2–12 the punishment of strange worship (idolatry) is stoning.<br>A person can be punished as a false prophet only if first he had established his credentials as a prophet by a sign or a miracle (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:2" href="/Deuteronomy.13.2"><i>Deut</i>. 13:2</a>, <a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 18:22" href="/Deuteronomy.18.22">18:22</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 11:5:9" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.11.5.9">Note 106</a>). Then if the prophet argues for idolatry, even if he does not abolish any commandment of the Torah, he has to be punished (even if he propagates foreign worship in the name of the Eternal; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Sanhedrin 89b" href="/Sanhedrin.89b">Babli 89b</a>). If he tells others not to obey some of the precepts of the Torah, for the Sages he is punishable, but not for R. Simeon. The prophet can be prosecuted only if he induces others to neglect Torah precepts, not if he himself seemingly violates them by Divine Command, as Elijah did on Mount Carmel, sacrificing on an altar which was authorized only for him.<br><i>Qorban Haˋedah</i> gives a reconstruction of the paragraph which is not impossible but not supported by any parallel evidence.<br>In the word פיונטייה the ending יֵהּ is the possessive suffix “his”. For the remaining פיונטי the best available conjecture is Kohut’s, Latin <i>punitio, -onis</i> “punishment” [or <i>poenaria</i> (<i>actiones</i>), punishable (actions) (E. G.)].</i> Rebbi Yose ben Ḥanina said, everything was included in <i>do not testify against your neighbor as a false witness</i>. It came to judge whether by sign, or by miracle, whether about foreign worship or any other commandment. But about foreign worship, whether he intended to uproot the entire body or did not intend to uproot the entire body, by the words of Rebbi Simeon one does not prosecute him, but by the words of the Sages one stones him. For any other commandment by the words of the Sages one stones him, by the words of Rebbi Simeon he should understand his <i>pywnṭ</i>.
If a prophet starts to prophesy, one listens to him if he gives a sign or miracle; otherwise one does not listen to him<sup class="footnote-marker">113</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 13:2" href="/Deuteronomy.13.2"><i>Deut.</i> 13:2</a>. It is no disrespect to Heaven if one disregards the sayings of an unqualified prophet.</i>. Two prophets who prophesied indentically, two prophets who prophesied in the same sense<sup class="footnote-marker">114</sup><i class="footnote">This reading (<i>Pene Moshe</i>) is preferable to reading בְכָרָךְ אֶחָד “in the same fortified place” (<i>Qorban Haˋedah</i>).</i>? Rebbi Isaac and Rebbi Hoshaia: One said, each one has to provide a sign or a miracle; the other said, not each one has to provide a sign or a miracle<sup class="footnote-marker">115</sup><i class="footnote">But the accredited prophet can legitimate his companion.</i>. The one who said he did objected to the one who said he did not: Is it not written<sup class="footnote-marker">116</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 20:8" href="/II_Kings.20.8"><i>2K</i>. 20:8</a>.</i>, <i>Ezekias said to Isaias, what is the sign</i>? He told him, that is different since he was occupied in reviving the dead. <i>He shall revive us after two days; on the third day He will lift us up and we shall live before Him</i><sup class="footnote-marker">117</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Hosea 6:2" href="/Hosea.6.2"><i>Hos</i>. 6:2</a>. The verse is the basic source for the belief that the resurrection has to be on the third day, or that souls have to suffer punishment for their misdeeds while alive for two days and on the third day are admitted to Paradise (<a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Berakhot 5:2:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Berakhot.5.2.2"><i>Berakhot</i> 5:2 Note 64</a>; <i>Taˋaniot</i> 1:1 63d l.52). Ezekias was declared ready to die (<a class="refLink" data-ref="II Kings 20:1" href="/II_Kings.20.1"><i>2K</i>. 20:1</a>) and was well enough to go to the Temple on the third day; this shows that his recovery was indeed a resurrection.</i>.
<sup class="footnote-marker">118</sup><i class="footnote">his now refers to the adulterous definitively married woman. A closely related text is <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Ketubot 4:7:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Ketubot.4.7.2"><i>Ketubot</i> 4:7, Notes 154–160</a>.</i> Rebbi Jehudah ben Pazi said. not only to the bridal chamber but also to a house containing the bridal chamber<sup class="footnote-marker">119</sup><i class="footnote">Where the definitive marriage is contracted. This חוּפָּה is not the wedding canopy used today, but a room where the newlyweds will consummate the marriage and spend the following week.<br>From here to the end of <i>Sanhedrin-Makkot</i> (except <i>Makkot</i> 1:13–2:7) there exists a Genizah fragment (G) edited (with readings compared to the Krotoschin Yerushalmi) by S. Wieder, <i>Tarbiz</i> 17 (1946) 130–135.</i>. The following is problematic: Dining room<sup class="footnote-marker">120</sup><i class="footnote">Greek τρικλίνιον, τó, Latin <i>triclinium</i>.</i> and bedroom<sup class="footnote-marker">121</sup><i class="footnote">Cf. <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:13:2" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.13.2">Chapter 7:19, Note 363</a>.</i>, bridal chamber and bedroom; if she entered the dining room, for which consequence<sup class="footnote-marker">122</sup><i class="footnote">Before the definitive marriage ceremony.</i>? Rebbi Joḥanan said, to inherit from her<sup class="footnote-marker">123</sup><i class="footnote">As definitive husband, if the woman died before entering the bridal chamber. Since this idea is not followed up, it does not represent practice. In <i>Ketubot</i>, the name is R. Eleazar. Therefore, the illegible name in G cannot be emended to “R. Johanan” as given in <i>Tarbiz</i> 17.</i>. Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, to dissolve her vows<sup class="footnote-marker">124</sup><i class="footnote"><i>Nedarim</i>, Chapters 10,11.</i>. Rebbi Zeˋira said, even though Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish said, to dissolve her vows, he agrees that he cannot actually dissolve them before she enters the bridal chamber<sup class="footnote-marker">125</sup><i class="footnote">If the time allotted to the husband to dissolve his wife’s vows elapses between the arrival of his bride at his home when she stated the fact of her vows and the definitive marriage ceremony, he lost his right of dissolution.</i>. Rebbi Huna<sup class="footnote-marker">126</sup><i class="footnote">In G, “Huna” is corrected to “Jonah”.</i> said, a verse supports Rebbi Simeon ben Laqish: <i>to whore in her father’s house</i><sup class="footnote-marker">127</sup><i class="footnote"><a class="refLink" data-ref="Deuteronomy 22:21" href="/Deuteronomy.22.21"><i>Deut</i>. 22:21</a>.</i>. This excludes the case where the father’s agents handed her over to the husband’s agents, that she could not be stoned, but is strangled<sup class="footnote-marker">128</sup><i class="footnote">A preliminarily married virgin who no longer is in her father's charge is treated in criminal law as if she already were definitively married. Babli Ketubot 49a .</i>.
Similarly by burning, she and they by burning. Similarly by stoning, she and they by stoning. Similarly by strangulation, she and they by strangulation<sup class="footnote-marker">129</sup><i class="footnote">This refers to the perjured witnesses. The text is a copy from <a class="refLink" data-ref="Jerusalem Talmud Sanhedrin 7:1:4" href="/Jerusalem_Talmud_Sanhedrin.7.1.4">Halakhah 7:1, Note 17</a>; <a class="refLink" data-ref="Tosefta Sanhedrin 14:4" href="/Tosefta_Sanhedrin.14.4">Tosephta 14:17</a>. If no man is involved, the perjured witnesses are punished by what the woman would have suffered had their testimony been truthful.</i>.
